[238|p8] We have completely revised and updated the material to support the revised Cambridge IGCSE™ and IGCSE (9-1) Mathematics syllabuses (0580/0980) for exa...
[239|p8|T1] So, what is new?
[240|p8] Besides the updated content and fresh new design, we have increased the number of real-life applications and links to other subjects. You'll find thes...
[241|p8] To align with modern thinking about maths and maths teaching, and to develop problem-solving skills, we have added open-ended and open-middle problems...
[242|p8] We've increased the number of practice questions at the end of each chapter and updated the past paper questions that we have included so that you get...
[243|p8] In line with modern thinking about how people learn best, we've built in opportunities for different types of self- and peer- assessment. The feedback...
[244|p8] There are also many opportunities for you to reflect on your own learning and to think about what you can do really well and to consider what you can ...
[245|p8] We hope that you will enjoy working through the course and that you will find the material interesting, engaging and worthwhile.
[246|p8] Karen Morrison and Nick Hamshaw
[247|p9|T1] How to use this book
[248|p9] Throughout this book, you will notice lots of different features that will help your learning. These are explained below.
[249|p9|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[250|p9] These set the scene for each chapter, help with navigation through the coursebook and indicate the important concepts in each topic.
[251|p9|T1] Extended Content
[252|p9] Where content is intended for students who are studying the Extended content of the syllabus as well as the Core, this is indicated using the arrow an...
[253|p9|T1] GETTING STARTED
[254|p9] These boxes contain questions and activities on subject knowledge you will need before starting this chapter.
[255|p9|T1] KEY WORDS
[256|p9] The key vocabulary appears in a box at the start of each chapter, and is highlighted in the text when it is first introduced. You will also find defin...
[257|p9|T1] TIP
[258|p9] The information in this feature will help you complete the exercises, and give you support in areas that you might find challenging or confusing.
[259|p9|T1] APPLY YOUR SKILLS
[260|p9] These activities give you an opportunity to apply your understanding of a concept to a real-world context. You can find answers to these questions in ...
[261|p9|T1] Exercise 9.1
[262|p9] Appearing throughout the text, exercises give you a chance to check that you have understood the topic you have just learned about and practise the ma...
[263|p9|T1] INVESTIGATION/DISCUSSION
[264|p9] These boxes contain questions and activities that will allow you to extend your learning by investigating a problem, or by discussing it with classmat...
[265|p9|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[266|p9] These boxes show you the step-by-step process to work through an example question or problem, giving you the skills to work through questions yourself...
[267|p9|T1] LINK
[268|p9] This feature presents real-world examples and applications of the content in a chapter, encouraging you to look further into topics. Many of these exa...
[269|p9|T1] REFLECTION
[270|p9] These activities ask you to think about the approach that you take to your work, and how you might improve this in the future.
[272|p9] This icon shows you where you should complete an exercise without using your calculator.
[273|p10|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[274|p10] This feature will help you to link content in the chapter to what you have already learned, and highlights where you will use your understanding again...
[275|p10|T1] Practice Questions
[276|p10] Questions at the end of each chapter provide more demanding practice, some of which may require use of knowledge from previous chapters. Answers to th...
[277|p10|T1] SUMMARY
[278|p10] There is a summary of key points at the end of each chapter.
[279|p10|T1] SELF/PEER ASSESSMENT
[280|p10] At the end of some exercises you will find opportunities to help you assess your own work, or that of your classmates, and consider how you can improv...
[282|p10] Projects from NRICH allow you to apply your learning from several chapters. They may give you the opportunity to extend your learning beyond the sylla...
[283|p10] Past paper questions at the end of each unit give further practice in applying your learning from the previous chapters. Although all past paper quest...
[284|p10] Answers to these questions can be found on Cambridge GO.

[301|p13|T1] Chapter 1
[302|p13|T1] Review of number concepts
[303|p13|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[304|p13] - identify and classify different types of numbers
[305|p13] find common factors and common multiples of numbers
[306|p13] write numbers as products of their prime factors
[307|p13] work with integers used in real-life situations
[308|p13] calculate with powers and roots of numbers
[309|p13] understand the meaning of indices
[310|p13] use the rules of indices
[311|p13] - revise the basic rules for operating with numbers
[312|p13] perform basic calculations using mental methods and with a calculator
[313|p13] round numbers in different ways to estimate and approximate answers.
[314|p14|T1] GETTING STARTED
[315|p14] 1 A lot of the work in this chapter is revision. Look through the chapter to see what is covered.
[316|p14] a Are there any parts of this chapter that you could confidently skip? Explain why.
[317|p14] b If you only had to do three topics in this chapter, which would you choose? Why?
[318|p14] 2 Look at this completed cross-number puzzle.
[319|p14] a Write a set of clues for the puzzle. Each clue should include at least one of the concepts from this chapter.
[320|p14] b Find the sum of the three greatest numbers. Write the answer in words.
[321|p14] 3 Write each of the following using only numbers and brackets if needed.
[322|p14] a nine cubed
[323|p14] b twelve squared
[324|p14] c seven to the power of five
[325|p14] d the reciprocal of three to the power of two
[326|p14] e the reciprocal of three-quarters to the power of zero.
[327|p14] f nine to the power of half
[328|p14] g fourteen billion, ten thousand and nineteen
[329|p14] 4 Look at this decision diagram for problems involving calculation.
[331|p14] a Give an example of a problem where an approximate answer is good enough.
[332|p14] b How do you decide which method to use when an exact answer is needed?
[333|p14] Estimates are useful for all of the methods in this decision tree. How could you convince someone that it is important to estimate even if you can use...

[353|p15] The statue shown in the photograph is a replica of a 22 000-year-old bone found in the Congo Basin. The real bone is only  $10\mathrm{cm}$  long and i...
[354|p15] Our modern number system is called the Hindu-Arabic system because it was developed by Hindus and spread by Arab traders who brought it with them when...
[355|p15|T1] 1.1 Different types of numbers
[356|p15] Make sure you know the correct mathematical words for the types of numbers in the table.
[357|p15] [Table Row] <tr><td>Number</td><td>Definition</td><td>Example</td></tr>
[358|p15] [Table Row] <tr><td>Natural number</td><td>Any whole number from 1 to infinity, sometimes called ‘counting numbers’. 0 is not included.</td><td>1, 2, ...
[359|p15] [Table Row] <tr><td>Odd number</td><td>A whole number that cannot be divided exactly by 2.</td><td>1, 3, 5, 7, ...</td></tr>
[360|p15] [Table Row] <tr><td>Even number</td><td>A whole number that can be divided exactly by 2.</td><td>2, 4, 6, 8, ...</td></tr>
[361|p15] [Table Row] <tr><td>Integer</td><td>Any of the negative and positive whole numbers, including zero.</td><td>... -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, ...</td></tr>
[362|p15] [Table Row] <tr><td>Prime number</td><td>A whole number greater than 1 which has only two factors: the number itself and 1.</td><td>2, 3, 5, 7, 11, .....
[363|p15] [Table Row] <tr><td>Square number</td><td>The product obtained when an integer is multiplied by itself.</td><td>1, 4, 9, 16, ...</td></tr>
[364|p15] [Table Row] <tr><td>Fraction</td><td>A number representing part of a whole number, written in the form \( \frac{a}{b} \), where \( a \) and \( b \) ar...
[365|p15] [Table Row] <tr><td>Decimal</td><td>A number that used place value and a decimal point to show a fraction.</td><td>0.5, 0.2, 0.08, 1.7</td></tr>
[366|p15] The set of real numbers is made up of rational numbers and irrational numbers
[367|p15] Rational numbers can be written as fractions in the form  $\frac{a}{b}$  where  $a$  and  $b$  are non-zero integers. The set of rational numbers incl...
[368|p15] Irrational numbers cannot be written as fractions. The set of irrational numbers consists of non-terminating, non-recurring decimals. The square root ...
[370|p15|T1] TIP
[371|p15] Find the product means multiply. So, the product of 3 and 4 is 12, i.e.  $3 \times 4 = 12$ .
[372|p15|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[373|p15] You will deal with rational and irrational numbers in more detail in Chapter 9.
[374|p16|T1] LINK
[375|p16] Some numbers, for example  $\sqrt{-1}$  and other roots of negative numbers, are not real numbers. They are neither rational nor irrational. Mathemati...
[376|p16|T1] Exercise 1.1
[377|p16] 1 Here is a set of numbers:  $\{-4, -1, 0, \frac{1}{2}, 0.75, 3, 4, 6, 11, 16, 19, 25\}$
[378|p16] List the numbers from this set that are:
[379|p16] a natural numbers
[380|p16] b even numbers
[381|p16] c odd numbers
[382|p16] d integers
[383|p16] negative integers
[384|p16] f fractions
[385|p16] 9 square numbers
[386|p16] h prime numbers
[387|p16] neither square nor prime.
[388|p16] 2 List:
[389|p16] a the next four odd numbers after 107
[390|p16] b four consecutive even numbers between 2008 and 2030
[391|p16] c all odd numbers between 993 and 1007
[392|p16] d the first five square numbers
[393|p16] e four decimal fractions that are smaller than 0.5
[394|p16] f four common fractions that are greater than  $\frac{1}{2}$  but smaller than  $\frac{3}{4}$
[395|p16] 3 State whether the following will be odd or even.
[396|p16] a the sum of two odd numbers
[397|p16] b the sum of two even numbers
[398|p16] c the sum of an odd and an even number
[399|p16] d the square of an odd number
[400|p16] the square of an even number
[401|p16] f an odd number multiplied by an even number
[402|p16|T1] INVESTIGATION
[403|p16] 4 There are many other types of numbers. Find out what these numbers are and give an example of each.
[404|p16] a Perfect numbers
[405|p16] b Palindromic numbers
[406|p16] c Narcissistic numbers (in other words, numbers that love themselves!)
[407|p16|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[408|p16] You will learn much more about sets in Chapter 9. For now, just think of a set as a list of numbers or other items that are often placed inside curly ...
[409|p16|T1] TIP
[410|p16] Remember that a 'sum' is the result of an addition. The term is often used for any calculation in early mathematics, but its meaning is very specific ...
[411|p16|T1] TIP
[412|p16] Being able to communicate information effectively is a key 21st-century skill. As you work, think about what you are being asked to do in this task an...
[413|p17|T1] Using symbols to link numbers
[414|p17] Mathematicians use numbers and symbols to write mathematical information in the shortest, clearest way possible.
[415|p17|T1] Exercise 1.2
[416|p17] 1 Rewrite each of these statements using mathematical symbols.
[417|p17] a 19 is less than 45
[418|p17] b 12 plus 18 is equal to 30
[419|p17] 0.5 is equal to  $\frac{1}{2}$
[420|p17] 0.8 is not equal to 8.0
[421|p17] e -34 is less than 2 times -16
[422|p17] f therefore the number  $x$  equals the square root of 72
[423|p17] a number  $(x)$  is less than or equal to negative 45
[424|p17] h  $\pi$  is approximately equal to 3.14
[425|p17] 5.1 is greater than 5.01
[426|p17] j the sum of 3 and 4 is not equal to the product of 3 and 4
[427|p17] k the difference between 12 and -12 is greater than 12
[428|p17] the sum of -12 and -24 is less than 0.
[429|p17] m the product of 12 and a number  $(x)$  is approximately -40
[431|p17] 2 Say whether these mathematical statements are true or false.
[432|p17] a  $0.599 > 6.0$
[433|p17] b  $5\times 1999$  is approximately equal to 10000
[434|p17] 8.1=810
[435|p17] $6.2 + 4.3 = 4.3 + 6.2$
[436|p17] e  $20\times 9\geqslant 21\times 8$
[437|p17] f 6.0=6
[438|p17] g -12>-4
[439|p17] 19.9≤20
[440|p17] 1000>199×5
[441|p17] j 16=4
[442|p17] $35\times 5\times 2\neq 350$
[443|p17] 20÷4=5÷20
[444|p17] m 20-4≠4-20
[445|p17] ${20} \times  4 \neq  4 \times  {20}$

[451|p17] Remember:
[452|p17] $=$  is equal to
[453|p17] $\neq$  is not equal to
[454|p17] < is less than
[455|p17] $\leqslant$  is less than or equal to
[456|p17] > is greater than
[457|p17] $\geq$  is greater than or equal to
[458|p17] therefore
[459|p17] √ the positive square root of
[460|p18|T1] 1.2 Multiples and factors
[461|p18|T1] Multiples
[462|p18] A multiple of a number is found when you multiply that number by a positive integer. You can think of the multiples of a number as the 'times table' f...
[463|p18|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[464|p18] a What are the first three multiples of 12?
[465|p18] b Is 300 a multiple of 12?
[466|p18|T1] Answers
[467|p18] a 12,24,36
[468|p18] Multiply 12 by 1, 2 and then 3.
[469|p18] $$
\begin{array}{l} 1 2 \times 1 = 1 2 \\ 1 2 \times 2 = 2 4 \\ 1 2 \times 3 = 3 6 \\ \end{array}
$$
[470|p18] b Yes, 300 is a multiple of 12.
[471|p18] Divide 300 by 12. If it goes exactly, then 300 is a multiple of 12.
[472|p18] $$
3 0 0 \div 1 2 = 2 5
$$

[475|p18] a 12

[480|p18] f 10

[495|p18] c the multiples of 100 between 4000 and 5000.
[496|p18] 4 Here are five numbers: 576, 396, 354, 792, 1164. Which of these are multiples of 12?

[503|p18|T1] The lowest common multiple (LCM)
[504|p18] The lowest common multiple of two or more numbers is the smallest number that is a multiple of all the given numbers.
[505|p19|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[506|p19] Find the lowest common multiple of 4 and 7.
[507|p19|T1] Answer
[508|p19] $$
M _ {4} = 4, 8, 1 2, 1 6, 2 0, 2 4, 2 8, 3 2
$$
[509|p19] List several multiples of 4.
[510|p19] $$
M _ {7} = 7, 1 4, 2 1, 2 8, 3 5, 4 2
$$
[511|p19] List several multiples of 7.
[512|p19] $$
\mathrm {L C M} = 2 8
$$
[513|p19] Find the lowest number that appears in both sets. This is the LCM.
[514|p19|T1] Exercise 1.4
[515|p19] 1 Find the lowest common multiple of:
[516|p19] a 2 and 5
[517|p19] b 8 and 10
[518|p19] 6 and 4
[519|p19] d 3 and 9
[520|p19] e 35 and 55
[521|p19] f 6 and 11
[522|p19] 2 Is it possible to find the highest common multiple of two or more numbers?
[523|p19] Give a reason for your answer.
[524|p19|T1] TIP
[525|p19] $M_4$  means the multiples of 4.

[527|p19] You will deal with rational and irrational numbers in more detail in Chapter 9.
[528|p19|T1] Factors
[529|p19] A factor is a number that divides exactly into another number with no remainder. For example, 2 is a factor of 16 because it goes into 16 exactly 8 ti...
[530|p19|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[531|p19] a 12
[532|p19] b 25
[533|p19] c 110
[534|p19|T1] Answers
[535|p19] a F12=1,2,3,4,6,12
[536|p19] Find pairs of numbers that multiply to give 12:
[537|p19] $$
\begin{array}{l} 1 \times 1 2 \\ 2 \times 6 \\ 3 \times 4 \\ \end{array}
$$
[538|p19] b  $F_{25} = 1,5,25$
[539|p19] Write the factors in numerical order.
[540|p19] $$
1 \times 2 5
$$
[541|p19] $$
5 \times 5
$$
[542|p19] Do not repeat the 5.
[543|p19] c  $F_{110} = 1,2,5,10,11,22,55,110$
[544|p19] $$
\begin{array}{l} 1 \times 1 1 0 \\ 2 \times 5 5 \\ 5 \times 2 2 \\ 1 0 \times 1 1 \\ \end{array}
$$
[545|p19|T1] TIP
[546|p19] $F_{12}$  means the factors of 12.

[585|p20|T1] The highest common factor (HCF)
[586|p20] The highest common factor of two or more numbers is the highest number that is a factor of all the given numbers.
[587|p20|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[588|p20] Find the highest common factor of 8 and 24.
[589|p20|T1] Answer
[590|p20] $$
F _ {8} = 1, 2, 4, 8
$$
[591|p20] List the factors of each number.
[592|p20] $$
F _ {2 4} = 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 1 2, 2 4
$$
[593|p20] Underline factors that appear in both sets.
[594|p20] $$
H C F = 8
$$
[595|p20] Pick out the highest underlined factor (HCF).
[596|p20|T1] Exercise 1.6
[597|p20] 1 Find the highest common factor of each pair of numbers.
[598|p20] a 3 and 6

[601|p20] d 42 and 70
[602|p20] 32 and 36

[607|p20] a an HCF of 2
[608|p20] b an HCF of 6

[610|p20] Give a reason for your answer.

[612|p20] You will learn how to find HCFs using prime factors later in the chapter.

[617|p21|T1] TIP
[618|p21] Recognising the type of problem helps you to choose the correct mathematical techniques for solving it.
[619|p21] Word problems involving HCF usually involve splitting things into smaller pieces or arranging things in equal groups or rows.
[620|p21|T1] 1.3 Prime numbers
[621|p21] Prime numbers have exactly two different factors: one and the number itself.
[622|p21] Composite numbers have more than two factors.
[623|p21] The number 1 has only one factor so it is not prime and it is not composite.
[624|p21|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[625|p21] Later in this chapter you will learn how to write integers as products of prime factors. One of the reasons why it is important for 1 to NOT be define...
[626|p21|T1] Finding prime numbers
[627|p21] Over 2000 years ago, a Greek mathematician called Eratosthenes made a simple tool for sorting out prime numbers. This tool is called the 'Sieve of Era...
[628|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr>
[629|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>⑪</td><td>12</td><td>⑬</td><td>14</td><td>15</td><td>16</td><td>17</td><td>18</td><td>19</td><td>20</td></tr>
[630|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>21</td><td>22</td><td>⑲</td><td>24</td><td>25</td><td>26</td><td>27</td><td>28</td><td>29</td><td>30</td></tr>
[631|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>⑲</td><td>32</td><td>33</td><td>34</td><td>35</td><td>36</td><td>37</td><td>38</td><td>39</td><td>40</td></tr>
[632|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>④</td><td>42</td><td>⑲</td><td>44</td><td>45</td><td>46</td><td>47</td><td>48</td><td>49</td><td>50</td></tr>
[633|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>51</td><td>52</td><td>⑳</td><td>54</td><td>55</td><td>56</td><td>57</td><td>58</td><td>59</td><td>60</td></tr>
[634|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>⑥</td><td>62</td><td>63</td><td>64</td><td>65</td><td>66</td><td>67</td><td>68</td><td>69</td><td>70</td></tr>
[635|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>⑦</td><td>72</td><td>⑳</td><td>74</td><td>75</td><td>76</td><td>77</td><td>78</td><td>79</td><td>80</td></tr>
[636|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>81</td><td>82</td><td>⑧</td><td>84</td><td>85</td><td>86</td><td>87</td><td>88</td><td>89</td><td>90</td></tr>
[637|p21] [Table Row] <tr><td>91</td><td>92</td><td>93</td><td>94</td><td>95</td><td>96</td><td>97</td><td>98</td><td>99</td><td>100</td></tr>
[638|p21] Cross out 1, it is not prime.
[639|p21] Circle 2, then cross out other multiples of 2.
[640|p21] Circle 3, then cross out other multiples of 3.
[641|p21] Circle the next available number then cross out all its multiples.
[642|p21] Repeat until all the numbers in the table are either circled or crossed out.
[643|p21] The circled numbers are the primes.
[644|p22] Other mathematicians over the years have developed ways of finding larger and larger prime numbers. Until 1955, the largest known prime number had les...
[645|p22] You should try to memorise the prime numbers between 1 and 100.
[647|p22|T1] INVESTIGATION
[648|p22] Why do mathematicians find prime numbers exciting?
[649|p22] One reason why prime numbers are interesting and intriguing is because there is a lot about them that we don't know and that mathematicians have not b...
[650|p22] 1 Goldbach's conjecture (1742) is one of the oldest and best-known unsolved problems in number theory.
[651|p22] a What is Goldbach's strong conjecture?
[652|p22] b A Peruvian mathematician, Harald Helfgott, has published a largely accepted proof of Goldbach's weak conjecture. Find out more about this.
[653|p22|T1] LINK
[654|p22] Today anyone can join the search for Mersenne prime numbers. This project links thousands of home computers to search continuously for larger and larg...
[655|p22|T1] LINK
[656|p22] Prime numbers are used in codes and codebreaking. The larger the prime you use, the harder it is to break the code. This is why it is more and more im...
[657|p23|T1] INVESTIGATION CONTINUED
[658|p23] 2 The Mersenne prime number search relies on massive computing power to find large primes. There is no other way to work out where the nth prime numbe...
[659|p23] a Riemann built his ideas on the prime number theorem. Find out what this is and express it in simple language.
[660|p23] b Is there a proof for the existence of infinitely-many prime numbers?
[661|p23] 3 And just for fun ... What is an emirp? Find some examples to show what these are.
[662|p23|T1] Exercise 1.7
[663|p23] 1 Which is the only even prime number?
[664|p23] 2 How many odd prime numbers are there that are less than 50?
[665|p23] 3 a List the composite numbers greater than four, but less than 30.
[666|p23] b Try to write each composite number on your list as the sum of two prime numbers. For example:  $6 = 3 + 3$  and  $8 = 3 + 5$ .
[667|p23] 4 Twin primes are pairs of prime numbers that differ by two. List the twin prime pairs up to 100.
[668|p23] 5 Is 149 a prime number? Explain how you decided.
[669|p23|T1] Prime factors
[670|p23] Prime factors are the factors of a number that are also prime numbers.
[671|p23] Every composite whole number can be broken down and written as the product of its prime factors. You can do this using tree diagrams or using division...
[672|p23|T1] TIP
[673|p23] Remember, a product is the answer to a multiplication. So to write a number as the product of its prime factors you write it like this:
[674|p23] $$
1 2 = 2 \times 2 \times 3.
$$
[675|p24|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[676|p24] Write the following numbers as the product of prime factors.
[677|p24] a 36
[678|p24] b 48
[679|p24|T1] Answers
[680|p24] Using a factor tree
[682|p24] $$
3 6 = 2 \times 2 \times 3 \times 3
$$
[684|p24] $$
4 8 = 2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 3
$$
[685|p24] Write the number as two factors.
[686|p24] If a factor is a prime number, circle it.
[687|p24] If a factor is a composite number, split it into two factors.
[688|p24] Keep splitting until you end up with two primes.
[689|p24|T1] TIP
[690|p24] Prime numbers only have two factors: 1 and the number itself. As 1 is not a prime number, do not include it when expressing a number as a product of p...
[691|p24] Using division
[692|p24] $$
\begin{array}{c c} 2 & 3 6 \\ 2 & 1 8 \\ 3 & 9 \\ 3 & 3 \\ & 1 \end{array}
$$
[693|p24] $$
\begin{array}{c c} 2 & 4 8 \\ 2 & \frac {2 4}{2 4} \\ 2 & 1 2 \\ 2 & 6 \\ 3 & 3 \\ & 1 \end{array}
$$
[694|p24] $$
3 6 = 2 \times 2 \times 3 \times 3
$$
[695|p24] $$
4 8 = 2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 3
$$
[696|p24] Write the primes in ascending order with  $\times$  signs.
[697|p24] Divide by the smallest prime number that will go into the number exactly.
[698|p24] Continue dividing, using the smallest prime number that will go into your new answer each time.
[699|p24] Stop when you reach 1.
[700|p24] Write the prime factors in ascending order with  $\times$  signs.
[701|p24|T1] TIP
[702|p24] Choose the method that works best for you and stick to it. Always show your method when using prime factors.
[703|p24|T1] Exercise 1.8
[704|p24] 1 Express the following numbers as the product of prime factors.
[705|p24] a 30
[706|p24] f 504
[707|p24] b 24
[708|p24] g 650
[709|p24] c 100
[710|p24] h 1125
[711|p24] d 225
[712|p24] i 756
[713|p24] e 360
[714|p24] i 9240
[715|p24|T1] TIP
[716|p24] When you write your number as a product of primes, group all occurrences of the same prime number together.
[717|p25|T1] Using prime factors to find the HCF and LCM
[718|p25] When you are working with larger numbers you can determine the HCF or LCM by expressing each number as a product of its prime factors.
[719|p25|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[720|p25] Find the HCF of 168 and 180.
[721|p25|T1] Answer
[722|p25] $$
1 6 8 = 2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 3 \times 7
$$
[723|p25] First express each number as a product of prime factors. Use tree diagrams or division to do this.
[724|p25] $$
1 8 0 = 2 \times 2 \times 3 \times 3 \times 5
$$
[725|p25] Underline the factors common to both numbers.
[726|p25] $$
2 \times 2 \times 3 = 1 2
$$
[727|p25] Multiply these out to find the HCF.
[728|p25] $$
H C F = 1 2
$$
[729|p25|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[730|p25] Find the LCM of 72 and 120.
[731|p25|T1] Answer
[732|p25] $$
7 2 = 2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 3 \times 3
$$
[733|p25] First express each number as a product of prime factors. Use tree diagrams or division to do this.
[734|p25] $$
1 2 0 = 2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 3 \times 5
$$
[735|p25] Underline the largest set of multiples of each factor.
[736|p25] $$
2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 3 \times 3 \times 5 = 3 6 0
$$
[737|p25] List these and multiply them out to find the LCM.
[738|p25] $$
\mathrm {L C M} = 3 6 0
$$
[739|p25|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[740|p25] You can also use prime factors to find the square and cube roots of numbers if you don't have a calculator. You will deal with this in more detail lat...

[765|p26|T1] APPLY YOUR SKILLS
[766|p26] 4 A radio station runs a phone-in competition for listeners. Every 30th caller gets a free airtime voucher and every 120th caller gets a free mobile p...

[771|p26] b How many factors does  $q$  have?
[772|p26] The number  $r$  can be written as a product of  $n$  different prime numbers.
[773|p26] c How many factors does  $r$  have?
[774|p26|T1] TIP
[775|p26] Recognising the type of problem helps you to choose the correct mathematical techniques for solving it.
[776|p26] Word problems involving LCM usually include repeating events. You may be asked how many items you need to have enough' or when something will happen a...
[777|p26|T1] 1.4 Working with directed numbers
[778|p26] When you use numbers to represent real-life situations like temperatures, altitude, depth below sea level, profit or loss and directions (on a grid), ...
[779|p26|T1] TIP
[780|p26] Once a direction is chosen to be positive, the opposite direction is taken to be negative. So:
[781|p26] if up is positive, down is negative
[782|p26] if right is positive, left is negative.
[783|p26] if north is positive, south is negative
[784|p26] if above 0 is positive, below 0 is negative.
[786|p27|T1] Exercise 1.10
[787|p27] 1 Express each of these situations using a directed number.
[788|p27] a a profit of $100
[789|p27] b 25 km below sea level
[790|p27] c a drop of 10 marks
[791|p27] d a gain of  $2\mathrm{kg}$
[792|p27] e a loss of  $1.5\mathrm{kg}$
[793|p27] 8000 m above sea level
[794|p27] g a temperature of  $10^{\circ}C$  below zero
[795|p27] a fall of  $24\mathrm{m}$
[796|p27] i a debt of $2000
[797|p27] an increase of $250
[798|p27] k a time two hours behind local time
[799|p27] a height of  $400\mathrm{m}$
[800|p27|T1] Calculating with directed numbers
[801|p27] In mathematics, directed numbers are also known as integers. You can represent the set of integers on a number line like this:
[803|p27] The further to the right a number is on the number line, the greater its value.
[804|p27|T1] LINK
[805|p27] Directed numbers are important when describing temperatures. The Celsius (or centigrade) temperature scale places the temperature at which water freez...
[806|p27] When you calculate with negative and positive integers, you need to pay attention to the signs and remember these rules:
[807|p27] - Adding a negative number is the same as subtracting the number.  $3 + -5 = -2$
[808|p27] - Subtracting a negative number is the same as adding a positive number.  $3 - - 5 = 8$
[809|p27] Multiplying or dividing the same signs gives a positive answer.  $-3 \times -5 = 15$  and  $-20 \div -4 = -5$
[810|p27] - Multiplying or dividing different signs gives a negative answer.  $3 \times -5 = 15$  and  $15 \div -3 = -5$ .

[877|p29|T1] 1.5 Powers, roots and laws of indices
[878|p29] You know that  $2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 2 = 16$ .
[879|p29] You can write this in index notation as:
[880|p29] $$
2 ^ {4} = 1 6
$$
[881|p29] 2 is the base
[882|p29] 4 is the index
[883|p29] The index is also called a power or an exponent.
[884|p29] $$
\text {b a s e} \rightarrow 2 ^ {4} \text {— i n d e x}
$$
[885|p29|T1] Square numbers and square roots
[886|p29] A number is squared when it is multiplied by itself. For example, the square of 5 is  $5 \times 5 = 25$ . The symbol for squared is  $^2$ . So you can...
[887|p29] The square root of a number is the number that was multiplied by itself to get the square number. The symbol for square root is  $\sqrt{}$ .
[888|p29] You know that  $25 = 5^2$ , so  $\sqrt{25} = 5$ .
[889|p29|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[890|p29] In Section 1.1 you learned that the product obtained when an integer is multiplied by itself is a square number.
[891|p30] You also know that  $-5 \times -5 = 25$ . However, the mathematical convention is that the square root sign only refers to the positive square root. T...
[892|p30] If you want to indicate both the positive and negative square roots of 25 you need to write  $\pm, \overline{25}$ .
[893|p30|T1] Cube numbers and cube roots
[894|p30] A number is cubed when it is multiplied by itself and then multiplied by itself again. For example, the cube of 2 is  $2 \times 2 \times 2 = 8$ . The ...
[895|p30] The cube root of a number is the number that was multiplied by itself to get the cube number. The symbol for cube root is  $\sqrt[3]{3}$ . You know th...
[896|p30|T1] Finding powers and roots
[897|p30] You should know the squares of numbers from 1 to 15 (and their roots) and the cubes of numbers from 1 to 5 as well as they cube of 10. For other numbe...
[898|p30|T1] TIP
[899|p30] Not all calculators have exactly the same buttons.  $x^{\square}$ $x^{\prime}$  and  $\wedge$  all mean the same thing on different calculators. Make ...

[902|p30] a 192

[916|p30|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[917|p30] To solve equations like  $x^{2} = 25$  you need to find both the positive and negative square roots, so if  $x^{2} = 25$  then  $x = \pm \sqrt{25} = 5...
[918|p31|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[919|p31] Without using a calculator find:
[920|p31] a 324
[921|p31] b 512
[922|p31|T1] Answers
[923|p31] a  $324 = \underbrace{2\times 2}_{2}\times \underbrace{3\times 3}_{3}\times \underbrace{3\times 3}_{3}$
[924|p31] $$
2 \times 3 \times 3 = 1 8
$$
[925|p31] $$
\sqrt {3 2 4} = 1 8
$$
[926|p31] b  $512 = \underbrace{2\times 2\times 2}_{2}\times \underbrace{2\times 2\times 2}_{2}\times \underbrace{2\times 2\times 2}_{2}$
[927|p31] $$
2 \times 2 \times 2 = 8
$$
[928|p31] $$
\sqrt [ 3 ]{5 1 2} = 8
$$
[929|p31] Group the factors into pairs, and write down the square root of each pair.
[930|p31] Multiply the roots together to get the square root of 324.
[931|p31] Group the factors into threes, and write the cube root of each group.
[932|p31] Multiply together to get the cube root of 512.

[1031|p32|T1] TIP
[1032|p32] Brackets act as grouping symbols. Work out any calculations inside brackets before doing the calculations outside the brackets.
[1033|p32] Root signs work in the same way as a bracket. If you have  $\sqrt{25 + 9}$ , you must add 25 and 9 before finding the root.

[1055|p33|T1] Other indices and roots
[1056|p33] You have seen that square numbers are all raised to the power of two (5 squared  $= 5 \times 5 = 5^2$ ) and that cube numbers are all raised to the po...
[1057|p33] $$
\begin{array}{l} 5 ^ {2} = 2 5 \quad , \overline {{2 5}} = 5 \\ 5 ^ {3} = 1 2 5 \quad \overline {{1 2 5}} = 5 \\ 5 ^ {4} = 6 2 5 \quad 4 \overline ...
[1058|p33] You can use your calculator to perform operations using any roots or squares.
[1059|p33] The  $y^*$  key calculates any power.
[1060|p33] So, to find  $75$ , you enter  $7\text{y}^{\prime}$  5 and get a result of 16 807.
[1061|p33] The  $\sqrt[3]{\cdot}$  key calculates any root.
[1062|p33] So, to find  $\sqrt[4]{81}$ , you enter 4  $\sqrt[4]{81}$  and get a result of 3.
[1063|p33] Make sure that you know which key is used for each function on your calculator and that you know how to use it. On some calculators these keys might b...
[1064|p33|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[1065|p33] You will work with higher powers and roots again when you deal with indices in algebra in Chapter 2, standard form in Chapter 5 and rates of growth an...
[1066|p33|T1] Index notation and products of prime factors
[1067|p33] Index notation is very useful when you have to express a number as a product of its prime factors because it allows you to write the factors in a shor...
[1068|p34|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[1069|p34] Express these numbers as products of their prime factors in index form.
[1070|p34] a 200
[1071|p34] b 19683
[1072|p34|T1] Answers
[1073|p34] These diagrams are a reminder of the factor tree and division methods for finding the prime factors.
[1074|p34] a
[1076|p34] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 5 \times 5 \\ 2 0 0 = 2 ^ {3} \times 5 ^ {2} \\ \end{array}
$$
[1077|p34] b
[1079|p34] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 \\ 1 9 6 8 3 = 3 ^ {9} \\ \end{array}
$$

[1100|p34] 4 Write several square numbers as products of prime factors, using index notation. What can you say about the index needed for each prime?
[1101|p34|T1] TIP
[1102|p34] Remember that anything raised to the power of zero is equal to 1.
[1103|p35|T1] The laws of indices
[1104|p35] The laws of indices are a set of mathematical rules that allow you to multiply and divide numbers written in index notation without having to write th...
[1105|p35] Make sure that you remember these three important rules.
[1106|p35] To multiply different powers of the same number, add the indices. For example,  $3^{2} \times 3^{5} = 3^{2 + 5} = 3^{7}$  and  $4^{-2} \times 4^{3} = ...
[1107|p35] To divide different powers of the same number, subtract the indices.
[1108|p35] For example,  $3^{6} \div 3^{2} = 3^{6 - 2} = 3^{4}$  and  $\frac{4^{3}}{4^{7}} = 4^{3 - 7} = 4^{-4}$
[1109|p35] To find the power of a power you multiply the indices. For example,  $(3^{1})^{2} = 3^{3 \times 2} = 3^{6}$  and  $(4^{2})^{-3} = 4^{2 \times -3} = 4^...
[1110|p35] In general terms:
[1111|p35] $$
\begin{array}{l} a ^ {m} \times a ^ {n} = a ^ {m + n} \\ a ^ {m} \div a ^ {n} = a ^ {m - n} \\ (a ^ {m}) ^ {n} = a ^ {n m} \\ \end{array}
$$
[1112|p35|T1] Zero and negative indices
[1113|p35] Do you remember how to work with zero and negative indices? Read through this information to refresh your memory.
[1114|p35] In this table, each value is  $\frac{1}{5}$  of the one to its left. For example,  $5^4 \div 5 = 5^3$ .
[1115|p35] [Table Row] <tr><td>Power of 5</td><td>54</td><td>53</td><td>52</td><td>51</td><td>50</td><td>5-1</td><td>5-2</td><td>5-3</td><td>5-4</td></tr>
[1116|p35] [Table Row] <tr><td>Value</td><td>625</td><td>125</td><td>25</td><td>5</td><td>1</td><td>1/5</td><td>1/25</td><td>1/125</td><td>1/625</td></tr>
[1117|p35] The pattern in the table shows that  $5^0 = 1$ . This is true for any number to the power of 0.
[1118|p35] We can say  $a^0 = 1$  (where  $a \neq 0$ , because  $0^0$  is undefined.).
[1119|p35] You can also see from the table that a number with a negative index is equal to its reciprocal with a positive index. For example:  $5^{-2} = \frac{1}...
[1120|p35] This is true for all negative indices.
[1121|p35] We can say  $a^{-m} = \frac{1}{a^{m}}$  (where  $a \neq 0$ ).

[1189|p36|T1] Fractional indices
[1190|p36] Do you remember what a fractional index such as  $5^{\frac{1}{2}}$  means?
[1191|p36] You can use the laws of indices to show the meaning of fractional indices.
[1192|p36] $$
5 ^ {\frac {1}{2}} \times 5 ^ {\frac {1}{2}} = 5 ^ {(\frac {1}{2} + \frac {1}{2})} = 5 ^ {1} = 5
$$
[1193|p36] ou also know that  $\sqrt{5}\times \sqrt{5} = 5$
[1194|p36] $$
\mathrm {S o}, 5 ^ {\frac {1}{2}} = \sqrt {5}
$$
[1195|p36] $$
5 ^ {1} \times 5 ^ {1} \times 5 ^ {1} = 5 ^ {1 + 1 + 1} = 5 ^ {1} = 5
$$
[1196|p36] $$
\text {A n d} \sqrt [ 3 ]{5} \times \sqrt [ 3 ]{5} \times \sqrt [ 3 ]{5} = 5
$$
[1197|p36] $$
\mathrm {S o}, 5 ^ {\frac {1}{2}} = \sqrt [ 3 ]{5}
$$
[1198|p36] In general terms, for unit fractions:
[1199|p36] $$
a ^ {\frac {1}{2}} = \sqrt {a} \quad a ^ {\frac {1}{2}} = \sqrt [ 3 ]{a} \quad a ^ {\frac {1}{2}} = \sqrt [ 3 ]{a}
$$
[1200|p36|T1] LINK
[1201|p36] Fractional indices and roots are used in many different financial calculations involving investments, insurance policies and economic decisions.
[1202|p37] You can use the rule for finding the power of a power to show the meaning of fractional indices where the numerator is not 1 (non-unit fractions).
[1203|p37] $$
(4 \frac {1}{2}) ^ {3} = 4 \frac {1}{4} \times \frac {1}{2}) = 4 \frac {1}{2}
$$
[1204|p37] This shows that a number such as  $5^{\frac{1}{2}}$  can be written with a unit fraction index as  $(5^{\frac{1}{2}})^{2}$ .
[1205|p37] You already know that you can write a unit fraction (such as  $\frac{1}{3}$ ) as a root.
[1206|p37] $$
S _ {0} 5 ^ {\frac {1}{2}} = (5 ^ {\frac {1}{2}}) ^ {2} = (\sqrt [ 3 ]{5}) ^ {2}
$$
[1207|p37] It is simpler to input the value in root form into your calculator than to enter  $5^{\ddagger}$ . In general terms, for non-unit fractions:
[1208|p37] $$
a ^ {\frac {m}{2}} = \left(a ^ {\frac {1}{2}}\right) ^ {m} = \left(\sqrt [ n ]{a}\right) ^ {m} = \sqrt [ n ]{a ^ {m}}
$$
[1209|p37|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11
[1210|p37] Work out the value of:
[1211|p37] a 273
[1212|p37] b 251.5
[1213|p37] Answers
[1214|p37] a 27 3 27
[1215|p37] $$
\begin{array}{l} = (3) ^ {2} \\ = 9 \\ \end{array}
$$
[1216|p37] $\frac{2}{3} = 2 \times \frac{1}{3}$ , so you square the cube root of 27.
[1217|p37] b  $25^{1.5} = 25^{\frac{3}{2}}$
[1218|p37] Change the decimal to a fraction.
[1219|p37] $$
\begin{array}{l} = (\sqrt {2 5}) ^ {3} \\ = (5) ^ {3} \\ = 1 2 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[1220|p37] $\frac{3}{2} = 3 \times \frac{1}{2}$ , so you need to cube the
[1221|p37] square root of 25.

[1254|p37|T1] TIP
[1255|p37] Multiplication is
[1256|p37] commutative, so
[1257|p37] $(a^{\frac{1}{2}})^{m}$  is the same as
[1258|p37] $$
(a ^ {m}) ^ {\frac {1}{n}} = \sqrt [ n ]{a ^ {m}}
$$
[1259|p38|T1] APPLY YOUR SKILLS
[1260|p38] 4 The number of calories a mammal uses when they are at rest can be worked out using the formula  $C = 70 \times m^{\frac{1}{2}}$ , where  $m$  is the...
[1261|p38] a Express the formula using a root sign.
[1262|p38] b A cat has a mass of 5.5 kilograms. Work out how many calories it consumes while it is at rest.
[1263|p38] c How many calories would a  $5000\mathrm{kg}$  elephant consume at rest?
[1264|p38|T1] 1.6 Order of operations
[1265|p38] At this level of mathematics you are expected to carry out calculations involving more than one operation  $(+, -, \times$  and  $\div$ ). When you do...
[1266|p38] complete operations in grouping symbols first
[1267|p38] - deal with powers and roots next
[1268|p38] do division and multiplication next, working from left to right.
[1269|p38] do addition and subtraction last, working from left to right.
[1270|p38] Many people use the letters BODMAS to remember the order of operations.
[1271|p38] The letters stand for:
[1272|p38] Brackets
[1273|p38] Orders
[1274|p38] Divide Multiply
[1275|p38] Add Subtract
[1276|p38] BODMAS indicates that indices (powers of) are considered after brackets but before all other operations.
[1277|p38|T1] Grouping symbols
[1278|p38] The most common grouping symbols in mathematics are brackets. Here are some examples of the different kinds of brackets used in mathematics:
[1279|p38] $$
\begin{array}{l} (4 + 9) \times (1 0 \div 2) \\ [ 2 (4 + 9) - 4 (3) - 1 2 ] \\ \{2 - [ 4 (2 - 7) - 4 (3 + 8) ] - 2 \times 8 \} \\ \end{array}
$$
[1280|p38|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[1281|p38] You will apply the order of operation rules to fractions, decimals and algebraic expressions as you progress through the course.
[1282|p39] When you have more than one set of brackets in a calculation, you work out the innermost set first.
[1283|p39] Other symbols used to group operations are:
[1284|p39] - fraction bars, e.g.  $\frac{5 - 12}{3 - 8}$
[1285|p39] - root signs, such as square roots and cube roots, e.g.  $\sqrt{9 + 16}$
[1286|p39|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 12
[1287|p39] Simplify.
[1288|p39] a  $7\times (3 + 4)$
[1289|p39] b (10 - 4) × (4 + 9)
[1290|p39] c 45-[20×(4-3)]
[1291|p39] Answers
[1292|p39] a  $7\times 7 = 49$
[1293|p39] b  $6\times 13 = 78$
[1294|p39] $45 - [20\times 1] = 45 - 20 = 25$
[1295|p39|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13
[1296|p39] Calculate.
[1297|p39] 4+28 a 17-9
[1298|p39] b 36÷4+100-36
[1299|p39] Answers
[1300|p39] a  $(4 + 28)\div (17 - 9)$
[1301|p39] b 36÷4+100-36
[1302|p39] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 3 2 \div 8 \\ = \sqrt {9} + \sqrt {6 4} \\ = 4 \\ = 3 + 8 \\ = 1 1 \\ \end{array}
$$
[1303|p39] Now that you know what to do with grouping symbols, you can apply the rules for order of operations to perform calculations with numbers.

[1504|p42|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[1505|p42] When you work with indices and standard form in Chapter 5, you will need to apply these skills and use your calculator effectively to solve problems i...
[1506|p43|T1] 1.7 Rounding and estimating
[1507|p43] In many calculations, particularly with decimals, you will not need to find an exact answer. Instead, you will be asked to give an answer to a stated ...
[1508|p43|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[1509|p43] Round 64.839906 to:
[1510|p43] a the nearest whole number
[1511|p43] b 1 decimal place
[1512|p43] c 3 decimal places.
[1513|p43|T1] Answers
[1514|p43] a 64.839906
[1515|p43] 4 is in the units place.
[1516|p43] 64.839906
[1517|p43] The next digit is 8, so you will round up to get 5.
[1518|p43] $= 65$  (to nearest whole number)
[1519|p43] To the nearest whole number.
[1520|p43] b 64.839906
[1521|p43] 8 is in the first decimal place.
[1522|p43] 64.839906
[1523|p43] The next digit is 3, so the 8 will remain unchanged.
[1524|p43] $= 64.8(1\mathrm{d.p.})$
[1525|p43] Correct to 1 decimal place.
[1526|p43] c 64.832906
[1527|p43] 9 is in the third decimal place.
[1528|p43] 64.839906
[1529|p43] The next digit is 9, so you need to round up.
[1530|p43] $= 64.840(3\mathrm{d}.p.)$
[1531|p43] When you round 9 up, you get 10, so carry one to the previous digit and write 0 in the place of the 9.
[1532|p43] Correct to 3 decimal places.
[1533|p43] When a number has many digits or decimal places it is useful to round it to significant figures (s.f.). The first significant digit of a number is the...
[1534|p43] If you are rounding to a whole number, write the appropriate number of zeros after the last significant digit as place holders to keep the number the ...
[1535|p43|T1] TIP
[1536|p43] Rounding to 1 significant figure does not mean you will only have one digit. When 13432 is rounded to 1 significant figure it is 10000 and not 1.
[1537|p43|T1] LINK
[1538|p43] We use 'rounding' in all subjects where numerical data is collected. Masses in physics, temperatures in biology, prices in economics: these all need t...
[1539|p44|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 16
[1540|p44|T1] Round:
[1541|p44] a 1.076 to 3 significant figures
[1542|p44] b 0.00736 to 1 significant figure
[1543|p44] c 23 512 435 to 2 significant figures
[1544|p44|T1] Answers
[1545|p44] a 1.0Z6
[1546|p44] $$
= 1. 0 8 (3 \mathrm {s}. \mathrm {f}.)
$$
[1547|p44] The third significant figure is the 7. The next digit is 6, so round 7 up to get 8.
[1548|p44] Correct to 3 significant figures.
[1549|p44] b 0.00Z36
[1550|p44] $$
= 0. 0 0 7 (1 \mathrm {s}. \mathrm {f}.)
$$
[1551|p44] The first significant figure is the 7. The next digit is 3, so 7 will not change.
[1552|p44] Correct to 1 significant figure.
[1553|p44] c 23512475
[1554|p44] $$
= 2 4 0 0 0 0 0 0 (2 \mathrm {s}. \mathrm {f}.)
$$
[1555|p44] The second significant figure is 3. The next digit is 5, so 3 will round up to 4.
[1556|p44] Include the zeros and state the level of accuracy.

[1607|p45] $$
3. 9 \times 2. 1 \text {i s a p p r o x i m a t e l y e q u a l t o} 4 \times 2 = 8
$$
[1608|p45] Notice that  $3.9 \times 2.1 = 8.19$ , so the estimated value of 8 is not too far from the real value!
[1609|p45|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 17
[1610|p45] Estimate the value of:
[1611|p45] 4.6+3.9 a 398
[1612|p45] b 42.2-5.1
[1613|p45|T1] Answers
[1614|p45] 4.6+3.9 is approximately equal to 5+4 398 400
[1615|p45] $$
= \frac {9}{2 0} = \frac {4 . 5}{1 0} = 0. 4 5
$$
[1616|p45] Check the estimate:
[1617|p45] $$
\frac {4 . 6 + 3 . 9}{3 9 8} = 0. 4 2 6 (3 \mathrm {s . f .})
$$
[1618|p45] Round the numbers to 1 significant figure.
[1619|p45] If you use a calculator you will find the exact value and see that the estimate was good.
[1620|p45] b  $\sqrt{42.2 - 5.1}$  is approximately equal to  $\sqrt{40 - 5}$
[1621|p45] $$
= \sqrt {3 5}
$$
[1622|p45] $$
i s \text {a p p r o x i m a t e l y e q u a l t o} \sqrt {3 6}
$$
[1623|p45] $$
= 6
$$

[1679|p47|T1] SUMMARY
[1680|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>Do you know ...?</td></tr>
[1681|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>Numbers can be classified as natural numbers, integers, prime numbers and square numbers.</td></tr>
[1682|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>A multiple is obtained by multiplying a number by a natural number. The LCM of two or more numbers is the lowest multiple found in...
[1683|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>A factor of a number divides into it exactly. The HCF of two or more numbers is the highest factor found in all the sets of factor...
[1684|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>Prime numbers have only two factors, 1 and the number itself. The number 1 is not a prime number.</td></tr>
[1685|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>A prime factor is a number that is both a factor and a prime number.</td></tr>
[1686|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>All natural numbers that are not prime can be expressed as a product of prime factors.</td></tr>
[1687|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>Integers are also called directed numbers. The sign of an integer (- or +) indicates whether its value is above or below 0.</td></...
[1688|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>When you multiply an integer (a) by itself you get a square number (a2). If you multiply it by itself again you get a cube number ...
[1689|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>The number you multiply to get a square is called the square root and the number you multiply to get a cube is called the cube roo...
[1690|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>You can express numbers as powers of their factors using index notation. For example, 23 means 2 × 2 × 2. The base is 2 and the in...
[1691|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>Any number to the power of 0 is equal to 1: a0 = 1.</td></tr>
[1692|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>A negative index can be written as a reciprocal fraction with a positive index: a-m = 1/a-m.</td></tr>
[1693|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>Fractional indices can be rewritten as roots: a1/2 = a/2.</td></tr>
[1694|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>For non-unit fractional indices: a1/2 = (a/2)1/2 = a1/m.</td></tr>
[1695|p47] [Table Row] <tr><td>The laws of indices are: a1/m × a1 = a1/m+n; a1/m = a1/m-n and (a1/m)1 = a1/m.</td></tr>

[1779|p50|T1] >Chapter 2
[1780|p50|T1] Making sense of algebra
[1781|p50|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[1782|p50] use letters to represent numbers
[1783|p50] write expressions to represent mathematical information
[1784|p50] - substitute numbers for words and letters in expressions
[1785|p50] - add and subtract like terms to simplify expressions
[1786|p50] - multiply and divide to simplify expressions
[1787|p50] expand expressions by removing grouping symbols
[1788|p50] use index notation in algebra
[1789|p50] learn and apply the laws of indices to simplify expressions
[1790|p50] work with fractional indices.
[1791|p51] You can think of algebra as the language of mathematics. When you learn a language, you have to learn its rules and structures. The language of algebr...
[1792|p51] Algebra lets you describe and represent complex mathematical patterns in clear mathematical language. At school, and in the real world, you will use a...
[1793|p51|T1] GETTING STARTED
[1794|p51] 1 How do you write each of these using algebra? Choose A, B or C.
[1795|p51] a a×a
[1796|p51] A 2°
[1797|p51] B 2a
[1798|p51] C  ${a}^{2}$
[1799|p51] b  $p$  multiplied by 5 and then added to 3.
[1800|p51] A  $5p + 3$
[1801|p51] B  $5(\rho +3)$
[1802|p51] C  $p + 15$
[1803|p51] c x cubed and then multiplied by 3.
[1804|p51] A  $3x^{3}$
[1805|p51] B (3x)³
[1806|p51] C  $9{x}^{3}$

[1816|p51] 3 These three examples contain some common mistakes that students make in algebra.
[1817|p51] [Table Row] <tr><td>Example 1

[1821|p51] 4 Work in pairs or small groups. Consecutive numbers are those that follow each other, for example 4 and 5 are consecutive.

[1825|p51|T1] KEY WORDS
[1826|p51] coefficient
[1827|p51] expression
[1828|p51] formula
[1829|p51] term
[1830|p51] variable
[1831|p52|T1] 2.1 Using letters to represent unknown values
[1832|p52] In primary school you used empty shapes to represent unknown numbers. For example,  $2 + \square = 8$  and  $\square + \diamond = 10$ . If  $2 + \squa...
[1833|p52] Algebra uses letters to represent unknown numbers. You could write the number sentences above as:  $2 + x = 8$  and  $a + b = 10$ . Number sentences l...
[1834|p52] When you worked with area of rectangles and triangles in the past, you used algebra to make a general rule, or formula, for working out the area,  $A$...
[1835|p52] Area of a rectangle  $=$  length  $\times$  width, so  $A = h$
[1836|p52] Area of a triangle  $= \frac{1}{2} \times$  base  $\times$  height, so  $A = \frac{1}{2} bh$  or  $A = \frac{bh}{2}$
[1837|p52] When two letters are multiplied together, you write them next to each other, e.g. for  $l \times w$  you would write  $l \times w$ .
[1838|p52] To use a formula you have to replace some or all of the letters with numbers. This is called substitution.
[1839|p52|T1] Writing algebraic expressions
[1840|p52] An algebraic expression is a group of letters and numbers linked by operation signs. Each part of the expression is called a term.
[1841|p52] Suppose the average height (in centimetres) of students in your class is an unknown number,  $h$ . A student who is  $10\mathrm{cm}$  taller than the ...
[1842|p52] $h + 10$  and  $h - 3$  are algebraic expressions. Because the unknown value is represented by  $h$ , we say these are expressions in terms of  $h$ .
[1843|p52|T1] LINK
[1844|p52] Algebra is used across all science subjects. For example, in Biology algebra is used to model biochemical networks, and linear relationships such as h...
[1845|p52|T1] TIP
[1846|p52] In an algebra problem, you must not change the 'case' of the letters being used. For example, 'n' and 'N' can represent different numbers in the same ...
[1847|p53|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[1848|p53] Use algebra to write an expression in terms of  $h$  (which represents average height) for:
[1849|p53] a a height 12 cm shorter than average
[1850|p53] b a height 2a taller than average
[1851|p53] a height twice the average height
[1852|p53] d a height half the average height.
[1853|p53|T1] Answers
[1854|p53] a  $h - 12$  Shorter than means less than, so you subtract.
[1855|p53] b  $h + 2a$  Taller than means more than, so you add. 2a is unknown, but it can still be used in the expression.
[1856|p53] $2\times h = 2h$  Twice means two times, so you multiply by two.
[1857|p53] d  $h\div 2 = \frac{h}{2}$  Half means divided by two.
[1858|p53|T1] Applying the rules
[1859|p53] You should write algebraic expressions in the shortest, simplest possible way:
[1860|p53] $2\times h$  is written as  $2h$  and  $x\times y$  is written as  $xy$
[1861|p53] $h$  means  $1\times h$  , but you do not write the 1
[1862|p53] $h\div 2$  is written as  $\frac{h}{2}$  and  $x\div y$  is written as  $\frac{x}{y}$
[1863|p53] - when you have the product of a number and a variable, the number is written first, so  $2h$  and not  $h2$ . Also, variables are normally written in...
[1864|p53] $h\times h$  is written as  $h^2$  (h squared) and  $h\times h\times h$  is written as  $h^3$  (h cubed). The  $\mathbf{2}$  and the  $\mathbf{3}$  ar...
[1865|p53] the power only applies to the number or variable directly before it, so  $5a^2$  means  $5 \times a \times a$
[1866|p53] - when a power is outside a bracket, it applies to everything inside the bracket, so  $(xy)^3$  means  $xy \times xy \times xy$ .
[1867|p53|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[1868|p53] Write expressions in terms of  $x$  to represent:
[1869|p53] a the number times four
[1870|p53] b the sum of the number and five
[1871|p53] c six times the number minus two
[1872|p53] d half the number.
[1873|p53|T1] Answers
[1874|p53] a x times four Let  $x$  represent 'the number'.
[1875|p53] $$
= x \times 4 \quad \text {R e p l a c e ' t i m e s f o u r ' w i t h} \times 4.
$$
[1876|p53] Leave out the  $\times$  sign, write the number before the variable.
[1877|p53|T1] TIP
[1878|p53] Mathematicians write the product of a number and a variable with the number first to avoid confusion with powers. For example, you would write  $x \ti...
[1879|p54|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2 CONTINUED
[1880|p54] b Sum of x and five
[1881|p54] $$
= x + 5
$$
[1882|p54] Let  $x$  represent 'the number'.
[1883|p54] Sum of means  $^+$  , replace five with 5.
[1884|p54] Six times x minus two
[1885|p54] $$
= 6 \times x - 2
$$
[1886|p54] Let  $x$  represent 'the number'.
[1887|p54] Times means  $\times$  and minus means -, insert numerals.
[1888|p54] $$
= 6 x - 2
$$
[1889|p54] Leave out the  $\times$  sign.
[1890|p54] d Half x
[1891|p54] $$
= x \div 2
$$
[1892|p54] Let  $x$  represent 'the number'.
[1893|p54] $$
= \frac {x}{2}
$$
[1894|p54] Half means  $\times \frac{1}{2}$  or  $\div 2$
[1895|p54] Write the division as a fraction.
[1896|p54|T1] Exercise 2.1
[1897|p54] 1 Rewrite each expression in its simplest form.
[1898|p54] a  $6\times x\times y$
[1899|p54] b 7xaxb
[1900|p54] $x\times y\times z$
[1901|p54] d  $2\times y\times y$
[1902|p54] e  $a\times 4\times b$
[1903|p54] f  $x\times y\times 12$
[1904|p54] $5 \times b \times a$
[1905|p54] h  $y\times z\times z$
[1906|p54] i  $6\div x$
[1907|p54] j  $4x\div 2y$
[1908|p54] k  $(x + 3)\div 4$
[1909|p54] $m\times m\times m\div m\times m$
[1910|p54] m  $4\times x + 5\times y$
[1911|p54] n  $a\times 7 - 2\times b$
[1912|p54] $2\times x\times (x - 4)$
[1913|p54] $3 \times (x + 1) \div 2 \times x$
[1914|p54] q  $2\times (x + 4)\div 3$
[1915|p54] r  $(4\times x)\div (2\times x + 4\times x)$
[1916|p54] 2 Let the unknown number be  $m$ . Write expressions for:
[1917|p54] a the sum of the unknown number and 13
[1918|p54] a number that will exceed the unknown number by five
[1919|p54] c the difference between 25 and the unknown number
[1920|p54] d the unknown number cubed
[1921|p54] a third of the unknown number plus three
[1922|p54] f four times the unknown number take away twice the number.
[1923|p54] 3 Let the unknown number be  $x$ . Write expressions for:
[1924|p54] a three more than x
[1925|p54] b six less than x
[1926|p54] ten times x
[1927|p54] d the sum of -8 and  $x$
[1928|p54] the sum of the unknown number and its square
[1929|p54] a number which is twice  $x$  more than  $x$
[1930|p54] 9 the fraction obtained when double the unknown number is divided by the sum of the unknown number and four.
[1931|p54|T1] TIP
[1932|p54] A 'sum' is the result of an addition and the 'difference' between two numbers is the result of a subtraction. The order of the subtraction matters.
[1933|p55] 4 A book and a pack of markers cost  $x$  dollars.
[1934|p55] a If the book costs $10 what does the pack of markers cost?
[1935|p55] b If the pack of markers is three times the price of the book, what does the book cost?
[1936|p55] c If the book costs $ (x - 15), what does the pack of markers cost?

[1939|p55] b How old was she ten years ago?
[1940|p55] Her son is half her age. How old is the son?

[1952|p55|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[1953|p55] Given that  $a = 2$  and  $b = 8$ , evaluate:
[1954|p55] a ab
[1955|p55] c 2a3
[1956|p55] d 2a(a + b)
[1957|p55|T1] Answers
[1958|p55] $\mathrm{a}\;\mathrm{{ab}} = \mathrm{a} \times  \mathrm{b}$
[1959|p55] $= 2\times 8$
[1960|p55] 16
[1961|p55] Put back the multiplication sign.
[1962|p55] Substitute the values for  $a$  and  $b$ .
[1963|p55] Calculate the answer.
[1964|p55|T1] TIP
[1965|p55] Evaluate means 'find the value of'.
[1966|p56|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3 CONTINUED
[1967|p56] b  $3b - 2a = 3\times b - 2\times a$
[1968|p56] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 3 \times 8 - 2 \times 2 \\ = 2 4 - 4 \\ = 2 0 \\ \end{array}
$$
[1969|p56] c  $2a^{3} = 2\times a^{3}$
[1970|p56] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 2 \times 2 ^ {3} \\ = 2 \times 8 \\ = 1 6 \\ \end{array}
$$
[1971|p56] Put back the multiplication signs.
[1972|p56] Substitute the values for  $a$  and  $b$ .
[1973|p56] Use the order of operations rules.
[1974|p56] (x before -).
[1975|p56] Calculate the answer.
[1976|p56] Put back the multiplication signs.
[1977|p56] Substitute the value for  $a$ .
[1978|p56] Work out  $2^{3}$  first (grouping symbols first).
[1979|p56] Calculate the answer.
[1980|p56] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 2 \times 2 \times (2 + 8) \\ = 4 \times 1 0 \\ \end{array}
$$
[1981|p56] d  $2a(a + b) = 2\times a\times (a + b)$
[1982|p56] Put back the multiplication signs.
[1983|p56] Substitute the values for  $a$  and  $b$ .
[1984|p56] In this case you can carry out two steps at the same time: multiplication outside the bracket, and the addition inside.
[1985|p56] Calculate the answer.
[1986|p56|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[1987|p56] Always apply the order of operations rules you learned in Chapter 1.

[1998|p57|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4 CONTINUED
[1999|p57|T1] Answers
[2000|p57] a i  $x + x + x + x = 4x$
[2001|p57] $$
\begin{array}{l} i i \quad 4 \times x = 4 \times 4 \\ = 1 6 \mathrm {c m} \\ \end{array}
$$
[2002|p57] b i  $3x + (x^{2} + 1) + 3x + (x^{2} + 1) = 2(3x) + 2(x^{2} + 1)$
[2003|p57] $$
\begin{array}{l} i i 2 \times (3 \times x) + 2 \times (x ^ {2} + 1) = 2 \times (3 \times 4) + 2 \times (4 ^ {2} + 1) \\ = 2 \times 1 2 + 2 \times (...
[2004|p57] c i  $x + 3 + x + 4 + 2x = 4x + 7$
[2005|p57] $$
\begin{array}{l} i i 4 x + 7 = 4 \times 4 + 7 \\ = 1 6 + 7 \\ = 2 3 \mathrm {c m} \\ \end{array}
$$
[2006|p57] Add the four lengths together.
[2007|p57] Substitute 4 into the expression.
[2008|p57] Add the four lengths together and simplify.
[2009|p57] Substitute 4 into the expression.
[2010|p57] Add the three lengths together and simplify
[2011|p57] Substitute 4 into the expression.

[2020|p57] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 \times 0 - 3 = 0 - 3 = - 3 \\ 3 \times 2 - 3 = 6 - 3 = 3 \\ 3 \times 4 - 3 = 1 2 - 3 = 9 \\ 3 \times 6 - 3 = 1 8 - 3 = 1 5 \\ \e...

[2102|p59|T1] DISCUSSION
[2103|p59] What is the point of algebra?
[2104|p59] Students sometimes ask why they have to learn algebra because they cannot see how it is useful.
[2105|p59] Work with a partner to prepare a short presentation to convince the rest of your class that algebra is valuable and useful.
[2106|p59] - Choose one of the topics in this chapter (or another algebra topic you like and know well).
[2107|p59] - Do research to find how this topic is useful in the real world.
[2108|p59] Prepare a slide show (or other presentation) to share what you find out. Include a description of the topic and how it is used. Provide at least three...
[2109|p59|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[2110|p59] Think back to Chapter 1 and the different types of number that you have already studied.
[2111|p59|T1] 2.3 Simplifying expressions
[2112|p59] The parts of an algebraic expression are called terms. Terms are separated from each other by  $+$  or  $-$  signs. So  $a + b$  is an expression with...
[2113|p59] The number in a term is called a coefficient. In the term  $2a$ , the coefficient is 2; in the term  $-3ab$ , the coefficient is  $-3$ . A term with o...
[2114|p59|T1] TIP
[2115|p59] Remember, terms are not separated by  $\times$  or  $+$  signs. A fraction line means divide, so the parts of a fraction are all counted as one term, ...
[2116|p60|T1] Collecting like terms
[2117|p60] Terms with exactly the same variables are called like terms.  $2a$  and  $4a$  are like terms;  $3xy^{2}$  and  $-xy^{2}$  are like terms.
[2118|p60] The variables and any indices attached to them have to be identical for terms to be like terms, so  $2x^{2}y$  and  $-3x^{2}y$  are like terms but  $2...
[2119|p60] You can add and subtract like terms to simplify algebraic expressions. This is known as collecting like terms.
[2120|p60|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[2121|p60] Simplify.
[2122|p60] a 4a+2a+3a
[2123|p60] b 4a+6b+3a
[2124|p60] c  $5x + 2y - 7x$
[2125|p60] d  $2p + 5q + 3q - 7p$
[2126|p60] e 2ab+3a2b-ab+3ab2
[2127|p60|T1] Answers
[2128|p60] a 4a+2a+3a
[2129|p60] b 4a+6b+3a
[2130|p60] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 9 a \\ = 7 a + 6 b \\ \end{array}
$$
[2131|p60] Terms are all like.
[2132|p60] Add the coefficients, write the term.
[2133|p60] Identify the like terms (4a and 3a).
[2134|p60] - Add the coefficients of like terms.
[2135|p60] Write terms in alphabetical order.
[2136|p60] c  $5x + 2y - 7x$
[2137|p60] $$
= - 2 x + 2 y
$$
[2138|p60] Identify the like terms (5x and  $-7x$
[2139|p60] Subtract the coefficients, remember the rules.
[2140|p60] Write the terms.
[2141|p60] (You can also write this as  $2y - 2x$ .)
[2142|p60] d  $2p + 5q + 3q - 7p$
[2143|p60] $$
= - 5 p + 8 q
$$
[2144|p60] Identify the like terms (2p and -7p; 5q and 3q).
[2145|p60] Add and subtract the coefficients.
[2146|p60] Write the terms.
[2147|p60] $$
= a b + 3 a ^ {2} b + 3 a b ^ {2}
$$
[2148|p60] e  $2ab + 3a^{2}b - ab + 3ab^{2}$
[2149|p60] Identify like terms; pay attention to terms that
[2150|p60] are squared because  $a$  and  $a^2$  are not like terms.
[2151|p60] Remember that ab means 1ab.
[2152|p60|T1] TIP
[2153|p60] You can rearrange the terms as long as you move the  $-$  and  $+$  signs with the terms to their right. For example:
[2154|p60] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 x - 2 y + 5 z \\ = 3 x + 5 z - 2 y \\ = 5 z + 3 x - 2 y \\ = - 2 y + 3 x + 5 z \\ \end{array}
$$
[2155|p60|T1] TIP
[2156|p60] Any  $^+$  or  $-$  that appears in an algebraic expression is attached to the term to its right. For example:  $3x - 4y$  contains two terms:  $3x$  ...

[2224|p62|T1] INVESTIGATION
[2225|p62|T1] Magic squares
[2226|p62] In a magic square, the sum of each row, column and diagonal is the same.
[2227|p62] 1 Is this a magic square?
[2228|p62] [Table Row] <tr><td>5x+2y</td><td>7y</td><td>7x+8y</td></tr>
[2229|p62] [Table Row] <tr><td>6x+9y</td><td>4x+5y</td><td>2x+y</td></tr>
[2230|p62] [Table Row] <tr><td>x+4y</td><td>8x+3y</td><td>3x+8y</td></tr>
[2231|p62] 2 Copy and complete this magic square.
[2232|p62] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr>
[2233|p62] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>a</td><td></td></tr>
[2234|p62] [Table Row] <tr><td>a+b</td><td>a-b-c</td><td>a+c</td></tr>
[2235|p62] 3 There are only four possible magic squares that use only the three terms:  $x - 1$ ,  $x$  and  $x + 1$
[2236|p62] a What are they?
[2237|p62] b Do you think the same applies to the terms  $2x - 2, 2x$  and  $2x + 2$ ? Justify your answer.
[2238|p62|T1] REFLECTION
[2239|p62] Think about how you worked on question 2 in the investigation.
[2240|p62] What steps did you follow to solve the problem? Could you work in a different order? If so, how?
[2241|p62] Could you solve the magic square using fewer steps? How?
[2242|p62] Will the strategies you used always work? Why?
[2243|p63|T1] Multiplying and dividing expressions
[2244|p63] In Section 2.1 you learned how to write expressions in simpler terms when multiplying and dividing them. Make sure you understand and remember these i...
[2245|p63] 3x means  $3\times x$  and 3xy means  $3\times x\times y$
[2246|p63] -  $x y$  means  $x \times y$
[2247|p63] $x^{2}$  means  $x\times x$  and  $x^{2}y$  means  $x\times x\times y$  (only the  $x$  is squared)
[2248|p63] 2a 4 means 2a-4
[2249|p63|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[2250|p63] Simplify.
[2251|p63] a  $4\times 3x$
[2252|p63] b  $4x\times 3y$
[2253|p63] 4ab×2bc
[2254|p63] d  $7x\times 4yz\times 3$
[2255|p63|T1] Answers
[2256|p63] a  $4\times 3x = 4\times 3\times x$
[2257|p63] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 1 2 \times x \\ = 1 2 x \\ \end{array}
$$
[2258|p63] Insert the missing  $\times$  signs.
[2259|p63] Multiply the numbers first.
[2260|p63] Write in simplest form.
[2261|p63] b  $4x\times 3y = 4\times x\times 3\times y$
[2262|p63] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 1 2 \times x \times y \\ = 1 2 x y \\ \end{array}
$$
[2263|p63] Insert the missing  $\times$  signs.
[2264|p63] Multiply the numbers.
[2265|p63] Write in simplest form.
[2266|p63] 4ab×2bc = 4×a×b×2×b×c
[2267|p63] Insert the missing  $\times$  signs.
[2268|p63] $$
= 8 \times a \times b \times b \times c
$$
[2269|p63] Multiply the numbers, then
[2270|p63] the variables.
[2271|p63] $$
= 8 a b ^ {2} c
$$
[2272|p63] Write in simplest form.
[2273|p63] d  $7x\times 4yz\times 3 = 7\times x\times 4\times y\times z\times 3$
[2274|p63] Insert the missing  $\times$  signs.
[2275|p63] Multiply the numbers.
[2276|p63] Write in simplest form.
[2277|p63] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 8 4 \times x \times y \times z \\ = 8 4 x y z \\ \end{array}
$$
[2278|p63|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[2279|p63] Simplify.
[2280|p63] 12x a 3
[2281|p63] 12xy b 3x
[2282|p63] 7xy 70y
[2283|p63] d  $\frac{2x}{3}\times \frac{4x}{2}$
[2284|p63|T1] Answers
[2285|p63] a  $\frac{12x}{3} = \frac{12x}{3} = \frac{4x}{1} = 4x$
[2286|p63] Divide both top and bottom by 3 (making the numerator and denominator smaller so that the fraction is in its simplest form is called cancelling).
[2287|p63] b  $\frac{12xy}{3x} = \frac{12xy}{3x} = \frac{4\times y}{1} = 4y$
[2288|p63] Cancel and then multiply.
[2289|p63|T1] TIP
[2290|p63] You can multiply numbers first and variables second because the commutative law  $(ab = ba)$  means that multiplication can be done in any order.
[2291|p63|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[2292|p63] You will learn more about cancelling and equivalent fractions in Chapter 5.
[2293|p64|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8 CONTINUED
[2294|p64] 7xy 7xy x 70y 10 10 10 Canel. 10
[2295|p64] d  $\frac{2x}{3} \times \frac{4x}{2} = \frac{2 \times x \times 4 \times x}{3 \times 2}$  Insert  $\times$  signs and multiply.
[2296|p64] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \frac {4 8 x ^ {2}}{6 3} \quad \text {C a n c e l .} \\ = \frac {4 x ^ {2}}{3} \\ \end{array}
$$
[2297|p64] or  $\frac{12x}{3} \times \frac{4x}{21} = \frac{1x}{3} \times \frac{4x}{1} = \frac{4x^2}{3}$  Cancel first, then multiply.

[2376|p65|T1] 2.4 Working with brackets
[2377|p65] When an expression has brackets, you normally have to remove the brackets before you can simplify the expression. Removing the brackets is called expa...
[2378|p65] To remove brackets you multiply each term inside the bracket by the number (and/ or variables) outside the bracket. When you do this you need to pay a...
[2379|p65] $$
x (y + z) = x y + x z
$$
[2380|p65] $$
x (y - z) = x y - x z
$$
[2381|p65] $$
- x (y + z) = - x y - x z
$$
[2382|p65] $$
- x (y - z) = - x y + x z
$$
[2383|p65|T1] TIP
[2384|p65] Expanding brackets is really just multiplying, so the same rules you used for multiplication apply in these examples.
[2385|p65|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[2386|p65] Expand the following expressions.
[2387|p65] a 2(2x+6)
[2388|p65] b 4(7-2x)
[2389|p65] c  $2x(x + 3y)$
[2390|p65] d  $xy(2 - 3x)$
[2391|p65|T1] Answers
[2393|p65] For parts (a) to (d) write out the expression, or do the multiplication mentally.
[2395|p65] Follow these steps when multiplying by a term outside a bracket:
[2396|p65] - Multiply the term on the left-hand inside of the bracket first - shown by the red arrow labelled i.
[2397|p65] - Then multiply the term on the right-hand side - shown by the blue arrow labelled ii.
[2398|p65] Then add the answers together.
[2399|p65|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[2400|p65] You will learn more about expanding expressions to remove brackets in Chapter 10.
[2401|p66|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9 CONTINUED
[2402|p66] c
[2403|p66] $$
\begin{array}{r l} \underset {\text {i}} {\text {i}} & = 2 x \times x + 2 x \times 3 y \\ \underset {\text {i}} {\text {i}} & = 2 x ^ {2} + 6 x y \...
[2404|p66] d
[2405|p66] $$
\begin{array}{r l} \underset {\mathrm {i}} {\mathrm {i}} & = x y \times 2 - x y \times 3 x \\ \underset {\mathrm {i i}} {\mathrm {i}} & = 2 x y - 3...

[2452|p67|T1] INVESTIGATION
[2453|p67|T1] Maths jokes
[2454|p67] If you do an internet search for 'maths jokes' you get about 12 million entries.
[2455|p67] What makes maths so funny?
[2456|p67] Look at these examples of maths jokes.
[2457|p67] If I had ten dollars for every time algebra helped me, I'd have 10x dollars.
[2458|p67] $$
\begin{array}{r l} & {\bullet \mathrm {E x p a n d} 2 (x + 3 y)} \\ & {2 (x + 3 y)} \\ & {= 2 (x + 3 y)} \\ & {= 2 (x + 3 y)} \end{array}
$$
[2459|p67] Algebra wasn't very challenging in Ancient Rome because x was always equal to 10.
[2460|p67] What is the premise of each joke? In other words, what makes it funny?
[2461|p67] Find at least two more maths jokes that you think are funny.
[2462|p67] Tell your group why each one is amusing to you.
[2463|p67|T1] Expanding and collecting like terms
[2464|p67] When you remove brackets and expand an expression you may end up with some like terms. When this happens, you collect the like terms together (add or ...
[2465|p67|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[2466|p67] Expand and simplify where possible.
[2467|p67] a  $6(x + 3) + 4$
[2468|p67] b 2(6a+1)-2a+4
[2469|p67] c  $2x(x + 3) + x(x - 4)$
[2470|p67|T1] Answers
[2471|p67] a  $6(x + 3) + 4 = 6x + 18 + 4$
[2472|p67] $$
= 6 x + 2 2
$$
[2473|p67] Remove the brackets.
[2474|p67] Add like terms.
[2475|p67] b  $2(6a + 1) - 2a + 4 = 12a + 2 - 2a + 4$
[2476|p67] $$
= 1 0 a + 6
$$
[2477|p67] Remove the brackets.
[2478|p67] Add or subtract like terms.
[2479|p67] $2x(x + 3) + x(x - 4) = 2x^{2} + 6x + x^{2} - 4x$
[2480|p67] $$
= 3 x ^ {2} + 2 x
$$
[2481|p67] Remove the brackets.
[2482|p67] Add or subtract like terms.

[2522|p68|T1] Expanding brackets with negative coefficients
[2523|p68] So far the numbers in front of the brackets you expanded were positive. You expand brackets in the same way when there is a negative number before the...
[2524|p68] The key is to remember that a  $+^{\prime}$  or a  $-$  is attached to the number immediately following it and should be included when you multiply ou...
[2525|p68|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11
[2526|p68] Expand and simplify the following expressions.
[2527|p68] a -3(x+4)
[2528|p68] b 4(y-7)-5(3y+5)
[2529|p68] c  $8(p + 4) - 10(9p - 6)$
[2530|p68|T1] Answers
[2531|p68] a -3(x+4)
[2532|p68] $$
\begin{array}{l} - 3 (x + 4) = - 3 x - 1 2 \\ - 3 \times x = - 3 x \text {a n d} - 3 \times 4 = - 1 2 \\ \end{array}
$$
[2533|p68] b  $4(y - 7) - 5(3y + 5) = 4y - 28 - 15y - 25$
[2534|p68] $$
= - 1 1 y - 5 3
$$
[2535|p68] Remember that the negative sign is attached to the 3.
[2536|p68] Remember that both terms in the second bracket are multiplied by -5.
[2537|p68] Collect like terms and simplify.
[2538|p68|T1] TIP
[2539|p68] Remember:
[2540|p68] $$
\begin{array}{l} + \times + = + \\ + \times - = - \\ - x - = + \\ \end{array}
$$
[2541|p69|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11 CONTINUED
[2542|p69] 8(p+4)-10(9p-6)=8p+32-90p+60
[2543|p69] $$
= - 8 2 p + 9 2
$$
[2544|p69] Remove the brackets. Pay attention to the negative signs.
[2545|p69] Collect like terms and simplify.
[2546|p69|T1] Exercise 2.7

[2583|p69] j  $2x(3 + x) - 3(x - 2)$
[2584|p69] k  $3(x - 5) - (3 + x)$
[2585|p69] 2x(3x+1)-2(3-2x)
[2586|p69|T1] 2.5 Indices
[2587|p69|T1] Revisiting index notation
[2588|p69] When you write a number using indices (powers) you have written it in index notation. Any number can be used as an index including 0, negative integer...
[2589|p69] The index tells you how many times the base has been multiplied by itself. So:
[2590|p69] [Table Row] <tr><td>\( 3 \times  3 \times  3 \times  3 = {3}^{4} \)</td><td>3 is the base, 4 is the index</td></tr>
[2591|p69] [Table Row] <tr><td>\( a \times  a \times  a \times  a \times  a = {a}^{5} \)</td><td>\( a \) is the base, 5 is the index</td></tr>
[2592|p69|T1] TIP
[2593|p69] Try not to carry out too many steps at once. Show every term of your expansion and then simplify.
[2594|p70|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 12
[2595|p70] Write each expression using index notation.
[2596|p70] a xxxxx
[2597|p70] b  $x\times x\times x\times y\times y\times y\times y$
[2598|p70|T1] Answers
[2599|p70] a XxXxXxX=x4
[2600|p70] Count how many times  $x$  is multiplied by itself to give you the index.
[2601|p70] b  $x\times x\times x\times y\times y\times y\times y = x^3 y^4$
[2602|p70] Count how many times  $x$  is multiplied by itself to get the index of  $x$ ; then work out the index of  $y$  in the same way.
[2603|p70] When you write a power out in full as a multiplication you are writing it in expanded form.
[2604|p70|T1] The laws of indices in algebra
[2605|p70] The laws of indices are very important in algebra because they give you quick ways of simplifying expressions. You will use these laws over and over a...
[2606|p70|T1] Multiplying the same base with different indices
[2607|p70] Look at these two multiplications:
[2608|p70] $$
3 ^ {2} \times 3 ^ {4} \quad x ^ {3} \times x ^ {4}
$$
[2609|p70] In the first multiplication, 3 is the base and in the second,  $x$  is the base.
[2610|p70] You already know you can simplify these by expanding them like this:
[2611|p70] $$
3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 = 3 ^ {6} \quad x \times x \times x \times x \times x \times x \times x = x ^ {7}
$$
[2612|p70] In other words:
[2613|p70] $$
3 ^ {2} \times 3 ^ {4} = 3 ^ {2 + 4} \quad \text {a n d} \quad x ^ {3} \times x ^ {4} = x ^ {3 + 4}
$$
[2614|p70] When you multiply index expressions with the same base you can add the indices:
[2615|p70] $$
x ^ {m} \times x ^ {n} = x ^ {m + n}
$$
[2616|p70|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13
[2617|p70] Simplify.
[2618|p70] a  $x^{2}\times x^{3}$
[2619|p70] b  $2x^{2}y\times 3xy^{4}$
[2620|p70] Answers
[2621|p70] a  $x^{2}\times x^{3} = x^{2 + 3} = x^{5}$
[2622|p70] Add the indices.
[2623|p70] b  $2x^{2}y\times 3xy^{4} = 2\times 3\times x^{2 + 1}\times y^{1 + 4} = 6x^{3}y^{5}$
[2624|p70] Multiply the numbers first, then add the indices of like variables.
[2625|p70|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[2626|p70] In finance, when you apply interest to savings, the value increases by the same percentage each day, month or other fixed period of time. This involve...
[2627|p70|T1] TIP
[2628|p70] Remember, every letter or number has a power of 1 (usually not written). So  $x$  means  $x^1$  and  $y$  means  $y^1$ .
[2629|p71|T1] Dividing the same base number with different indices
[2630|p71] Look at these two divisions:
[2631|p71] $$
3 ^ {4} \div 3 ^ {2} \quad \text {a n d} \quad x ^ {6} \div x ^ {2}
$$
[2632|p71] You already know you can simplify these by writing them in expanded form and cancelling like this:
[2633|p71] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3}{3 \times 3} \quad \frac {x \times x \times x \times x \times x \times x}{x \times x} \\ = 3 \...
[2634|p71] In other words:
[2635|p71] $$
3 ^ {4} \div 3 ^ {2} = 3 ^ {4 - 2} \quad \text {a n d} \quad x ^ {6} \div x ^ {2} = x ^ {6 - 2}
$$
[2636|p71] When you divide index expressions with the same base you can subtract the indices:
[2637|p71] $$
x ^ {m} \div x ^ {n} = x ^ {m - n}
$$
[2638|p71|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[2639|p71] You will use the multiplication and division rules more when you study standard form in Chapter 5.
[2640|p71|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 14
[2641|p71] Simplify.
[2642|p71] a  $\frac{x^6}{x^2}$
[2643|p71] b 6a 3a²
[2644|p71] 10x3y2 5xy
[2645|p71] Answers
[2646|p71] a  $\frac{x^6}{x^2} = x^{6 - 2} = x^4$
[2647|p71] Subtract the indices.
[2648|p71] b 6a 6 6 a5 3 a2 3 3
[2649|p71] Divide (cancel) the coefficients.
[2650|p71] $$
= \frac {2}{1} \times a ^ {5 - 2}
$$
[2651|p71] Subtract the indices.
[2652|p71] $$
= 2 a ^ {3}
$$
[2653|p71] 10x3y² 10x3x3x2 5xy
[2654|p71] Divide the coefficients.
[2655|p71] $$
= \frac {2}{1} \times x ^ {3 - 1} \times y ^ {2 - 1}
$$
[2656|p71] Subtract the indices.
[2657|p71] $$
= 2 x ^ {2} y
$$
[2658|p71|T1] The power 0
[2659|p71] Any value divided by itself gives 1, so  $3 \div 3 = 1$  and  $x \div x = 1$  and  $\frac{x^4}{x^4} = 1$ .
[2660|p71] If you use the law of indices for division you can see that  $\frac{x^4}{x^4} = x^{4 - 4} = x^0$
[2661|p71] So, you can see that  $\frac{x^4}{x^4} = x^0 = 1$
[2662|p71] Any value to the power 0 is equal to 1. So  $x^0 = 1$ .
[2663|p71|T1] TIP
[2664|p71] Remember: the coefficient is the number in the term.
[2665|p72|T1] Raising a power
[2666|p72] Look at these two examples:
[2667|p72] $$
(x ^ {3}) ^ {2} = x ^ {3} \times x ^ {3} = x ^ {3 + 3} = x ^ {6} \quad (2 x ^ {3}) ^ {4} = 2 x ^ {3} \times 2 x ^ {3} \times 2 x ^ {3} \times 2 x ^...
[2668|p72] By writing in expanded form like this you can see that  $(x^{3})^{2} = x^{6}$  and  $(2x^{3})^{4} = 16x^{12}$
[2669|p72] When you have to raise a power to another power you multiply the indices:  $(x^{m})^{n} = x^{mn}$
[2670|p72|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[2671|p72] Simplify.
[2672|p72] a  $(x^{3})^{6}$
[2673|p72] b (3x4y3)2
[2674|p72] c (p3)4÷(p6)2
[2675|p72|T1] Answers
[2676|p72] a  $(x^{3})^{6} = x^{3\times 6}$
[2677|p72] $$
= x ^ {1 8}
$$
[2678|p72] b  $(3x^{4}y^{3})^{2}$
[2679|p72] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 3 ^ {2} \times x ^ {4 \times 2} \times y ^ {3 \times 2} \\ = 9 x ^ {8} y ^ {6} \\ \end{array}
$$
[2680|p72] Multiply the indices.
[2681|p72] c (p3)4÷(p6)2
[2682|p72] $$
\begin{array}{l} = p ^ {3 \times 4} \div p ^ {6 \times 2} \\ = p ^ {1 2} \div p ^ {1 2} \\ = p ^ {1 2 - 1 2} \\ = p ^ {0} \\ = 1 \\ \end{array}
$$
[2683|p72] Square each of the terms to remove the brackets and multiply the indices.
[2684|p72] Expand the brackets first by multiplying the indices. Divide by subtracting the indices.
