[2753|p73|T1] TIP
[2754|p73] When there is a mixture of numbers and letters, deal with the numbers first and then apply the laws of indices to the letters in alphabetical order.
[2755|p73|T1] Negative indices
[2756|p73] In Chapter 1 you learned how to use negative numbers as indices. You will now apply those rules to expressions containing letters.
[2757|p73] Look at these two methods of working out.
[2758|p73] Using expanded notation:
[2759|p73] Using the law of indices for division:
[2760|p73] $$
\begin{array}{l} x ^ {3} \div x ^ {5} = \frac {x \times x \times x}{x \times x \times x \times x \times x} \\ x ^ {3} \div x ^ {5} = x ^ {3 - 5} \\...
[2761|p73] This shows that  $\frac{1}{x^2} = x^{-2}$
[2762|p73] $$
\mathrm {S o}, x ^ {- m} = \frac {1}{x ^ {m}} (\mathrm {w h e n} x \neq 0)
$$
[2763|p73|T1] TIP
[2764|p73] In everyday language you can say that when a number is written with a negative power, it is equal to '1 over' the number to the same positive power. A...
[2765|p73] When an expression contains negative indices, you apply the same laws as for other indices to simplify it.
[2766|p73|T1] LINK
[2767|p73] Negative indices are often used in units in physics. For example, you often write 'kilometres per hour' as 'kmh-1'.
[2768|p73|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[2769|p73] Both positive and negative indices are used in standard form. You will learn to use standard form to write very large or very small numbers in Chapter...
[2770|p74|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 16
[2771|p74] 1 Write these with a positive index.
[2772|p74] a  $x^{-4}$
[2773|p74] b y-3
[2774|p74] Answers
[2775|p74] a  $x^{-4} = \frac{1}{x^4}$
[2776|p74] b  $y^{-3} = \frac{1}{y^3}$
[2777|p74] 2 Simplify. Give your answers with positive indices.
[2778|p74] 4x² 2x4
[2779|p74] b  $2x^{-2}\times 3x^{-4}$
[2780|p74] c  $(3y^{2})^{-3}$
[2781|p74] Answers
[2782|p74] $$
\begin{array}{l} a \frac {4 x ^ {2}}{2 x ^ {4}} = \frac {4}{2} \times x ^ {2 - 4} \\ = 2 x ^ {- 2} \\ = \frac {2}{x ^ {2}} \\ \end{array}
$$
[2783|p74] $$
\begin{array}{l} b 2 x ^ {- 2} \times 3 x ^ {- 4} = \frac {2}{x ^ {2}} \times \frac {3}{x ^ {4}} \\ = \frac {6}{x ^ {2 + 4}} \\ = \frac {6}{x ^ {6}...
[2784|p74] $$
\begin{array}{l} c (3 y ^ {2}) ^ {- 3} = \frac {1}{(3 y ^ {2}) ^ {3}}. \\ = \frac {1}{3 ^ {3} \times y ^ {2 \times 3}} \\ = \frac {1}{2 7 y ^ {6}} ...
[2785|p74] The laws of indices can also help you find the value of an index in simple equations. For the same base, if  $a^x = a^n$ , then  $x = n$ .
[2786|p74] For example,  $2^x = 8$ . You know that  $2^3 = 8$ , so  $2^x = 2^3$  and  $x = 3$ .
[2787|p74|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 17
[2788|p74] If  $2^{x} = 128$  find the value of  $x$ .
[2789|p74] Answer
[2790|p74] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 ^ {x} = 1 2 8 \\ 2 ^ {\prime} = 1 2 8 \\ \therefore x = 7 \\ \end{array}
$$
[2791|p74] Rewrite 128 as a power of 2. You might need to use trial and improvement to do this.

[2838|p75|T1] Summary of index laws
[2839|p75] $x^{m}\times x^{n} = x^{m + n}$
[2840|p75] When multiplying terms, add the indices.
[2841|p75] $x^{m}\div x^{n} = x^{m - n}$
[2842|p75] When dividing, subtract the indices.
[2843|p75] $(x^{m})^{n} = x^{mn}$
[2844|p75] When finding the power of a power, multiply the indices.
[2845|p75] $x^0 = 1$
[2846|p75] Any value to the power 0 is equal to 1.
[2847|p75] x-m=1x
[2848|p75] (when  $x\neq 0$
[2849|p75|T1] Fractional indices
[2850|p75] The laws of indices also apply when the index is a fraction. Look at these examples carefully to remind yourself what fractional indices mean in algeb...
[2851|p75] $= x^{\frac{1}{2} +\frac{1}{2}}$  Use the law of indices and add the powers.
[2852|p75] $$
\begin{array}{l} x ^ {\frac {1}{2}} \times x ^ {\frac {1}{2}} \\ = x ^ {1} \\ = x \\ \end{array}
$$
[2853|p75] In order to understand what  $x^{\frac{1}{2}}$  means, ask yourself: what number multiplied by itself will give  $x$ ?
[2854|p75] $= y^{\frac{1}{2} +\frac{1}{3} +\frac{1}{4}}$  Use the law of indices and add the powers.
[2855|p75] $$
\begin{array}{l} \sqrt {x} \times \sqrt {x} = x \\ \mathrm {S o}, x ^ {\frac {1}{2}} = \sqrt {x} \\ y ^ {\frac {1}{2}} \times y ^ {\frac {1}{2}} \t...
[2856|p76] What number multiplied by itself and then by itself again will give  $y$ ?
[2857|p76] $$
\sqrt [ 3 ]{y} \times \sqrt [ 3 ]{y} \times \sqrt [ 3 ]{y} = y
$$
[2858|p76] $$
\mathrm {S o} y ^ {\frac {1}{4}} = \sqrt [ 3 ]{y}
$$
[2859|p76] This shows that any root of a number can be written using rational indices.
[2860|p76] $$
\mathrm {S o}, x ^ {\frac {1}{\mathrm {s}}} = \sqrt [ m ]{x}.
$$
[2861|p76|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18
[2862|p76] 1 Rewrite using root signs.
[2863|p76] a y
[2864|p76] b x
[2865|p76] C X
[2866|p76] Answers
[2867|p76] a  $y^{\frac{1}{2}} = \sqrt{y}$
[2868|p76] b x=
[2869|p76] x=√x
[2870|p76] 2 Write in index notation.
[2871|p76] a  $\sqrt{90}$
[2872|p76] b 64
[2873|p76] 4X
[2874|p76] d  $\sqrt[5]{(x - 2)}$
[2875|p76] Answers
[2876|p76] a 90=90
[2877|p76] b 64
[2878|p76] C 4x=x
[2879|p76] d  $\sqrt[5]{(x - 2)} = (x - 2)^{\frac{1}{5}}$
[2880|p76|T1] Dealing with non-unit fractions
[2881|p76] Indices may contain non-unit fractions, for example  $x^{\frac{1}{3}}$  or  $y^{\frac{1}{3}}$ . To find the rule for working with these, you have to t...
[2882|p76] $$
\begin{array}{l} x ^ {\frac {1}{3}} = \left(x ^ {\frac {1}{3}}\right) ^ {2} \quad \frac {1}{3} \times 2 = \frac {2}{3} \\ y ^ {\frac {1}{4}} = \lef...
[2883|p76] You already know that a unit fraction gives a root. So you can rewrite these expressions using root signs like this:
[2884|p76] $$
\begin{array}{l} (x) ^ {2} = (\sqrt {x}) ^ {2} \text {a n d} (y) ^ {3} = (\sqrt {y}) ^ {3} \\ \mathbf {S o}, x ^ {1} = (\sqrt {x}) ^ {2} \text {a n...
[2885|p76|T1] TIP
[2886|p76] You can reverse the order of calculations here and the result will be the same.
[2887|p76] In general terms:  $x^{*} = x^{m + 1} - (x^{1})^{m} = (\sqrt[m]{x})^{m}$
[2888|p76|T1] TIP
[2889|p76] A non-unit fraction
[2890|p76] has a numerator
[2891|p76] that is not 1. For
[2892|p76] example, 2 and 5 are
[2893|p76] non-unit fractions.

[2898|p77] Apply the rule  $\sqrt{a^m} = a^m$
[2899|p77] $$
= a ^ {\frac {3}{5}} \times a ^ {\frac {1}{3}}
$$
[2900|p77] Raise the powers. Simplify the fractions.
[2901|p77] $$
= \rho \frac {2}{3} + \frac {1}{3}
$$
[2902|p77] Apply laws of indices.
[2903|p77] $$
= a ^ {\frac {9}{1 5}} + \frac {5}{1 5}
$$
[2904|p77] Form equivalent fractions and add them.
[2905|p77] $$
= a ^ {\frac {1 4}{1 5}}
$$

[2907|p77|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 20
[2908|p77] if  $2^{x + 3} = \frac{1}{16}$  find the value of  $x$ .
[2909|p77|T1] Answer
[2910|p77] [ 2^{x + 3} = \frac{1}{16} ] Rewrite the fraction as a power of 2 with a negative index.
[2911|p77] $$
2 ^ {x + 3} = 2 ^ {- 4}
$$
[2912|p77] Equate the indices.
[2913|p77] $$
x + 3 = - 4
$$
[2914|p77] $$
x = - 7
$$

\begin{array}{l} = x ^ {\frac {1}{3} - \frac {1}{2}} \\ = x \frac {2}{1 0} - \frac {5}{1 0} \\ = x ^ {- \frac {1}{\mathrm {的}}} \\ = \frac {1}{x ^ ...
[2949|p78|T1] SELF ASSESSMENT
[2950|p78] These are the stems of a  $3:2:1$  summary:
[2951|p78] - 3 things I learned are:
[2952|p78] - 2 questions I had were:

[2954|p78] You can use a  $3:2:1$  summary to assess your own learning.
[2955|p78] Here is an example of a student self assessment for this chapter.
[2956|p78] 3 things I learnt are:
[2957|p78] - Indices in algebra work the same as in number
[2958|p78] You can write terms with negative indices as fractions to get positive indices
[2959|p78] - cube roots can be written using  $\frac{1}{3}$  as the index
[2960|p78] 2 questions I had were:
[2961|p78] How do you work with fractions when the numerator isn't 1?
[2962|p78] - can you use your calculator to work with indices?
[2963|p78] I thing I understood really quickly was:
[2964|p78] How to use the laws of indices with letters.
[2965|p78] Complete your own  $3:2:1$  summary to assess your learning in this chapter.
[2966|p78|T1] SUMMARY
[2967|p78|T1] Do you know ...?
[2968|p78] Algebra has special conventions (rules) that allow you to write mathematical information in short ways.
[2969|p78] Letters in algebra are called variables, the number before a letter is called a coefficient and numbers on their own are called constants.
[2970|p78] A group of numbers and variables is called a term. Terms are separated by  $+$  and  $-$  signs, but not by  $\times$  or  $\div$  signs.
[2971|p78] Like terms have exactly the same combination of variables and powers. You can add and subtract like terms. You can multiply and divide like and unlike...
[2972|p78] The order of operations rules for numbers (BODMAS) apply in algebra as well.
[2973|p78] Removing brackets (multiplying out) is called expanding the expression. Collecting like terms is called simplifying the expression.
[2974|p78] Powers are also called indices. The index tells you how many times a number or variable is multiplied by itself. Indices only apply to the number or v...
[2975|p78] The laws of indices are a set of rules for simplifying expressions with indices. These laws apply to positive, negative, zero and fractional indices.
[2976|p79|T1] SUMMARY CONTINUED
[2977|p79] Are you able to ...?
[2978|p79] use letters to represent numbers
[2979|p79] write expressions to represent mathematical information
[2980|p79] To substitute letters with numbers to find the value of an expression.
[2981|p79] add and subtract like terms to simplify expressions
[2982|p79] multiply and divide to simplify expressions
[2983|p79] expand expressions by removing brackets and getting rid of other grouping symbols
[2984|p79] use and make sense of positive, negative and zero indices
[2985|p79] We apply the laws of indices to simplify expressions.
[2986|p79] work with fractional indices
[2987|p79] solve exponential equations using fractional indices.
[2988|p79|T1] Practice questions
[2989|p79] 1 For a number,  $n$  write an expression for:
[2990|p79] a the sum of the number and 12 [1]
[2991|p79] b twice the number minus four [1]
[2992|p79] c the number multiplied by  $x$  and then squared [1]
[2993|p79] d the square of the number cubed. [1]
[2994|p79] 2 If  $n$  is any positive integer,
[2995|p79] a Write an expression that is an even number for all possible values of  $n$  [1]
[2996|p79] b Explain why  $2n + 1$  is always an odd number. [1]
[2997|p79] Every positive odd number  $p$  can be written in the form  $p = 2n + 1$ .
[2998|p79] c Write an expression, in terms of  $n$ , for the next largest odd number after  $p$ . [1]
[2999|p79] d Use your answer to part (c) to show that any two consecutive odd numbers always add up to an even number. [3]

[3112|p82] - talk about the properties of triangles, quadrilaterals, circles and polygons
[3113|p82] - construct triangles using a ruler and a pair of compasses.

[3141|p84] The shortest distance between a point and a line is the perpendicular distance from the point to the line.

[3166|p87] [Table Row] <tr><td>Term</td><td>What it means</td><td>Examples</td></tr>
[3167|p87] [Table Row] <tr><td>Revolution</td><td>A revolution is a complete turn: an angle of exactly 360°.</td><td>360°</td></tr>
[3168|p87|T1] Measuring and drawing angles
[3169|p87] The size of an angle is the amount of turn from one arm of the angle to the other. Angle sizes are measured in degrees  $(^{\circ})$  from 0 to 360 us...
[3171|p87] A  $180^{\circ}$  protractor has two scales. You need to choose the correct one when you measure an angle.
[3172|p87|T1] LINK
[3173|p87] Geographers and other geoscientists use a piece of equipment called a 'clinometer' to measure angles and calculate the heights of cliffs on the coastl...
[3175|p87|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[3176|p87] You will use these skills when drawing pie charts in Chapter 4.
[3177|p87|T1] TIP
[3178|p87] If the arm of the angle does not extend up to the scale, extend the arm past the scale. The length of the arms of the angle does not affect the size o...
[3179|p88|T1] Measuring angles  $< {180}^{ \circ  }$
[3180|p88] When an angle is smaller than  $180^{\circ}$  you can read the size from the scale onto the protractor.
[3181|p88|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[3182|p88] Measure angles ABC and PQR.
[3186|p88] Place the centre of the protractor at  $B$  and align the baseline so it sits on arm BC. Extend arm BA so that it reaches past the scale. Read the inn...
[3188|p88] Put the centre of the protractor at  $Q$  and the baseline along  $QP$ . Start at  $0^{\circ}$  and read the outer scale. Angle  $PQR = 105^{\circ}$
[3189|p88|T1] Measuring angles  $>180^{\circ}$
[3190|p88] Here are two different methods for measuring a reflex angle with a  $180^{\circ}$  protractor. Use the method that you find easier.
[3191|p88] Suppose you had to measure the reflex angle  $ABC$ :
[3193|p88] Angle ABC is  $>180^{\circ}$
[3194|p88|T1] TIP
[3195|p88] If the word reflex is not included you can assume you are dealing with the angle between the two arms (acute, right or obtuse).
[3196|p89] Method 1: Extend one arm of the angle to form a straight line (180° angle) and then measure the 'extra bit'. Add the 'extra bit' to 180° to get the to...
[3198|p89] Extend  $AB$  to point  $D$ . You know the angle of a straight line is  $180^{\circ}$ . So  $ABD = 180^{\circ}$ .
[3200|p89] Measure the other piece of the angle  $DBC$  (marked  $x$ ) and add this to  $180^\circ$  to find angle  $ABC$ .
[3201|p89] $$
\begin{array}{l} 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} + 1 3 0 ^ {\circ} = 3 1 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \therefore A B C = 3 1 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \end{array}
$$
[3202|p89] Method 2: Measure the inner (non-reflex) angle and subtract it from  $360^{\circ}$  to get the size of the reflex angle.
[3204|p89] You can see that the angle  $ABC$  is almost  $360^{\circ}$ .
[3206|p89] Measure the size of the angle that is  $< 180^{\circ}$  (non-reflex) and subtract from  $360^{\circ}$ .
[3207|p89] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 6 0 ^ {\circ} - 5 0 ^ {\circ} = 3 1 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \therefore A B C = 3 1 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \end{array}
$$

[3212|p89] iii use a protractor to measure the actual size of each angle to the nearest degree.

[3214|p89] b BAD

[3216|p89] d CAD

[3218|p89] f CAE

[3221|p89] i DAF

[3230|p90|T1] Drawing angles
[3231|p90] You can draw an angle of any given size if you have a ruler, a protractor and a sharp pencil. Work through this example to remind yourself how to draw...
[3232|p90|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[3233|p90] Draw each angle:
[3234|p90] a  $ABC = 76^{\circ}$
[3235|p90] b  $XYZ = 195^{\circ}$
[3236|p90] Answers
[3237|p90] a
[3239|p90] Use a ruler to draw a line to represent one arm of the angle, make sure the line extends beyond the protractor.
[3240|p90] Mark the vertex (B).
[3242|p90] Place your protractor on the line with the centre at the vertex.
[3243|p90] Measure the size of the angle you wish to draw and mark a small point.
[3245|p90] Remove the protractor and use a ruler to draw a line from the vertex through the point.
[3246|p90] Label the angle correctly.
[3247|p90] b
[3249|p90] For a reflex angle, draw a line as in (a) but mark one arm (X) as well as the vertex (Y). The arm should extend beyond the vertex to create a  $180^{\...
[3250|p91|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2 CONTINUED
[3253|p91] Calculate the size of rest the angle:  $195^{\circ} - 180^{\circ} = 15^{\circ}$
[3254|p91] Measure and mark the  $15^{\circ}$  angle (on either side of the  $180^{\circ}$  line).
[3255|p91] Remove the protractor and use a ruler to draw a line from the vertex through the third point.
[3256|p91] Label the angle correctly.
[3257|p91|T1] TIP
[3258|p91] To draw a reflex angle, you can also work out the size of the inner angle and simply draw that.
[3259|p91] $360^{\circ} - 195^{\circ} = 165^{\circ}.$
[3260|p91] If you do this,
[3261|p91] remember to mark the reflex angle on your sketch and no the inner angle!

[3270|p91|T1] PEER ASSESSMENT
[3271|p91] Exchange the angles you drew in Exercise 3.2 with a partner.
[3272|p91] 1 Use your protractor to measure each angle and give them a rating from 1 to 4 for accuracy (1 is not very accurate and 4 is extremely accurate).
[3273|p91] 2 What hints can you give people to help them draw angles as accurately as possible?
[3274|p91|T1] Angle relationships
[3275|p91] Make sure you know the following angle facts:
[3276|p91] Complementary angles
[3277|p91] Angles in a right angle add up to  $90^{\circ}$ .
[3278|p92] When the sum of two angles is  $90^{\circ}$  those two angles are complementary angles.
[3281|p92|T1] Supplementary angles
[3282|p92] Angles on a straight line add up to  $180^{\circ}$ .
[3283|p92] When the sum of two angles is  $180^{\circ}$  those two angles are supplementary angles.
[3286|p92|T1] Angles round a point
[3287|p92] Angles at a point make a complete revolution.
[3288|p92] The sum of the angles at a point is  $360^{\circ}$
[3292|p92|T1] Vertically opposite angles
[3293|p92] When two lines intersect, two pairs of vertically opposite angles are formed.
[3294|p92] Vertically opposite angles are equal in size.
[3298|p92|T1] TIP
[3299|p92] In general terms:
[3300|p92] For complementary angles, if one angle is  $x^{\circ}$ , the other must be  $90 - x^{\circ}$  and vice versa.
[3301|p92] For supplementary angles, if one angle is  $x^{\circ}$ , the other must be  $180 - x^{\circ}$  and vice versa.
[3302|p92|T1] TIP
[3303|p92] The adjacent angle pairs in vertically opposite angles form pairs of supplementary angles because they are also angles on a straight line.
[3304|p93|T1] Using angle relationships to find unknown angles
[3305|p93] You can use the relationships between angles to work out the size of unknown angles.
[3306|p93] To do this:
[3307|p93] identify the relationship
[3308|p93] make an equation
[3309|p93] - give reasons for statements
[3310|p93] - solve the equation to find the unknown value.
[3311|p93|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[3312|p93] Find the size of the angle marked  $x$  in each of these figures. Give reasons.
[3313|p93|T1] Answers
[3315|p93] a  $72^{\circ} + x = 90^{\circ}$  angle ABC  $= 90^{\circ}$  comp angles)
[3316|p93] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = 9 0 ^ {\circ} - 7 2 ^ {\circ} \\ x = 1 8 ^ {\circ} \\ \end{array}
$$
[3317|p93] You are told that angle ABC is a right angle, so you know that  $72^{\circ}$  and  $x$  are complementary angles. This means that  $72^{\circ} + x = 9...
[3319|p93] b  $48^{\circ} + 90^{\circ} + x = 180^{\circ}$  (angles on line)
[3320|p93] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - 9 0 ^ {\circ} - 4 8 ^ {\circ} \\ x = 4 2 ^ {\circ} \\ \end{array}
$$
[3321|p93] You can see that  $48^{\circ}$  the right angle and  $x$  are angles on a straight line. Angles on a straight line add up to  $180^{\circ}$ . So you c...
[3323|p93] c  $x = 30^{\circ}$  (vertically opposite angles)
[3324|p93] You know that when two lines intersect, the resulting vertically opposite angles are equal.  $x$  and  $30^{\circ}$  are vertically opposite, so  $x =...
[3325|p93|T1] TIP
[3326|p93] In geometry problems you need to present your reasoning in a logical and structured way.
[3327|p93] You will usually be expected to give reasons when you are finding the size of an unknown angle. To do this, state the relationship that you used to fi...
[3328|p93] comp angles
[3329|p93] - supp angles
[3330|p93] angles on line
[3331|p93] angles round point

[3361|p94] a

[3365|p94] C
[3367|p95] 4 Two angles are supplementary. The first angle is twice the size of the second. What are their sizes?
[3368|p95] 5 One of the angles formed when two lines intersect is  $127^{\circ}$ . What are the sizes of the other three angles?
[3369|p95|T1] Angles and parallel lines
[3370|p95] When two parallel lines are cut by a third line (the transversal) eight angles are formed. These angles form pairs which are related to each other in ...
[3371|p95|T1] Corresponding angles ( $F$ -shape)
[3372|p95] When two parallel lines are cut by a transversal four pairs of corresponding angles are formed. Corresponding angles are equal to each other.
[3377|p95|T1] Alternate angles (‘Z’-shape)
[3378|p95] When two parallel lines are cut by a transversal two pairs of alternate angles are formed. Alternate angles are equal to each other.
[3381|p95|T1] Co-interior angles ('C'-shape)
[3382|p95] When two parallel lines are cut by a transversal two pairs of co-interior angles are formed. Co-interior angles are supplementary (together they add u...
[3385|p95|T1] TIP
[3386|p95] Although  $F^{\prime},Z^{\prime}$  and  $C^\prime$  shapes help you to remember these properties, you must use the terms corresponding, 'alternate' an...
[3387|p95|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[3388|p95] You will use the angle relationships in this section again when you deal with triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons and circles later in this chapter.
[3389|p95|T1] TIP
[3390|p95] 'Co-means together. Co-interior angles are found together on the same side of the transversal.
[3391|p95] Co-interior angles will only be equal if the transversal is perpendicular to the parallel lines (when they will both be  $90^{\circ}$ ).
[3392|p96] The angle relationships around parallel lines and the other angle relationships from earlier in the chapter are very useful for solving unknown angles...
[3393|p96|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[3394|p96] Find the size of angles  $a, b$  and  $c$  in this figure.
[3396|p96|T1] Answer
[3397|p96] $a = 47^{\circ}$  (CAB alt SBA)
[3398|p96] $c = 62^{\circ}$  (ACB alt CBT)
[3399|p96] $a + b + c = 180^{\circ}$  (angles on line)
[3400|p96] $\therefore b = 180^{\circ} - 47^{\circ} - 62^{\circ}$
[3401|p96] $b = 71^{\circ}$
[3402|p96] CAB and SBA are alternate angles and are equal. ACB and CBT are alternate angles and equal.
[3403|p96] Angles on a straight line  $= 180^{\circ}$
[3404|p96] You know the values of  $a$  and  $c$ , so can use these to find  $b$ .

[3424|p97|T1] General results
[3425|p97] Mathematical reasoning doesn't always involve numbers. You can use letters and algebra to get results that will be true for any numbers. Results like ...

[3434|p98|T1] 3.2 Triangles
[3435|p98] A triangle is a plane shape with three sides and three angles.
[3436|p98] Triangles are classified according to the lengths of their sides and the sizes of their angles (or both).
[3437|p98|T1] LINK
[3438|p98] If you fix three straight sticks or rods together in a triangle it is not possible for the triangle to change its shape without breaking. This is why ...
[3440|p98|T1] TIP
[3441|p98] Plane means flat. Plane shapes are flat or two-dimensional shapes.
[3442|p98|T1] Scalene triangle
[3444|p98] Scalene triangles have no sides of equal length and no angles that are of equal sizes.
[3445|p98|T1] Isosceles triangle
[3447|p98] Isosceles triangles have two sides of equal length. The angles at the base of the equal sides are equal in size.
[3448|p99|T1] Equilateral triangle
[3450|p99] Equilateral triangles have three equal sides and three equal angles (each is  $60^{\circ}$
[3451|p99|T1] Other triangles
[3455|p99] Acute-angled triangles have all angles  $<  90^{\circ}$
[3456|p99] Right-angled triangles have one angle  $= 90^{\circ}$
[3457|p99] Obtuse-angled triangles have one angle  $>90^{\circ}$
[3458|p99|T1] Angle properties of triangles
[3459|p99] The three angles inside a triangle are called interior angles.
[3460|p99] If you extend a side of a triangle you make another angle outside the triangle. Angles outside the triangle are called exterior angles.
[3461|p99] Look at the following diagram carefully to see two important angle properties of triangles.
[3465|p99] The diagram shows two things:
[3466|p99] the three interior angles of a triangle add up to  $180^{\circ}$
[3467|p99] - two interior angles of a triangle are equal to the opposite exterior angle.
[3468|p99] If you try this yourself with any triangle you will get the same results. But why is this so? Mathematicians cannot just show things to be true, they ...
[3469|p100] Angles in a triangle add up to  $180^{\circ}$
[3470|p100] To prove this you can draw a line parallel to one side of the triangle.
[3473|p100] $$
x + a + y = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} (\text {a n g l e s o n a l i n e})
$$
[3474|p100] but:
[3475|p100] $$
b = x \text {a n d} c = y \text {(a l t e r n a t e a n g l e s a r e e q u a l)}
$$
[3476|p100] $$
\text {s o} a + b + c = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[3477|p100] The exterior angle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles
[3479|p100] $$
c + x = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} (\text {a n g l e s o n a l i n e})
$$
[3480|p100] $$
\mathrm {s o}, c = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - x
$$
[3481|p100] $$
a + b + c = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} (\text {a n g l e s u m o f t r i a n g l e})
$$
[3482|p100] $$
c = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - (a + b)
$$
[3483|p100] $$
\text {s o}, 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - (a + b) = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - x
$$
[3484|p100] $$
\text {h e n c e}, a + b = x
$$
[3485|p100] These two properties allow you to find the missing angles in triangles and other diagrams involving triangles.
[3486|p100|T1] TIP
[3487|p100] You don't need to know these proofs, but you do need to remember the rules associated with them.
[3488|p100|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[3489|p100] Some of the algebraic processes used here are examples of the solutions to linear equations. You've done this before, but it is covered in more detail...

$$

[3497|p100] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 x = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - 9 0 ^ {\circ} \\ 2 x = 9 0 ^ {\circ} \\ x = 4 5 ^ {\circ} \\ \end{array}
$$

[3580|p104|T1] The angle sum of a quadrilateral
[3581|p104] All quadrilaterals can be divided into two triangles by drawing one diagonal. You already know that the angle sum of a triangle is  $180^{\circ}$ . Th...
[3582|p104] This is an important property and you can use it together with the other properties of quadrilaterals to find the sizes of unknown angles.

[3637|p106|T1] 3.4 Polygons
[3638|p106] A polygon is a plane shape with three or more straight sides. Triangles are polygons with three sides and quadrilaterals are polygons with four sides....
[3645|p106] A polygon with all its sides and all its angles equal is called a regular polygon. If a polygon has any reflex angles, it is called a concave polygon....
[3646|p107|T1] Angle sum of a polygon
[3647|p107] By dividing polygons into triangles, you can work out the sum of their interior angles.
[3651|p107] Can you see the pattern that is forming here?
[3652|p107] The number of triangles you can divide the polygon into is always two less than the number of sides. If the number of sides is  $n$ , then the number ...
[3653|p107] The angle sum of the polygon is  $180^{\circ} \times$  the number of triangles. So for any polygon, the angle sum can be worked out using the formula:
[3654|p107] sum of interior angles  $= (n - 2)\times 180^{\circ}$
[3655|p107|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[3656|p107] Find the angle sum of a decagon and state the size of each interior angle if the decagon is regular.
[3657|p107|T1] Answers
[3658|p107] sum of interior angles
[3659|p107] $$
= (n - 2) \times 1 8 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[3660|p107] Sum of angles
[3661|p107] $$
= (1 0 - 2) \times 1 8 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[3662|p107] A decagon has 10 sides, so  $n = 10$ .
[3663|p107] $$
= 1 4 4 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[3664|p107] $$
= \frac {1 4 4 0}{1 0}
$$
[3665|p107] $$
= 1 4 4 ^ {\circ}
$$
[3666|p107] A regular decagon has 10 equal angles.
[3667|p107] Size of one angle.
[3668|p107|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[3669|p107] A polygon has an angle sum of  $2340^{\circ}$ . How many sides does it have?
[3670|p107|T1] Answers
[3671|p107] $$
2 3 4 0 ^ {\circ} = (n - 2) \times 1 8 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[3672|p107] Put values into angle sum formula.
[3673|p107] $$
\frac {2 3 4 0}{1 8 0} = n - 2
$$
[3674|p107] $$
1 3 = n - 2
$$
[3675|p107] $$
1 3 + 2 = n
$$
[3676|p107] $$
\therefore 1 5 = n
$$
[3677|p107] Rearrange the formula to get  $n$ .
[3678|p107] So the polygon has 15 sides.
[3679|p107|T1] The sum of exterior angles of a convex polygon
[3680|p107] The sum of the exterior angles of a convex polygon is always  $360^{\circ}$ , no matter how many sides it has. Read carefully through the following in...
[3682|p108] A hexagon has six interior angles.
[3683|p108] The angle sum of the interior angles  $= (n - 2) \times 180^{\circ}$
[3684|p108] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 4 \times 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} \\ = 7 2 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \end{array}
$$
[3686|p108] If you extend each side you make six exterior angles; one next to each interior angle.
[3687|p108] Each pair of interior and exterior angles adds up to  $180^{\circ}$  (angles on line).
[3688|p108] There are six vertices, so there are six pairs of interior and exterior angles that add up to  $180^{\circ}$ .
[3690|p108] $$
\therefore \text {s u m o f (i n t e r i o r + e x t e r i o r a n g l e s)} = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} \times 6
$$
[3691|p108] $$
= 1 0 8 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[3692|p108] But, sum of interior angles  $= 720^{\circ}$
[3693|p108] $$
\begin{array}{l} \mathrm {S o}, 7 2 0 ^ {\circ} + \text {s u m o f e x t e r i o r a n g l e s} = 1 0 8 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \text {s u m o f e x t e r i...
[3694|p108] This can be expressed as a general rule like this:
[3695|p108] If  $I =$  sum of the interior angles,  $E =$  sum of the exterior angles and  $n =$  number of sides of the polygon
[3696|p108] $$
I + E = 1 8 0 n
$$
[3697|p108] $$
E = 1 8 0 n - I
$$
[3698|p108] $$
\text {b u t} I = (n - 2) \times 1 8 0
$$
[3699|p108] $$
\begin{array}{l} \text {s o} E = 1 8 0 n - (n - 2) \times 1 8 0 \\ E = 1 8 0 n - 1 8 0 n + 3 6 0 \\ E = 3 6 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \end{array}
$$
[3700|p108|T1] TIP
[3701|p108] You do not have to remember this proof, but you must remember that the sum of the exterior angles of any convex polygon is  $360^{\circ}$ .

[3771|p111|T1] 3.6 Construction
[3772|p111] In geometry, constructions are accurate geometrical drawings. You use mathematical instruments to construct geometrical drawings.
[3773|p111|T1] Using a ruler and a pair of compasses
[3774|p111] A ruler (sometimes called a straight edge) and a pair of compasses are the most useful construction tools. You use the ruler to draw straight lines an...
[3776|p112] When you want to measure very accurately, you can use a pair of compasses to mark a given length. This method of drawing lines is useful in geometric ...
[3777|p112] Use a ruler and sharp pencil to draw a straight line longer than the length you need. Mark point  $A$  on the line with a short vertical dash (or a do...
[3779|p112] - Open your pair of compasses to  $4.5\mathrm{cm}$  by measuring against a ruler.
[3782|p112] - Put the point of the pair of compasses on point  $A$ . Twist the pair of compasses lightly to draw a short arc on the line at  $4.5 \, \text{cm}$ . ...
[3784|p112|T1] TIP
[3785|p112] It is important that you use a sharp pencil and that your pair of compasses are tightened.
[3786|p112|T1] TIP
[3787|p112] Once you can use a ruler and pair of compasses to measure and draw lines, you can construct triangles and other geometric shapes.
[3788|p113|T1] Constructing triangles
[3789|p113] You can construct an accurate triangle if you know the length of three sides.
[3790|p113|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11
[3791|p113] Construct triangle ABC with  $AB = 5\mathrm{cm}$ $BC = 6\mathrm{cm}$  and  $CA = 4\mathrm{cm}$
[3795|p113] Always start with a rough sketch.
[3796|p113] Draw the longest side  $(BC = 6cm)$  and label it.
[3797|p113] Set your pair of compasses at 5cm. Place the point on B and draw an arc.
[3800|p113] Set your pair of compasses at 4cm. Place the point on C and draw an arc.
[3803|p113] The point where the arcs cross is A. Join BA and CA.
[3804|p113|T1] TIP
[3805|p113] It is a good idea to draw the line longer than you need it and then measure the correct length along it. When constructing a shape, it can help to mar...
[3806|p113|T1] TIP
[3807|p113] Note that these diagrams are NOT TO SCALE but when you are asked to construct a triangle, you must use the accurate measurements!
[3808|p114|T1] Exercise 3.9
[3809|p114] 1 Construct these lines.
[3810|p114] a  $AB = 6\mathrm{cm}$
[3811|p114] b  $CD = 75\mathrm{mm}$
[3812|p114] c  $EF = 5.5\mathrm{cm}$
[3813|p114] 2 Accurately construct these triangles.
[3814|p114] a
[3816|p114] b
[3818|p114] C
[3820|p114] 3 Construct these triangles.

[3854|p115|T1] TIP
[3855|p115] Success criteria are sometimes called 'what I'm looking for'.
[3856|p115|T1] SUMMARY
[3857|p115|T1] Do you know ...?
[3858|p115] A point is position and a line is the shortest distance between two points.
[3859|p115] Parallel lines are the same distance apart along their length.
[3860|p115] Perpendicular lines meet at right angles.
[3861|p115] Acute angles are  $< {90}^{ \circ  }$  ,right angles are exactly  ${90}^{ \circ  }$  ,obtuse angles are  $> {90}^{ \circ  }$  but  $< {180}^{ \circ  }...
[3862|p115] Scalene triangles have no equal sides, isosceles triangles have two equal sides and a pair of equal angles, and equilateral triangles have three equal...
[3863|p115] Complementary angles have a sum of  $90^{\circ}$ . Supplementary angles have a sum of  $180^{\circ}$ .
[3864|p115] Angles on a line have a sum of  $180^{\circ}$
[3865|p115] Angles round a point have a sum of  $360^{\circ}$
[3866|p115] Vertically opposite angles are formed when two lines intersect. Vertically opposite angles are equal.
[3867|p116|T1] SUMMARY CONTINUED
[3868|p116|T1] Do you know ...?
[3869|p116] When a transversal cuts two parallel lines various angle pairs are formed. Corresponding angles are equal. Alternate angles are equal. Co-interior ang...
[3870|p116] The angle sum of a triangle is  $180^{\circ}$
[3871|p116] The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two opposite interior angles.
[3872|p116] Quadrilaterals can be classified as parallelograms, rectangles, squares, rhombuses, trapeziums or kites according to their properties.
[3873|p116] The angle sum of a quadrilateral is  $360^{\circ}$ .
[3874|p116] Polygons are many-sided plane shapes. Polygons are named according to the number of sides they have, e.g. pentagon (5), hexagon (6), octagon (8) and d...
[3875|p116] Regular polygons have equal sides and equal angles.
[3876|p116] Irregular polygons have unequal sides and unequal angles.
[3877|p116] The angle sum of a polygon is  $(n - 2)\times 180^{\circ}$  , where  $n$  is the number of sides.
[3878|p116] The angle sum of exterior angles of any convex polygon is  $360^{\circ}$
[3879|p116|T1] Are you able to ...?
[3880|p116] calculate unknown angles on a line and round a point.
[3881|p116] calculate unknown angles using vertically opposite angles and the angle relationships associated with parallel lines
[3882|p116] To calculate unknown angles using the angle properties of triangles, quadrilaterals and polygons,
[3883|p116] accurately measure and construct lines and angles
[3884|p116] construct a triangle using given measurements.

[3950|p121|T1] 4.1 Collecting and classifying data
[3951|p121] Data is a set of facts, numbers or other information. Statistics involves a process of collecting data and using it to try and answer a question. The ...
[3953|p121|T1] Different types of data
[3954|p121] Answer these two questions:
[3955|p121] Who is your favourite singer?
[3956|p121] How many people in your class wear glasses?
[3957|p121] Your answer to the first question will be the name of a person. Your answer to the second question will be a number. Both the name and the number are ...
[3958|p121] Categorical data is non-numerical data. It names or describes something without reference to number or size. Colours, names of people and places, yes ...
[3959|p121] Numerical data is data in number form. It can be an amount, a measurement, a time or a score. Numerical data is also called quantitative data (from th...
[3960|p121|T1] TIP
[3961|p121] Data is actually the plural of the Latin word datum, but in modern English the word data is accepted and used as a singular form, so you can talk abou...
[3962|p121|T1] TIP
[3963|p121] The information that is stored on a computer hard-drive or your phone is also called data. In computer terms, data has nothing to do with statistics, ...
[3964|p121|T1] LINK
[3965|p121] All of this work is very important in the fields of human and social sciences, where scientists need to present data to inform their conclusions.
[3966|p122] Numerical data can be further divided into two groups:
[3967|p122] - discrete data - this is data that can only take certain values, for example, the number of students in a class, goals scored in a match or red cars ...
[3968|p122] - continuous data - this is data that can take any value between two given values, for example, the height of a person who is between  $1.5\mathrm{m}$...
[3969|p122|T1] TIP
[3970|p122] One way to decide if data is continuous is to ask whether it is possible for the values to be fractions or decimals. If the answer is yes, the data is...
[3971|p122] - age may seem to be discrete, because it is often given in full years, but it is actually continuous because we are getting older all the time
[3972|p122] - shoe sizes are discrete, even though you can get shoes in half sizes, because you don't get shoes in size  $7\frac{1}{4}$  or  $7\frac{3}{4}$  or  $...
[3973|p122|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[3974|p122] You will need to fully understand continuous data when you study histograms in Chapter 20.

[4017|p124|T1] 4.2 Organising data
[4018|p124] When you collect a large amount of data you need to organise it so that it is easy to read and use. Tables (tally tables, frequency tables and two-way...
[4019|p124|T1] Tally tables
[4020|p124] A tally table is used to keep a record when you count things.
[4021|p124|T1] TIP
[4022|p124] Remember each tally (I) shows one item. Tallies are grouped in fives (JH) to make it easier to get a total when you need one.
[4023|p124|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[4024|p124] You will use and extend these methods of organising data in later chapters. Make sure that you understand them now.
[4025|p124|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[4026|p124] Aisha wanted to find out what people thought about pop-up adverts on their social media feeds. She did a survey of 100 people. Each person chose an an...
[4027|p124] What do you think about this statement? Please choose one response.
[4028|p124] Advertising should be strictly controlled on social media. Pop-up adverts should be banned from all social media feeds.
[4029|p124] A I strongly agree
[4030|p124] B I agree
[4031|p124] C I disagree
[4032|p124] D I strongly disagree
[4033|p124] Aisha recorded these results:
[4034|p124] [Table Row] <tr><td>A</td><td>B</td><td>A</td><td>C</td><td>A</td><td>C</td><td>C</td><td>D</td><td>A</td><td>C</td></tr>
[4035|p124] [Table Row] <tr><td>C</td><td>C</td><td>D</td><td>A</td><td>D</td><td>D</td><td>C</td><td>C</td><td>C</td><td>A</td></tr>
[4036|p124] [Table Row] <tr><td>B</td><td>B</td><td>A</td><td>C</td><td>D</td><td>B</td><td>B</td><td>A</td><td>C</td><td>C</td></tr>
[4037|p124] [Table Row] <tr><td>A</td><td>B</td><td>C</td><td>A</td><td>D</td><td>B</td><td>C</td><td>D</td><td>A</td><td>B</td></tr>

[4039|p124] [Table Row] <tr><td>D</td><td>D</td><td>C</td><td>C</td><td>C</td><td>A</td><td>B</td><td>B</td><td>A</td><td>C</td></tr>

[4044|p124] a Draw a tally table to organise the results.
[4045|p124] b What do the results of her survey suggest people think about pop-up advertising on social media?

[4047|p125|T1] Answers
[4048|p125] a
[4049|p125] [Table Row] <tr><td>Response</td><td>Tally</td></tr>
[4050|p125] [Table Row] <tr><td>A</td><td>HHHHHHIII</td></tr>

[4053|p125] [Table Row] <tr><td>D</td><td>HHHHHH</td></tr>
[4054|p125] Count each letter. Make a tally each time you count one.
[4055|p125] It may help to cross the letters off the list as you count them.
[4056|p125] Check that your tallies add up to 100 to make sure you have included all the scores. (It is more efficient to work across the rows or down the columns...
[4057|p125] b The results suggest that people generally don't think advertising should be banned on social media. 57 people disagreed or strongly disagreed. Only ...
[4058|p125] By giving people a very definite statement and asking them to respond to it, Aisha has shown her own bias and that could affect the results of her sur...

[4114|p127] [Table Row] <tr><td>80–84</td><td>9</td></tr>

[4116|p127] The range of scores (40-84) has been divided into class intervals. Notice that the class intervals do not overlap so it is clear which data goes in wh...
[4117|p127|T1] TIP
[4118|p127] This data suggests that TB is the most common illness at this clinic. However, this does not mean that TB is the most common illness in the community....
[4119|p127|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[4120|p127] You will use tables like these to construct bar charts and histograms. These diagrams give a clear, visual impression of the data.

[4151|p128|T1] TIP
[4152|p128] Note that currency (money) is discrete data because when you are paying for an item in dollars you cannot use a coin smaller than one cent.
[4153|p129|T1] Stem-and-leaf diagrams
[4154|p129] A stem-and-leaf diagram allows you to organise and display grouped data using the actual data values. When you use a frequency table to organise group...
[4155|p129|T1] LINK
[4156|p129] Sociologists and geographers sometimes draw population pyramids. These are sideways bar charts that show the numbers of people in various age categori...
[4157|p129] In a stem-and-leaf diagram each data item is broken into two parts: a stem and a leaf. The final digit of each value is the leaf and the previous digi...
[4158|p129] [Table Row] <tr><td>Stem</td><td>Leaf</td></tr>
[4159|p129] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>3</td></tr>
[4160|p129] In this case, the tens digit is the stem and the units digit is the leaf.
[4161|p129] A larger data value such as 259 is shown as:
[4162|p129] [Table Row] <tr><td>Stem</td><td>Leaf</td></tr>
[4163|p129] [Table Row] <tr><td>25</td><td>9</td></tr>
[4164|p129] In this case, the stem represents both the tens and the hundreds digits while the units digit is the leaf.
[4165|p129] To be useful, a stem-and-leaf diagram should have at least five stems. If the number of stems is less than that, you can split the leaves into two (or...
[4166|p129] [Table Row] <tr><td>Stem</td><td>Leaf</td></tr>
[4167|p129] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>0 3 4 2 1</td></tr>
[4168|p129] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>5 9 8 7 5 6</td></tr>
[4169|p129] Values from 10 to 14 (leaves 0 to 4) are included in the first class, values from 15 to 19 (leaves 5 to 9) are included in the second class.
[4170|p129] Stem-and-leaf diagrams are easier to work with if the leaves are ordered from smallest to greatest.
[4171|p129|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[4172|p129] You will work with stem-and-leaf diagrams again when you calculate averages and measures of spread in Chapter 12.
[4173|p130|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[4174|p130] This data set shows the ages of customers in a café one lunchtime.
[4175|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>34</td><td>23</td><td>40</td><td>35</td><td>25</td><td>28</td><td>18</td><td>32</td></tr>
[4176|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>37</td><td>29</td><td>19</td><td>17</td><td>32</td><td>55</td><td>36</td><td>42</td></tr>
[4177|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>33</td><td>20</td><td>25</td><td>34</td><td>48</td><td>39</td><td>36</td><td>30</td></tr>
[4178|p130] Draw a stem-and-leaf diagram to display this data.
[4179|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>Stem</td><td>Leaf</td></tr>
[4180|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>8 9 7</td></tr>
[4181|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>2</td><td>3 5 8 9 0 5</td></tr>
[4182|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>3</td><td>4 5 2 7 6 6 3 4 2 9 0</td></tr>
[4183|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>4</td><td>0 2 8</td></tr>
[4184|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>5</td><td>5</td></tr>
[4185|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>Stem</td><td>Leaf</td><td>Key</td></tr>
[4186|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>7 8 9</td><td rowspan="5">1 | 7 represents 17</td></tr>
[4187|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>2</td><td>0 3 5 5 8 9</td></tr>
[4188|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>3</td><td>0 2 2 3 4 4 5 6 6 7 9</td></tr>
[4189|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>4</td><td>0 2 8</td></tr>
[4190|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>5</td><td>5</td></tr>
[4191|p130] Group the ages in intervals of ten, 10-19; 20-29 and so on.
[4192|p130] These are two-digit numbers, so the tens digit is the stem.
[4193|p130] List the stems in ascending order down the left of the diagram.
[4194|p130] Work through the data in the order it is given, writing the units digits (the leaves) in a row next to the appropriate stem. Space the leaves to make ...
[4195|p130] If you need to work with the data, you can redraw the diagram, putting the leaves in ascending order.
[4196|p130] From this reorganised stem-and-leaf diagram you can quickly see that:
[4197|p130] the youngest person using the internet cafe was 17 years old (the first data item)
[4198|p130] the oldest person was 55 (the last data item)
[4199|p130] - most users were in the age group 30-39 (the group with the largest number of leaves).
[4200|p130] If you want to show two sets of data, you can use a back-to-back stem-and-leaf diagram. The second set of data is plotted against the same stem, but t...
[4201|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>Brand X
Leaf</td><td>Stem</td><td>Brand Y
Leaf</td></tr>
[4202|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>9 4 8 7 2</td><td>0</td><td>5 8</td></tr>
[4203|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>7 8 7 2 3</td><td>1</td><td>4 7 8 2</td></tr>
[4204|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>8 4 6 2 7 9 8</td><td>2</td><td>8 9 7 1 5</td></tr>
[4205|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>7 2</td><td>3</td><td>7 2 1 0</td></tr>
[4206|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>4</td><td>2</td></tr>
[4207|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>5</td><td>1</td></tr>
[4208|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>Key</td></tr>
[4209|p130] [Table Row] <tr><td>Brand X 8 | 2 represents 28 hours
Brand Y 4 | 2 represents 42 hours</td></tr>

[4238|p132] 4 This stem-and-leaf diagram shows the pulse rate of a group of people measured before and after exercising on a treadmill.

[4247|p132|T1] Two-way tables
[4248|p132] A two-way table shows the frequency of certain results for two or more sets of data. Here is a two-way table showing how many people in cars were wear...
[4249|p132] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>Wearing a seat belt</td><td>Not wearing a seat belt</td></tr>
[4250|p132] [Table Row] <tr><td>Drivers</td><td>10</td><td>4</td></tr>
[4251|p132] [Table Row] <tr><td>Passengers</td><td>6</td><td>3</td></tr>
[4252|p132] The headings at the top of the table give you information about wearing seat belts. The headings down the side of the table give you information about...
[4253|p133] You can use the table to find out:
[4254|p133] how many drivers were wearing seat belts
[4255|p133] how many passengers were wearing seat belts
[4256|p133] how many drivers were not wearing seat belts
[4257|p133] how many passengers were not wearing seat belts.
[4258|p133] You can also add the totals across and down to work out:
[4259|p133] how many drivers were surveyed
[4260|p133] how many passengers were surveyed
[4261|p133] - how many people (drivers and passengers) were wearing seat belts or not wearing seat belts.
[4262|p133] Here are two more examples of two-way tables:
[4263|p133] Drinks and crisps sold at a school snack shop during lunch break
[4264|p133] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>Sweet chilli</td><td>Plain</td><td>Cheese and onion</td></tr>
[4265|p133] [Table Row] <tr><td>Cola</td><td>9</td><td>6</td><td>23</td></tr>
[4266|p133] [Table Row] <tr><td>Fruit juice</td><td>10</td><td>15</td><td>12</td></tr>
[4267|p133] How often Grade 10 and Grade 11 students use the school group chat app
[4268|p133] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>Never use it</td><td>Use it sometimes</td><td>Use it every day</td></tr>
[4269|p133] [Table Row] <tr><td>Grade 10</td><td>35</td><td>18</td><td>52</td></tr>
[4270|p133] [Table Row] <tr><td>Grade 11</td><td>42</td><td>26</td><td>47</td></tr>

[4299|p134|T1] Two-way tables in everyday life
[4300|p134] Two-way tables are often used to summarise and present data in real-life situations. You need to know how to read these tables so that you can answer ...
[4301|p134|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[4302|p134] This table shows population data for mid-2021 with estimated figures for 2025 and 2050.
[4303|p134] [Table Row] <tr><td>Region</td><td>Population in mid-2021</td><td>Projected population 2035</td><td>Projected population 2050</td></tr>
[4304|p134] [Table Row] <tr><td>World</td><td>7 837 000 000</td><td>8 848 000 000</td><td>9 688 000 000</td></tr>
[4305|p134] [Table Row] <tr><td>Africa</td><td>1 373 000 000</td><td>1 890 000 000</td><td>2 529 000 000</td></tr>
[4306|p134] [Table Row] <tr><td>North America</td><td>371 000 000</td><td>396 000 000</td><td>412 000 000</td></tr>
[4307|p134] [Table Row] <tr><td>Latin America and the Caribbean</td><td>656 000 000</td><td>725 000 000</td><td>762 000 000</td></tr>
[4308|p134] [Table Row] <tr><td>Asia</td><td>4 651 000 000</td><td>5 043 000 000</td><td>5 192 000 000</td></tr>
[4309|p134] [Table Row] <tr><td>Europe</td><td>744 000 000</td><td>742 000 000</td><td>731 000 000</td></tr>
[4310|p134] [Table Row] <tr><td>Oceania</td><td>43 000 000</td><td>53 000 000</td><td>62 000 000</td></tr>
[4311|p134] Data from Population Reference Bureau.
[4312|p135|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3 CONTINUED
[4313|p135] a What was the total population of the world in mid-2021?
[4314|p135] b By how much is the population of the world expected to grow by 2035?
[4315|p135] c What percentage of the world's population lived in Asia in mid-2021? Give your answer to the closest whole per cent.
[4316|p135] d i Which region is likely to experience a decrease in population between 2021 and 2035?
[4317|p135] ii What is the population of this region likely to be in 2035?
[4318|p135] iii By how much is the population of this region expected to decrease by 2050?
[4319|p135|T1] Answers
[4320|p135] a 7837000000
[4321|p135] Read this from the table.
[4322|p135] b 8848000000-7837000000=101100000
[4323|p135] Read the value for 2035 from the table and subtract the smaller figure from the larger.
[4324|p135] 4651000000 7837000000 × 100 = 59.3467% ≈ 59%
[4325|p135] Read the figures from the table and then calculate the percentage.
[4326|p135] d i Europe
[4327|p135] Look to see which numbers are decreasing across the row.
[4328|p135] ii 742000000
[4329|p135] Read this from the table.
[4330|p135] iii 744000000-731000000=13000000
[4331|p135] Read the values from the table and subtract the smaller figure from the larger.
[4332|p135|T1] Exercise 4.6
[4333|p135|T1] APPLY YOUR SKILLS
[4334|p135] 1 This distance table shows the flying distance (in miles) between some major world airports.
[4335|p135] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>Mumbai</td><td>Hong Kong</td><td>London</td><td>Montreal</td><td>Singapore</td><td>Sydney</td></tr>

[4337|p135] [Table Row] <tr><td>Hong Kong</td><td>2673</td><td></td><td>8252</td><td>10345</td><td>1605</td><td>4586</td></tr>
[4338|p135] [Table Row] <tr><td>Istanbul</td><td>2992</td><td>7016</td><td>1554</td><td>5757</td><td>5379</td><td>11772</td></tr>
[4339|p135] [Table Row] <tr><td>Karachi</td><td>544</td><td>3596</td><td>5276</td><td>8888</td><td>2943</td><td>8269</td></tr>
[4340|p135] [Table Row] <tr><td>Lagos</td><td>5140</td><td>8930</td><td>3098</td><td>6734</td><td>7428</td><td>11898</td></tr>
[4341|p135] [Table Row] <tr><td>London</td><td>4477</td><td>8252</td><td></td><td>3251</td><td>6754</td><td>10564</td></tr>
[4342|p135] [Table Row] <tr><td>Singapore</td><td>2432</td><td>1605</td><td>6754</td><td>9193</td><td></td><td>3912</td></tr>
[4343|p135] [Table Row] <tr><td>Sydney</td><td>6308</td><td>4586</td><td>10564</td><td>12045</td><td>3916</td><td></td></tr>
[4344|p135] a Find the flying distance from Hong Kong to:
[4345|p135] i Dubai
[4346|p135] ii London
[4347|p135] iii Sydney

[4353|p136|T1] 4.3 Using charts to display data
[4354|p136] Charts are useful for displaying data because you can see patterns and trends easily and quickly. You can also compare different sets of data easily. ...
[4355|p136|T1] Pictograms
[4356|p136] Pictograms are fairly simple charts. Small symbols (pictures) are used to represent quantities. The meaning of the symbol and the amount it represents...
[4357|p136|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[4358|p136] This pictogram shows the amount of time that five friends spent talking on their phones during one week.
[4361|p136] a Who spent the most time on the phone that week?
[4362|p136] b How much time did Isobel spend on the phone that week?
[4363|p136] c Who spent  $3\frac{1}{2}$  hours on the phone that week?
[4364|p136] d Draw the symbols you would use to show  $4\frac{1}{4}$  hours.
[4365|p137|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4 CONTINUED
[4366|p137|T1] Answers
[4367|p137] a Anna
[4368|p137] The person with the most clocks.
[4369|p137] b 3 hours
[4370|p137] There are three whole clocks; the key shows you that each one stands for 1 hour. The fourth clock is only three-quarters, so it must be  $\frac{3}{4}$...
[4371|p137] c Tara
[4372|p137] She has three full clocks, each worth 1 hour, and one half clock.
[4373|p137] d
[4377|p137] Two full clocks to represent two hours, and a quarter of a clock to represent  $\frac{1}{4}$  hours.

[4408|p138|T1] Bar charts
[4409|p138] Bar charts are normally used to display discrete data. The chart shows information as a series of bars plotted against a scale on the axis. The bars c...
[4412|p139] There are different methods of drawing bar charts, but all bar charts should have:
[4413|p139] a title that tells you what data is being displayed
[4414|p139] - a number scale or axis (so you can work out how many are in each class) and a label on the scale that tells you what the numbers stand for
[4415|p139] a scale or axis that lists the categories displayed
[4416|p139] - bars that are equally wide and equally spaced
[4417|p139] - bars that do not touch for qualitative of discrete data.

[4429|p140|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[4430|p140] A bar chart is not the same as a histogram. A histogram is often used for continuous data. You will learn more about histograms in Chapter 20.

[4437|p141|T1] Composite bar charts
[4438|p141] A composite (stacked) bar chart breaks the whole set of data shown on each bar into groups.

[4441|p141] The graph shows that Zawadi spent most of the time cycling (about  $80\%$ ). By comparison, Kofi only spent about  $10\%$  of the time cycling.
[4442|p141] This composite bar graph shows the number of students taking different computer programming courses. The bars are different heights because the total ...

[4481|p143|T1] PEER ASSESSMENT
[4482|p143] How can you decide whether another student's bar chart is correct or not?
[4483|p143] One way of assessing a piece of work is to write a checklist. A checklist is an assessment tool. It is a list of statements that give the criteria you...
[4484|p143] 1 Work in small groups to write a checklist to assess whether someone can draw an accurate and clear bar chart.
[4485|p143] Consider the learning outcomes for this work and what you have covered in the lessons.
[4486|p143] - Your statements should be clear, specific and easy to check. For example: The chart has a clear heading [ ] yes [ ] no
[4487|p143] Leave space in your checklist to add comments. For example: Your heading has spelling mistakes in it. or The vertical scale needs to start at 0.
[4488|p143] 2 Use your checklist to assess another student's completed work in Exercise 4.8.
[4489|p143] 3 Use the checklist to suggest corrections, improvements or learning goals that still need to be met.
[4490|p143|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[4491|p143] Look at the earlier sections of this chapter to remind yourself about grouped frequency tables if you need to.
[4492|p144|T1] REFLECTION
[4493|p144] Think about your own academic performance as you worked through the material on bar charts and answer these questions.
[4494|p144] What new things did you learn? Why are these important?
[4495|p144] - Were the strategies, skills and procedures that you knew or learned useful for completing the exercises? Explain why or why not.
[4496|p144] Did you come to each lesson prepared to learn? (Think about your attitude and the equipment you needed to bring.)
[4497|p144] - Which activities helped you to learn the most? Why?
[4498|p144] Did you experience any difficulty or frustration in this work? What did you do about it?

[4518|p145|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[4519|p145] The table shows how a student spent one day.
[4520|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>Activity</td><td>School</td><td>Sleeping</td><td>Eating</td><td>Online</td><td>On the phone</td><td>Complaining about stuff</td></...
[4521|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>Number of hours</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>1.5</td><td>3</td><td>2.5</td><td>2</td></tr>
[4522|p145] Draw a pie chart to show this data.
[4523|p145] $7 + 8 + 1.5 + 3 + 2.5 + 2 = 24$  First work out the total number of hours.
[4524|p145] Then work out each category as a fraction of the whole and convert the fraction to degrees:
[4525|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>(as a fraction of 24)</td><td>(convert to degrees)</td></tr>
[4526|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>School</td><td>= 7/24</td><td>= 7/24 × 360 = 105°</td></tr>
[4527|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>Sleeping</td><td>= 8/24</td><td>8/24 × 360 = 120°</td></tr>
[4528|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>Eating</td><td>= 1.5/24 = 15/240</td><td>15/240 × 360 = 22.5°</td></tr>
[4529|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>Online</td><td>= 3/24</td><td>3/24 × 360 = 45°</td></tr>
[4530|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>On the phone</td><td>= 2.5/24 = 25/240</td><td>25/240 × 360 = 37.5°</td></tr>
[4531|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>Complaining about stuff</td><td>= 2/24</td><td>2/24 × 360 = 30°</td></tr>
[4532|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>Activity</td><td>School</td><td>Sleeping</td><td>Eating</td><td>Online</td><td>On the phone</td><td>Complaining about stuff</td></...
[4533|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>Number of hours</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>1.5</td><td>3</td><td>2.5</td><td>2</td></tr>
[4534|p145] [Table Row] <tr><td>Angle</td><td>105°</td><td>120°</td><td>22.5°</td><td>45°</td><td>37.5°</td><td>30°</td></tr>
[4535|p145] Draw a circle to represent the whole day.
[4536|p145] Use a ruler and a protractor to measure each sector.
[4537|p145] Label the chart and give it a title.

[4541|p146|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[4542|p146] This pie chart shows how Javi spent one day of the school holidays.
[4545|p146] a What fraction of the day did Javi spend playing computer games?
[4546|p146] b How much time did Javi spend sleeping?
[4547|p146] c What do you think 'other stuff' involved?
[4548|p146|T1] Answers
[4549|p146] a  $\frac{120}{360} = \frac{1}{3}$
[4550|p146] Measure the angle and convert it to a fraction. The yellow sector has an angle of  $120^{\circ}$ . Convert to a fraction by writing it over 360 and si...
[4551|p146] b  $\frac{210}{360} \times 24 = 14$  hours
[4552|p146] Measure the angle, convert it to hours.
[4553|p146] c Things Javi didn't bother to list. Possibly eating, showering, getting dressed.

[4616|p151|T1] SELF ASSESSMENT
[4617|p151] Copy and complete this writing outline frame to assess your own learning in this chapter. The notes at the side tell you what to include and why.
[4619|p152|T1] SUMMARY
[4620|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Do you know ...?</td></tr>
[4621|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>In statistics, data is a set of information collected to answer a particular question.</td></tr>
[4622|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Categorical (qualitative) data is non-numerical. Colours, names, places and other descriptive terms are all categorical.</td></tr>
[4623|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Numerical (quantitative) data is collected in the form of numbers. Numerical data can be discrete or continuous. Discrete data tak...
[4624|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Primary data is data you collect yourself from a primary source. Secondary data is data you collect from other sources (previously...
[4625|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Unsorted data is called raw data. Raw data can be organised using tally tables, frequency tables, stem-and-leaf diagrams and two-w...
[4626|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Data in tables can be displayed as graphs to show patterns and trends at a glance.</td></tr>
[4627|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Pictograms are simple graphs that use symbols to represent quantities.</td></tr>
[4628|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Bar charts have rows of horizontal bars or columns of vertical bars of different lengths. The bar length (or height) represents an...
[4629|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Dual bar charts display two or more sets of data side by side on the same set of axes.</td></tr>
[4630|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Composite bar charts display groups within a set of data stacked on a single bar.</td></tr>
[4631|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Pie charts are circular charts divided into sectors to show categories of data.</td></tr>
[4632|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Line graphs use lines to plot changes in the data over time.</td></tr>
[4633|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>The type of graph you draw depends on the data and what you wish to show.</td></tr>
[4634|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>Are you able to ...?</td></tr>
[4635|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>collect data to answer a statistical question</td></tr>
[4636|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>classify different types of data</td></tr>
[4637|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>use tallies to count and record data</td></tr>
[4638|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>draw a frequency table to organise data</td></tr>
[4639|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>use class intervals to group data and draw a grouped frequency table</td></tr>
[4640|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>construct single and back-to-back stem-and-leaf diagrams to organise and display sets of data</td></tr>
[4641|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>draw and use two-way tables to organise two or more sets of data</td></tr>
[4642|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>construct and interpret pictograms</td></tr>
[4643|p152] [Table Row] <tr><td>construct and interpret bar charts, dual bar charts and composite bar charts</td></tr>

[4820|p160|T1] Chapter 5
[4821|p160|T1] Fractions, percentages and standard form
[4822|p160|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[4823|p160] find equivalent fractions
[4824|p160] - simplify fractions
[4825|p160] - add, subtract, multiply and divide fractions and mixed numbers
[4826|p160] find fractions of numbers
[4827|p160] find a percentage of a number
[4828|p160] find one number as a percentage of another
[4829|p160] calculate percentage increases and decreases
[4830|p160] increase and decrease by a given percentage
[4831|p160] calculate reverse percentages (undoing increases and decreases)
[4832|p160] use standard form
[4833|p160] calculate with values in standard form.
[4834|p161] Sea nettle jellyfish bodies on the previous page are  $\frac{1}{20}$  protein, muscles and nerve cells - the rest is water. Work out what percentage o...
[4835|p161] We use fractions and percentages on an almost daily basis, often without realising it. For example, we use fractions to answer questions like these:
[4836|p161] How far can you travel on half a tank of petrol?
[4837|p161] If you share  $\frac{3}{4}$  of a cake between two people, how much will they each get?
[4838|p161] If three-fifths of a  $100\mathrm{km}$  journey is complete, how far do you still have to travel?
[4839|p161] If a shop is offering a 25% discount, what will you pay for an item costing $120?
[4840|p161|T1] GETTING STARTED
[4841|p161] 1 Match pairs of bubbles with the same value to find the one that has no matching value.
[4844|p161] 2 Draw diagrams with labels or short notes to show why:
[4845|p161] a a  $50\%$  increase followed by a  $50\%$  decrease does not get you back to where you started
[4846|p161] b an increase of  $40\%$  followed by an increase of  $50\%$  is not equal to an increase of  $90\%$ .
[4847|p161|T1] KEY WORDS
[4848|p161] common
[4849|p161] denominator
[4850|p161] denominator
[4851|p161] equivalent fraction
[4852|p161] fraction
[4853|p161] lowest terms
[4854|p161] mixed number
[4855|p161] numerator
[4856|p161] simplest form
[4857|p161] standard form
[4858|p162|T1] 5.1 Revisiting fractions
[4859|p162] A fraction tells you what share or part of a whole amount you are working with. For example,  $\frac{1}{2}$  of a pie means 1 of 2 equal parts of the ...
[4860|p162] Proper fractions are written in the form  $\frac{a}{b}$  where  $a > b$ . The number on the top,  $a$ , can be any number and is called the numerator....
[4861|p162] When you multiply or divide both the numerator and the denominator by the same number you get a new fraction that has the same value as the original f...
[4862|p162] For example,  $\frac{2}{3} = \frac{2 \times 4}{3 \times 4} = \frac{8}{12}$  and  $\frac{25}{35} = \frac{25 \div 5}{35 \div 5} = \frac{5}{7}$ .
[4863|p162] Notice in the second example that the original fraction  $\left(\frac{25}{35}\right)$  was divided rather than multiplied to get  $\frac{5}{7}$ . The ...
[4864|p162|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[4865|p162] Before you work through this section remind yourself about highest common factors (HCFs) in Chapter 1, but remember you can multiply or divide by any ...
[4866|p162|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[4867|p162] Express each fraction in its simplest form.
[4868|p162] a 3 15
[4869|p162] b 16 24
[4870|p162] 21 28
[4871|p162] 5 d 8
[4872|p162|T1] Answers
[4873|p162] 3 3÷3 15 15+3 5
[4874|p162] 16 16+8 2 b 24 24+8 3
[4875|p162] 21+7 3 28+7 4
[4876|p162] d  $\frac{5}{8}$  is already in its simplest form
[4877|p162] (5 and 8 have no common factors other than 1).
[4878|p162|T1] TIP
[4879|p162] Notice that in each case you divide the numerator and the denominator by their HCF.
[4880|p162|T1] TIP
[4881|p162] Fractions were originally written with a slant line like this: 2/5. You will often find fractions written like this and when you enter fractions onlin...
[4882|p162|T1] TIP
[4883|p162] Remember, dividing the numerator and denominator by the same number simplifies the fraction.
[4884|p163|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[4885|p163] Which two of  $\frac{5}{6}, \frac{20}{25}$  and  $\frac{15}{18}$  are equivalent fractions?
[4886|p163|T1] Answer
[4887|p163] 5 is already in its simplest form.
[4888|p163|T1] Alternative method
[4889|p163] Simplify each of the other fractions:
[4890|p163] You could have written:
[4891|p163] $$
\frac {2 0}{2 5} = \frac {2 0 + 5}{2 5 + 5} = \frac {4}{5}
$$
[4892|p163] $$
\frac {5 1 8}{1 8} = \frac {5}{6}
$$
[4893|p163] $$
\frac {1 5}{1 8} = \frac {1 5 \div 3}{1 8 \div 3} = \frac {5}{6}
$$
[4894|p163] This is called cancelling and is a shorter way of showing what you have done.
[4895|p163] So  $\frac{5}{6}$  and  $\frac{15}{18}$  are equivalent.
[4896|p163|T1] Exercise 5.1
[4897|p163] 1 By multiplying or dividing both the numerator and denominator by the same number, find three equivalent fractions for each of the following.
[4898|p163] $\frac{5}{9}$
[4899|p163] b  $\frac{3}{7}$
[4900|p163] 12 18
[4901|p163] d 18 36
[4902|p163] 110 110 128
[4903|p163] 2 Express each of the following fractions in its simplest form.
[4904|p163] 7 21
[4905|p163] b
[4906|p163] 9 12
[4907|p163] d  $\frac{15}{25}$
[4908|p163] 500 2500
[4909|p163] f
[4910|p163] 108 9 360
[4911|p163|T1] INVESTIGATION
[4912|p163|T1] Fraction diagrams
[4913|p163] 1 Read this activity and look at the solutions from three students.
[4915|p163] a What fractions did each student produce?
[4916|p163] b Is it possible to do this and only produce two fractional parts? If so, how?
[4917|p163] c What is the smallest fraction you can make in this task?
[4918|p163|T1] TIP
[4919|p163] Work on squared or dotted paper to make it easier to draw the rectangles you need.
[4921|p164|T1] INVESTIGATION CONTINUED
[4922|p164] 2 The second part of the task had the same instructions but used this rectangle with more dots on the sides.
[4924|p164] Work in pairs or small groups to investigate how many fractions you can make. Label your fractions.
[4925|p164|T1] 5.2 Operations on fractions
[4926|p164|T1] Multiplying fractions
[4927|p164] To multiply two or more fractions, multiply the numerators and then multiply the denominators. Sometimes you will need to simplify your answer.
[4928|p164|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[4929|p164] Calculate.
[4930|p164] a  $\frac{3}{4}\times \frac{2}{7}$
[4931|p164] b  $\frac{5}{7}\times 3$
[4932|p164] 3 of 4 1 8
[4933|p164] Answers
[4934|p164] a  $\frac{3}{4} \times \frac{2}{7} = \frac{3 \times 2}{4 \times 7} = \frac{6}{28} = \frac{3}{14}$
[4935|p164] Another method is to cancel before multiplying:
[4936|p164] $$
\frac {3}{2 4} \times \frac {2}{7} = \frac {3 \times 1}{2 \times 7} = \frac {3}{1 4}
$$
[4937|p164] b  $\frac{5}{7} \times 3 = \frac{5 \times 3}{7 \times 1} = \frac{15}{7}$
[4938|p164] 3 of 4 1 3 3 2 16
[4939|p164] Multiply the numerators to get the new numerator value. Do the same with the denominators. Then express the fraction in its simplest form.
[4940|p164] Divide the denominator of the first fraction, and the numerator of the second fraction, by two.
[4941|p164] 15 and 7 do not have a common factor other than 1 and so cannot be simplified.
[4942|p164] You need to change the mixed number to an improper fraction. This allows you to complete the multiplication. Notice that the word 'of' is replaced wit...
[4943|p164|T1] TIP
[4944|p164] To multiply a fraction by an integer you only multiply the numerator by the integer.
[4945|p164] For example,
[4946|p164] $$
\frac {5}{7} \times 3 = \frac {5 \times 3}{7} = \frac {1 5}{7}.
$$
[4947|p164|T1] TIP
[4948|p164] An improper fraction is a fraction where the numerator is larger than the denominator. To change a mixed number to a common fraction, multiply the who...
[4949|p164] $$
4 \frac {1}{2} = \frac {4 \times 2 + 1}{2} = \frac {9}{2}.
$$
[4951|p165|T1] Exercise 5.2
[4952|p165] Evaluate each of the following.
[4953|p165] 1 a  $\frac{2}{3}\times \frac{5}{9}$
[4954|p165] b
[4955|p165] 1 8 4 9
[4956|p165] d  $\frac{2}{7}\times \frac{14}{16}$
[4957|p165] 50 2 a 128 500
[4958|p165] b  $1\frac{1}{3}\times \frac{2}{7}$
[4959|p165] 2 7 8
[4960|p165] d  $\frac{4}{5}$  of  $3\frac{2}{7}$
[4961|p165] e 1 1/3 of 24
[4962|p165] f  $5\frac{1}{2}\times 7\frac{1}{4}$
[4963|p165] g 8 20 1 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 9...
[4964|p165] h 7 10
[4965|p165|T1] Adding and subtracting fractions
[4966|p165] You can add or subtract fractions that have same denominators (common denominator). You can use equivalent fractions to make fractions with the same d...
[4967|p165] This example shows how to use the lowest common multiple (LCM) of both denominators to find a common denominator.
[4968|p165|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[4969|p165] Write each of the following as a single fraction in its simplest form.
[4970|p165] a 3 +5 4 6
[4971|p165] b 23-15
[4972|p165|T1] Answers
[4973|p165] a 3 5 4 6
[4974|p165] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \frac {9}{1 2} + \frac {1 0}{1 2} \\ = \frac {1 9}{1 2} \\ = 1 \frac {7}{1 2} \\ \end{array}
$$
[4975|p165] b 23-15 11-12 4 7
[4976|p165] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \frac {7 7}{2 8} - \frac {4 8}{2 8} \\ = \frac {7 7 - 4 8}{2 8} \\ = \frac {2 9}{2 8} \\ = 1 \frac {1}{2 8} \\ \end{array}
$$
[4977|p165] Find the common denominator.
[4978|p165] The LCM of 4 and 6 is 12. Use this as the common denominator and find the equivalent fractions.
[4979|p165] Add the numerators.
[4980|p165] Change the improper fraction to a mixed number.
[4981|p165] Change mixed numbers to improper fractions to make them easier to work with.
[4982|p165] The LCM of 4 and 7 is 28. Use this as the common denominator and find the equivalent fractions.
[4983|p165] Subtract one numerator from the other.
[4984|p165] Change the improper fraction to a mixed number.
[4985|p165|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[4986|p165] You will use the LCM in this section.
[4987|p165] You learnt about this in Chapter 1.
[4988|p165|T1] TIP
[4989|p165] Once you have a common denominator, you only add the numerators. Never add the denominators.
[4990|p165|T1] TIP
[4991|p165] Adding two fractions can result in an improper fraction.
[4992|p165] To write the fraction in its simplest form, rewrite it as a mixed number.
[4994|p166|T1] Exercise 5.3
[4995|p166] Evaluate the following.
[4996|p166] 1 a 1 3 + 1 3
[4997|p166] e  $\frac{1}{6} +\frac{1}{5}$
[4998|p166] b
[4999|p166] 2 5 3 8
[5000|p166] 5 3 8 8
[5001|p166] g 2-1
[5002|p166] d 5 8 9 9
[5003|p166] h 51-316
[5004|p166] 2 a 4- 3
[5005|p166] d 11-7
[5006|p166] 9 51-316+4
[5007|p166] j 3 2 4

[5016|p166|T1] INVESTIGATION
[5017|p166|T1] Fraction patterns
[5018|p166] 1 You can convert any fraction to a decimal number using your calculator. For example, if you work out  $\frac{1}{2}$  as a decimal by dividing 1 by 2...
[5019|p166] Try converting the following fractions to decimals:
[5020|p166] 2 5
[5022|p166] 3 7
[5023|p166] 4 9
[5024|p166] 3 16
[5025|p166] 2 Which fractions in question 1 stop ('terminate') after a few decimal places and which seem to go on forever? Try some more fractions and decide whic...
[5026|p166] 3 Look at the dominators of the fractions that with decimals that terminate. What do they have in common? [Hint: what are the factors of the denominat...
[5027|p166] 4 Now work out the decimals for:
[5028|p166] 1
[5030|p166] 4 7
[5031|p166] 5 7
[5032|p166] Do the answers have anything in common?
[5033|p166] Try the same thing with denominator 11. What about 13?
[5034|p166] Explain any patterns that you see.
[5035|p166|T1] TIP
[5036|p166] Remember to use the correct order of operations (BODMAS) here.
[5037|p166|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[5038|p166] You will revisit multiplication, division, addition and subtraction of fractions in Chapter 14 when you deal with algebraic fractions.
[5039|p167|T1] Dividing fractions
[5040|p167] To divide one fraction by another, you multiply the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second fraction.
[5041|p167] To find the reciprocal of a fraction you invert it. So, the reciprocal of  $\frac{3}{4}$  is  $\frac{4}{3}$  and the reciprocal of  $\frac{7}{2}$  is ...
[5042|p167] The reciprocal of  $\frac{1}{2}$  is  $\frac{2}{1}$  or just 2 and the reciprocal of 5 is  $\frac{1}{5}$ .
[5043|p167] When you multiply a fraction by its reciprocal the result is always 1. For example:
[5044|p167] $$
\frac {1}{3} \times \frac {3}{1} = 1, \quad \frac {3}{8} \times \frac {8}{3} = 1 \quad \text {a n d} \quad \frac {a}{b} \times \frac {b}{a} = 1.
$$
[5045|p167] Look at the example below to understand why this method works.
[5046|p167] $$
\frac {5}{1 1} \div \frac {1}{2} = \frac {\frac {5}{1 1}}{\frac {1}{2}}
$$
[5047|p167] To get rid of the fraction  $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)$  in the denominator, multiply both the numerator and denominator by 2.
[5048|p167] $$
\frac {5}{1 1} \div \frac {1}{2} = \frac {\frac {5}{1 1} \times \frac {2}{1}}{\frac {1}{2} \times \frac {2}{1}} = \frac {\frac {1 0}{1 1}}{1} = \fr...
[5049|p167] If you invert the fraction you are dividing by and multiply, you will give the same answer with fewer steps:
[5050|p167] $$
\frac {5}{1 1} \div \frac {1}{2} = \frac {5}{1 1} \times \frac {2}{1} = \frac {1 0}{1 1}
$$
[5051|p167|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[5052|p167] Evaluate each of the following.
[5053|p167] a 3 1 4 2
[5054|p167] b 13 2 1 3 4 3 2 3
[5055|p167] 5 8 2
[5056|p167] d  $\frac{6}{7} +3$
[5057|p167|T1] Answers
[5058|p167] a 3 3 2 1
[5059|p167] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \frac {3}{2} \\ = 1 \frac {1}{2} \\ \end{array}
$$
[5060|p167] Multiply by the reciprocal of  $\frac{1}{2}$ .
[5061|p167] Use the rules you have learned about multiplying fractions.
[5062|p167] b  $1\frac{3}{4} +2\frac{1}{3} = \frac{7}{4} +\frac{7}{3}$
[5063|p167] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \frac {1}{4} \times \frac {3}{7} \\ = \frac {3}{4} \\ \end{array}
$$
[5064|p167] Convert the mixed fractions to improper fractions.
[5065|p167] Multiply by the reciprocal of  $\frac{7}{3}$ .
[5066|p168|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5 CONTINUED
[5067|p168] c  $\frac{5}{8} \div 2 = \frac{5}{8} \div \frac{2}{1}$
[5068|p168] Write 2 as an improper fraction.
[5069|p168] $$
= \frac {5}{8} \times \frac {1}{2}
$$
[5070|p168] Multiply by the reciprocal of  $\frac{2}{1}$ .
[5071|p168] $$
= \frac {5}{1 6}
$$
[5072|p168] d 6 6 1 7 7 7
[5073|p168] $$
= \frac {2}{7}
$$

[5086|p168] b 2 1-1 2 1 3
[5087|p168|T1] Fractions with decimals
[5088|p168] In some calculations either the numerator or the denominator, or both, might not be whole numbers. To express these fractions in their simplest forms:
[5089|p168] - find an equivalent fraction where both the numerator and denominator are integers
[5090|p168] - check that the equivalent fraction is in its simplest form.
[5091|p168|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[5092|p168] Simplify each of the following fractions.
[5093|p168] a 0.1 3
[5094|p168] b  $\frac{1.3}{2.4}$
[5095|p168] 36 0.12
[5096|p168|T1] Answers
[5097|p168] a 0.1 0.1×10 3 3×10
[5098|p168] $$
= \frac {1}{3 0}
$$
[5099|p168] Multiply 0.1 by 10 to convert 0.1 to an integer.
[5100|p168] Make sure the fraction is equivalent by also multiplying the denominator (3) by 10.
[5101|p168|T1] TIP
[5102|p168] To divide a fraction by an integer you can either multiply the denominator by the integer, or divide the numerator by the same integer.
[5103|p169|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6 CONTINUED
[5104|p169] b  $\frac{1.3}{2.4} = \frac{1.3 \times 10}{2.4 \times 10}$
[5105|p169] $$
= \frac {1 3}{2 4}
$$
[5106|p169] Multiply both the numerator and denominator by 10 to get integers.
[5107|p169] 13 and 24 do not have a HCF other than 1, so you cannot simplify the fraction.
[5108|p169] 36 36×100 0.12 0.12×100
[5109|p169] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \frac {3 6 0 0}{1 2} \\ = 3 0 0 \\ \end{array}
$$
[5110|p169] Multiply 0.12 by 100 to produce an integer.
[5111|p169] Remember to multiply the numerator by 100, so the fraction is equivalent.
[5112|p169] Simplify the final fraction by cancelling.

[5123|p169|T1] Further calculations with fractions
[5124|p169] You can use fractions to help you solve problems.
[5125|p169|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[5126|p169] Suppose that  $\frac{2}{5}$  of the students in a school wear glasses. If the school has 600 students, how many students wear glasses?
[5127|p169] Answer
[5128|p169] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {2}{5} \text {o f} 6 0 0 = \frac {2}{5} \times 6 0 0 \\ = \frac {2}{1 8} \times \frac {6 0 0}{1} ^ {1 2 0} \\ = 2 \times 1 2...
[5129|p169|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[5130|p169] of the students in a school do not wear glasses. If 360 students do not wear glasses, how many students are there in the whole school?
[5131|p169] Answer
[5132|p169] $\frac{2}{5}$  of the total is 360, so  $\frac{1}{5}$  of the total must be half of this, 180.
[5133|p169] This means that the total  $\left(\frac{5}{5}\right)$  is  $5 \times 180 = 900$  students altogether.
[5134|p169|T1] TIP
[5135|p169] Remember: a fraction that contains a decimal is not its simplest form.
[5136|p169|T1] TIP
[5137|p169] Remember: in Worked example 3, you saw that 'of' is replaced by  $\times$ .
