[10667|p324] has a  $y$  -intercept of  $\frac{1}{2}$
[10668|p324] 11 A graph has the equation  $3y - 2x = 9$
[10669|p324] a Write down the equation of one other graph that is parallel to this one.
[10670|p324] b Write down the equation of one other graph that crosses the  $y$ -axis at the same point as this one.
[10671|p324] c Write down the equation of a line that passes through the  $y$ -axis at the same point as this one and which is parallel to the  $x$ -axis.
[10672|p324|T1] Perpendicular lines
[10673|p324] You have already seen that parallel lines have the same gradient and that lines with the same gradient are parallel.
[10674|p324] Perpendicular lines meet at right angles. The product of the gradients is  $-1$ .
[10675|p324] So,  $m_{1} \times m_{2} = -1$ , where  $m$  is the gradient of each line.
[10676|p324] The sketch shows two perpendicular graphs.
[10677|p324] $$
y = - \frac {1}{3} x + 2 \text {h a s a g r a d i e n t o f} - \frac {1}{3}
$$
[10678|p324] $$
y = 3 x - 4 \text {h a s a g r a d i e n t o f 3}
$$
[10679|p324] The product of the gradients is
[10680|p324] $$
- \frac {1}{3} \times 3 = - 1.
$$
[10682|p324|T1] TIP
[10683|p324] Remember that a product is the result of multiplying two numbers together.
[10684|p324|T1] TIP
[10685|p324] If the product of the gradients of two lines is equal to  $-1$ , it follows that the lines are perpendicular to each other.
[10686|p325|T1] INVESTIGATION
[10687|p325] In two dimensions, straight lines that are not parallel always meet at one point. Is this true in three dimensions?
[10688|p325|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[10689|p325] Given that  $y = \frac{2}{3} x + 2$ , determine the equation of the straight line that is:
[10690|p325] a perpendicular to this line and which passes through the origin.
[10691|p325] b perpendicular to this line and which passes through the point  $(-3,1)$ .
[10692|p325|T1] Answers
[10693|p325] a  $y = mx + c$
[10694|p325] $$
\begin{array}{l} m = - \frac {3}{2} \\ c = 0 \\ \end{array}
$$
[10695|p325] The gradient is the negative reciprocal
[10696|p325] $$
\text {o f} \frac {2}{3}.
$$
[10697|p325] The equation of the line is
[10698|p325] $$
y = - \frac {3}{2} x.
$$
[10699|p325] b  $y = -\frac{3}{2} x + c$
[10700|p325] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = - 3 \text {a n d} y = 1 \\ 1 = - \frac {3}{2} (- 3) + c \\ 1 = \frac {9}{2} + c \\ c = - 3 \frac {1}{2} \\ y = - \frac {3}{2} ...
[10701|p325] Using  $m = -\frac{3}{2}$  from part (a).
[10702|p325] Substitute the values of  $x$  and  $y$  for the
[10703|p325] given point to solve for  $c$ .

[10721|p326|T1] TIP
[10722|p326] The perpendicular bisector is the line that is perpendicular to the original line and passes through its midpoint.
[10723|p326|T1] Intersection with the  $x$ -axis
[10724|p326] So far you have only found the  $y$ -intercept, either from the graph or from the equation. There is, of course, an  $x$ -intercept too. The following...
[10726|p326] Notice that the line crosses the  $x$ -axis at the point where  $x = 2$  and, importantly,  $y = 0$ . In fact, all points on the  $x$ -axis have  $y$ ...
[10727|p326] If you substitute  $y = 0$  into the equation of the line:
[10728|p326] $$
\begin{array}{l} y = 3 x - 6 \\ 0 = 3 x - 6 \quad \left(\text {p u t} y = 0\right) \\ 3 x = 6 \quad \text {(a d d 6 t o b o t h s i d e s)} \\ x = ...
[10729|p326] This is exactly the answer that you found from the graph.
[10730|p327] You can also find the  $y$ -intercept by putting  $x = 0$ . The following worked examples show calculations for finding both the  $x$ - and  $y$ -inte...
[10731|p327|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[10732|p327] Find the  $x$ - and  $y$ -intercepts for each of the following lines. Sketch the graph in each case.
[10733|p327] a  $y = 6x - 12$
[10734|p327] b  $y = -x + 3$
[10735|p327] $2x + 5y = 20$
[10736|p327|T1] Answers
[10737|p327] a  $y = 6x - 12$
[10738|p327] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = 0 \Rightarrow y = - 1 2 \\ y = 0 \Rightarrow 6 x - 1 2 = 0 \\ \Rightarrow x = 2 \\ \end{array}
$$
[10740|p327] b  $y = -x + 3$
[10741|p327] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = 0 \Rightarrow y = 3 \\ y = 0 \Rightarrow - x + 3 = 0 \\ \Rightarrow x = 3 \\ \end{array}
$$
[10743|p327] $2x + 5y = 20$
[10744|p327] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = 0 \Rightarrow 5 y = 2 0 \\ \Rightarrow y = 4 \\ \end{array}
$$
[10745|p327] $$
\begin{array}{l} y = 0 \Rightarrow 2 x = 2 0 \\ \Rightarrow x = 1 0 \\ \end{array}
$$
[10747|p327|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[10748|p327] The  $y$  -intercept is also very important. You met it earlier in the chapter. The  $c^{\prime}$  in the equation  $y = mx + c$  is the  $y$  -interc...
[10749|p327|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[10750|p327] You will need to understand this method when solving simultaneous equations in Chapter 14.
[10751|p328|T1] Exercise 10.6
[10752|p328] 1 Find the  $x$ - and  $y$ -intercepts for each of the following lines. Sketch the graph in each case.
[10753|p328] a  $y = -5x + 10$
[10754|p328] b  $y = \frac{x}{3} - 1$
[10755|p328] $y = -3x + 6$
[10756|p328] d  $y = 4x + 2$
[10757|p328] $y = 3x + 1$
[10758|p328] f  $y = -x + 2$
[10759|p328] g  $y = 2x - 3$
[10760|p328] 2x 1 h y=3-1
[10761|p328] $y = \frac{x}{4} - 2$
[10762|p328] j  $y - \frac{2x}{5} = +1$
[10763|p328] [ - 2 + y = \frac{x}{4}]
[10764|p328] y 4x-2 3
[10765|p328] 2 For each equation the given point lies on the graph. Find each value of  $c$ .

[10774|p328|T1] Finding the length of a straight line segment
[10775|p328] Although lines are infinitely long, you are usually only interested in a part of a line. Any section of a line joining two points is called a line seg...
[10776|p328|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[10777|p328] The word 'segment' means 'part'. You have seen this word used in Chapter 3, where a segment of a circle is the part of a circle 'cut off' by a chord.
[10778|p328] If you know the coordinates of the end points of a line segment you can use Pythagoras' theorem to calculate the length of the line segment.
[10779|p329|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[10780|p329] Find the distance between the points (1, 1) and (7, 9).
[10782|p329|T1] Answer
[10783|p329] $$
\begin{array}{l} a ^ {2} = 8 ^ {2} + 6 ^ {2} \\ a ^ {2} = b ^ {2} + c ^ {2} (\text {P y t h a g o r a s} ^ {\prime} \text {t h e o r e m}) \\ \end{...
[10784|p329] $$
a ^ {2} = 6 4 + 3 6
$$
[10785|p329] Work out each expression.
[10786|p329] $$
a ^ {2} = 1 0 0
$$
[10787|p329] $$
\therefore a = \sqrt {1 0 0}
$$
[10788|p329] Undo the square by taking the square root of both sides.
[10789|p329] $$
a = 1 0 \text {u n i t s}
$$
[10790|p329|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[10791|p329] Given  $A(3,6)$  and  $B(7,3)$ , find the length of  $AB$ .
[10793|p329|T1] Answer
[10794|p329] $$
A B ^ {2} = A C ^ {2} + C B ^ {2}
$$
[10795|p329] $$
a ^ {2} = b ^ {2} + c ^ {2} (\text {P y t h a g o r a s} ^ {\prime} \text {t h e o r e m})
$$
[10796|p329] $$
A B ^ {2} = 3 ^ {2} + 4 ^ {2}
$$
[10797|p329] Work out each expression.
[10798|p329] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 9 + 1 6 \\ = 2 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[10799|p329] $$
\therefore A B = \sqrt {2 5} = 5 \text {u n i t s}
$$
[10800|p329|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS

[10802|p330|T1] Midpoints
[10803|p330] It is possible to find the coordinates of the midpoint of the line segment (i.e. the point that is exactly halfway between the two original points).
[10804|p330] Consider the following line segment and the points  $A(3,4)$  and  $B(5,10)$
[10805|p330] If you add both  $x$ -coordinates and divide by two you get  $\frac{(3 + 5)}{2} = \frac{8}{2} = 4$ .
[10806|p330] If you add both  $y$ -coordinates and divide by two you get  $\frac{(4 + 10)}{2} = \frac{14}{2} = 7$ .
[10807|p330] This gives a new point with coordinates (4, 7). This point is exactly halfway between  $A$  and  $B$ .
[10809|p330|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[10810|p330] In Chapter 12 you will learn about the mean of two or more numbers. To find the midpoint you use the mean of the  $x$ -coordinates and the mean of the...

[10842|p332|T1] 10.2 Quadratic expressions and equations
[10844|p332] The diagram shows a rectangle of width  $(x + 3)$  cm and length  $(x + 5)$  cm that has been divided into smaller rectangles.
[10845|p332] The area of the whole rectangle is equal to the sum of the smaller areas, so the area of whole rectangle  $= (x + 3) \times (x + 5)$ .
[10846|p332] The sum of smaller rectangle areas:  $x^{2} + 3x + 5x + 15 = x^{2} + 8x + 15$ .
[10847|p332] This means that  $(x + 3) \times (x + 5) = x^2 + 3x + 5x + 15 = x^2 + 8x + 15$  and this is true for all values of  $x$ .
[10848|p332] Notice what happens if you multiply every term in the second bracket by every term in the first:
[10850|p332] Notice that the four terms in boxes are exactly the same as the four smaller areas that were calculated before.
[10851|p332] Another way to show this calculation is to use a grid:
[10852|p332] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>x</td><td>3</td></tr>
[10853|p332] [Table Row] <tr><td>x</td><td>x2</td><td>3x</td></tr>
[10854|p332] [Table Row] <tr><td>5</td><td>5x</td><td>15</td></tr>
[10855|p332] You will notice that this is almost the same as the areas method above but it can also be used when the constants are negative, as you will see in Wor...
[10856|p332] When you remove the brackets and rewrite the algebraic expression you are expanding or multiplying out the brackets. The resulting algebraic expressio...

[10870|p333] In this version of the
[10871|p333] method you will notice that the arrows have not been included and the multiplication 'arcs' have been arranged so that the are symmetrical and easy to...
[10872|p333] b x -7 x x² -7x +6 6x -42
[10873|p333] $x^{2} - 7x + 6x - 42$
[10874|p333] $= x^{2} - x - 42$
[10875|p333] The grid method with a
[10876|p333] negative value.
[10877|p333] c (2x-1)(x+9)
[10878|p333] First:  $2x + x = 2x^{2}$
[10879|p333] Outside:  $2x \times 9 = 18x$
[10880|p333] Inside:  $-1 \times x = -x$
[10881|p333] Last:  $-1 \times 9 = -9$
[10882|p333] $2x^{2} + 18x - x - 9$
[10883|p333] $= x^{2} + 17x - 9$
[10884|p333] A third method uses the
[10885|p333] mnemonic 'FOIL', which stands for First, Outside, Inside, Last. This means that you multiply the first terms in each bracket together, then the 'outsi...

[10887|p333] Quadratic expressions and formulae are useful for modelling situations that involve movement, including acceleration, stopping distances, velocity and...
[10888|p334|T1] The product of more than two sets of brackets
[10889|p334] You can multiply in steps to expand three (or more) sets of brackets. Your answer may contain terms with powers of  $x$  greater than 2.
[10890|p334|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 12
[10891|p334] Expand and simplify  $(3x + 2)(2x + 1)(x - 1)$ .
[10892|p334|T1] Answers
[10893|p334] $$
\begin{array}{l} (3 x + 2) (2 x + 1) (x - 1) \\ = (6 x ^ {2} + 4 x + 3 x + 2) (x - 1) \\ = (6 x ^ {2} + 7 x + 2) (x - 1) \\ = 6 x ^ {3} + 7 x ^ {2}...
[10894|p334] Expand the first two brackets.
[10895|p334] Collect like terms.
[10896|p334] Multiply each term in the first bracket by each term in the second.
[10897|p334] Collect like terms to simplify.

[10965|p335|T1] Squaring a binomial
[10966|p335] $$
(x + y) ^ {2} \text {m e a n s} (x + y) (x + y)
$$
[10967|p335] To find the product, you can use the method you learnt earlier.
[10968|p335] $$
(x + y) (x + y) = x ^ {2} + x y + x y + y ^ {2} = x ^ {2} + 2 x y + y ^ {2}
$$
[10969|p335] However, you should be able to expand by just noticing that:
[10970|p335] the first term is the square of the first term  $(x^{2})$
[10971|p335] the middle term is twice the product of the middle terms  $(2xy)$
[10972|p335] the last term is the square of the last term  $(y^{2})$

[11013|p336|T1] Factorising simple quadratic expressions
[11014|p336] Look again at the expansion of  $(x + 2)(x + 9)$ , which gave  $x^2 + 11x + 18$ :
[11016|p336] Here the two numbers add to give the coefficient of  $x$  in the final expression and the two numbers multiply to give the constant term.
[11017|p336] This works whenever there is just one  $x$  in each bracket.
[11018|p336|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13
[11019|p336] Expand and simplify.
[11020|p336] a  $(x + 6)(x + 12)$
[11021|p336] b  $(x + 4)(x - 13)$
[11022|p336|T1] Answers
[11023|p336] a  $(x + 6)(x + 12) = x^{2} + 18x + 72$
[11024|p336] $6 + 12 = 18$  and  $6 \times 12 = 72$  so this gives  $18x$  and  $72$ .
[11025|p336] b  $(x + 4)(x - 13) = x^{2} - 9x - 52$
[11026|p336] $4 + -13 = -9$  and  $4 \times -13 = -52$  so this gives  $-9x$  and  $-52$ .
[11027|p336] If you use the method in worked example 13 and work backwards you can see how to put a quadratic expression back into brackets. Note that the coeffici...
[11028|p336] Consider the expression  $x^{2} + 18x + 72$  and suppose that you want to write it in the form  $(x + a)(x + b)$ .
[11029|p336] From the worked example you know that  $a + b = 18$  and  $a \times b = 72$ .
[11030|p336] Now  $72 = 1 \times 72$  but these two numbers don't add up to give 18.
[11031|p336] However,  $72 = 6 \times 12$  and  $6 + 12 = 18$ .
[11032|p336] So,  $x^{2} + 18x + 72 = (x + 6)(x + 12)$ .
[11033|p336] The process of putting a quadratic expression back into brackets like this is called factorisation.
[11034|p336|T1] DISCUSSION 1
[11035|p336] Talk to a partner or teacher about why this does not work if there is more than one x in either or both brackets. Try expanding some pairs of brackets...
[11036|p336|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[11037|p336] $1 \times 72$  and  $6 \times 12$  are factor pairs of 72. You learnt about factor pairs in Chapter 1.
[11038|p337|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 14
[11039|p337] Factorise completely:
[11040|p337] a  $x^{2} + 7x + 12$
[11041|p337] b  $x^{2} - 6x - 16$
[11042|p337] $x^{2} - 8x + 15$
[11043|p337] d  $2x^{2} + 14x + 20$
[11044|p337|T1] Answers
[11045|p337] a  $12 = 1\times 12$
[11046|p337] You need two numbers that multiply to give 12 and add to give 7.
[11047|p337] $$
1 2 = 2 \times 6
$$
[11048|p337] These don't add to give 7.
[11049|p337] $$
1 2 = 3 \times 4 \text {a n d} 3 + 4 = 7
$$
[11050|p337] These don't add to give 7.
[11051|p337] $$
S _ {0}, x ^ {2} + 7 x + 1 2 = (x + 3) (x + 4)
$$
[11052|p337] These multiply to give 12 and add to give 7.
[11053|p337] b -8x2=-16and-8+2=-6
[11054|p337] $$
S _ {0}, x ^ {2} - 6 x - 1 6 = (x - 8) (x + 2)
$$
[11055|p337] You need two numbers that multiply to give -16 and add to give -6.
[11056|p337] Since they multiply to give a negative answer, one of the numbers must be negative and the other must be positive. (Since they add to give a negative ...
[11057|p337] c  $-5\times -3 = 15$  and  $-5 + - 3 = -8$
[11058|p337] $$
S _ {0}, x ^ {2} - 8 x + 1 5 = (x - 3) (x - 5)
$$
[11059|p337] You need two numbers that multiply to give 15 and add to give -8. Since they multiply to give a positive value but add to give a negative then both mu...
[11060|p337] d  $2x^{2} + 14x + 20$
[11061|p337] $$
= 2 (x ^ {2} + 7 x + 1 0)
$$
[11062|p337] $$
= 2 (x + 5) (x + 2)
$$
[11063|p337] There is a common factor of 2 in all the terms.
[11064|p337] Remove this then find the factors that give 7 and 10.
[11065|p337] $$
5 \times 2 = 1 0 \text {a n d} 5 + 2 = 7
$$
[11066|p337|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[11067|p337] You have already seen in Chapter 1 that positive whole numbers are either prime or can be written as the product of two or more other numbers. The pro...
[11068|p337|T1] TIP
[11069|p337] List the factor pairs of 12.
[11070|p337] If you spot which pair of numbers works straight away then you don't need to write out all the other factor pairs.)
[11071|p338|T1] Exercise 10.10
[11072|p338] Factorise each of the following.
[11073|p338] a  $x^{2} + 14x + 24$
[11074|p338] b  $x^{2} + 3x + 2$
[11075|p338] $x^{2} + 7x + 12$

[11110|p338] x²-100
[11111|p338|T1] REFLECTION
[11112|p338] When you look for your pair of integers, think about the factors of the constant term first. Then choose the pair that adds up to the  $x$  term in th...
[11113|p338|T1] Difference between two squares
[11114|p338] The very last question in the previous exercise was a special kind of quadratic.
[11115|p338] To factorise  $x^{2} - 100$  you must notice that  $x^{2} - 100 = x^{2} + 0x - 100$ .
[11116|p338] Now, continuing as in Worked example 14:
[11117|p338] $$
1 0 \times - 1 0 = - 1 0 0 \text {a n d} - 1 0 + 1 0 = 0, \text {s o} x ^ {2} + 0 x - 1 0 0 = (x - 1 0) (x + 1 0).
$$
[11118|p338] Now think about a more general case in which you try to factorise  $x^{2} - a^{2}$ .
[11119|p338] Notice that  $x^{2} - a^{2} = x^{2} + 0x - a^{2}$ .
[11120|p338] Since  $a \times -a = -a$  and  $a + -a = 0$ , this leads to:
[11121|p338] $$
x ^ {2} - a ^ {2} = (x - a) (x + a)
$$
[11122|p338] You must remember this special case. This kind of expression is called the difference between two squares
[11123|p338|T1] LINK
[11124|p338] Although the difference between two squares may seem like a very small part of quadratic expressions it is, in fact, a very important one. Beyond Camb...
[11125|p338|T1] TIP
[11126|p338] Note that the difference 'between' two squares can also be called the difference 'of' two squares. It doesn't matter which you use.
[11127|p339|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[11128|p339] Factorise the following using the difference between two squares:
[11129|p339] a  $x^{2} - 49$
[11130|p339] b x²-1 4
[11131|p339] 16y²-25w²
[11132|p339|T1] Answers
[11133|p339] a  $49 = 7^{2}$
[11134|p339] $$
\begin{array}{l} x ^ {2} - 4 9 = x ^ {2} - 7 ^ {2} \\ = (x - 7) (x + 7) \\ \end{array}
$$
[11135|p339] Use the formula for the difference between two squares:
[11136|p339] $$
x ^ {2} - a ^ {2} = (x - a) (x + a).
$$
[11137|p339] You know that  $\sqrt{49} = 7$  so you can write 49 as  $7^{2}$ . This gives you  $a^2$ . Substitute  $7^2$  into the formula.
[11138|p339] b  $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2} = \frac{1}{4}$
[11139|p339] $$
\begin{array}{l} x ^ {2} - \frac {1}{4} = x ^ {2} - \left(\frac {1}{2}\right) ^ {2} \\ = \left(x - \frac {1}{2}\right) \left(x + \frac {1}{2}\right...
[11140|p339] $\sqrt{\frac{1}{4}}$  is  $\frac{1}{2}$  so you can rewrite  $\frac{1}{4}$  as  $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2$
[11141|p339] and substitute it into the formula for the difference between two squares.
[11142|p339] $(4y)^2 = 4y \times 4y = 16y^2$  and
[11143|p339] $$
1 6 y ^ {2} = (4 y) ^ {2}
$$
[11144|p339] $$
(5 w) ^ {2} = 5 w \times 5 w = 2 5 w ^ {2}
$$
[11145|p339] $$
2 5 w ^ {2} = (5 w) ^ {2}
$$
[11146|p339] $$
1 6 y ^ {2} - 2 5 w ^ {2} = (4 y) ^ {2} - (5 w) ^ {2}
$$
[11147|p339] Substitute in  $(4y)^2$  and  $(5w)^2$
[11148|p339] $$
= (4 y - 5 w) (4 y + 5 w)
$$
[11149|p339|T1] Perfect squares
[11150|p339] Consider what happens when you expand expressions of the form  $(a + b)^2$  and  $(a - b)^2$ .
[11151|p339] $$
(a + b) ^ {2} = (a + b) (a + b) = a ^ {2} + 2 a b + b ^ {2}
$$
[11152|p339] $$
(a - b) ^ {2} = (a - b) (a - b) = a ^ {2} - 2 a b + b ^ {2}
$$
[11153|p339] Expressions in the form  $(a + b)^2$  and  $(a - b)^2$  are perfect squares.
[11154|p339] You can use the results of the expansions in reverse to factorise expressions that follow this pattern.
[11155|p339|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 16
[11156|p339] Factorise:
[11157|p339] a  $x^{2} + 8x + 16$
[11158|p339] b  $x^{2} - 10x + 25$
[11159|p339|T1] Answers
[11160|p339] a  $x^{2} + 8x + 16$
[11161|p339] $$
\begin{array}{l} = (x + 4) (x + 4) \\ = (x + 4) ^ {2} \\ \end{array}
$$
[11162|p339] Check for the perfect square pattern.
[11163|p339] Take the root of each square. Note the signs are both positive.
[11164|p339] b  $x^{2} - 10x + 25$
[11165|p339] $$
\begin{array}{l} = (x - 5) (x - 5) \\ = (x - 5) ^ {2} \\ \end{array}
$$
[11166|p339] Check for the perfect square pattern.
[11167|p339] Take the root of each square. Note the signs are both negative.

[11198|p340|T1] Using factors to solve quadratic equations
[11199|p340] You can now use the factorisation method to solve some quadratic equations A quadratic equation is an equation of the form  $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$ . The ...
[11200|p340|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 17
[11201|p340] Solve each of the following equations for  $x$ .
[11202|p340] a  $x^{2} - 3x = 0$
[11203|p340] b  $x^{2} - 7x + 12 = 0$
[11204|p340] $x^{2} + 6x - 4 = 12$
[11205|p340] d  $x^{2} - 8x + 16 = 0$
[11206|p340|T1] Answers
[11207|p340] a  $x^{2} - 3x = 0$
[11208|p340] $$
x (x - 3) = 0
$$
[11209|p340] Now the key point:
[11210|p340] If two or more quantities multiply to give zero, then at least one of the quantities must be zero.
[11211|p340] So either  $x = 0$  or  $x - 3 = 0 \Rightarrow x = 3$ .
[11212|p340] Check:  $0^2 - 3 \times 0 = 0$  (this works).
[11213|p340] $3^{2} - 3 \times 3 = 9 - 9 = 0$  (this also works)
[11214|p340] In fact both  $x = 0$  and  $x = 3$  are solutions.
[11215|p340] b  $x^{2} - 7x + 12 = 0$
[11216|p340] $$
(x - 4) (x - 3) = 0
$$
[11217|p340] Therefore either  $x - 4 = 0 \Rightarrow x = 4$ .
[11218|p340] $$
\text {o r} x - 3 = 0 \Rightarrow x = 3.
$$
[11219|p340] Again, there are two possible values of  $x$ .
[11220|p340] Notice that both terms of the left-hand side are multiples of  $x$  so you can take out a common factor of  $x$ .
[11221|p340] Use the factorisation method of Worked example 14 on the left-hand side of the equation.
[11222|p340|T1] TIP
[11223|p340] Where the numbers are not square, try taking a common factor out first.
[11224|p340|T1] TIP
[11225|p340] When you solve quadratic equations, you should rearrange them so that a zero appears on one side, i.e. so that they are in the form  $ax^2 + bx + c = ...
[11226|p340|T1] TIP
[11227|p340] There are still two solutions here, but they are identical. When a quadratic equation has solutions, there are always two of them, even if they are bo...
[11228|p340] 国国国
[11229|p341|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 17 CONTINUED
[11230|p341] $x^{2} + 6x - 4 = 12$
[11231|p341] $\Rightarrow x^{2} + 6x - 16 = 0$  (subtract 12 from both sides)
[11232|p341] Factorising, you get  $(x + 8)(x - 2) = 0$
[11233|p341] So either  $x + 8 = 0 \Rightarrow x = -8$ .
[11234|p341] or  $x - 2 = 0\Rightarrow x = 2$
[11235|p341] d Factorise  $x^{2} - 8x + 16 = 0$
[11236|p341] to give  $(x - 4)(x - 4) = 0$
[11237|p341] So either  $x - 4 = 0 \Rightarrow x = 4$ .
[11238|p341] or  $x - 4 = 0\Rightarrow x = 4$
[11239|p341] Of course these are both the same thing, so the only solution is  $x = 4$ .
[11240|p341] When you rearrange some equations with fractions you get quadratic expressions and you may have to factorise those find the solutions.
[11241|p341|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18
[11242|p341] Solve the equation  $\frac{x}{x + 3} = \frac{8}{x + 6}$
[11243|p341] $$
x (x + 6) = 8 (x + 3)
$$
[11244|p341] Multiply both sides by  $(x + 6)(x + 2)$
[11245|p341] $$
x ^ {2} + 6 x = 8 x + 2 4
$$
[11246|p341] Expand the brackets. Note there is now a term with  $x^2$ .
[11247|p341] $$
x ^ {2} - 2 x = 2 4
$$
[11248|p341] Subtract 8x from both sides.
[11249|p341] $$
x ^ {2} - 2 x - 2 4 = 0
$$
[11250|p341] Subtract 24 from both sides.
[11251|p341] $$
(x - 6) (x + 4) = 0
$$
[11252|p341] Factorise the quadratic expression.
[11253|p341] Either  $x - 6 = 0 \Rightarrow x = 6$
[11254|p341] Or  $x + 4 = 0\Rightarrow x = -4$

[11284|p342|T1] SUMMARY
[11285|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>Do you know ...?</td></tr>
[11286|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>The equation of a line tells you how the x- and y-coordinates are related for all points that sit on the line.</td></tr>
[11287|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>The gradient of a line is a measure of its steepness.</td></tr>
[11288|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>The x- and y-intercepts are where the line crosses the x- and y-axes respectively.</td></tr>
[11289|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>The value of m in y=mx+c is the gradient of the line.</td></tr>
[11290|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>The value of c in y=mx+c is the y-intercept.</td></tr>
[11291|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>The x-intercept can be found by substituting y=0 and solving for x.</td></tr>
[11292|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>The y-intercept can be found by substituting x=0 and solving for y.</td></tr>
[11293|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>Two lines with the same gradient are parallel.</td></tr>
[11294|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>The gradients of two perpendicular lines multiply to give -1.</td></tr>
[11295|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>Two brackets can be expanded by multiplying each term in the first bracket by each term in the second bracket.</td></tr>
[11296|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>Some quadratic expressions can be factorised to solve quadratic equations.</td></tr>
[11297|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>Sometimes the two solutions of a quadratic equation might be equal.</td></tr>
[11298|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>Are you able to ...?</td></tr>
[11299|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>draw a line from its equation by constructing a table and plotting points</td></tr>
[11300|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>find the gradient, x-intercept and y-intercept from the equation of a line</td></tr>
[11301|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>calculate the gradient of a line from its graph</td></tr>
[11302|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>find the equation of a line if you know its gradient and y-intercept</td></tr>
[11303|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>find the equation of a vertical or horizontal line</td></tr>
[11304|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>calculate the gradient of a line from the coordinates of two points on the line</td></tr>
[11305|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>find the length of a line segment and the coordinates of its midpoint</td></tr>
[11306|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>expand double brackets</td></tr>
[11307|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>expand three or more sets of brackets</td></tr>
[11308|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>factorise a quadratic expression</td></tr>
[11309|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>factorise an expression that is the difference between two squares</td></tr>
[11310|p342] [Table Row] <tr><td>solve a quadratic equation by factorising.</td></tr>

[11375|p346|T1] >Chapter 11
[11376|p346|T1] Pythagoras' theorem and similar shapes
[11377|p346|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[11378|p346] use Pythagoras' theorem to find unknown sides of right-angled triangles

[11384|p346] - recognise similar solids
[11385|p346] calculate the volume and surface area of similar solids
[11386|p346] - recognise whether shapes are congruent or not.

[11425|p348|T1] Learning the rules
[11426|p348] Pythagoras' theorem describes the relationship between the sides of a right-angled triangle.
[11427|p348] The longest side – the side that does not touch the right angle – is known as the hypotenuse.
[11428|p348] For this triangle, Pythagoras' theorem states that  $a^2 + b^2 = c^2$ .
[11429|p348] In words this means that the square on the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares on the other two sides. Notice that the square of the hypoten...
[11432|p348|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[11433|p348] Find the value of  $x$  in each of these triangles. Give your answers to 1 decimal place where appropriate.
[11434|p348] a
[11436|p348] b
[11438|p348|T1] Answers
[11439|p348] a a² + b² = c²
[11440|p348] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 ^ {2} + 5 ^ {2} = x ^ {2} \\ 9 + 2 5 = x ^ {2} \\ \Rightarrow x ^ {2} = 3 4 \\ x = \sqrt {3 4} = 5. 8 3 0 9 \dots \\ \end{array}...
[11441|p348] is approximately equal to  $5.8\mathrm{cm}$  (1 d.p.)
[11442|p348] Round your final answer to 1 decimal place.
[11443|p348] b a² + b² = c²
[11444|p348] $$
\begin{array}{l} 8 ^ {2} + x ^ {2} = 1 7 ^ {2} \\ 6 4 + x ^ {2} = 2 8 9 \\ x ^ {2} = 2 8 9 - 6 4 \\ x ^ {2} = 2 2 5 \\ x = \sqrt {2 2 5} = 1 5 \mat...
[11445|p348] You need to find a shorter side, so rearrange the formula to make  $x^{2}$  the subject.

[11450|p349|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[11451|p349] Use Pythagoras' theorem to decide whether this triangle is right angled.
[11453|p349|T1] Answer
[11454|p349] Check to see if Pythagoras' theorem is satisfied:
[11455|p349] $$
c ^ {2} = a ^ {2} + b ^ {2}
$$
[11456|p349] $$
a ^ {2} + b ^ {2} = 3. 1 ^ {2} + 4. 2 ^ {2} = 2 7. 2 5
$$
[11457|p349] $$
c ^ {2} = 5. 3 ^ {2} = 2 8. 0 9 \neq 2 7. 2 5
$$
[11458|p349] Pythagoras' theorem is not satisfied, so the triangle is not right angled.
[11459|p349|T1] TIP
[11460|p349] Notice here the theorem is written as  $c^2 = a^2 + b^2$ ; you will see it written like this or as  $a^2 + b^2 = c^2$ , but it means the same thing.
[11461|p349|T1] TIP
[11462|p349] The symbol  $\neq$  means 'does not equal'.

[11507|p352|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[11508|p352] Find the distance between the points  $A(3,5)$  and  $B(5,11)$
[11510|p352] Draw a sketch showing the approximate position of points A and B.
[11511|p352] Difference between the  $y$ -coordinates  $= 11 - 5 = 6$
[11512|p352] Difference between the  $x$ -coordinates  $= 5 - 3 = 2$
[11513|p352] $$
\begin{array}{l} A B ^ {2} = 6 ^ {2} + 2 ^ {2} \\ = 3 6 + 4 \\ = 4 0 \\ \end{array}
$$
[11514|p352] $$
\begin{array}{l} A B = \sqrt {4 0} \\ = 6. 3 2 \text {u n i t s} (3 \text {s . f .}) \\ \end{array}
$$
[11515|p352] Find the vertical and the horizontal distances.

[11563|p355|T1] 11.2 Understanding similar triangles
[11564|p355] Two mathematically similar objects have exactly the same shape and proportions, but may be different in size.
[11565|p355] When one shape is enlarged to produce the second shape, each part of the original will correspond to a particular part of the new shape. For triangles...
[11566|p355] All of the following are true for similar triangles:
[11569|p355] Corresponding angles are equal.
[11572|p355] 'Internal' ratios of sides are the same for both triangles. For example:
[11573|p355] $$
\frac {A B}{B C} = \frac {D E}{E F}
$$
[11576|p355] Ratios of corresponding sides are equal:
[11577|p355] $$
\frac {A B}{D E} = \frac {B C}{E F} = \frac {A C}{D F}
$$
[11578|p355] If any of these things are true about two triangles, then all of them will be true for both triangles.
[11579|p355|T1] INVESTIGATION

[11581|p355] You learnt about gradients of lines in Chapter 10.
[11582|p355] 1 Look back at Chapter 10 and use the ideas you learnt to plot the line with equation  $y = 3x - 1$ .
[11583|p355] 2 Mark the points  $A(-1, - 4),B(1,2)$  and  $C(2,5)$  on the line.
[11584|p355] 3 Draw a triangle on your graph, to show the gradient of the line AB and another to show the gradient BC. (Look back to Worked example 3 in Chapter 10...

[11590|p356|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[11591|p356] Explain why the two triangles shown in the diagram are similar and work out the lengths of  $x$  and  $y$ .
[11593|p356|T1] Answer
[11594|p356] Angle ACB = 180° - 27° - 108° = 45°
[11595|p356] Angle FED = 180° - 45° - 108° = 27°
[11596|p356] Both triangles have exactly the same three angles, so they are similar.
[11597|p356] Since the triangles are similar:  $\frac{DE}{AB} = \frac{EF}{BC} = \frac{DF}{AC}$
[11598|p356] So:  $\frac{y}{8} = \frac{18}{6} = 3 \Rightarrow y = 24 \mathrm{~m}$
[11599|p356] and:  $\frac{9}{x} = \frac{18}{6} = 3 \Rightarrow x = 3m$
[11600|p356|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[11601|p356] You learnt that the angle sum in a triangle is always  $180^{\circ}$  in Chapter 3.
[11602|p356|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[11603|p356] The diagram shows a tent that has been attached to the ground using ropes AB and CD. ABF and DCF are straight lines and the sides of the tent BG and C...
[11605|p357|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6 CONTINUED
[11606|p357|T1] Answer
[11607|p357] Consider triangles ABG and AEF:
[11610|p357] Angle BAG = FAE
[11611|p357] Common to both triangles.
[11612|p357] Angle AGB = AEF = 90°
[11613|p357] Angle ABG = AFE
[11614|p357] BG and FE are both vertical, hence parallel lines.
[11615|p357] Angles correspond.
[11616|p357] Therefore triangle ABG is similar to triangle AEF.
[11617|p357] So:  $\frac{\text{height}}{0.9} = \frac{3}{1.2} \Rightarrow \text{height} = \frac{0.9 \times 3}{1.2} = 2.25 \text{m}$

[11672|p360|T1] 11.3 Understanding similar shapes
[11673|p360] In the previous section you worked with similar triangles, but any shapes can be similar. A shape is similar if the ratio of corresponding sides is eq...
[11674|p360] You can use the ratio of corresponding sides to find unknown sides of similar shapes just as you did with similar triangles.
[11675|p360|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[11676|p360] Ahmed has two rectangular flags. One measures  $1000\mathrm{mm}$  by  $500\mathrm{mm}$ , the other measures  $500\mathrm{mm}$  by  $350\mathrm{mm}$ . ...
[11677|p360|T1] Answer
[11678|p360] $$
\frac {1 0 0 0}{5 0 0} = 2 \text {a n d} \frac {5 0 0}{3 5 0} = 1. 4 3
$$
[11679|p360] Work out the ratio of corresponding sides.
[11680|p360] $$
\frac {1 0 0 0}{5 0 0} \neq \frac {5 0 0}{3 5 0}
$$
[11681|p360] The ratio of corresponding sides is not equal, therefore the shapes are not similar.
[11682|p360|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[11683|p360] Given that the two shapes in the diagram are mathematically similar, find the unknown length  $x$ .
[11685|p360|T1] Answer
[11686|p360] Using the ratios of corresponding sides:  $\frac{x}{12} = \frac{20}{8} = 2.5$
[11687|p360] $$
\Rightarrow x = 1 2 \times 2. 5 = 3 0 m
$$

[11725|p362|T1] REFLECTION
[11726|p362] There are two types of similar shape problems:
[11727|p362] problems where you have to prove or decide whether a given set of shapes are similar
[11728|p362] problems where you have to calculate the missing angles and side lengths of similar shapes.
[11729|p362] What do you need to do, or remember, to solve each type of problem?

[11737|p363|T1] Area of similar shapes
[11738|p363] The two shapes in each pair below are similar:
[11743|p363] If you look at the diagrams and the dimensions you can see that there is a relationship between the scale factor for corresponding sides and the area ...
[11744|p363] In similar figures where the ratio of corresponding sides is  $a:b$ , the ratio of areas is  $a^2:b^2$ .
[11745|p363] In other words, scale factor of areas  $=$  (scale factor of lengths)².
[11746|p363|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[11747|p363] These two rectangles are similar. What is the ratio of the smaller area to the larger?
[11750|p363|T1] Answer
[11751|p363] Ratio of sides  $= 18:21 = 6:7$
[11752|p363] Simplify the ratio before squaring it.
[11753|p363] Ratio of areas  $= 6^{2}:7^{2}$
[11754|p363] Square the ratio of lengths.
[11755|p363] $$
= 3 6: 4 9
$$
[11756|p363|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[11757|p363] Similar rectangles ABCD and MNOP have lengths in the ratio 3:5. If rectangle ABCD has an area of  $900\mathrm{cm}^2$ , find the area of MNOP.
[11758|p363|T1] Answer
[11759|p363] Area MNOP  $= \frac{5^2}{3^2}$  Area ABCD
[11760|p363] Square the ratio of lengths.
[11761|p363] $$
\frac {\text {A r e a M N O P}}{9 0 0 \mathrm {c m} ^ {2}} = \frac {2 5}{9}
$$
[11762|p363] Simplify and substitute in any known values.
[11763|p363] Area MNOP = 25/9 × 900
[11764|p363] Solve the equation.
[11765|p363] $$
= 2 5 0 0 \mathrm {c m} ^ {2}
$$
[11766|p363] The area of MNOP is  $2500\mathrm{cm}^2$
[11767|p364|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11
[11768|p364] The shapes below are similar. Given that the area of  $ABCD = 48 \, \text{cm}^2$  and the area of  $PQRS = 108 \, \text{cm}^2$ , find the length of di...
[11771|p364|T1] Answer
[11772|p364] Let the length of the diagonal be  $x$  cm.
[11773|p364] $$
\frac {4 8}{1 0 8} = \frac {x ^ {2}}{1 8 ^ {2}}
$$
[11774|p364] Square the ratio of lengths.
[11775|p364] $$
\frac {4 8}{1 0 8} = \frac {x ^ {2}}{3 2 4}
$$
[11776|p364] $$
\frac {4 8}{1 0 8} \times 3 2 4 = x ^ {2}
$$
[11777|p364] Simplify and solve.
[11778|p364] $$
\begin{array}{l} x ^ {2} = 1 4 4 \\ x = 1 2 \\ \end{array}
$$
[11779|p364] Diagonal AC is 12 cm long.

[11800|p365] 4 If the areas of two similar quadrilaterals are in the ratio 64:9, what is the ratio of matching sides?
[11801|p365|T1] Similar solids
[11802|p365] Three-dimensional shapes (solids) can also be similar.
[11803|p365] Similar solids have the same shape, their corresponding angles are equal and all corresponding linear measures (edges, diameters, radii, heights and s...
[11804|p365] Volume and surface area of similar solids
[11806|p366] The following table shows the side length and volume of each of these cubes.
[11808|p366] Notice that when the side length is multiplied by 2 the volume is multiplied by  $2^{3} = 8$ .
[11809|p366] Here, the scale factor of lengths is 2 and the scale factor of volumes is  $2^3$ .
[11810|p366] Also, when the side length is multiplied by 5 the volume is multiplied by  $5^{3} = 125$ .
[11811|p366] This time the scale factor of lengths is 5 and the scale factor of volumes is  $5^3$ .
[11812|p366] In fact, this pattern is true in the general case:
[11813|p366] Scale factor of volumes  $=$  (scale factor of lengths)
[11814|p366] By considering the surface areas of the cubes you can also see that the rule about the scale factor of areas is still true:
[11815|p366] Scale factor of areas  $=$  (scale factor of lengths)²
[11816|p366] In summary, if two solids  $(A$  and  $B$  ) are similar:
[11817|p366] the ratio of their volumes is equal to the cube of the ratio of corresponding lengths (edges, diameter, radii, heights and slant heights). In other wo...
[11818|p366] the ratio of their surface areas is equal to the square of the ratio of corresponding linear measures. In other words:  $\frac{\text{Surface area } A}...
[11819|p366] The following worked examples show how you can use these scale factors.
[11820|p366|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 12
[11821|p366] The cones shown in the diagram are mathematically similar. The smaller cone has a volume of  $40\mathrm{cm}^3$ . Find the volume of the larger cone.
[11824|p366|T1] Answer
[11825|p366] Scale factor of lengths  $= \frac{12}{3} = 4$ $\Rightarrow$  Scale factor of volumes  $= 4^{3} = 64$
[11826|p366] So the volume of the larger cone  $= 64 \times 40 = 2560 \, \text{cm}^3$ .
[11827|p366|T1] TIP
[11828|p366] Sometimes you are given the scale factor of areas or volumes instead of the scale factor of lengths. You can use square roots or cube roots to find th...
[11829|p367|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13
[11830|p367] The two shapes shown in the diagram are mathematically similar. If the area of the larger shape is  $216\mathrm{cm}^2$ , and the area of the smaller s...
[11832|p367|T1] Answer
[11833|p367] Scale factor of areas  $= \frac{216}{24} = 9$
[11834|p367] $$
\begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow (\text {S c a l e f a c t o r o f l e n g t h s}) ^ {2} = 9 \\ \Rightarrow \text {S c a l e f a c t o r o f l e n g t ...
[11835|p367] $$
\mathrm {S o}: x = 3 \times 1 2 = 3 6 \mathrm {c m}
$$
[11836|p367|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 14
[11837|p367] A shipping crate has a volume of  $2000\mathrm{cm}^3$ . If the dimensions of the crate are doubled, what will its new volume be?
[11838|p367|T1] Answer
[11839|p367] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {\text {O r i g i n a l v o l u m e}}{\text {N e w v o l u m e}} = \left(\frac {\text {o r i g i n a l d i m e n s i o n s}}...
[11840|p368|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[11841|p368] The two cuboids  $A$  and  $B$  are similar. The larger cuboid has a surface area of  $608 \, \text{cm}^2$ . What is the surface area of the smaller c...
[11844|p368|T1] Answer
[11845|p368] $$
\frac {\text {S u r f a c e a r e a} A}{\text {S u r f a c e a r e a} B} = \left(\frac {\text {w i d t h} A}{\text {w i d t h} B}\right) ^ {2}
$$
[11846|p368] $$
\frac {\text {S u r f a c e a r e a A}}{6 0 8} = \left(\frac {5}{8}\right) ^ {2}
$$
[11847|p368] $$
\frac {\text {S u r f a c e a r e a A}}{6 0 8} = \frac {2 5}{6 4}
$$
[11848|p368] $$
\text {S u r f a c e a r e a} A = \frac {2 5}{6 4} \times 6 0 8
$$
[11849|p368] $$
\text {S u r f a c e a r e a} A = 2 3 7. 5 \mathrm {c m} ^ {2}
$$
[11850|p368] Cuboid A has a surface area of  $237.5\mathrm{cm}^2$

[11902|p370|T1] TIP

[11904|p370|T1] TIP
[11905|p370] A cone cut along a plane parallel to its base produces a smaller cone and a solid called a frustum.
[11906|p371|T1] 11.4 Understanding congruence
[11907|p371] Two shapes are congruent if they are the same shape and size.
[11908|p371|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[11909|p371] You will meet rotations and reflections in Chapter 19. When an object is reflected or rotated its shape and size remain unchanged. The resulting objec...
[11910|p371] If two shapes are congruent then:
[11911|p371] corresponding sides are equal in length.
[11912|p371] corresponding angles are equal
[11913|p371] the shapes have the same area.
[11914|p371] Look at these pairs of congruent shapes. The corresponding sides and angles on each shape are marked using the same colours and symbols.
[11919|p371] When you make a congruency statement, you name the shape so that corresponding vertices are in the same order.
[11920|p371] For the shapes above:
[11921|p371] ABCD is congruent to EFGH
[11922|p371] MNOP is congruent to RQTS.

[11929|p372] ii  ${EF}$  ?
[11930|p372] MN?

[11932|p372] i BAG?
[11933|p372] PQR?
[11934|p372] DEF?

[11940|p372] b

[11974|p374|T1] APPLY YOUR SKILLS
[11975|p374] 6 Two people in different parts of a park take a walk. They both walk in a straight line for 1000 metres, then they turn  $110^{\circ}$  right and con...
[11976|p374|T1] SUMMARY
[11977|p374|T1] Do you know ...?
[11978|p374] The longest side of a right-angled triangle is called the hypotenuse.
[11979|p374] The square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the two shorter sides of the triangle.
[11980|p374] Similar shapes have equal corresponding angles and the ratios of corresponding sides are equal.
[11981|p374] If shapes are similar and the lengths of one shape are multiplied by a scale factor of  $n$ :
[11982|p374] then the areas are multiplied by a scale factor of  $n^2$
[11983|p374] and the volumes are multiplied by a scale factor of  $n^3$
[11984|p374] Congruent shapes are exactly equal to each other.
[11985|p374|T1] Are you able to...?
[11986|p374] Use Pythagoras' theorem to find an unknown side of a right-angled triangle.
[11987|p374] use Pythagoras' theorem to solve real-life problems
[11988|p374] decide whether or not two objects are mathematically similar
[11989|p374] Use the fact that two objects are similar to calculate:
[11990|p374] unknown lengths
[11991|p374] areas or volumes
[11992|p374] recognise whether two shapes are congruent or not.

[12037|p377|T1] Chapter 12
[12038|p377|T1] Averages and measures of spread
[12039|p377|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[12040|p377] calculate the mean, median and mode of sets of data
[12041|p377] calculate and interpret the range as a measure of spread
[12042|p377] - interpret the meaning of average and range, and use them to compare sets of data
[12043|p377] - construct and use frequency distribution tables for grouped data
[12044|p377] calculate and work with quartiles
[12045|p377] - divide data into quartiles and calculate the interquartile range
[12046|p377] - identify the modal class from a grouped frequency distribution.
[12047|p378] You can present statistical information in many different ways. If you choose a more complicated method, you increase the chance that another person w...
[12048|p378] You do not always need to draw a diagram. Sometimes you present the information using a numerical summary. In this chapter you will explore different ...
[12049|p378|T1] GETTING STARTED
[12050|p378] Rohan records the number of hours, to the nearest half hour, he spends reading each week for seven weeks:
[12051|p378] 1.5 1.5 2 3.5 5 5.5 11.5
[12052|p378] Roham says to Jessi, "On average, I read for 3.5 hours per week."
[12053|p378] How has Raham worked out 3.5 hours?
[12054|p378] 2 Do you agree with Rohan's claim?
[12055|p378] 3 What information is lost when Roham makes his calculation?
[12056|p378] Jess records how long she spends reading for the next seven weeks:
[12057|p378] 5.5 7 25 -3 7.5 9.5 1
[12058|p378] Jess says to Roham, "On average, I read for 3 hours per week."
[12059|p378] 4 Why is Jess imcorrect?
[12060|p378] 5 What can you do to give a better answer?
[12061|p378] Rohan has made a mistake. His final value should be 14 and not 11.5.
[12062|p378] 6 What will happen to Raham's claim? Why?
[12063|p378] 7 What other ways do you know to calculate averages? Are they useful here?
[12064|p378|T1] 12.1 Different types of average
[12065|p378] The shoe sizes of 19 students in a class are:
[12066|p378] 47667486811686356764
[12067|p378] How would you describe the shape sizes in this class?
[12068|p378] Sometimes you might want to represent a set of data with a single value. When you do this, you use an average value.
[12069|p378] There are three main types of average used in statistics and you can use each of them to describe the shoe sizes for the class.
[12070|p378] The is the value that occurs the most often. If you count how times each shoe size occurs in the class, you will find that the most common (most frequ...
[12071|p378|T1] KEY WORDS
[12072|p378] grouped data
[12073|p378] interquartile range
[12074|p378] lowerquartile
[12075|p378] 作
[12076|p378] median
[12077|p378] modal class
[12078|p378] mode
[12079|p378] range
[12080|p378] upper quartile
[12081|p378|T1] T
[12082|p378] There is more than one "average", so you should never refer to the average.
[12083|p378] Always specify which average you are talking about: the mean, median or mode.
[12084|p379] Another average is the mean. This is the value you get when you add up all the shoe sizes and divide your answer by the number of students:
[12085|p379] $$
\frac {\text {t o t a l o f s h o e s i z e s}}{\text {n u m b e r o f s t u d e n t s}} = \frac {1 1 5}{1 9} = 6. 0 5 (2 \mathrm {d}. \mathrm {p}....
[12086|p379] The mean value tells you that the shoe sizes appear to be distributed in some way around the value 6.05. It also gives you a good impression of the ge...
[12087|p379] The third average is called the median. The median is the middle value when data is arranged in ascending order. So, putting the shoe sizes in order f...
[12088|p379] [Table Row] <tr><td>3</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>4</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>6</td><td>6</td><td>6</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>7</td><td>...
[12089|p379] To find the middle number you can think of the first and last values as one pair and cross them off. Then continue crossing off pairs until you are le...
[12090|p379] [Table Row] <tr><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>...
[12091|p379] For these shoe sizes, the median value is 6.
[12092|p379] Crossing off numbers from each end can be difficult if you have a lot of data. If you count from the left, you find that the median is the 10th value....
[12093|p379] But what if there had been 20 students in the class? For example, if there is an extra student with a shoe size of 11. Crossing off pairs gives this r...
[12094|p379] [Table Row] <tr><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>...
[12095|p379] You are left with a middle pair rather than a single value. If this happens then you need to find the mean of this middle pair:  $\frac{(6 + 6)}{2} = ...
[12096|p379] Notice that the position of the first value in this middle pair is  $\frac{20}{2} = 10$ . If you have an even number of data values, dividing the numb...
[12097|p379] In summary:
[12098|p379] Mode The value that appears in the list more than any other. There can be more than one mode but if there are no values that occur more often than any...
[12099|p379] Mean The value when you calculate total of all data number of values The mean may not be one of the actual data values.
[12100|p379] Median 1 Arrange the data into ascending numerical order.
[12101|p379] 2 If the number of data is  $n$  and  $n$  is odd, find  $\frac{n + 1}{2}$ . This will give you the position of the median.
[12102|p379] 3 If  $n$  is even, then calculate  $\frac{n}{2}$ . This will give you the position of the first of the middle pair. Find the mean of this pair.
[12103|p379|T1] TIP
[12104|p379] If you take the mean of  $n$  items and multiply it by  $n$ , you get the total of all  $n$  values.
[12105|p379] The mean is sometimes referred to as a measure of 'central tendency' of the data.
[12106|p380|T1] LINK
[12107|p380] Many people use averages in their work. Geographers use them to summarise numerical results for large populations, so they don't have to show every pi...
[12108|p380] Medical scientists use means and medians to test whether or not a treatment makes a significant difference to the recovery of patients. They compare t...
[12109|p380] Estate agents often list the median value of property sales in an area because the median price is not influenced by extreme values.
[12111|p380|T1] Dealing with extreme values
[12112|p380] Sometimes your set of data may contain values that are extreme in some way. For example, if you measure the speeds of cars passing a certain point you...
[12113|p380] Imagine these are the speeds (in kilometres per hour) of six cars passing a certain point in a five-minute period:
[12114|p380] 67.2 58.3 128.9 65.0 49.0 55.7
[12115|p380] The value  $128.9\mathrm{km/h}$  seems much faster than any other car. How does this extreme value affect your averages?
[12116|p380] You can check yourself that the mean of the above data including the extreme value is  $70.7\mathrm{km / h}$
[12117|p380] This average is larger than all but one of the values and is not representative of the data. This means that in this situation the mean might be a poo...
[12118|p380] If the extreme value is genuine and you cannot exclude it, then using the median is a better way to represent the main body of data. Start by writing ...
[12119|p380] 49.0 55.7 58.3 65.0 67.2 128.9
[12120|p380] The median is the mean of 58.3 and 65.0. This is 61.7. Notice that if you remove the highest value, the median reduces to 58.3, so this doesn't change...
[12121|p380] There is no mode for these data.
[12122|p380|T1] TIP
[12123|p380] The number of data values is even, so the median is the mean of the 3rd and 4th data points.
[12124|p381|T1] LINK
[12125|p381] Most numerical quantities in physics are predictable, at least approximately, by using mathematical formulae to describe the situation. In these situa...
[12126|p381|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[12127|p381] After six tests, Gad has a mean average score of  $48\%$ . He takes a seventh test and scores  $83\%$ .
[12128|p381] What is Gadl's total score after six tests?
[12129|p381] b What is Gad's mean average score after seven tests?
[12130|p381|T1] Answers
[12131|p381] a Since mean= total of all data number of values
[12132|p381] them, total of all data = mean × number of values
[12133|p381] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 4 8 \times 6 \\ = 2 8 8 \\ \end{array}
$$
[12134|p381] Total of all seven scores  $=$  total of first six plus seventh
[12135|p381] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 2 8 8 + 8 3 \\ = 3 7 1 \\ \end{array}
$$
[12136|p381] $$
m e a m = \frac {371}{7} = 53 \%
$$
[12137|p381|T1] TIP
[12138|p381] You could be asked to give reasons for choosing the mean or median as your average.
[12139|p381|T1] TIP
[12140|p381] This is good example of where you need to think before you conclude that Gad is a typical student (sconing  $53\%$ ). He may have had extra tuition an...

[12163|p382|T1] LINK
[12164|p382] Cricket players often talk about 'batting averages'. These usually refer to the mean number of runs per innings.
[12165|p382] If the mean height of 31 children is  $143.6\mathrm{cm}$ , calculate the sum of the heights used to calculate the mean.
[12166|p382] 7 The mean mass of 12 bags of potatoes is  $2.4\mathrm{kg}$ . If a 13th bag containing  $2.2\mathrm{kg}$  of potatoes is added, what will the new mean...

[12168|p382] 9 Find a set of five numbers with mean five, median four and mode four.

[12171|p382|T1] 12.2 Making comparisons using averages and ranges
[12172|p382] Now you know how to find an average value to represent your data, you can compare two or more sets of data. However, just comparing the averages can s...
[12173|p382] It can also be helpful to know how consistent the data is. You do this by thinking about how scattered – or spread – the values are. A simple measure ...
[12174|p382] Range = largest value - smallest value
[12175|p382|T1] TIP
[12176|p382] Think about whether the player will choose an average that helps them claim they are a good player or an average that is a fair representation of thei...
[12177|p383] The larger the range, the more spread out the data is and the less consistent the values are with one another.
[12178|p383|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[12179|p383] Two groups of athletes want to compare their  $100\mathrm{m}$  sprint times. Each person runs once and records their time in seconds.
[12180|p383] [Table Row] <tr><td>Team Pythagoras</td><td>14.3</td><td>16.6</td><td>14.3</td><td>17.9</td><td>14.1</td><td>15.7</td></tr>
[12181|p383] [Table Row] <tr><td>Team Socrates</td><td>13.2</td><td>16.8</td><td>14.7</td><td>14.7</td><td>13.6</td><td>16.2</td></tr>
[12182|p383] a Calculate the mean 100m time for each team.
[12183|p383] b Which is the smaller mean?
[12184|p383] c What does this tell you about the  $100\mathrm{m}$  times for Team Pythagoras compared to those for Team Socrates?
[12185|p383] d Calculate the range for each team.
[12186|p383] e What does this tell you about the performance of each team?
[12187|p383|T1] Answers
[12188|p383] a Team Pythagoras:
[12189|p383] $$
\text {M e a n} = \frac {1 4 . 3 + 1 6 . 6 + 1 4 . 3 + 1 7 . 9 + 1 4 . 1 + 1 5 . 7}{6} = \frac {9 2 . 9}{6} = 1 5. 4 8 \text {s e c o n d s}
$$
[12190|p383] $$
\text {M e a n} = \frac {1 3 . 2 + 1 6 . 8 + 1 4 . 7 + 1 4 . 7 + 1 3 . 6 + 1 6 . 2}{6} = \frac {8 9 . 2}{6} = 1 4. 8 7 \text {s e c o n d s}
$$
[12191|p383] b Team Socrates have the smaller mean 100m time.
[12192|p383] c The smaller time means that Team Socrates are slightly faster as a team than Team Pythagoras.
[12193|p383] d Team Pythagoras' range  $= 17.9 - 14.1 = 3.8$  seconds Team Socrates' range  $= 16.8 - 13.2 = 3.6$  seconds
[12194|p383] e Team Socrates are slightly faster as a whole and they are slightly more consistent.

[12263|p386|T1] 12.3 Calculating averages and ranges for frequency data
[12264|p386] So far, you have calculated averages for quite small sets of data. When you have larger sets with more than 20 pieces of data, it is better to collect...
[12265|p386|T1] TIP
[12266|p386] Sometimes a frequency distribution table is simply called a frequency distribution.
[12267|p387|T1] Data shown in a frequency distribution table
[12268|p387] If you throw a single dice 100 times, each of the six numbers will appear several times. You can record the number of times each number appears in a t...
[12269|p387] [Table Row] <tr><td>Number showing on the upper face</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td></tr>
[12270|p387] [Table Row] <tr><td>Frequency</td><td>16</td><td>13</td><td>14</td><td>17</td><td>19</td><td>21</td></tr>
[12271|p387|T1] Mean
[12272|p387] To calculate the mean, you first need to find the total of all 100 throws. There are sixteen 1s, which give a subtotal of  $1 \times 16 = 16$ , thirte...
[12273|p387] [Table Row] <tr><td>Number showing on the upper face</td><td>Frequency</td><td>Frequency x number on the upper face</td></tr>
[12274|p387] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>16</td><td>1 x 16 = 16</td></tr>
[12275|p387] [Table Row] <tr><td>2</td><td>13</td><td>2 x 13 = 26</td></tr>
[12276|p387] [Table Row] <tr><td>3</td><td>14</td><td>3 x 14 = 42</td></tr>
[12277|p387] [Table Row] <tr><td>4</td><td>17</td><td>17 x 4 = 68</td></tr>
[12278|p387] [Table Row] <tr><td>5</td><td>19</td><td>19 x 5 = 95</td></tr>
[12279|p387] [Table Row] <tr><td>6</td><td>21</td><td>21 x 6 = 126</td></tr>
[12280|p387] The total of all 100 throws is the sum of all values in this third column:
[12281|p387] $$
\begin{array}{l} \text {T o t a l s c o r e} = 1 6 + 2 6 + 4 2 + 6 8 + 9 5 + 1 2 6 \\ = 3 7 3 \\ \end{array}
$$
[12282|p387] So the mean score per throw  $= \frac{\text{total score}}{\text{total number of throws}} = \frac{373}{100} = 3.73$ .
[12283|p387|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[12284|p387] In Chapter 8 you studied the idea of 'experimental probability'. Notice that you also recorded data in frequency tables, so that you could estimate pr...
[12285|p387|T1] Median
[12286|p387] There are 100 throws, which is an even number, so the median will be the mean of a middle pair. The first of this middle pair is in position  $\frac{1...
[12287|p387] The values are all in order in the table. The first 16 are 1s, the next 13 are 2s and so on. If you add the first three frequencies, you get  $16 + 13...
[12289|p387|T1] TIP
[12290|p387] You can add columns to a table given to you to help organise your calculations. In this case you need to swap the rows and columns to make it easier t...
[12291|p388|T1] Mode
[12292|p388] For the mode you simply need to find the value that has the highest frequency. The number 6 occurs most often (21 times), so 6 is the mode.
[12293|p388|T1] Range
[12294|p388] The highest and lowest values are known, so the range is  $6 - 1 = 5$
[12295|p388|T1] Data organised into a stem-and-leaf diagram
[12296|p388] You can determine averages and the range from stem-and-leaf diagrams.
[12297|p388|T1] Mean
[12298|p388] A stem-and-leaf diagram shows all the data values, so you find the mean by adding all the values and dividing them by the number of values in the same...
[12299|p388|T1] Median
[12300|p388] You can use an ordered stem-and-leaf diagram to find the median. In an ordered stem-and-leaf diagram the leaves for each stem are arranged in order fr...
[12301|p388|T1] Mode
[12302|p388] An ordered stem-and-leaf diagram allows you see which values are repeated in each row. You can compare these to find the mode.
[12303|p388|T1] Range
[12304|p388] You can use the first and last value in an ordered stem-and-leaf diagram to find the range.
[12305|p388] [Table Row] <tr><td>Stem</td><td>Leaf</td><td>Key</td></tr>
[12306|p388] [Table Row] <tr><td>0</td><td>2 5 5 6 6 6 6</td><td rowspan="3">0 | 2 represents 2 customers</td></tr>
[12307|p388] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>1 3 3 5 5 6 7 7</td></tr>
[12308|p388] [Table Row] <tr><td>2</td><td>1</td></tr>
[12309|p388|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[12310|p388] You learnt about stem-and-leaf diagrams in Chapter 4.
[12311|p389|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3 CONTINUED
[12312|p389|T1] Answers
[12313|p389] a The lowest number is 2 and the highest number is 21. The range is  $21 - 2 = 19$  customers.
[12314|p389] b 6 is the value that appears most often.
[12315|p389] c There are 16 pieces of data, so the median is the mean of the 8th and 9th values:
[12316|p389] $$
\frac {(1 1 + 1 3)}{2} = \frac {2 4}{2} = 1 2
$$
[12317|p389] d To calculate the total number of customers, find the sum of all the values. Find the total for each row and combine them to find the overall total:
[12318|p389] Row 1:  $2 + 5 + 5 + 6 + 6 + 6 + 6 = 36$   
Row 2:  $11 + 13 + 13 + 15 + 15 + 16 + 17 + 17 = 117$   
Row 3: 21  
 $36 + 117 + 21 = 174$  customers in ...
[12319|p389] e Mean  $= \frac{\text{sum of data values}}{\text{number of data values}} = \frac{174}{16} = 10.875$  customers per half hour
[12320|p389|T1] In summary:
[12321|p389] Mode The value that has the highest frequency is the mode. If more than one value has the same highest frequency, then there is no single mode.
[12322|p389] Mean total of all data sum of frequency  $\times$  value number of values total frequency
[12323|p389] (Remember to extend the table so that you can fill in a column for calculating frequency  $\times$  value in each case.)
[12324|p389] - Median - If the number of data values is  $n$  and  $n$  is odd, then  $\frac{n + 1}{2}$  gives the position of the median. Add the frequencies unti...
[12325|p389] If  $n$  is even, then  $\frac{n}{2}$  gives the position of the first of the middle pair. Add the frequencies until you reach this position and then ...

[12334|p389] [Table Row] <tr><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>2</td><td>1</td><td>5</td><td>4</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>1</td><td>...

[12382|p391|T1] REFLECTION
[12383|p391] What have you learnt about using averages in real-life situations in this section? Has what you know about averages changed in any way? If so, how?
[12384|p391|T1] 12.4 Estimating the mean and finding the modal class for grouped data
[12385|p391|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[12386|p391] You learnt about discrete, continuous and grouped data in Chapter 4 and you used inequality notation to define the groups. You may find it helpful to ...
[12387|p391|T1] LINK
[12388|p391] Real-world data can involve thousands of data points, so it is clear that grouping data, rather than recording a list of exact values is sensible.
[12389|p391] When a government carries out a national census to collect numerical data about the population, the questions asked often involve ranges of ages, sala...
[12390|p391] When data is grouped in a frequency table you do not have the actual data points, so you have to work with the classes to estimate the mean and mode.
[12391|p391] The following worked example shows how a grouped frequency table is used to find the estimated mean and the modal class
[12392|p392|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[12393|p392] The heights of 100 children were measured in cm and the results recorded in a table.
[12394|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>Height in cm (h)</td><td>Frequency (f)</td></tr>
[12395|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>120 &lt; h ≤ 130</td><td>12</td></tr>
[12396|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>130 &lt; h ≤ 140</td><td>16</td></tr>
[12397|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>140 &lt; h ≤ 150</td><td>38</td></tr>
[12398|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>150 &lt; h ≤ 160</td><td>24</td></tr>
[12399|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>160 &lt; h ≤ 170</td><td>10</td></tr>
[12400|p392] Find:
[12401|p392] a an estimate for the mean height of the children
[12402|p392] b the modal class.
[12403|p392|T1] Answers
[12404|p392] a You don't know any of the children's heights exactly, so you use the midpoint of each class as the best estimate of the height of each child in that...
[12405|p392] Halfway between  $120\mathrm{cm}$  and  $130\mathrm{cm}$  is  $\frac{(120 + 130)}{2} = 125\mathrm{cm}$ .
[12406|p392] A good estimate of the total height of the 12 children in this class is  $12 \times 125$  (frequency  $\times$  midpoint).
[12407|p392] Extend your table to include midpoints and totals for each class:
[12408|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>Height in cm (h)</td><td>Frequency (f)</td><td>Midpoint (x)</td><td>Frequency x midpoint (fx)</td></tr>
[12409|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>120 &lt; h ≤ 130</td><td>12</td><td>125</td><td>12 × 125 = 1500</td></tr>
[12410|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>130 &lt; h ≤ 140</td><td>16</td><td>135</td><td>16 × 135 = 2160</td></tr>
[12411|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>140 &lt; h ≤ 150</td><td>38</td><td>145</td><td>38 × 145 = 5510</td></tr>
[12412|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>150 &lt; h ≤ 160</td><td>24</td><td>155</td><td>24 × 155 = 3720</td></tr>
[12413|p392] [Table Row] <tr><td>160 &lt; h ≤ 170</td><td>10</td><td>165</td><td>10 × 165 = 1650</td></tr>
[12414|p392] An estimate for the mean height of the children is:
[12415|p392] $$
\frac {1 5 0 0 + 2 1 6 0 + 5 5 1 0 + 3 7 2 0 + 1 6 5 0}{1 2 + 1 6 + 3 8 + 2 4 + 1 0} = \frac {1 4 5 4 0}{1 0 0} = 1 4 5. 4 \mathrm {c m}
$$
[12416|p392] b The class with the highest frequency is the modal class. In this case it is the class:  $140 < h \leqslant 150$ .
[12417|p392|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[12418|p392] Histograms provide a clear way of representing grouped data in graphical form. You will study these in Chapter 20.
[12419|p392|T1] TIP
[12420|p392] If a question asks you to explain why your calculations only give an estimate, remember that you don't have the exact data, only frequencies and class...

[12453|p393|T1] TIP
[12454|p393] The symbol  $\Sigma$  is the Greek letter capital 'sigma'. It is used to mean 'sum'. So,  $\Sigma f$  simply means 'the sum of all the frequencies'.

[12479|p394|T1] 12.5 Quartiles
[12480|p394] Quartiles are used to divide a data set into four groups. Quartiles are indicated by the symbols  $Q_{1}$ ,  $Q_{2}$  and  $Q_{3}$ .
[12481|p394] You can use the following rules to estimate the positions of each quartile within a set of  $n$  items of ordered data:
[12482|p395] $$
\begin{array}{l} Q _ {1} = \text {l o w e r q u a r t i l e} = \text {v a l u e i n p o s i t i o n} \frac {1}{4} (n + 1) \\ Q _ {2} = \text {m e d...
[12483|p395] If the position does not turn out to be a whole number, find the mean of the pair of numbers on either side. For example, if the position of the lower...
[12484|p395|T1] Interquartile range
[12485|p395] As with the range, the interquartile range gives a measure of how spread out or consistent the data is. The main difference is that the interquartile ...
[12486|p395] $$
I Q R = Q _ {3} - Q _ {1}
$$
[12487|p395] If one set of data has a smaller IQR than another set, then the first set is more consistent and less spread out. This can be a useful comparison tool...
[12488|p395|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[12489|p395] For each set of data calculate the median, upper quartile, lower quartile and the interquartile range.
[12490|p395] a 13 12 8 6 11 14 8 5 1 10 16 12
[12491|p395] b 14 10 8 19 15 14 9
[12492|p395|T1] Answer
[12493|p395] a First sort the data into ascending order:
[12494|p395] 1568810111212131416
[12495|p395] There are an even number of items (12). So, to find the median, find the mean of the middle pair. The first of the pair is in position  $\frac{12}{2} ...
[12496|p395] Calculate the position of the quartiles:
[12497|p395] $$
\frac {1}{4} (1 2 + 1) = 3. 2 5 \text {a n d} \frac {3}{4} (1 2 + 1) = 9. 7 5
$$
[12498|p395] These are not whole numbers, so the lower quartile is the mean of the 3rd and 4th values, and the upper quartile is the mean of the 9th and 10th value...
[12499|p395] $$
Q _ {1} \frac {(6 + 8)}{2} = 7 \text {a n d} Q _ {3} = \frac {(1 2 + 1 3)}{2} = 1 2. 5
$$
[12500|p395] Then you know that the IQR = 12.5 - 7 = 5.5.
[12501|p395] b The ordered data is:
[12502|p395] 891014141519
[12503|p395] There is an odd number of data values, so the median is in position  $\frac{(7 + 1)}{2} = 4$ . The median is 14.
[12504|p395|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[12505|p395] In Chapter 20 you will learn about cumulative frequency graphs. These allow you to calculate estimates for the median and quartiles when there are too...
[12506|p396|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5 CONTINUED
[12507|p396] There are seven items, so the positions of the quartiles are:  $\frac{1}{4} (7 + 1) = 2$  and  $\frac{3}{4} (7 + 1) = 6$ .
[12508|p396] These are whole numbers so the lower quartile is in position two and the upper quartile is in position six.
[12509|p396] So  $Q_{1} = 9$  and  $Q_{3} = 15$ .
[12510|p396] IQR=15-9=6

[12512|p396] Two companies sell sunflower seeds. In one year, seeds from Allbright produce flowers with a median height of 98 cm and IQR of 13 cm. In the same year...
[12513|p396|T1] Answer
[12514|p396] I would buy Barstows' seeds. Although Allbright sunflowers seem taller (with a higher median) they are less consistent. So, there is a chance of a ver...

[12535|p397|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7 CONTINUED
[12536|p397] a Determine the median for each group.
[12537|p397] b Find the range for:
[12538|p397] i vegetarians
[12539|p397] ii non-vegetarians.
[12540|p397] c Determine the interquartile range for:
[12541|p397] i vegetarians
[12542|p397] ii non-vegetarians.
[12543|p397] d LDL levels of  $<  130$  are desirable, levels of 130-160 are considered borderline high and levels  $>160$  are considered high risk. Using these f...
[12544|p397|T1] Answer
[12545|p397] a The data is already ordered and there are 35 values in each set.
[12546|p397] $$
\frac {1}{2} (3 5 + 1) = 1 8, \text {s o t h e m e d i a n i s t h e 1 8 t h v a l u e}.
$$
[12547|p397] Median  $= 128$  for vegetarians
[12548|p397] ii Median  $= 164$  for non-vegetarians
[12549|p397] b i Range  $= 173 - 90 = 83$  for vegetarians
[12550|p397] ii Range  $= 215 - 112 = 103$  for non-vegetarians
[12551|p397] c Determine the position of  $Q_{1}$  and  $Q_{3}$
[12552|p397] The lower quartile  $= \frac{1}{4} (35 + 1) = 9$ th value
[12553|p397] The upper quartile  $= \frac{3}{4} (35 + 1) = 27$ th value
[12554|p397] IQR = Q3 - Q1 = 142 - 116 = 26 for vegetarians
[12555|p397] ii  $IQR = Q_{3} - Q_{1} = 180 - 145 = 35$  for non-vegetarians.
[12556|p397] d For vegetarians the data is skewed toward the lower levels on the stem- and-leaf diagram. More than half of the values are in the desirable range, w...
[12557|p397] This might suggest that non-vegetarians have higher levels of bad cholesterol in general. However, without considering other risk factors or medical h...

[12625|p400|T1] SUMMARY
[12626|p400|T1] Do you know ...?
[12627|p400] Averages - the mode, median and mean - are used to summarise a collection of data.
[12628|p400] Discrete data can be listed or arranged in a frequency distribution.
[12629|p400] Continuous data can be listed or arranged into groups.
[12630|p400] The mean is affected by extreme data.
[12631|p400] The median is less affected by extreme data.
[12632|p400] The lower quartile  $(Q_{1})$  lies  $25\%$  of the way through the data.
[12633|p400] The upper quartile  $(Q_{1})$  lies  $75\%$  of the way through the data.
[12634|p400] The interquartile range  $(\mathrm{IQR} = \mathrm{Q}_3 - \mathrm{Q}_1)$  gives a measure of how spread out or consistent the central  $50\%$  of the d...
[12635|p400] The range is the difference between the largest and smallest values and also measures spread, but it is affected by extreme values and is used less of...
[12636|p400|T1] Are you able to...?
[12637|p400] calculate the mean, median, mode and range of data given in a list
[12638|p400] calculate the mean, median, mode and range of data given in a frequency distribution and a stem-and-leaf diagram
[12639|p400] calculate an estimate for the mean of grouped data
[12640|p400] find the modal class for grouped data
[12641|p400] compare sets of data using summary averages and-ranges
[12642|p400] find the quartiles of data arranged in order
[12643|p400] find the interquartile range for listed data.

[12648|p400] A final batch of sweets is made, with total weight  $184\mathrm{g}$ , giving an overall mean of  $17.2\mathrm{g}$ . Calculate the number of sweets in ...
[12649|p400] 2 Residents on a Pacific island record how many earth tremors can be felt each year over 18 years. In the first 10 years of records, the mean number o...
[12650|p401] 3 A scientist collects insects in two different places: in the sunlight and in the shade. The stem-and-leaf diagram shows the masses of the bugs.

[12837|p410|T1] Unit 3 Project
[12838|p410|T1] Litov's mean value theorem
[12839|p410] Start with any two numbers, for example 8 and 2.
[12840|p410] Generate a sequence where the next number is the mean of the previous two numbers.
[12841|p410] So the next number is half of  $(8 + 2)$  , and the sequence continues: 8, 2, 5.
[12842|p410] The next number is half of  $(2 + 5)$  , and the sequence continues: 8, 2, 5, 3.5.
[12843|p410] What would happen if you continued this process indefinitely?
[12844|p410] Choose a few pairs of starting numbers and repeat the process.
[12845|p410] Each time, your sequence should get closer and closer to a value which we call the limit.
[12846|p410] Can you find a relationship between your starting numbers and the limit of the sequence they generate?
[12847|p410] Can you explain why this happens?
[12848|p410|T1] Investigate starting with three numbers
[12849|p410] Generate a sequence where the next number is the mean of the previous three numbers.
[12850|p410] - Check you agree that if we start with 4, 1, 10, the next number is 5, and the number after that is  $\frac{16}{3}$ .
[12851|p410] What would happen if you continued this process indefinitely?
[12852|p410] Choose some more sets of three starting numbers.
[12853|p410] Can you find a relationship between your starting numbers and the limit of the sequence they generate?
[12854|p410] Can you explain why this happens?
[12855|p410|T1] GO FURTHER
[12856|p410] Explore what happens when you have  $n$  starting numbers and you generate a sequence where the next number is the mean of the last  $n$  numbers.

[12859|p411|T1] Understanding measurement
[12860|p411|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[12861|p411] learn how to convert between units in the metric system
[12862|p411] - solve problems involving time calculations and timetables
[12863|p411] use a calculator to work out time calculations
[12864|p411] find lower and upper bounds of numbers that are written to a given level of accuracy
[12865|p411] - solve problems involving upper and lower bounds
[12866|p411] - use conversion graphs to change units from one measuring system to another
[12867|p411] use exchange rates to convert currencies.

[12869|p412] All these different measurements mean that lots of small errors can combine to give a large total error, so there is always some uncertainty when tryi...

[12890|p413|T1] LINK
[12891|p413] Centimetres and metres are examples of metric measurements. The table below shows some important conversions.
[12892|p413] [Table Row] <tr><td>Measure</td><td>Units used</td><td>Equivalent to ...</td></tr>

[12913|p413|T1] LINK
[12914|p413] The International System of Units (known as S.I. units, from the French name Système International) is the most commonly accepted and used system for ...
[12915|p413|T1] TIP
[12916|p413] Capacity measures what something can contain, not how much it does contain. For example, a jug with a capacity of 1 litre might be half full and only ...
[12917|p414|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[12918|p414] Express:
[12919|p414] a 5km in cm
[12920|p414] b 3.2cm in m
[12921|p414] 2000000cm² in m².
[12922|p414|T1] Answers
[12923|p414] a  $1\mathrm{km} = 1000\mathrm{m} = 1000\times 100\mathrm{cm} = 100000\mathrm{cm}$
[12924|p414] So.  $5\mathrm{km} = 5\times 100000\mathrm{cm} = 500000\mathrm{cm}$
[12925|p414] b  $100\mathrm{cm} = 1\mathrm{m}$  so  $1\mathrm{cm} = 0.01\mathrm{m}$
[12926|p414] So,  $3.2\mathrm{cm} = 3.2 \times 0.01 = 0.032\mathrm{m}$
[12927|p414] $1\mathrm{m}^2 = 100\mathrm{cm}\times 100\mathrm{cm} = 10000\mathrm{cm}^2$
[12928|p414] So,  $2000000\mathrm{cm}^2 = \frac{2000000}{10000} = 200\mathrm{m}^2$

[12931|p414] 4kg (g)
[12932|p414] b 5km (m)
[12933|p414] 35mm (cm)
[12934|p414] d 81 mm (cm)

[12936|p414] f 5760kg(t)
[12937|p414] g 2.1 m (cm)
[12938|p414] 2t (kg)
[12939|p414] 140cm(m)
[12940|p414] 2024g(kg)
[12941|p414] 121mg (g)
[12942|p414] 23m (mm)
[12943|p414] m 3cm 5mm (mm)
[12944|p414] 8km36m(m)
[12945|p414] 9g77mg(g)

[12996|p416|T1] 13.2 Time
[12997|p416] You have already learnt how to tell the time and you should know how to read and write time using the 12-hour and 24-hour systems.
[12998|p416|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[12999|p416] Sara left home at 2.15 p.m. and returned at 3.50 p.m. How long was Sara away from home?
[13000|p416|T1] Answer
[13001|p416] From 2.15p.m. to 3.00p.m. is 45 minutes Start by counting on to the next  
From 3.00p.m. to 3.50p.m. is 50 minutes whole hour.
[13002|p416] 45 + 50 = 95 minutes Add together the times in minutes.
[13003|p416] = 1 hour and 35 minutes Convert to hours and minutes.
[13004|p416|T1] INVESTIGATION
[13005|p416|T1] Babylonian mathematics
[13006|p416] It may seem strange to have 60 as the number for converting units of time. This choice seems to have been made by the ancient Babylonians. They used 6...
[13007|p416] 1 Find all of the factors of the number 60.
[13008|p416] 2 Our decimal system is useful because we have 10 fingers and thumbs on our hands, divided into 2 lots of 5. Look at the factors of 60 and carry out s...
[13009|p416] 3 The Babylonians also seem to be the reason why we have 360 degrees in a full circle. What unit of time do you know that is divided into just over 36...
[13010|p416] The next example shows you how to calculate the duration of an event.
[13012|p417|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[13013|p417] A train leaves at 05:35 and arrives at 18:20. How long is the journey?
[13014|p417|T1] Answers
[13015|p417] You cannot simply calculate 18:20 - 05:35 because this does not take into account that time is not decimal. You can use the degrees, minutes and secon...
[13016|p417] Enter 18
[13017|p417] Press DMS
[13018|p417] Enter 20
[13019|p417] Press DMS
[13020|p417] Press the -key to subtract.
[13021|p417] Enter 5
[13022|p417] Press DMS
[13023|p417] Enter 35
[13024|p417] Press DMS
[13025|p417] Press
[13026|p417] The display will show  $12^{\circ}45'00''$
[13027|p417] Write this as 12 hours and 45 minutes.
[13028|p417|T1] TIP
[13029|p417] Calculators work differently, so learn how the time functions work on your calculator. Try to use your calculator to get the same answers as in the wo...
[13030|p417] The methods you have seen in the examples so far are best used when you are dealing with time within the same day. But what happens when the time diff...
[13031|p417|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[13032|p417] How much time passes from 19:35 on Monday to 03:55 on Tuesday?
[13033|p417|T1] Answer
[13034|p417] 19:35 to 24:00 is one part and 00:00 to 03:55 the next day is the other part.
[13035|p417] A good way to start this problem is to divide the time into parts.
[13036|p417|T1] Part one:
[13037|p417] 19:35 to 20:00 is 25 minutes  
20:00 to 24:00 is 4 hours  
So, 19:35 to 24:00 is 4 h 25 min
[13038|p417] Work out how much time passes to reach midnight.
[13039|p417|T1] Part two:
[13040|p417] 0:00 to 03:55 is 3 h 55 min
[13041|p417] 03:55 is 3 hours and 55 minutes past midnight.
[13042|p417] 4h 25min + 3h 55min = 7h 80min = 8h 20min
[13043|p417] Add the result of the two parts together.
[13044|p417] The total time is 8 hours and 20 minutes.
[13045|p417] 80 minutes = 1 hour 20 minutes
