[13126|p420|T1] 13.3 Limits of accuracy - upper and lower bounds
[13127|p420] Measurements are always given to a certain level of accuracy. The limits of accuracy of any measurement depends on the instruments used to measure it,...
[13129|p421|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[13130|p421] You learnt to round numbers in Chapter 1. Make sure that you remember how rounding works before continuing with this section.
[13131|p421] The way we round numbers means that all measurements have to be between certain limits. These limits depend on the level of accuracy that was used to ...
[13132|p421] The smallest value a measurement can take is called the lower bound. The greatest value it can take is called the upper bound. The difference between ...
[13133|p421] Read through the next example to see how these bounds apply in real life.
[13134|p421] Raeman operates a crane at a building site. The manufacturer states that the crane can safely lift a maximum of 6.2 tonnes. Raeman needs to move some ...
[13135|p421] But, the mass of the blocks has been rounded to 1 decimal place. What if the blocks all weigh 1.245 tonnes? They all round to 1.2 tonnes to 1 decimal ...
[13136|p421] $5 \times 1.245 = 6.225$  tonnes.
[13137|p421] This is more than the crane can lift safely.
[13138|p421] How can Raeman work out the maximum number of blocks he can lift safely?
[13140|p421|T1] LINK
[13141|p421] The Hubble Space Telescope, launched into space in 1990, was originally made with a  $1\mathrm{mm}$  error in the shape of the lens. This caused many ...
[13143|p421|T1] Finding the greatest and least possible values of a rounded measurement
[13144|p421] In the crane example 1.2 tonnes is rounded to 1 decimal place. It can be useful to work out the greatest and least possible values of the actual measu...
[13145|p421] If you place 1.2 on a number line, you can see much more clearly what the range of possible values are:
[13147|p421] At the upper end, the range of possible values stops at 1.25. If you round 1.25 to 1 decimal place you get 1.3. Although 1.25 does not round to 1.2 (t...
[13148|p422] it is still used as the upper value. However, you should understand that the actual value can be anything up to but not including 1.25. The largest po...
[13149|p422|T1] TIP
[13150|p422] To find the limits think about what 1 decimal place means. One decimal place is 0.1. If you divide 0.1 by 2 you get 0.05. Add 0.05 to find the upper l...
[13151|p422] $$
1. 1 5 <   \frac {+ 0 . 0 5}{1 . 2} \frac {+ 0 . 0 5}{1 . 2} <   1. 2 5
$$
[13152|p422] If  $m$  represents the mass (in tonnes) of the block, then you can express the error interval as:
[13153|p422] $$
1. 1 5 \leqslant m <   1. 2 5
$$
[13154|p422] This is called inequality notation and it shows that the true value of  $m$  lies between 1.15 (including 1.15) and 1.25 (not including 1.25).
[13155|p422|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[13156|p422] Find the upper and lower bounds of the following, taking into account the level of rounding shown in each case.
[13157|p422] a  $10\mathrm{cm}$  to the nearest cm
[13158|p422] b 22.5, to 1 decimal place
[13159|p422] c 128000,to 3 significant figures
[13160|p422] d 120, to the nearest 20
[13161|p422|T1] Answers
[13162|p422] a Show  $10\mathrm{cm}$  on a number line. The real value will be closest to  $10\mathrm{cm}$  if it lies between the lower bound of  $9.5\mathrm{cm}$...
[13163|p422] b Look at 22.5 on a number line. The real value will be closest to 22.5 if it lies between the lower bound of 22.45 and the upper bound of 22.55.
[13164|p422] 128000 is shown on a number line. 128000 lies between the lower bound of 127500 and the upper bound of 128500.
[13165|p422] 120 is shown on a number line. 120 lies between the lower bound of 110 and the upper bound of 130.
[13170|p423|T1] Exercise 13.4

[13173|p423] b 8
[13174|p423] c 100
[13175|p423] d 9
[13176|p423] e 72

[13180|p423] b 34.4
[13181|p423] c 5.0
[13182|p423] d 1.1
[13183|p423] e -2.3
[13184|p423] f -7.2

[13187|p423] b 300 (nearest one hundred)
[13188|p423] 405 (nearest five)

[13195|p423] j 0.134 (3 s.f.)
[13196|p423|T1] APPLY YOUR SKILLS

[13199|p423] 5 In a race, Nomatyala ran  $100\mathrm{m}$  in 15.3 seconds. The distance is correct to the nearest metre and the time is correct to 1 decimal place....
[13200|p423] a the actual distance Nomatyala ran
[13201|p423] b the actual time taken.
[13202|p423] 6 The length of a piece of thread is  $4.5\mathrm{m}$  to the nearest  $10\mathrm{cm}$ . The actual length of the thread is  $L\mathrm{cm}$ . Find the...
[13203|p423|T1] Problem-solving with upper and lower bounds
[13204|p423] Some calculations use more than one rounded value. You can use the upper and lower bounds of each value to find the upper and lower bounds for the cal...
[13205|p423|T1] TIP
[13206|p423] If you get confused when dealing with upper and lower bounds, draw a number line to help you.
[13207|p424|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[13208|p424] The dimensions of a rectangular rug are given as  $14\mathrm{m}\times 2\mathrm{m}$  correct to the nearest metre.
[13209|p424] Find the greatest and smallest values for the area of this rug.
[13210|p424|T1] Answer
[13211|p424] $13.5\leq L <   14.5$
[13212|p424] Find the upper and lower bounds of each measurement.
[13213|p424] $1.5 \leqslant W < 2.5$
[13214|p424] Smallest possible area:
[13215|p424] $13.5 \times 1.5 = 20.25 \mathrm{~m}^{2}$
[13216|p424] Multiply the lower bounds of the measurements to find the smallest possible area.
[13217|p424] Greatest possible area:
[13218|p424] $14.5 \times 2.5 = 36.25 \mathrm{~m}^{2}$
[13219|p424] Multiply the upper bounds of the measurements to find the greatest possible area.
[13220|p424|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[13221|p424] An antelope runs across a riverbed that is  $380\mathrm{m}$  wide (to the nearest 10 metres) at a speed of 3.9 metres per second (to 1 decimal place)....
[13222|p424|T1] Answer
[13223|p424] Start by finding the upper and lower bounds of each measurement.
[13224|p424] Draw a two-way table to relate the measurements.
[13225|p424] Divide the distance in each column by each speed.
[13226|p424] [Table Row] <tr><td>Speed\Distance</td><td>375</td><td>385</td></tr>
[13227|p424] [Table Row] <tr><td>3.85</td><td>97.40</td><td>100</td></tr>
[13228|p424] [Table Row] <tr><td>3.95</td><td>94.94</td><td>97.47</td></tr>
[13229|p424] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr>
[13230|p424] The greatest possible time is 100 seconds. The least possible time is 94.94 seconds (correct to 2 decimal places).
[13231|p424|T1] TIP
[13232|p424] $$
\text {T i m e} = \frac {\text {d i s t a n c e}}{\text {s p e e d}}
$$
[13233|p425|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[13234|p425] If  $a = 3.6$  (to 1 d.p.) and  $b = 14$  (to the nearest whole number), find the upper and lower bounds for each of the following:
[13235|p425] a a+b
[13236|p425] b ab
[13237|p425] c b-a
[13238|p425] d  $\frac{a}{b}$
[13239|p425] a+b
[13240|p425|T1] Answers
[13241|p425] First, find the upper and lower bounds of  $a$  and  $b$ :
[13242|p425] $$
3. 5 5 \leqslant a <   3. 6 5 \text {a n d} 1 3. 5 \leqslant b <   1 4. 5
$$
[13243|p425] a Upper bound for  $(a + b) =$  upper bound of  $a +$  upper bound of  $b$
[13244|p425] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 3. 6 5 + 1 4. 5 \\ = 1 8. 1 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13245|p425] Lower bound for  $(a + b) =$  lower bound for  $a +$  lower bound for  $b$
[13246|p425] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 3. 5 5 + 1 3. 5 \\ = 1 7. 0 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13247|p425] You can write this as:  $17.05 \leqslant (a + b) < 18.15$
[13248|p425] b Upper bound for ab = upper bound for a  $\times$  upper bound for b
[13249|p425] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 3. 6 5 \times 1 4. 5 \\ = 5 2. 9 2 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13250|p425] Lower bound for  $ab =$  lower bound of  $a \times$  lower bound of  $b$
[13251|p425] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 3. 5 5 \times 1 3. 5 \\ = 4 7. 9 2 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13252|p425] You can write this as:  $47.925 \leqslant ab < 52.925$
[13253|p425] c Think carefully about  $b - a$  .To find the upper bound you need to subtract the smallest possible number from the largest possible number. So:
[13254|p425] Upper bound for  $(b - a) =$  upper bound for  $b -$  lower bound for a
[13255|p425] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 1 4. 5 - 3. 5 5 \\ = 1 0. 9 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13256|p425] For the lower bound, subtract the largest possible number from the smallest possible number:
[13257|p425] Lower bound for  $(b - a) =$  lower bound for  $b$  - upper bound for a
[13258|p425] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 1 3. 5 - 3. 6 5 \\ = 9. 8 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13259|p425] You can write this as:  $9.85 \leqslant (b - a) < 10.95$
[13260|p425] d To find the upper bound of  $\frac{a}{b}$  you need to divide the largest possible value of  $a$  by the smallest possible value of  $b$ :
[13261|p425] $$
\text {U p p e r b o u n d} = \frac {\text {u p p e r b o u n d f o r a}}{\text {l o w e r b o u n d f o r b}} = \frac {3 . 6 5}{1 3 . 5} = 0. 2 7 ...
[13262|p425] $$
\text {L o w e r b o u n d} = \frac {\text {l o w e r b o u n d f o r} a}{\text {u p p e r b o u n d f o r} b} = \frac {3 . 5 5}{1 4 . 5} = 0. 2 4 ...
[13263|p425] You can write this as:  $0.245 \leq \frac{a}{b} < 0.270$
[13264|p426|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8 CONTINUED
[13265|p426] e Upper bound of  $= \frac{a + b}{a} = \frac{\text{upper bound for } a + b}{\text{lower bound for } a} = \frac{18.15}{3.55}$
[13266|p426] $$
= 5. 1 1 2 6 \dots = 5. 1 1 (3 \mathrm {s}. \mathrm {f})
$$
[13267|p426] Lower bound of  $= \frac{a + b}{a} = \frac{\text{lower bound for } a + b}{\text{upper bound for } a} = \frac{17.05}{3.65}$
[13268|p426] $$
= 4. 6 7 1 2 \dots = 4. 6 7 (3 \mathrm {s}. \mathrm {f}.)
$$
[13269|p426] You can write this as:  $4.67 \leq \frac{a + b}{a} < 5.11$
[13270|p426|T1] REFLECTION
[13271|p426] Do you think the worked examples have improved your skills in working with upper and lower bounds? Explain why or why not.
[13272|p426] Are there any ideas that you are still not sure about? If so, what can you do to develop more confidence in this topic?

[13282|p426] a C h d b

[13284|p426] j dc-√b

[13329|p428] Measurements are not ever exact.

[13332|p428] When you use approximate measurements in calculations you combine small errors to get a bigger error and the answer will be less accurate than if you ...

[13338|p429|T1] 13.4 Conversion graphs
[13339|p429] So far in this chapter, you have seen that it is possible to convert between different units in the metric system. Another measuring system is the imp...
[13340|p429] You can use conversion graphs when you need to convert from one measurement to another, for example from miles (imperial) to kilometres (metric) or fr...
[13341|p429] Eight kilometres is approximately equal to five miles.
[13342|p429] If you travel no distance in kilometres then you also travel no distance in miles.
[13343|p429] These two facts mean you can draw a graph for converting between miles and kilometres.
[13344|p429] If you extend the line far enough you can read higher values. Notice, for example, that the line passes through the point with coordinates (25, 40). T...
[13346|p429|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[13347|p429] You learned about line graphs and how to draw them in Chapter 4.
[13348|p429|T1] LINK
[13349|p429] Imperial units are still used in some countries. For example, the United States and United Kingdom often give road distances in miles and speed limits...
[13350|p430] Check for yourself that you can see that the following are true:
[13351|p430] 10 miles is roughly  $16\mathrm{km}$
[13352|p430] 12 miles is roughly  $19\mathrm{km}$
[13353|p430] $20\mathrm{km}$  is roughly 12.5 miles, and so on.

[13412|p433|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[13413|p433] Convert £50 into Botswanaan pula, given that £1 = 15.63 pula.
[13414|p433|T1] Answer
[13415|p433] $$
\begin{array}{l} £ 1 = 1 5. 6 3 \text {p u l a} \\ £ 5 0 = 1 5. 6 3 \text {p u l a} \times 5 0 = 7 8 1. 5 0 \text {p u l a} \\ \end{array}
$$
[13416|p433|T1] TIP
[13417|p433] You can write currency exchange rates using ratios, For example:
[13418|p433] British pounds : Botswana pula = 1 : 15.63
[13419|p433] Botswanaan pula : British pounds = 1 :  $\frac{1}{15.63}$
[13420|p433|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10

[13423|p433] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 7. 6 3 \text {p e s o s} = £ 1 \\ \text {S o} 1 \text {p e s o} = £ \frac {1}{2 7 . 6 3} \\ 8 0 3 \text {p e s o s} = £ \frac {1...
[13424|p433|T1] LINK
[13425|p433] Currency conversion rates change constantly. You can find up-to-date conversion factors as well as currency conversion apps and calculators on the int...

[13449|p434|T1] SUMMARY
[13450|p434|T1] Do you know ...?
[13451|p434] There are several measuring systems; the most common are metric and imperial.
[13452|p434] Time is measured in different units, so you have to consider the conversion factors when you work with time.
[13453|p434] Every measurement quoted to a given accuracy has a lower bound and an upper bound. The actual value of a measurement is greater than or equal to the l...
[13454|p434] You can draw a graph to help convert between different systems of units.
[13455|p434] Countries use different currencies and you can convert between them if you know the exchange rate.

[13548|p438|T1] Chapter 14
[13549|p438|T1] Further solving of equations and inequalities
[13550|p438|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[13551|p438] - derive and solve simultaneous linear equations graphically and algebraically
[13552|p438] use number lines to represent and interpret inequalities
[13553|p438] - solve linear inequalities algebraically
[13554|p438] - derive linear inequalities and find regions in a plane
[13555|p438] - solve quadratic equations by completing the square
[13556|p438] - solve quadratic equations by using the quadratic formula
[13557|p438] factorise quadratics where the coefficient of  $x^{2}$  is not 1
[13558|p438] - simplify algebraic fractions.
[13559|p439] Think about a number of boats leaving and entering a port. They are all on separate paths and there are no markings in the ocean to guide them. Unders...
[13560|p439] Think about how to work out where a ship is at any given time. What do you need to know? Why is this more complicated than a problem with two cars mov...
[13561|p439|T1] GETTING STARTED
[13562|p439] 1 In this chapter you need to be good at plotting straight lines from their equations. Draw a pair of axes, with  $x$ -values from -2 to 6 and  $y$ -v...

[13565|p439] $$
\begin{array}{l} y = 1 \\ x = 4 \\ 3 x + 2 y = 8 \\ \end{array}
$$

[13570|p439|T1] 14.1 Simultaneous linear equations
[13571|p439|T1] Graphical solution of simultaneous linear equations
[13572|p439] Miguel enjoys walking and has two favourite walks. One is into the hills and is  $4\mathrm{km}$  long. The other is along the river and is  $2\mathrm{...
[13573|p439|T1] KEY WORDS
[13574|p439] completing the square
[13575|p439] linear inequalities
[13576|p439] region
[13577|p439] simultaneous
[13578|p439|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[13579|p439] You studied equations of straight lines in Chapter 10 and you already know how to solve equations with one unknown.
[13580|p440] If you let  $x$  be the number of walks into the hills and  $y$  be the number of walks along the river, you can use the total number of walks to see ...
[13581|p440] The total distance walking in the hills will be  $x \times 4 = 4x$  and the total distance walking along the river will be  $y \times 2 = 2y$ . So the...
[13582|p440] This gives two equations:
[13583|p440] $$
x + y = 8
$$
[13584|p440] $$
4 x + 2 y = 2 6
$$
[13585|p440] The information has two unknown values and you can use it to form two different equations. The equations are both linear equations and you can plot th...
[13587|p440] Notice that the point with coordinates (5, 3) lies on both lines so,  $x = 5$  and  $y = 3$  satisfy both equations. You can check this by substitutin...
[13588|p440] $$
x + y = 5 + 3 = 8
$$
[13589|p440] and
[13590|p440] $$
4 x + 2 y = 4 (5) + 2 (3) = 2 0 + 6 = 2 6
$$
[13591|p440] This means that there were five walks into the hills and three walks by the river.
[13592|p440|T1] TIP
[13593|p440] It is important that you remember to work out both unknowns. Every pair of simultaneous linear equations will have a pair of solutions.
[13594|p440|T1] TIP
[13595|p440] Simultaneous means, 'at the same time'. When you draw graphs of simultaneous linear equations you are looking for the point where two lines cross. The...
[13596|p441|T1] LINK
[13597|p441] Many problems in economics involve formulae containing several variables. When we try to answer financial questions – for example finding when a busin...
[13598|p441|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[13599|p441] By drawing the graphs of each of the following equations on the same pair of axes, find the simultaneous solutions to the equations.
[13600|p441] $$
\begin{array}{l} x - 3 y = 6 \\ 2 x + y = 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13601|p441|T1] Answer
[13603|p441] For the first equation:
[13604|p441] $$
\begin{array}{l} i f x = 0, - 3 y = 6 \Rightarrow y = - 2 \\ a n d, i f y = 0, x = 6 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13605|p441] So this line passes through the points  $(0, -2)$  and  $(6, 0)$ .
[13606|p441] For the second equation:
[13607|p441] $$
i f x = 0, y = 5
$$
[13608|p441] $$
\text {a n d , i f} y = 0, 2 x = 5 \Rightarrow x = \frac {5}{2}
$$
[13609|p441] So this line passes through the points (0, 5) and  $\left(\frac{5}{2}, 0\right)$ .
[13610|p441] Plot the pairs of points and draw lines through them.
[13611|p441] Notice that the two lines meet at the point with coordinates  $(3, -1)$ .
[13612|p441] So, the solution to the pair of equations is  $x = 3$  and  $y = -1$ .
[13613|p441|T1] Exercise 14.1
[13614|p441] 1 Draw the lines for each pair of equations and then use the point of intersection to find the simultaneous solution. The axes that you should use are...
[13615|p441] a  $x + 2y = 11$
[13616|p441] $$
2 x + y = 1 0
$$
[13617|p441] (x from 0 to 11 and y from 0 to 10)
[13618|p441] b  $x - y = -1$
[13619|p441] $$
2 x + y = 4
$$
[13620|p441] (x from -2 to 3 and  $y$  from 0 to 4)
[13621|p441] 5x-4y=-1
[13622|p441] $$
2 x + y = 1 0
$$
[13623|p441] (x from -1 to 5 and y from 0 to 10)

[13649|p442] 4 a Explain why the graphical method does not always give an accurate and correct answer.
[13650|p442] b How can you check whether a solution you obtained graphically is correct or not?
[13651|p442|T1] INVESTIGATION
[13652|p442] When is there a solution?
[13653|p442] $$
3 x + 2 y = 7
$$
[13654|p442] $$
6 x + 4 y = - 2
$$
[13655|p442] 1 Plot the following lines on the same pair of axes:
[13656|p442] 2 Why is it not possible to solve these equations simultaneously?
[13657|p442] 3 Is there any way that you can tell, from the equations, that there are no solutions?
[13658|p442] 4 (Challenge!) If you have the following pair of equations, what needs to be true for there to be a solution?
[13659|p442] $$
\begin{array}{l} a x + b y = 3 \\ c x + d y = 4 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13660|p443|T1] Algebraic solution of simultaneous linear equations
[13661|p443] The graphical method for solving simultaneous equations is suitable for whole number solutions but it can be slow and, for non-integer solutions, may ...
[13662|p443] You are going to learn two methods of solving simultaneous equations:
[13663|p443] - solving by substitution
[13664|p443] - solving by elimination.
[13665|p443|T1] Solving by substitution
[13666|p443] You can solve simultaneous equations by substitution by writing one of the equations in the form  $y = \ldots$  or  $x = \ldots$  and substituting int...
[13667|p443|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[13668|p443] Solve simultaneously by substitution.
[13669|p443] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 x - 2 y = 2 9 (1) \\ 4 x + y = 2 4 (2) \\ \end{array}
$$
[13670|p443|T1] Answer
[13671|p443] $$
\begin{array}{l} 4 x + y = 2 4 \\ y = 2 4 - 4 x \tag {3} \\ \end{array}
$$
[13672|p443] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 x - 2 y = 2 9 \tag {1} \\ 3 x - 2 (2 4 - 4 x) = 2 9 \\ 3 x - 4 8 + 8 x = 2 9 \\ 3 x + 8 x = 2 9 + 4 8 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13673|p443] $$
\begin{array}{l} 1 1 x = 7 7 \\ x = 7 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13674|p443] $$
\mathrm {S o}, x = 7
$$
[13675|p443] $$
\begin{array}{l} y = 2 4 - 4 (7) \\ y = 2 4 - 2 8 \\ y = - 4 \\ x = 7 \text {a n d} y = - 4 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13676|p443] Solve equation [2] for  $y$ .
[13677|p443] Label the new equation [3].
[13678|p443] [1]
[13679|p443] Substitute [3] into [1] by replacing  $y$  with  $24 - 4x$
[13680|p443] Remove brackets.
[13681|p443] Add 48 to both sides.
[13682|p443] Add like terms.
[13683|p443] Divide both sides by 11.
[13684|p443] Now, substitute the value of  $x$  into any of the
[13685|p443] Equations to find  $y$ . Equation [3] will be easiest,
[13686|p443] so use this one.
[13687|p443] Write out the solutions.
[13688|p443|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[13689|p443] The substitution method involves rearranging formulae to make one of the variables the subject. You learnt how to do this in Chapter 6.
[13690|p443|T1] TIP
[13691|p443] You should always number the
[13692|p443] equations so you
[13693|p443] can identify each
[13694|p443] equation quickly
[13695|p443] and easily.
[13696|p444|T1] Solving by elimination
[13697|p444] You can also solve simultaneous equations by eliminating (getting rid of) one of the variables.
[13698|p444|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[13699|p444] Solve the following pair of equations using elimination:
[13700|p444] $$
x - y = 4 \tag {1}
$$
[13701|p444] $$
x + y = 6 \tag {2}
$$
[13702|p444|T1] Answer
[13703|p444] $x - y = 4$  [1] You can add the two equations together by adding the  $x + y = 6$  [2] left-hand sides and adding the right-hand sides.
[13704|p444] $$
2 x = 1 0
$$
[13705|p444] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 x = 1 0 \\ \Rightarrow x = \frac {1 0}{2} \\ x = 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13706|p444] Notice that the equation that comes from this addition no longer contains a  $y$  term, so you can now solve to find the value of  $x$ .
[13707|p444] $x + y = 6$  [2] You now need to find the  $y$  -value that goes with this  $5 + y = 6$  value of  $x$  .Substitute  $x$  into equation [2].
[13708|p444] $$
y = 1
$$
[13709|p444] $x - y = 5 - 1 = 4$  Check that these values for  $x$  and  $y$  work in equation [1].
[13710|p444] Both equations are satisfied by the pair of values  $x = 5$  and  $y = 1$
[13711|p444] The following worked examples look at different cases where you may need to subtract the equations, instead of adding, or where you need to multiply o...
[13712|p444|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[13713|p444] Solve the following pairs of simultaneous equations:
[13714|p444] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 x - 3 y = - 8 \quad [ 1 ] \\ 5 x + 3 y = 1 \tag {2} \\ \end{array}
$$
[13715|p444|T1] Answer
[13716|p444] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 x - 3 y = - 8 \\ 5 x + 3 y = 1 \\ 7 x = - 7 [ 1 ] + [ 2 ] \\ \Rightarrow x = - 1 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13717|p444] Notice that both equations have the same coefficient of  $y$  though the signs are different. If you add the equations together, you make use of the f...
[13718|p444|T1] TIP
[13719|p444] Always line up' x's with 'x's, y's with 'y's and  $\mathbf{\Pi}^{\prime} = \mathbf{\Pi}^{\prime}$  with  $\mathbf{\Pi}^{\prime} = \mathbf{\Pi}^{\prime...
[13720|p444] It will make your method clearer.
[13721|p445|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4 CONTINUED
[13722|p445] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 x - 3 y = - 8 \\ \Rightarrow 2 (- 1) - 3 y = - 8 \\ 6 - 3 y = 0 \\ 3 y = 6 \\ y = 2 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13723|p445] Substitute in [1]
[13724|p445] Now you know the value of  $x$ , you can substitute this into either equation and solve for  $y$ .
[13725|p445] $$
\begin{array}{l} 5 x + 3 y = 5 (- 1) + 3 (2) \\ = - 5 + 6 = 1 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13726|p445] Check your values in equation [2] to be sure.
[13727|p445] The second equation is also satisfied by these values, so  $x = -1$  and  $y = 2$ .
[13728|p445|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[13729|p445] If you need to remind yourself about working with directed numbers, look back to Chapter 1. In particular, make sure you are confident subtracting neg...
[13730|p445|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[13731|p445] Solve simultaneously:
[13732|p445] $$
\begin{array}{l} 4 x + y = - 1 \tag {1} \\ 7 x + y = - 4 \quad [ 2 ] \\ \end{array}
$$
[13733|p445] Answer
[13734|p445] $$
\begin{array}{l} 7 x + y = - 4 \quad [ 2 ] - [ 1 ] \\ 4 x + y = - 1 \\ 3 x = - 3 \\ \Rightarrow x = - 1 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13735|p445] The  $y$ -values have the same coefficient again, but this time they have the same sign. Use the fact that  $y - y = 0$  and subtract one equation fro...
[13736|p445] $$
4 x + y = - 1
$$
[13737|p445] [1]
[13738|p445] Substitute into equation [1].
[13739|p445] $$
\begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow 4 (- 1) + y = - 1 \\ y = 3 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13740|p445] $$
7 x + y = 7 (- 1) + 3
$$
[13741|p445] Check that the values  $x = -1$  and  $y = 3$  work in equation [2].
[13742|p445] Equation [2] is also satisfied by these values, so  $x = -1$  and  $y = 3$ .
[13743|p445|T1] Manipulating equations before solving them
[13744|p445] Sometimes you need to manipulate or rearrange one or both of the equations before you can solve them simultaneously by elimination. Worked examples 6 ...
[13745|p445|T1] TIP
[13746|p445] Always make it clear which equation you have chosen to subtract from which.
[13747|p445] Here, you have used the fact that  $-4 - (-1) = -3$ .
[13748|p446|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[13749|p446] Solve simultaneously:
[13750|p446] $$
2 x - 5 y = 2 4 \tag {1}
$$
[13751|p446] $$
4 x + 3 y = - 4 \tag {2}
$$
[13752|p446] Answer
[13753|p446] $$
2 \times [ 1 ]
$$
[13754|p446] $$
4 x - 1 0 y = 4 8 \tag {3}
$$
[13755|p446] Here, neither the coefficients of  $x$  nor the coefficients of  $y$  match. But, if you multiply equation [1] by 2, you can make the coefficient of  ...
[13756|p446] Call this new equation [3].
[13757|p446] $$
4 x + 3 y = - 4 \quad [ 2 ]
$$
[13758|p446] $$
4 x - 1 0 y = 4 8 \tag {3}
$$
[13759|p446] Equations [2] and [3] have the same coefficient of  $x$ , so write these equations together and solve as before.
[13760|p446] $$
4 x + 3 y = - 4 [ 2 ] - [ 3 ]
$$
[13761|p446] $$
4 x - 1 0 y = 4 8
$$
[13762|p446] $$
1 3 y = - 5 2
$$
[13763|p446] $$
\Rightarrow y = - 4
$$
[13764|p446] $$
2 x - 5 y = 2 4
$$
[13765|p446] $$
\Rightarrow 2 x - 5 (- 4) = 2 4
$$
[13766|p446] $$
2 x + 2 0 = 2 4
$$
[13767|p446] $$
x = 2
$$
[13768|p446] $$
4 x + 3 y = 4 (2) + 3 (- 4)
$$
[13769|p446] Substitute  $y = -4$  into equation [1].
[13770|p446] $$
= 8 - 1 2 = - 4
$$
[13771|p446] So the pair of values  $x = 2$  and  $y = -4$  satisfy the pair of simultaneous equations.
[13772|p446|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[13773|p446] Solve simultaneously:
[13774|p446] $$
2 x - 2 1 = 5 y
$$
[13775|p446] $$
3 + 4 y = - 3 x
$$
[13776|p446] Answer
[13777|p446] Before you can work with these equations you need to rearrange them so they are in the same form.
[13778|p446] $$
2 x - 5 y = 2 1
$$
[13779|p446] [1]
[13780|p446] In this pair, you cannot make the coefficients of  $x$ .
[13781|p446] $$
3 x + 4 y = - 3
$$
[13782|p446] or  $y$  match by multiplying just one equation.
[13783|p447|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7 CONTINUED
[13784|p447] $4\times [1]$
[13785|p447] $$
8 x - 2 0 y = 8 4 \tag {3}
$$
[13786|p447] $5\times [2]$
[13787|p447] $$
1 5 x + 2 0 y = - 1 5 \tag {4}
$$
[13788|p447] Here, you need to multiply each equation by a different value so that the coefficient of  $x$  or the coefficient of  $y$  match. It is best to choose...
[13789|p447] $$
8 x - 2 0 y = 8 4 \quad [ 3 ] + [ 4 ]
$$
[13790|p447] $$
1 5 x + 2 0 y = - 1 5
$$
[13791|p447] $$
2 3 x = 6 9
$$
[13792|p447] $$
\Rightarrow x = 3
$$
[13793|p447] $$
2 x - 5 y = 2 1
$$
[13794|p447] $$
\Rightarrow 2 (3) - 5 y = 2 1
$$
[13795|p447] $$
6 - 5 y = 2 1
$$
[13796|p447] $$
5 y = - 1 5
$$
[13797|p447] $$
y = - 3
$$
[13798|p447] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 x + 4 y = 3 (3) + 4 (- 3) \\ = 9 - 1 2 = - 3 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13799|p447] Substitute for  $x$  in equation [1].
[13800|p447] So  $x = 3$  and  $y = -3$  satisfy the pair of simultaneous equations.
[13801|p447|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[13802|p447] Solve simultaneously:
[13803|p447] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {3 x - 4 y}{2} = 1 0 \quad [ 1 ] \\ \frac {3 x + 2 y}{4} = 2 \tag {2} \\ \end{array}
$$
[13804|p447] Answer
[13805|p447] $$
3 x - 4 y = 2 0
$$
[13806|p447] In this pair of equations it makes sense to remove the fractions before you work with them. Multiply both sides of equation [1] by 2.
[13807|p447] $$
3 x + 2 y = 8
$$
[13808|p447] Multiply both sides of equation [2] by 4.
[13809|p448|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8 CONTINUED
[13810|p448] $3x - 4y = 20$  [3] - [4] Subtract equation [4] from equation [3].
[13811|p448] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 x + 2 y = 8 \\ - 6 y = 1 2 \\ y = - 2 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13812|p448] $3x - 4(-2) = 20$  Substitute the value for  $y$  into equation [3].
[13813|p448] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 x + 8 = 2 0 \\ 3 x = 1 2 \\ x = 4 \\ \end{array}
$$
[13814|p448] 3(4) + 2(-2) = 12 - 4 = 8 Check using equation [4].
[13815|p448] So  $x = 4$  and  $y = -2$  satisfy the pair of simultaneous equations.
[13816|p448|T1] Exercise 14.2
[13817|p448|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[13818|p448] Remember from Chapter 1 that adding a negative is the same as subtracting a positive.
[13819|p448] 1 Solve for  $x$  and  $y$  by substitution. Check each solution.
[13820|p448] a  $y + x = 7$
[13821|p448] $$
y = x + 3
$$
[13822|p448] d  $x - 8 = 2y$
[13823|p448] $$
x + y = - 2
$$
[13824|p448] g  $4x - 1 = 2y$
[13825|p448] $$
x + 1 = 3 y
$$
[13826|p448] b  $y = 1 - x$
[13827|p448] $$
x - 5 = y
$$
[13828|p448] e  $3x - 2 = -2y$
[13829|p448] $$
2 x - y = - 8
$$
[13830|p448] h  $3x - 4y = 1$
[13831|p448] $$
2 x = 4 - 3 y
$$
[13832|p448] $2x + y = -14$
[13833|p448] $$
y = 6
$$
[13834|p448] f  $3x + y = 6$
[13835|p448] $$
9 x + 2 y = 1
$$
[13836|p448] 2 Solve for  $x$  and  $y$  by elimination. Check each solution.
[13837|p448] a  $2x - y = 4$
[13838|p448] $$
5 x + y = 2 4
$$
[13839|p448] d  $5x - 2y = 27$
[13840|p448] $$
3 x + 2 y = 1 3
$$
[13841|p448] ${4x} + y = {27}$
[13842|p448] $$
3 x - y = 1 5
$$
[13843|p448] j  $6x - y = 18$
[13844|p448] $$
4 x - y = 1 0
$$
[13845|p448] b  $- {3x} + {2y} = 6$
[13846|p448] $$
3 x + 5 y = 3 6
$$
[13847|p448] [x + {2y} = {11}]
[13848|p448] $$
x + 3 y = 1 5
$$
[13849|p448] h  $4x - y = 16$
[13850|p448] $$
6 x - y = 2 6
$$
[13851|p448] k  $x + y = 12$
[13852|p448] $$
5 x - y = 2 4
$$
[13853|p448] $2x + 5y = 12$
[13854|p448] $$
2 x + 3 y = 8
$$
[13855|p448] f  $-2x + 5y = 13$
[13856|p448] $$
2 x + 3 y = 1 1
$$
[13857|p448] i  $6x - 5y = 9$
[13858|p448] $$
2 x + 5 y = 2 3
$$
[13859|p448] ${4x} + {3y} = {22}$
[13860|p448] $$
4 x + y = 1 8
$$
[13861|p448|T1] TIP
[13862|p448] Remember that you need either the same coefficient of  $x$  or the same coefficient of  $y$ .
[13863|p448] If both have the same sign, you should then subtract one equation from the other. If they have a different sign, then you should add them.
[13864|p449] 3 Solve simultaneously. Use the method you find easiest. Check all solutions.
[13865|p449] a  $5x + 3y = 22$ $10x - y = 16$
[13866|p449] b  $4x + 3y = 25$ $x + 9y = 31$
[13867|p449] -3x+y=5 -6x+5y=-20
[13868|p449] d  $x + y = 10$ $3x + 5y = 40$
[13869|p449] e  $5x + y = 11$ $-2x + 2y = 1$
[13870|p449] ${4x} - {3y} = {11}$ ${5x} - {9y} =  - 2$
[13871|p449] g  $6x + 2y = 9$ $7x + 4y = 12$
[13872|p449] 12x-13y=34 3x-26y=19
[13873|p449] i  $5x - 17y = -3$ $25x - 19y = -45$
[13874|p449] j  $3x - 3y = 13$ $4x - 12y = -6$
[13875|p449] k  $10x^{\prime} = 2 - 2y$ $2y = -7x - 1$
[13876|p449] -2y=1-7x 4x=4+2y
[13877|p449] m  $x = 12 + y$ $2x = 3 - y$
[13878|p449] n  $3x + 4y = -1$ $3x + 10 = 2y$
[13879|p449] $2x + y = 7$ $11 + x = 2y$
[13880|p449|T1] REFLECTION

[13883|p449] a  $3x + 7y = 37$ $5x + 6y = 39$

[13888|p449] $3x - 4y = 25$ $x - 3y = 15$
[13889|p449] ${7x} - {4y} = {23}$ ${4x} + {5y} = {35}$
[13890|p449] h  $3x - y = 2$ $3x + 5y = 26$
[13891|p449] i  $2x + 7y = 25$ $x + y = 5$
[13892|p449] j  $x + 3 = y$ $4x + y = -7$
[13893|p449] k  $3x + 11 = -y$ $-2x + y = 4$
[13894|p449] $y = {6x} - 1$ ${4x} - {3y} =  - 4$
[13895|p449] m  $2x + 3y - 8 = 0$ $4x + 5 = y$
[13896|p449] n  $y = \frac{2}{3} x + 6$ $2y - 4x = 20$

[13900|p449] b  $4y + x + 5 = 0$ $y = x - 5$

[13906|p449] If an equation contains fractions, clear the fractions by multiplying each term by a suitable number (a common denominator).

[13932|p451] If you draw a number line, you can use an arrow to represent the set of numbers less than 4:
[13934|p451|T1] LINK
[13935|p451] You are already familiar with the idea of a number line. Both the  $x$ - and  $y$ -axes are examples of number lines.
[13936|p451] Any kind of regular scale like a thermometer or tape measure used in a long jump pit, for example, is really a kind of number line.
[13937|p451] This allows you to show the possible values of  $x$  neatly without writing them all down. (In fact, there is an infinite number of values, so you can...
[13938|p451] Now imagine that  $x \geq -2$ . This means that  $x$  can be greater than, or equal to  $-2$ . You can show that  $x$  can be equal to  $-2$  by 'fill...

[13943|p452|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[13944|p452] a Show the set of values that satisfy each of the following inequalities on a number line.
[13945|p452] $$
i x > 3
$$
[13946|p452] $$
i i \quad 4 <   y <   8
$$
[13947|p452] $$
- 1. 4 <   x \leqslant 2. 8
$$
[13948|p452] b List all integers that satisfy the inequality  $4.2 < x \leqslant 10.4$
[13949|p452|T1] Answers
[13950|p452] a i The values of  $x$  have to be larger than 3.  $x$  cannot be equal to 3, so do not fill in the circle. 'Greater than' means 'to the right' on the...
[13952|p452] ii Notice that  $y$  is now being used as the variable and this should be clearly labelled on your number line. Also, two inequality symbols have been...
[13953|p452] $4 < y$  means that  $y$  is greater than (but not equal) to 4.
[13954|p452] $y < 8$  means that  $y$  is less than (but not equal to) 8.
[13955|p452] So,  $y$  lies between 4 and 8 (not inclusive):
[13957|p452] iii This example has two inequalities that must both be satisfied.  $x$  is greater than (but not equal to) -1.4, and  $x$  is less than or equal to 2...
[13959|p452] b  $x$  must be greater than, but not equal to 4.2, so the smallest possible value of  $x$  is 5.  $x$  must also be less than or equal to 10.4, so th...
[13960|p452] The possible integer values of  $x$  are 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 or 10.

[13982|p453|T1] Solving inequalities algebraically
[13983|p453] Consider the inequality  $3x > 6$
[13984|p453] Now, suppose that  $x = 2$ , then  $3x = 6$  but this doesn't quite satisfy the inequality! However, any value of  $x$  that is larger than 2 will wor...
[13985|p453] If  $x = 2.1$ , then  $3x = 6.3$ , which is greater than 6.
[13986|p453] In the same way that you could divide both sides of an equation by 3, both sides of the inequality can be divided by 3 to get the solution:
[13987|p453] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 x > 6 \\ \frac {3 x}{3} > \frac {6}{3} \\ x > 2 \end{array}
$$
[13988|p453] Notice that this solution is a range of values of  $x$  rather than a single value. Any value of  $x$  that is greater than 2 is a solution.
[13989|p453] You can solve any linear inequality in a similar way to how you would solve a linear equation. But there are important exceptions, which are described...
[13990|p453|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[13991|p453] Find the set of values of  $x$  which satisfy each of the following inequalities.
[13992|p453] a  $3x - 4 <   14$
[13993|p453] b  $4(x - 7)\geq 16$
[13994|p453] c  $5x - 3\leqslant 2x + 18$
[13995|p453] d  $4 - 7x\leqslant 53$
[13996|p453] e  $-10\leqslant 3x - 2 <   4$
[13997|p453|T1] Answers
[13998|p453] a  $3x - 4 <   14$
[13999|p453] $$
3 x <   1 8
$$
[14000|p453] Add 4 to both sides.
[14001|p453] $$
\frac {3 x}{3} <   \frac {1 8}{3}
$$
[14002|p453] Divide both sides by 3.
[14003|p453] $$
\mathrm {S o}, x <   6
$$
[14004|p453] b  $4(x - 7)\geq 16$
[14005|p453] $4x - 28\geq 16$
[14006|p453] $$
4 x \geqslant 4 4
$$
[14007|p453] $$
\frac {4 x}{4} \geqslant \frac {4 4}{4}
$$
[14008|p453] $$
\mathrm {S o}, x \geqslant 1 1
$$
[14009|p453] $$
4 (x - 7) \geqslant 1 6
$$
[14010|p453] $$
x - 7 \geqslant 4
$$
[14011|p453] $$
x \geqslant 1 1
$$
[14012|p453] Expand the brackets.
[14013|p453] Add 28 to both sides.
[14014|p453] Divide both sides by 4.
[14015|p453] You can also solve this inequality by dividing both sides by 4 at the beginning:
[14016|p453] Divide both sides by 4.
[14017|p453] Add 7 to both sides to get the same answer as before.
[14018|p453|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14019|p453] There is a clear relationship between this method and how you solved equations in Chapter 6.
[14020|p454|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10 CONTINUED
[14021|p454] c  $5x - 3\leqslant 2x + 18$
[14022|p454] $$
\begin{array}{l} 5 x - 3 - 2 x \leqslant 2 x + 1 8 - 2 x \\ 3 x - 3 \leqslant 1 8 \\ 3 x \leqslant 2 1 \\ x \leqslant 7 \\ \end{array}
$$
[14023|p454] Subtract the smaller number of  $x$ 's from both sides (2x).
[14024|p454] Simplify.
[14025|p454] Add 3 to both sides.
[14026|p454] Divide both sides by 3.
[14027|p454] d  $4 - 7x\leqslant 53$
[14028|p454] $$
4 \leqslant 5 3 + 7 x
$$
[14029|p454] $$
- 4 9 \leqslant 7 x
$$
[14030|p454] $$
- 7 \leqslant x
$$
[14031|p454] And,  $x\geq -7$
[14032|p454] Add 7x to both sides
[14033|p454] Subtract 53 from both sides.
[14034|p454] Divide both sides by 7.
[14035|p454] The  $x$  is on the right-hand side of the inequality in this answer. This is acceptable. You can reverse the entire inequality to place the  $x$  on ...
[14036|p454] e  $-10\leqslant 3x - 2 <   4$
[14037|p454] $$
\begin{array}{l} - 1 0 \leqslant 3 x - 2 \text {a n d} 3 x - 2 <   4 \\ - 8 \leqslant 3 x \\ - \frac {8}{3} \leqslant x \\ - \frac {8}{3} \leq x < ...
[14038|p454] There are three parts to this inequality.
[14039|p454] Split into two inequalities.
[14040|p454] Solve each part.
[14041|p454] Recombine the solutions.
[14042|p454|T1] A warning
[14043|p454] Before working through the next exercise you must understand and apply one further rule. Think about this inequality:
[14044|p454] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 - 5 x > 1 8 \\ \Rightarrow - 5 x > 1 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[14045|p454] If you divide both sides by  $-5$  it appears that the solution will be,
[14046|p454] $$
x > - 3
$$
[14047|p454] This is satisfied by any value of  $x$  that is greater than -3, for example -2, -1, 2.4, 3.5, 10 ...
[14048|p454] If you calculate the value of  $3 - 5x$  for each of these values you get 13, 8, -9, -14.5, -47 ... and not one of these works in the original inequal...
[14049|p454] Here is an alternative solution:
[14050|p454] $$
3 - 5 x > 1 8
$$
[14051|p454] $$
\begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \quad 3 > 1 8 + 5 x \\ - 1 5 > 5 x \\ - 3 > x \\ \end{array}
$$
[14052|p454] $$
\text {O r}, \quad x <   - 3
$$
[14053|p454] This is a correct solution, and the final answer is very similar to the 'wrong' one above.
[14054|p454] The only difference is that the inequality symbol has been reversed.
[14055|p455] Why does this happen? When you multiply both sides by a negative value, the side that was greater will end up being a 'bigger' negative number, which ...
[14056|p455] You need to remember the following:
[14057|p455] If you multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a negative number then you must reverse the direction of the inequality.
[14058|p455] If you can avoid negatives, by adding or subtracting terms, then try to do so.
[14059|p455|T1] REFLECTION
[14060|p455] Have you completely understood this warning? How will you make sure you remember to reverse the inequality symbol at the right moment each time?

[14109|p456] The diagram shows a broken line that is parallel to the  $x$ -axis. Every point on the line has a  $y$ -coordinate of 3. This means that the equation ...
[14111|p456] All of the points above the line  $y = 3$  have  $y$ -coordinates that are greater than 3. The region above the line represents the inequality  $y > 3...
[14112|p457] The regions  $y > 3$  and  $y < 3$  are shown on this diagram.
[14115|p457] In the diagram below, the graph of  $y = 2x + 1$  is shown as a broken line. Every point on the line has coordinates  $(x, y)$  which satisfy  $y = 2x...
[14116|p457] $Q$  is a point on the line. Point  $P$  has a  $y$ -coordinate that is greater than the  $y$ -coordinate of  $Q$ .  $P$  and  $Q$  have the same  $x$...
[14118|p457] The region above the line represents the inequality  $y > 2x + 1$ .
[14119|p457] Similarly, the region below the line represents the inequality  $y < 2x + 1$ .
[14120|p457] You can see this on the following diagram.
[14122|p458] If the equation of the line is in the form  $y = mx + c$ , then:
[14123|p458] the inequality  $y > mx + c$  is above the line
[14124|p458] the inequality  $y <   mx + c$  is below the line.
[14125|p458] If the equation is not in the form  $y = mx + c$ , you have to find a way to check which region represents which inequality.

[14135|p459] When the inequality does not include equal to  $(< \text{or} >)$ , the boundary line is not included in the graphical representation, so it is shown a...
[14136|p459|T1] TIP
[14137|p459] Sometimes it is better to shade out the unwanted region.

[14182|p461|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[14183|p461] By shading the unwanted regions, show the region defined by the set of inequalities  $y < x + 2$ ,  $y \leq 4$  and  $x \leq 3$ .
[14185|p461] The boundaries of the required region are  $y = x + 2$  (broken line),  $y = 4$  (solid line) and  $x = 3$  (solid line).
[14186|p461] Start by drawing the line  $y = x + 2$ .  $y < x + 2$  so shade the unwanted region above the line.
[14187|p462|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15 CONTINUED
[14189|p462] Continue drawing the other boundary lines and shading the unwanted regions.
[14190|p462] The unshaded region in the diagram represents the set of inequalities
[14191|p462] $$
y <   x + 2, y \leqslant 4 \text {a n d} x \leqslant 3.
$$
[14192|p462] Notice that this region does not have a finite area - it is not 'closed'.
[14193|p462|T1] INVESTIGATION
[14194|p462] Shading the wanted region
[14195|p462] In the questions you have seen so far, you were asked to shade unwanted regions. Try working through Worked example 15 again, but shade the wanted reg...

[14206|p463|T1] 14.4 Completing the square
[14207|p463|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14208|p463] The material here builds on everything you learnt about quadratic expressions in Chapter 10. Make sure you have reviewed that work before you start th...
[14209|p463] Compare these two quadratic expressions:
[14210|p463] $$
\begin{array}{l} x ^ {2} + 6 x + 9 \\ x ^ {2} + 6 x - 7 \\ \end{array}
$$
[14211|p463] You should recognise from your work in Chapter 10 that the first expression is a perfect square and that it factorises to give two identical factors:
[14212|p463] $$
x ^ {2} + 6 x + 9 = (x + 3) (x + 3) = (x + 3) ^ {2}.
$$
[14213|p463] The second quadratic is not the square of a single bracket, but you can use a similar idea to write it in a different way that does involve a square b...
[14214|p463] Compare the two expressions again and write the second quadratic using a squared bracket:
[14215|p463] $$
\begin{array}{l} x ^ {2} + 6 x + 9 = (x + 3) ^ {2} \\ x ^ {2} + 6 x - 7 = (x + 3) ^ {2} - 1 6 \quad \text {S u b t r a c t} 1 6 \text {f r o m} - 7...
[14216|p463|T1] TIP
[14217|p463] Notice that the two quadratics are very similar. The only difference is that the constant term in the second one is 16 less than in the first.
[14218|p464] Notice that the coefficient of  $x$  in the original expression is twice the constant inside the bracket. The coefficient of  $x$  is always twice the...
[14219|p464] $$
(x + a) ^ {2} = (x + a) (x + a) = x ^ {2} + 2 a x + a ^ {2}
$$
[14220|p464] The method of rewriting a quadratic expression in the form  $(x + p)^2 + q$  is called completing the square
[14221|p464|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 16
[14222|p464] Rewrite the expression  $x^{2} - 4x + 11$  in the form  $(x + p)^{2} + q$ .
[14223|p464|T1] Answer
[14224|p464] The coefficient of  $x$  is -4. Half of this is -2.
[14225|p464] So start by thinking about  $(x - 2)^2 = x^2 - 4x + 4$ .
[14226|p464] You need to add 7 to make the constant equal to 11, so
[14227|p464] $$
x ^ {2} - 4 x + 1 1 = (x - 2) ^ {2} + 7.
$$
[14228|p464|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 17
[14229|p464] a Write the expression  $x^{2} + 4x - 6$  in the form  $(x + p)^2 +q$
[14230|p464] b Hence solve  $x^{2} + 4x - 6 = 0$  giving your answers to 2 decimal places.
[14231|p464|T1] Answers
[14232|p464] a Try  $(x + 2)^2 = x^2 + 4x + 4$
[14233|p464] The coefficient of  $x$  in  $x^2 + 4x - 6$  is 4. Half of this is 2.
[14234|p464] $$
\begin{array}{l} (x + 2) ^ {2} - 1 0 = x ^ {2} + 4 x + 4 - 1 0 \\ = x ^ {2} + 4 x - 6 \\ \end{array}
$$
[14235|p464] Subtract 10 from both sides to make the constant term  $-6$ .
[14236|p464] b  $x^{2} + 4x - 6 = 0$
[14237|p464] $$
\begin{array}{l} (x + 2) ^ {2} - 1 0 = 0 \\ (x + 2) ^ {2} = 1 0 \\ x + 2 = \pm \sqrt {1 0} \\ x = - 2 \pm \sqrt {1 0} \\ \end{array}
$$
[14238|p464] $$
x = 1. 1 6 \text {o r} x = - 5. 1 6
$$
[14239|p464] Rewrite the quadratic expression in completed square form.
[14240|p464] Solve for  $x$ .
[14241|p464] Give your answers to 2 decimal places.
[14242|p464|T1] Exercise 14.7

$$

[14285|p465|T1] Completing the square when the coefficient of  $x$  is not 1
[14286|p465] Sometimes you will need to write an expression in completed square form when the coefficient of  $x$  is not equal to 1. This means that you will need...
[14287|p465|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18
[14288|p465] Write these expressions in the form  $a(x + p)^2 + q$
[14289|p465] a  $2x^{2} + 8x - 3$
[14290|p465] b  $3x^{2} + 5x - 2$
[14291|p465|T1] Answers
[14292|p465] a  $2x^{2} + 8x - 3$
[14293|p465] $$
= 2 (x ^ {2} + 8 x) - 3
$$
[14294|p465] Take the coefficient of  $x^{2}$  out of the first two terms only.
[14295|p465] $$
= 2 \{(x + 2) ^ {2} - 4 \} - 3
$$
[14296|p465] Complete the square on the expression inside the bracket.
[14297|p465] $$
= 2 (x + 2) ^ {2} - 8 - 3
$$
[14298|p465] Expand the outer bracket.
[14299|p465] $$
= 2 (x + 2) ^ {2} - 1 1
$$
[14300|p465] Simplify.
[14301|p466|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18 CONTINUED
[14302|p466] b  $3x^{2} + 5x - 2$
[14303|p466] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 3 \left(x ^ {2} + \frac {5}{3} x\right) - 2 \\ = 3 \left\{\left(x + \frac {5}{6}\right) ^ {2} - \left(\frac {5}{6}\right) ^ {2} ...
[14304|p466] Take the coefficient of  $x^2$  out of the first two terms only.
[14305|p466] Complete the square on the expression inside the bracket.
[14306|p466] Expand the outer bracket.
[14307|p466] Simplify fully.

[14329|p466] 3 Write  $ax^2 +bx + c$  in the form  $(x + p)^2 +q$  and hence show that provided
[14330|p466] $b^{2} - 4ac\geqslant 0$  , the equation  $ax^2 +bx + c = 0$  has solutions  $x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}$
[14331|p466|T1] 14.5 Quadratic formula
[14332|p466] If you complete the square for the general form of a quadratic equation  $(ax^2 + bx + c = 0)$ , the following result is produced:
[14333|p466] $$
\text {I f} a x ^ {2} + b x + c = 0 \text {t h e n} x = \frac {- b \pm \sqrt {b ^ {2} - 4 a c}}{2 a}
$$
[14334|p466] This is known as the quadratic formula.
[14335|p466] Notice the  $\pm$  symbol. This tells you that you should calculate two values: one with a  $+$  and one with a  $-$  in the position occupied by the ...
[14336|p466] The advantage of the quadratic formula over completing the square is that you don't have any extra steps to include when the coefficient of  $x^2$  is...
[14337|p466|T1] TIP
[14338|p466] Remember that half
[14339|p466] $$
\text {o f} \frac {5}{3} \text {i s} \frac {5}{6}.
$$
[14340|p467|T1] TIP
[14341|p467] If you are asked to give solutions to a number of decimal places or significant figures or to leave the answer in surd form it is a good indication th...
[14342|p467|T1] DISCUSSION
[14343|p467] By starting with  $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$  and dividing every term by  $a$  it is possible to use completing the square to get the formula above. Work wit...
[14344|p467|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14345|p467] You saw in Chapter 2 that the coefficient of a variable is the number that multiplies it. This is still true for quadratic equations:  $a$  is the coe...
[14346|p467|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 19
[14347|p467] Solve the following quadratic equations, giving your answers to 3 significant figures.
[14348|p467] a  $x^{2} + 4x + 3 = 0$
[14349|p467] b  $x^{2} - 7x + 11 = 0$
[14350|p467] $3x^{2} - 2x - 1 = 0$
[14351|p467|T1] Answers
[14352|p467] a Compare the quadratic equation  $x^{2} + 4x + 3 = 0$  with  $ax^2 +bx + c = 0$  From this you can see that  $a = 1$ $b = 4$  and  $c = 3$
[14353|p467] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = \frac {- b \pm \sqrt {b ^ {2} - 4 a c}}{2 a} = \frac {- 4 \pm \sqrt {4 ^ {2} - 4 \times 1 \times 3}}{2 \times 1} \\ = - 4 \pm ...
[14354|p467] $$
S _ {0}, x = \frac {- 4 + 2}{2} = \frac {- 2}{2} = - 1 \text {o r} x = \frac {- 4 - 2}{2} = \frac {- 6}{2} = - 3
$$
[14355|p467] Notice that the original quadratic equation can be factorised to give  $(x + 1)(x + 3) = 0$  and the same solutions. If you can factorise the quadrati...
[14356|p467|T1] TIP
[14357|p467] Here you need to take particular care. BODMAS always applies and you should check the order of your working, and your solution, carefully.
[14358|p468|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 19 CONTINUED
[14359|p468] b  $x^{2} - 7x + 11 = 0$  so  $a = 1$ $b = -7$  and  $c = 11$
[14360|p468] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = \frac {- (- 7) \pm \sqrt {(- 7) ^ {2} - 4 \times 1 \times 1 1}}{2 \times 1} = \frac {7 \pm \sqrt {4 9 - 4 4}}{2} \\ = \frac {7...
[14361|p468] $$
S _ {0}, x = \frac {7 + \sqrt {5}}{2} = 4. 6 1 8 0 \dots \text {o r} x = \frac {7 - \sqrt {5}}{2} = 2. 3 8 1 9 \dots
$$
[14362|p468] $x$  is approximately equal to 4.62 or 2.38 (3 s.f.)
[14363|p468] c  $3x^{2} - 2x - 1 = 0$  so  $a = 3,b = -2$  and  $c = -1$
[14364|p468] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = \frac {- (- 2) \pm \sqrt {(- 2) ^ {2} - 4 \times 3 \times (- 1)}}{2 \times 3} = \frac {2 \pm \sqrt {4 + 1 2}}{6} \\ = \frac {2...
[14365|p468] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = \frac {- (- 2) \pm \sqrt {(- 2) ^ {2} - 4 \times 3 \times (- 1)}}{2 \times 3} = \frac {2 \pm \sqrt {4 + 1 2}}{6} \\ = \frac {2...
[14366|p468|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 20
[14367|p468] Use the quadratic formula to find the exact solutions, in surd form, to this equation:
[14368|p468] $$
- 3 x ^ {2} - 1 2 x - 7 = 0
$$
[14369|p468] Answer
[14370|p468] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = \frac {- (- 1 2) \pm \sqrt {(- 1 2) ^ {2} - 4 \times (- 3) \times (- 7)}}{2 \times (- 3)} = \frac {1 2 \pm \sqrt {6 0}}{- 6} \...
[14371|p468] $$
\mathrm {S o}, x = \frac {6 + \sqrt {1 5}}{- 3} \text {o r} x = \frac {6 - \sqrt {1 5}}{- 3}
$$
[14372|p468|T1] TIP
[14373|p468] It is more accurate to leave your answer in surd form than to convert to a decimal. Surds are exact, but decimals are approximations.
[14374|p468|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14375|p468] You learnt how to work with surds in Chapter 9. Review that work if you need to.
[14376|p468|T1] TIP
[14377|p468] Notice that there are brackets around the -7. If you miss these the calculation becomes  $-7^{2} = -49$  rather than  $+49$ .
[14378|p468] If  $b$  is negative always use brackets to make sure that you square it correctly.

[14443|p470|T1] REFLECTION
[14444|p470] Did you make any mistakes with negative coefficients of  $x$ ? How did you correct them and how will you avoid making the same mistake in the future?
[14445|p470|T1] 14.6 Factorising quadratics where the coefficient of  $x^2$  is not 1
[14446|p470] The quadratic equation in part (c) of Worked example 19 gave two solutions that could have been obtained by factorisation. It turns out that  $(x - 1)...
[14447|p470] In general, if the coefficient of  $x^2$  in a quadratic is a number other than 1 you need to carry out more steps to factorise the expression.
[14448|p470|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 21
[14449|p470] Factorise each of the following expressions:
[14450|p470] a  $2x^{2} + 3x + 1$
[14451|p470] b  $3x^{2} - 14x + 8$
[14452|p470] 6x²+14x-12
[14453|p470] d  $10x^{2} + 11x - 8$
[14454|p470|T1] Answers
[14455|p470] a  $2x^{2} + 3x + 1$
[14456|p470] $$
2 x ^ {2} + 3 x + 1 = (2 x) (x)
$$
[14457|p470] The only way to produce the term  $2x^{2}$  is to multiply  $2x$  and  $x$ . Place these two terms at the front of each bracket. There are blank space...
[14458|p470] The constant term is 1, so the only possible values are +1 or -1. Since the constant term is positive, the unknown values must be either both -1 or bo...
[14459|p470] Try each of these combinations systematically:
[14460|p470] $(2x - 1)(x - 1) = 2x^{2} - 3x + 1$
[14461|p470] The coefficient of  $x$  is wrong.
[14462|p470] $(2x + 1)(x + 1) = 2x^{2} + 3x + 1$
[14463|p470] This is correct.
[14464|p470] So,  $2x^{2} + 3x + 1 = (2x + 1)(x + 1)$
[14466|p471|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 21 CONTINUED
[14467|p471] b  $3x^{2} - 14x + 8$
[14468|p471] Start by writing  $3x^{2} - 14x + 8 = (3x)(x)$
[14469|p471] The two unknown terms must multiply to give 8. Since the constant term is positive, the unknowns must have the same sign. The possible pairs are:
[14470|p471] 8 and 1 2 and 4 -8 and -1 -2 and -4
[14471|p471] Try each pair in turn, remembering that you can reverse the order:
[14472|p471] $$
(3 x + 8) (x + 1) = 3 x ^ {2} + 3 x + 8 x + 8 = 3 x ^ {2} + 1 1 x + 8 \quad \text {I n c o r r e c t}
$$
[14473|p471] $$
(3 x + 1) (x + 8) = 3 x ^ {2} + 2 4 x + x + 8 = 3 x ^ {2} + 2 5 x + 8 \quad \text {I n c o r r e c t}
$$
[14474|p471] $$
(3 x + 2) (x + 4) = 3 x ^ {2} + 1 2 x + 2 x + 8 = 3 x ^ {2} + 1 4 x + 8 \quad \text {I n c o r r e c t}
$$
[14475|p471] This last one is very close. You just need to change the sign of the 'x' term. This can be done by jumping to the last pair: -2 and -4.
[14476|p471] $$
(3 x - 2) (x - 4) = 3 x ^ {2} - 1 2 x - 2 x + 8 = 3 x ^ {2} - 1 4 x + 8 \quad \text {C o r r e c t}
$$
[14477|p471] $$
S _ {0}, 3 x ^ {2} - 1 4 x + 8 = (3 x - 2) (x - 4)
$$
[14478|p471] c  $6x^{2} + 14x - 12 = 2(3x^{2} + 7x - 6)$  Take out the common factor first.
[14479|p471] Write the pair of brackets; the factors have to be  $3x$  and  $x$ :
[14480|p471] $$
6 x ^ {2} + 1 4 x - 1 2 = 2 (3 x) (x)
$$
[14481|p471] The two unknown terms must multiply to give  $-6$ , because you have taken out the common factor 2. The possible pairs are:
[14482|p471] 2 and -3 3 and -2 6 and -1 -6 and 1
[14483|p471] Test the pairs until you find the correct combination.
[14484|p471] You will find that:
[14485|p471] $$
6 x ^ {2} + 1 4 x - 1 2 = 2 (3 x - 2) (x + 3)
$$
[14486|p471] d  $10x^{2} + 11x - 8$
[14487|p471] This question requires more thought because there is more than one way to multiply two expressions to get  $10x^{2}$ :
[14488|p471] 2x and 5x or 10x and x.
[14489|p471] Each possibility needs to be tried.
[14490|p471] Start with  $10x^{2} + 11x - 8 = (10x)(x)$
[14491|p471] Factor pairs that multiply to give -8 are:
[14492|p471] -8 and 1 8 and -1 2 and -4 -2 and 4
[14493|p471] Remember that you will need to try each pair with the two values in either order.
[14494|p471] For this particular quadratic you will find that none of the eight possible combinations works!
[14495|p471] Instead, you must now try:  $10x^{2} + 11x - 8 = (5x)(2x)$ .
[14496|p471] Trying the above set of pairs once again you will eventually find that:
[14497|p471] $$
1 0 x ^ {2} + 1 1 x - 8 = (5 x + 8) (2 x - 1)
$$
[14498|p472|T1] Exercise 14.10
[14499|p472] Factorise each of the following expressions.
[14500|p472] a  $3{x}^{2} + {14x} + 8$
[14501|p472] b  $2x^{2} + x - 3$
[14502|p472] c  $6x^{2} + x - 2$
[14503|p472] d  $3x^{2} + 14x + 16$
[14504|p472] e  $2x^{2} - x - 10$
[14505|p472] $16x^{2} + 32x - 9$
[14506|p472] $3{x}^{2} + {16x} + 5$
[14507|p472] h  $8x^{2} + 2x - 1$
[14508|p472] 2x²-x-6
[14509|p472] $2x^{2} + 9x + 9$
[14510|p472] k  $3x^{2} + 2x - 16$
[14511|p472] 10x²-x-3
[14512|p472] m  $5x^{2} + 6x + 1$
[14513|p472] n  $2x^{2} - 19x + 9$
[14514|p472] 12x²+8x-15
[14515|p472] Here is another method for factorising a quadratic like those in the previous exercise.
[14516|p472|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 22
[14517|p472] Factorise  $10x^{2} + 11x - 8$
[14518|p472|T1] Answer
[14519|p472] $10 \times -8 = -80$
[14520|p472] Multiply the coefficient of  $x^2$  by the constant term.
[14521|p472] -1, 80 (no)
[14522|p472] List the factor pairs of -80 until you obtain a pair that totals the coefficient of  $x$ , which is 11.
[14523|p472] -2, 40 (no)
[14524|p472] (Note that as 11 is positive and -80 is negative, the larger number of the pair must be positive and the other negative.)
[14525|p472] $10x^{2} - 5x + 16x - 8$
[14526|p472] Rewrite the  $x$  term using this factor pair.
[14527|p472] $5x(2x - 1) + 8(2x - 1)$
[14528|p472] Factorise pairs of terms.
[14529|p472] $(5x + 8)(2x - 1)$
[14530|p472] (Be careful with signs here so that the second bracket is the same as the first bracket.)
[14531|p472] Factorise, using the bracket as the common term.
[14532|p472|T1] Exercise 14.11
[14533|p472] 1 Go back to Exercise 14.10 and try to factorise the expressions using this new method.
[14534|p472] 2 Factorise each expression completely. Remember to remove any common factors before factorising.
[14535|p472] a  $6x^{2} - 5x - 21$

[14540|p472] $6{x}^{2} - {38xy} + {40}{y}^{2}$
[14541|p472] 6x²+7x+2
[14542|p472] h  $3x^{2} - 13x + 12$
[14543|p472] 3x²-39x+120

[14550|p472|T1] 14.7 Algebraic fractions
[14551|p472] You will now use several of the techniques covered so far in this chapter to simplify complex algebraic fractions.
[14552|p472] You already know that you can simplify fractions by dividing the numerator and denominator by a common factor. This can also be done with algebraic fr...
[14553|p473|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14554|p473] You revised highest common factors (HCFs) in Chapter 1.
[14555|p473|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 23
[14556|p473] Simplify each of the following fractions as far as possible:
[14557|p473] 3x a 6
[14558|p473] b y
[14559|p473] 12p3 16p7
[14560|p473] d  $\frac{x^2 - 4x + 3}{x^2 - 7x + 12}$
[14561|p473|T1] Answers
[14562|p473] a  $\frac{3x}{6}$
[14563|p473] $$
\frac {3 x}{6} = \frac {3 x \div 3}{6 \div 3} = \frac {x}{2}
$$
[14564|p473] The highest common factor (HCF) of 3 and 6 is 3.
[14565|p473] b  $\frac{y^2}{y^5}$
[14566|p473] $$
\frac {y ^ {2}}{y ^ {5}} = \frac {y ^ {2} \div y ^ {2}}{y ^ {5} \div y ^ {2}} = \frac {1}{y ^ {3}}
$$
[14567|p473] The HCF of  $y^{2}$  and  $y^{3}$  is  $y^{2}$ .
[14568|p473] 12p3 16p7
[14569|p473] $$
\frac {1 2 p ^ {3}}{1 6 p ^ {7}} = \frac {3 p ^ {3}}{4 p ^ {7}}
$$
[14570|p473] Consider the constants first.
[14571|p473] $$
= \frac {3}{4 p ^ {4}}
$$
[14572|p473] The HCF of 12 and 16 is 4, so you can divide both 12 and 16 by 4.
[14573|p473] The HCF of  $p^3$  and  $p^7$  is  $p^3$ . You can divide both the numerator and the denominator by this HCF.
[14574|p473] d  $\frac{x^2 - 4x + 3}{x^2 - 7x + 12}$
[14575|p473] Notice that you can factorise both the numerator and the denominator.
[14576|p473] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {x ^ {2} - 4 x + 3}{x ^ {2} - 7 x + 1 2} = \frac {(x - 3) (x - 1)}{(x - 3) (x - 4)} \\ = \frac {(x - 3) (x - 1)}{(x - 3) (x ...
[14577|p473] $(x - 3)$  is a factor of both the numerator and the denominator, so you can cancel this common factor.

[14602|p474|T1] Multiplying and dividing algebraic fractions
[14603|p474|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14604|p474] You learned how to multiply and divide numerical fractions in Chapter 5.
[14605|p474] Consider the following multiplication:  $\frac{x}{y^2} \times \frac{y^4}{x^3}$ .
[14606|p474] You already know that the numerators and denominators can be multiplied in the
[14607|p474] usual way:  $\frac{x}{y^2} \times \frac{y^4}{x^3} = \frac{xy^4}{y^2x^3}$ .
[14608|p474] Now you can see that the HCF of the numerator and denominator is  $xy^2$ . If you divide
[14609|p474] through by  $xy^2$  you get:  $\frac{x}{y^2} \times \frac{y^4}{x^3} = \frac{y^2}{x^2}$ .
[14610|p474] The following worked example will help you to understand the process for slightly more complicated multiplications and divisions.
[14611|p475|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 24
[14612|p475] Simplify each of the following.
[14613|p475] $$
a \frac {4}{3 x ^ {2}} \times \frac {1 4 x ^ {3}}{1 6 y ^ {2}}
$$
[14614|p475] $$
b \frac {3 (x + y) ^ {3}}{1 6 z ^ {2}} \times \frac {1 2 z}{9 (x + y) ^ {7}}
$$
[14615|p475] $$
c \frac {1 4 x ^ {4} y ^ {3}}{9} + \frac {7 x ^ {2} y}{1 8}
$$
[14616|p475|T1] Answers
[14617|p475] $$
\begin{array}{l} a \frac {4}{3 x ^ {2}} \times \frac {1 4 x ^ {3}}{1 6 y ^ {2}} \\ \frac {4}{3 x ^ {2}} \times \frac {1 4 x ^ {3}}{1 6 y ^ {2}} = \...
[14618|p475] Multiply the numerators and the denominators and then simplify using the methods you have just learnt.
[14619|p475] $$
\begin{array}{l} b \frac {3 (x + y) ^ {3}}{1 6 z ^ {2}} \times \frac {1 2 z}{9 (x + y) ^ {7}} \\ \frac {3 (x + y) ^ {3}}{1 6 z ^ {2}} \times \frac ...
[14620|p475] $$
\begin{array}{l} c \frac {1 4 x ^ {4} y ^ {3}}{9} \div \frac {7 x ^ {2} y}{1 8} \\ \frac {1 4 x ^ {4} y ^ {3}}{9} + \frac {7 x ^ {2} y}{1 8} = \fra...
[14621|p475|T1] REFLECTION
[14622|p475] The multiplication or division was carried out before any simplification in these examples, but you have already seen that it is possible to cancel fi...

[14646|p476|T1] Adding and subtracting algebraic fractions
[14647|p476] You can use common denominators to add or subtract algebraic fractions, just as you do with ordinary fractions.
[14648|p476|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 25
[14649|p476] Write as a single fraction in its lowest terms,  $\frac{1}{x} + \frac{1}{y}$
[14650|p476|T1] Answer
[14651|p476] $\frac{1}{x} + \frac{1}{y} = \frac{y}{xy} + \frac{x}{xy} = \frac{y + x}{xy}$  The lowest common multiple of  $x$  and  $y$  is  $xy$ . This will be th...
[14652|p476|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 26
[14653|p476] Write as a single fraction in its lowest terms,  $\frac{1}{x + 1} + \frac{1}{x + 2}$
[14654|p476|T1] Answer
[14655|p476] The lowest common multiple of  $(x + 1)$  and  $(x + 2)$  is  $(x + 1)(x + 2)$ .
[14656|p476] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {1}{x + 1} + \frac {1}{x + 2} = \frac {x + 2}{(x + 1) (x + 2)} + \frac {x + 1}{(x + 1) (x + 2)} \\ = \frac {x + 2 + x + 1}{(...
[14657|p477|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 27
[14658|p477] Write as a single fraction in its lowest terms,  $\frac{3x + 4}{x^2 + x - 6} - \frac{1}{x + 3}$
[14659|p477|T1] Answer
[14660|p477] First you should factorise the quadratic expression:
[14661|p477] $$
\frac {3 x + 4}{x ^ {2} + x - 6} - \frac {1}{x + 3} = \frac {3 x + 4}{(x + 3) (x - 2)} - \frac {1}{(x + 3)}
$$
[14662|p477] The two denominators have a common factor of  $(x + 3)$ , and the lowest common multiple of these two denominators is  $(x + 3)(x - 2)$ :
[14663|p477] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {3 x + 4}{x ^ {2} + x - 6} - \frac {1}{x + 3} = \frac {3 x + 4}{(x + 3) (x - 2)} - \frac {1}{(x + 3)} \\ = \frac {3 x + 4}{(...
[14664|p477] This may appear to be the final answer, but if you factorise the numerator you will find that more can be done!
[14665|p477] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {3 x + 4}{x ^ {2} + x - 6} - \frac {1}{x + 3} = \frac {2 x + 6}{(x + 3) (x - 2)} \\ = \frac {2 (x + 3)}{(x + 3) (x - 2)} \\ ...
[14666|p477|T1] TIP
[14667|p477] Always check to see if your final numerator can be factorised. If it can, then there may be more stages to go.

[14704|p478|T1] SUMMARY
[14705|p478|T1] Do you know ...?
[14706|p478] Simultaneous means at the same time.
[14707|p478] The intersection of two straight lines is the simultaneous solution of their equations.
[14708|p478] Simultaneous linear equations can be solved graphically or algebraically.
[14709|p478] Inequalities represent a range of solutions.
[14710|p478] Inequalities in one variable can be represented on a number line and inequalities in two variables as a region on a plane.
[14711|p478] A quadratic expression,  $x^{2} + bx + c$  can be written in the completed square form as  $\left(x + \frac{b}{2}\right)^2 - \left(\frac{b}{2}\right)^...
[14712|p478] Quadratic equations that do not factorise can be solved by completing the square or by using the quadratic formula.
[14713|p478] $$
\text {I f} a x ^ {2} + b x + c = 0 \text {t h e n} x = \frac {- b \pm \sqrt {b ^ {2} - 4 a c}}{2 a}.
$$
[14714|p478] Complex algebraic fractions can be simplified by factorising and cancelling like terms.
[14715|p478|T1] Are you able to ...?
[14716|p478] solve simultaneous linear equations graphically
[14717|p478] solve simultaneous linear equations algebraically
[14718|p478] show an inequality in one variable on a number line.
[14719|p478] show an inequality in two variables as a region in the  $x - y$  plane.
[14720|p478] show a region in the  $x - y$  plane that satisfies more than one inequality.
[14721|p478] 1. rewrite a quadratic expression in completed square form.
[14722|p478] To solve a quadratic equation using the completed square or the quadratic formula,
[14723|p478] simplify complex algebraic fractions.
[14724|p479|T1] Practice questions
[14725|p479|T1] SELF ASSESSMENT
[14726|p479] Answer these questions before you work through the practice questions:
[14727|p479] What do I aim to achieve?
[14728|p479] What do I already know or am able to do well?
[14729|p479] How will I know if I have met my aims?
[14730|p479] Answer these questions once you have completed the practice questions.
[14731|p479] What evidence shows that I have achieved my aims?
[14732|p479] What did I do well?
[14733|p479] What can I improve on?
[14734|p479] 1 Solve the following pair of simultaneous equations.
[14735|p479] $$
\begin{array}{l} 6 x - 5 y = - 3 \\ 5 x + 4 y = 2 2 \tag {4} \\ \end{array}
$$
[14736|p479] 2 A rectangle has sides of length  $3x + 1$  cm and  $6x - 3$  cm. The perimeter of the rectangle is less than  $88\mathrm{cm}$ .
[14737|p479] a Form an solve an inequality for  $x$  [4]
[14738|p479] b Given that  $x$  is an integer, find the largest possible area of the rectangle. [3]

[14786|p482|T1] >Chapter 15 Scale drawings, bearings and trigonometry
[14787|p482|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[14788|p482] - interpret scale drawings
[14789|p482] calculate bearings
[14790|p482] calculate sine, cosine and tangent ratios for right-angled triangles
[14791|p482] - use sine, cosine and tangent ratios to calculate the angles and lengths of sides of right-angled triangles
[14792|p482] - solve trigonometric equations, finding all the solutions between  $0^{\circ}$  and  $360^{\circ}$
[14793|p482] - apply the sine and cosine rules to calculate unknown sides and angles in triangles that are not right-angled
[14794|p482] calculate the area of a triangle that is not right-angled using the sine ratio
[14795|p482] - use the sine, cosine and tangent ratios, together with Pythagoras' theorem in three-dimensions
[14796|p482] - use exact sine, cosine and tangent ratios for certain angles.

[14829|p484|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[14830|p484] A rectangular field is  $100\mathrm{m}$  long and  $45\mathrm{m}$  wide. A scale drawing of the field is made with a scale of  $1\mathrm{cm}$  to  $10...
[14831|p484|T1] Answer
[14832|p484] 10m is represented by 1cm
[14833|p484] :  $100\mathrm{m}$  is represented by  $(100\div 10)\mathrm{cm} = 10\mathrm{cm}$
[14834|p484] and  $45\mathrm{m}$  is represented by  $(45\div 10)\mathrm{cm} = 4.5\mathrm{cm}$
[14835|p484] So, the dimensions on the drawing are: length  $= 10\mathrm{cm}$  and width  $= 4.5\mathrm{cm}$

[14837|p484] Today most draughtspeople, architects and designers use computers to generate accurate scale diagrams and plans, but most of these designs start with ...

[14875|p486|T1] REFLECTION
[14876|p486] What advice would you give to a student who finds this work difficult?
[14877|p487|T1] 15.2 Bearings
[14878|p487] You have now used scale drawings to find distances between objects and to measure angles. When you want to move from one position to another, you not ...
[14879|p487] The angle  $118^{\circ}$ , shown on the right, is measured clockwise from the north direction. Such an angle is called a bearing.
[14880|p487] All bearings are measured clockwise from the north direction.
[14881|p487] Here the bearing of  $P$  from  $O$  is  $118^{\circ}$
[14882|p487|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14883|p487] One degree of bearing does not seem like a lot but it can represent a huge distance in the real world. This is why you need to use the trigonometry yo...
[14884|p487] If the angle is less than  $100^{\circ}$  you still use three figures so that it is clear that you mean to use a bearing.
[14885|p487] Here the bearing of  $Q$  from  $O$  is  $040^{\circ}$
[14888|p487] Since you always measure clockwise from north it is possible for your bearing to be a reflex angle.
[14889|p487] Here the bearing of  $R$  from  $O$  is  $315^{\circ}$
[14891|p487|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14892|p487] You saw in Chapter 3 that a reflex angle is  $>180^{\circ}$  but  $< 360^{\circ}$ .
[14893|p487] You may sometimes need to use angle properties from previous chapters to solve bearings problems.
[14894|p488|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[14895|p488] The bearing of town B from city A is  $048^{\circ}$ . What is the bearing of city A from town B?
[14898|p488|T1] Answer
[14899|p488] In the second diagram, the two north lines are parallel. Hence angle  $\theta = 48^{\circ}$  (using the properties of corresponding angles).
[14900|p488] The bearing of city A from town  $B = 48^{\circ} + 180^{\circ} = 228^{\circ}$
[14901|p488] Notice that the difference between the two bearings  $(48^{\circ}$  and  $228^{\circ})$  is  $180^{\circ}$
[14902|p488|T1] TIP
[14903|p488] Always make sure that you draw a clear diagram and mark all north lines clearly. Bearings should always be measured from north.
[14904|p488|T1] TIP
[14905|p488] This is an example of a 'back' bearing. If you know the bearing of point  $X$  from point  $Y$  then, to find the bearing to return to point  $Y$  fro...
[14906|p488|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14907|p488] You should remind yourself how to deal with alternate and corresponding angles from Chapter 3.

[14983|p491|T1] Tangent ratio
[14984|p491] It turns out that  $\frac{\mathrm{opp}(A)}{\mathrm{adj}(A)}$  is constant for any given angle  $A$ .  $\frac{\mathrm{opp}(A)}{\mathrm{adj}(A)}$  depen...
[14985|p491] $$
\tan A = \frac {\operatorname {o p p} (A)}{\operatorname {a d j} (A)}
$$
[14986|p491|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14987|p491] You will need to use the skills you learnt for constructing accurate drawings of triangles in Chapter 3.
[14988|p491|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[14989|p491] Look back at the work on calculating gradients in Chapter 10 and compare it with the tangent ratio. What connection do you notice?
[14990|p492] Your calculator can work out the tangent ratio for any given angle and you can use this to help work out the lengths of unknown sides of a right-angle...
[14991|p492] For example, if you wanted to find the tangent of the angle  $22^{\circ}$  you enter:
[14993|p492] Notice that the answer has many decimal places. When using this value you must make sure that you don't round your answers too soon.
[14994|p492] Now, consider the right-angled triangle shown.
[14995|p492] You can find the unknown side,  $x$  cm, by writing down what you know about the tangent ratio:
[14996|p492] $$
\begin{array}{l} \tan 2 2 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\operatorname {o p p} (2 2 ^ {\circ})}{\operatorname {a d j} (2 2 ^ {\circ})} = \frac {x}{1 2} \\ \Rig...

[15081|p496|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[15082|p496] Find the acute angle with the following tangents, correct to 1 decimal place:
[15083|p496] a 0.1234
[15084|p496] b5
[15085|p496] c 2.765
[15086|p496|T1] TIP
[15087|p496] You need to be able to work out whether you can solve a problem using trigonometry or whether you can use Pythagoras' theorem.
[15088|p497|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6 CONTINUED
[15089|p497|T1] Answers
[15090|p497] a
[15092|p497] So the angle is  $7.0^{\circ}$
[15093|p497] b
[15095|p497] So the angle is  $78.7^{\circ}$
[15096|p497] C
[15098|p497] So the angle is  $70.1^{\circ}$
[15099|p497|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[15100|p497] Calculate, correct to 1 decimal place, the lettered angles.
[15101|p497] a
[15103|p497] b
[15105|p497] c
[15107|p497|T1] Answers
[15108|p497] opp(a) 3 0.75 tan a adj(a) 4
[15109|p497] $$
\begin{array}{l} a = \tan^ {- 1} (0. 7 5) \\ = 3 6. 8 6 9 8 9 7 \dots \\ \end{array}
$$
[15110|p497] $$
a = 3 6. 9 ^ {\circ} (1 d. p.)
$$
[15111|p497] opp(b) 12 2.4
[15112|p497] $$
\begin{array}{l} b = \tan^ {- 1} (2. 4) \\ = 6 7. 3 8 0 1 3 5 \dots \\ \end{array}
$$
[15113|p497] $$
b = 6 7. 4 ^ {\circ} (1 d. p.)
$$
[15114|p498|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7 CONTINUED
[15115|p498] $$
c \quad \tan c = \frac {\operatorname {o p p} (c)}{\operatorname {a d j} (c)} = \frac {2 4}{7}
$$
[15116|p498] $$
\begin{array}{l} c = \tan^ {- 1} \left(\frac {2 4}{7}\right) \\ = 7 3. 7 3 9 7 9 5 \dots \\ \end{array}
$$
[15117|p498] $$
c = 7 3. 7 ^ {\circ} (1 d. p.)
$$
[15118|p498] To find the angle  $d$ , you could use the fact that the angle sum in a triangle is  $180^\circ$ . This gives  $d = 180^\circ - (90^\circ + 73.7^\circ...
[15119|p498] Alternatively, you could use the tangent ratio again but with the opp and adj reassigned to match this angle:
[15120|p498] $$
\tan d = \frac {\operatorname {o p p} (d)}{\operatorname {a d j} (d)} = \frac {7}{2 4}
$$
[15121|p498] $$
\begin{array}{l} d = \tan^ {- 1} \left(\frac {7}{2 4}\right) \\ = 1 6. 2 6 0 2 0 4 \dots \\ \end{array}
$$
[15122|p498] $$
d = 1 6. 3 ^ {\circ} (1 d. p.)
$$

[15156|p499|T1] Sine and cosine ratios
[15157|p499] You will have noticed that the tangent ratio only makes use of the opposite and adjacent sides. What happens if you need to use the hypotenuse? In fac...
[15158|p499] - opposite and adjacent (already used with the tangent ratio)
[15159|p499] - opposite and hypotenuse
[15160|p499] or adjacent and hypotenuse.
[15161|p500] This means that you need two more ratios:
[15162|p500] The sine ratio is written as  $\sin (A) = \frac{\mathrm{opp}(A)}{\mathrm{hyp}}$
[15163|p500] adj(A) the cosine ratio is written as cos(A) = hyp
[15164|p500] As with the tangent ratio, you can use the sin and cos keys on your calculator to find the sine and cosine ratios associated with given angles. You ca...
[15165|p500] Before looking at some worked examples you should note that with three possible ratios you need to know how to pick the right one! 'SOHCAHTOA' might h...
[15167|p500] The letters 'SOHCAHTOA' can be divided into three triangles of letters, each representing one of the three trigonometric ratios. The first letter in e...
[15168|p500] For example, if a problem involves the opposite and hypotenuse, you simply need to find the triangle of letters that includes 'O' and 'H': SOH.
[15169|p500] The 'S' tells you that it is the sine ratio, the 'O' at the top of the triangle sits on top of the fraction, and the lower 'H' sits on the bottom.
[15170|p500] The use of 'SOHCAHTOA' is shown clearly in the following worked examples. The tangent ratio has been included again in these examples to help show you...
[15171|p500|T1] TIP
[15172|p500] S = sine
[15173|p500] $0 =$  opposite
[15174|p500] H = hypotenuse
[15175|p500] C = cosine
[15176|p500] A = adjacent
[15177|p500] T = tan

[15212|p502|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[15213|p502] A ladder  $4.8\mathrm{m}$  long leans against a vertical wall and on horizontal ground. The ladder makes an angle of  $70^{\circ}$  with the ground.
[15214|p502] a How far up the wall does the ladder reach?
[15215|p502] b How far is the bottom of the ladder from the wall?
[15217|p502|T1] Answers
[15218|p502] a In the diagram, AC is the hypotenuse of the right-angled triangle ABC. AB is the distance that the ladder reaches up the wall.
[15219|p502] $$
\begin{array}{l} \mathrm {o p p} (7 0 ^ {\circ}) = A B \\ \mathrm {h y p} = 4. 8 \mathrm {m} \\ \mathrm {S o} \sin 7 0 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\mathrm {...
[15222|p502] So the ladder reaches  $4.5\mathrm{m}$  up the wall.
[15223|p502] b The distance of the bottom of the ladder from the wall is BC.
[15224|p502] $$
\begin{array}{l} \operatorname {a d j} (7 0 ^ {\circ}) = B C \\ \mathrm {h y p} = 4. 8 \mathrm {m} \\ \mathrm {S o} \cos 7 0 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\ma...
[15227|p502] The bottom of the ladder is  $1.64\mathrm{m}$  from the wall.

[15359|p506|T1] INVESTIGATION
[15360|p506] 16 Using trigonometry is sometimes called triangulation. Investigate how triangulation is used in surveying and how this is used to locate satellites ...
[15361|p506|T1] 15.4 Exact trigonometric ratios
[15362|p506] You saw in Chapter 3 that some angles arise naturally in familiar shapes. Here are some important examples.
[15363|p506] Equilateral triangles contain three  $60^{\circ}$  angles:
[15365|p506] $$
\begin{array}{l} x + x + x = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 3 x = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} \\ x = \frac {1 8 0 ^ {\circ}}{3} = 6 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \end{a...
[15366|p506] Isosceles right-angled triangles contain one  $90^{\circ}$  angle and two  $45^{\circ}$  angles:
[15368|p506] $$
\begin{array}{l} y + y + 9 0 ^ {\circ} = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 2 y = 9 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y = \frac {9 0 ^ {\circ}}{2}...
[15369|p506] Think about an isosceles right-angled triangle, where the two shorter sides are both 1 cm long.
[15371|p506] By Pythagoras' theorem:
[15372|p506] $$
\begin{array}{l} d ^ {2} = 1 ^ {2} + 1 ^ {2} = 2 \\ \Rightarrow d = \sqrt {2} \\ \end{array}
$$
[15373|p507] This means that  $d$  is the exact length of the hypotenuse, which you can now use to find the exact values of some trigonometric ratios:
[15374|p507] $$
\sin 4 5 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\text {o p p o s i t e}}{\text {h y p o t e n u s e}} = \frac {1}{\sqrt {2}}
$$
[15375|p507] $$
\cos 4 5 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\text {a d j a c e n t}}{\text {h y p o t e n u s e}} = \frac {1}{\sqrt {2}}
$$
[15376|p507] $$
\tan 4 5 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\text {o p p o s i t e}}{\text {a d j a c e n t}} = \frac {1}{1} = 1
$$
[15377|p507] $$
= \frac {1}{\sqrt {2}} \times \frac {\sqrt {2}}{\sqrt {2}} = \frac {\sqrt {2}}{2}
$$
[15378|p507] $$
= \frac {1}{\sqrt {2}} \times \frac {\sqrt {2}}{\sqrt {2}} = \frac {\sqrt {2}}{2}
$$
[15379|p507|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[15380|p507] You learnt about irrational numbers in Chapter 9. Surds such as  $\sqrt{2}$  and recurring decimals such as  $\frac{2}{3}$  are irrational numbers and...
[15381|p507] When a question asks for an answer in exact form, you need to leave surds in root form and recurring decimals as fractions.
[15382|p507] You can also use an equilateral triangle, with side  $2\mathrm{cm}$ , to find exact trigonometric ratios for the sine, cosine and tangent of  $30^{\ci...
[15384|p507] By Pythagoras' theorem:
[15385|p507] $$
\begin{array}{l} d ^ {2} + 1 ^ {2} = 2 ^ {2} \\ \Rightarrow d ^ {2} = 4 - 1 = 3 \\ \Rightarrow \quad d = \sqrt {3} \\ \end{array}
$$
[15386|p507] If you think about the angle  $60^{\circ}$  shown in the diagram. Side  $CD$  is the opposite,  $BD$  is the adjacent and  $BC$  is the hypotenuse.
[15387|p507] $$
\begin{array}{l} \sin 6 0 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\text {o p p o s i t e}}{\text {h y p o t e n u s e}} \\ \cos 6 0 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\text {a d j a c ...
[15388|p507] If you think about the angle marked  $30^{\circ}$  instead, then  $BD$  becomes the opposite,  $CD$  becomes the adjacent and  $BC$  remains the hypot...
[15389|p507] $$
\sin 3 0 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\text {o p p o s i t e}}{\text {h y p o t e n u s e}}
$$
[15390|p507] $$
\cos 3 0 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\text {a d j a c e n t}}{\text {h y p o t e n u s e}}
$$
[15391|p507] $$
\tan 3 0 ^ {\circ} = \frac {\text {o p p o s i t e}}{\text {a d j a c e n t}} = \frac {1}{\sqrt {3}}
$$
[15392|p507] $$
= \frac {1}{2}
$$
[15393|p507] $$
= \frac {\sqrt {3}}{2}
$$
[15394|p507] $$
= \frac {1}{\sqrt {3}} \times \frac {\sqrt {3}}{\sqrt {3}} = \frac {\sqrt {3}}{3}
$$
[15395|p508] It is important to notice that you can write the exact values of fractions involving surds in more than one way. Mathematicians usually prefer to use ...
