[15401|p508] [Table Row] <tr><td>30°</td><td>1/2</td><td>√3/2</td><td>1/√3 or √3/3</td></tr>
[15402|p508] [Table Row] <tr><td>45°</td><td>1/√2 or √2/2</td><td>1/√2 or √2/2</td><td>1</td></tr>
[15403|p508] [Table Row] <tr><td>60°</td><td>√3/2</td><td>1/2</td><td>√3</td></tr>
[15404|p508] [Table Row] <tr><td>90°</td><td>1</td><td>0</td><td>Doesn’t exist</td></tr>
[15405|p508|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11
[15406|p508] Find the exact area of the triangle shown in the diagram.
[15408|p508|T1] Answer
[15409|p508] First, find the height of the triangle,  $h$
[15410|p508] $$
\begin{array}{l} \tan 6 0 ^ {\circ} = \frac {h}{5} \\ \Rightarrow h = 5 \tan 6 0 ^ {\circ} \\ \end{array}
$$
[15411|p508] $h = 5\sqrt{3}\mathrm{cm}$  using the exact value of tan  $60^{\circ}$
[15412|p508] $$
\begin{array}{l} \text {A r e a} = \frac {1}{2} \times \text {b a s e} \times \text {h e i g h t} \\ = \frac {1}{2} \times 5 \times 5 \sqrt {3} \\ ...

[15427|p510|T1] 15.5 Solving problems using trigonometry
[15428|p510] You may need to use more than one trigonometric ratio when you solve problems that involve right-angled triangles. To make it clear which ratio to use...
[15429|p510] - If the question does not include a diagram, draw one. Make it clear and large.
[15430|p510] - Identify any right-angled triangles that may be useful to you.
[15431|p510] - Draw each triangle separately and clearly label any sides and angles that you already know.
[15432|p510] - Write down which of the opposite, adjacent and hypotenuse you are going to use, and then use SOHCAHTOA to help you decide which ratio to use.
[15433|p510] Write down the ratio and solve, either for an angle or a side.
[15434|p510] - If you need to use a side or angle that you have calculated for another part of a question, try to use the unrounded value that you have in your cal...
[15435|p510|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[15436|p510] It will be useful to remind yourself about general angle properties of triangles from Chapter 3.
[15437|p510|T1] Calculating distances
[15438|p510] In mathematics, when you are asked to calculate the distance from a point to a line you are expected to find the shortest distance between the point a...
[15439|p510] In this diagram, the distance from  $P$  to the line  $AB$  is 5 units.
[15441|p510] Any other line from the point to the line creates a right-angled triangle and the line itself becomes the hypotenuse of that triangle. Any hypotenuse ...
[15442|p510] There are different ways of working out the distance between a point and a line. The method you choose will depend on the information you are given. F...
[15444|p511|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[15445|p511] You will use the distance between a point and a line again when you deal with circles in Chapter 19.
[15446|p511] Worked example 12 shows you how to use trigonometry to find the distance between point  $A$  and the line  $BD$  and then how to use it to solve the p...
[15447|p511|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 12
[15448|p511] The diagram shows an isosceles trapezium ABDC. Calculate the area of the trapezium.
[15450|p511|T1] Answer
[15451|p511] The area of a trapezium  $=$  (mean of the parallel sides)  $\times$  (perpendicular distance between them).
[15452|p511] In this diagram, perpendiculars have been added to form right-angled triangles so that trigonometry can be used.
[15454|p511] $AC = MN$  and you can find the length of MN if you calculate the lengths of BM and ND.
[15455|p511] In triangle  ${ABM}$  ,  $\sin {60}^{ \circ  } = \frac{\operatorname{opp}\left( {60}^{ \circ  }\right) }{\operatorname{hyp}} = \frac{AM}{4.6}$  and  $...
[15456|p511] Hence,  $AM = 4.6 \times \sin 60^\circ$  and  $BM = 4.6 \times \cos 60^\circ$
[15457|p511] $AM = 3.983716\ldots cm$  and  $BM = 2.3cm$
[15458|p511] By symmetry,  $ND = BM = 2.3\mathrm{cm}$
[15459|p511] and  $\therefore MN = 8.2 - (2.3 + 2.3) = 3.6\mathrm{cm}$
[15460|p511] Hence,  $AC = 3.6$  cm and  $AM = CN = 3.983716 \dots$  cm
[15461|p511] The area of  $ABDC = \left(\frac{AC + BD}{2}\right)\times AM$
[15462|p511] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \left(\frac {3 . 6 + 8 . 2}{2}\right) \times 3. 9 8 3 7 1 6 \dots \mathrm {c m} ^ {2} \\ = 2 3. 5 0 3 9 2 9 \dots \mathrm {c m} ...
[15463|p511] Area of ABDC  $= 23.5\mathrm{cm}^2$  (to 3 s.f.)
[15464|p511|T1] TIP
[15465|p511] Give your answer to 3 significant figures if no degree of accuracy is specified.
[15466|p512|T1] LINK
[15467|p512] Trigonometry is used to work out lengths and angles when they can't really be measured. For example in navigation, surveying, engineering, constructio...
[15468|p512|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13
[15469|p512] The span between the towers of Tower Bridge in London is  $76\mathrm{m}$ . When the arms of the bridge are raised to an angle of  $35^{\circ}$ , how w...
[15471|p512|T1] Answer
[15472|p512] Here is a simplified labelled drawing of the bridge, showing the two halves raised to  $35^{\circ}$ .
[15474|p512] The gap  $= BD = MN$  and  $MN = AC - (AM + NC)$
[15475|p512] The right-angled triangles  $ABM$  and  $CDN$  are congruent, so  $AM = NC$ .
[15476|p512] When the two halves are lowered, they must meet in the middle.
[15477|p512] $$
\therefore A B = C D = \frac {7 6}{2} = 3 8 m
$$
[15478|p512] In triangle ABM, cos  $35^{\circ} = \frac{\text{adj}(35^{\circ})}{\text{hyp}} = \frac{\text{AM}}{38}$
[15479|p512] $$
\begin{array}{l} A M = 3 8 \times \cos 3 5 ^ {\circ} \\ = 3 1. 1 2 7 7 \dots m \\ \end{array}
$$
[15480|p512] $$
\begin{array}{l} \therefore M N = 7 6 - (3 1. 1 2 7 7 \dots + 3 1. 1 2 7 7 \dots) \\ = 1 3. 7 4 4 \dots m \\ \end{array}
$$
[15481|p512] The gap  $BD = 13.7\mathrm{m}$  (to 3 s.f.)
[15482|p512|T1] TIP
[15483|p512] Drawing a clear, labelled sketch can help you work out what mathematics you need to do to solve the problem.

[15531|p516|T1] 15.6 Sines, cosines and tangents of angles greater than  $90^{\circ}$
[15532|p516] You have now seen that we can find the sine, cosine or tangent of an angle in a triangle by using your calculator.
[15533|p516] It is possible to find sines, cosines and tangents of angles of any size.
[15534|p516|T1] INVESTIGATION
[15535|p516] Relationships between sines, cosines and tangents
[15536|p516] Use a calculator to find each of the following:
[15537|p516] sin 30° and sin 150°
[15538|p516] sin 10° and sin 170°
[15539|p516] sin 60° and sin 120°
[15540|p516] sin5° and sin175°
[15541|p516] What did you notice? What is the relationship between the two angles in each pair?
[15542|p516] Now do the same for these pairs:
[15543|p516] [Table Row] <tr><td>cos30°and cos330°</td><td>tan30°and tan210°</td></tr>
[15544|p516] [Table Row] <tr><td>cos60°and cos300°</td><td>tan60°and tan240°</td></tr>
[15545|p516] [Table Row] <tr><td>cos50°and cos310°</td><td>tan15°and tan195°</td></tr>
[15546|p516] [Table Row] <tr><td>cos15°and cos345°</td><td>tan100and tan280°</td></tr>
[15547|p516] The pattern is different for each of sine, cosine and tangent.
[15548|p516] Try plotting the value of  $\sin \theta$ ,  $\cos \theta$  and  $\tan \theta$  against  $\theta$  for several values of  $\theta$ . You can find a gra...
[15549|p516] In the rest of this section you will explore the graphs of  $y = \sin \theta$ ,  $y = \cos \theta$  and  $y = \tan \theta$  in more detail.
[15550|p516|T1] The graph of  $y = \sin \theta$
[15551|p516] If you plot several values of  $\sin \theta$  against  $\theta$  you will get the following:
[15553|p517] The graph repeats itself every  $360^{\circ}$  in both the positive and negative directions.
[15554|p517] Notice that the section of the graph between 0 and  $180^{\circ}$  has reflection symmetry, with the line of reflection being  $\theta = 90^{\circ}$ ....
[15555|p517] It is also very important to notice that the value of  $\sin \theta$  is never larger than 1 nor smaller than  $-1$ .
[15556|p517|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[15557|p517] sinθ, cosθ and tanθ are actually functions. Functions take input values and give you a numerical output. For example, if you use your calculator to fi...
[15558|p517|T1] The graph of  $y = \cos \theta$
[15559|p517] If you plot several values of  $\cos \theta$  against  $\theta$  you will get a similar shape, but the line of symmetry is in a different place:
[15561|p517] The graph repeats itself every  $360^{\circ}$  in both the positive and negative directions.
[15562|p517] Here the graph is symmetrical from 0 to  $360^{\circ}$ , with the reflection line at  $\theta = 180^{\circ}$ . This means that  $\cos \theta = \cos (3...
[15563|p517] It is also very important to notice that the value of  $\cos \theta$  is never larger than 1 normally smaller than  $-1$ .
[15564|p518|T1] The graph of  $y = \tan \theta$
[15565|p518] Finally, if you plot values of  $\tan \theta$  against  $\theta$  you get this graph:
[15567|p518] The graph approaches the vertical dotted lines, but it never touches nor crosses them.
[15568|p518] Notice that this graph has no reflection symmetry, but it does repeat every  $180^{\circ}$ . This means that  $\tan \theta = \tan (180^{\circ} + \thet...
[15569|p518] Note that, unlike  $\sin \theta$  and  $\cos \theta$ ,  $\tan \theta$  is not restricted to being less than 1 or greater than -1.
[15570|p518] The shapes of these three graphs means that equations involving sine, cosine or tangent will have multiple solutions. The following examples show you ...
[15571|p518|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[15572|p518] A line that is approached by a graph in this way is known as an asymptote. You will learn more about asymptotes in Chapter 18.
[15573|p518|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 14
[15574|p518] Which acute angle has the same sine as  $120^{\circ}$ ?
[15575|p518|T1] Answer
[15576|p518] $$
\sin (1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - \theta) = \sin \theta
$$
[15577|p518] The graph of  $\sin \theta$  gives this relationship.
[15578|p518] $$
\sin (1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - 1 2 0 ^ {\circ}) = \sin 1 2 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[15579|p518] Let  $\theta = 120^{\circ}$  and subtract to find another angle with the same sine value.
[15580|p518] $$
\sin 6 0 ^ {\circ} = \sin 1 2 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[15581|p519|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[15582|p519] Express each of the following in terms of another angle between  $0^{\circ}$  and  $180^{\circ}$
[15583|p519] a cos100°
[15584|p519] b -cos  $35^{\circ}$
[15585|p519|T1] Answers
[15586|p519] a cos(180°-0）=-cos0
[15587|p519] Start with the general relationship.
[15588|p519] $$
\cos (1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - 1 0 0 ^ {\circ}) = - \cos 1 0 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[15589|p519] Let  $\theta = 100^{\circ}$  and subtract.
[15590|p519] $$
\cos 8 0 ^ {\circ} = - \cos 1 0 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[15591|p519] So, cos  $100^{\circ} = -\cos 80^{\circ}$
[15592|p519] Rearrange to find another value equal to  $\cos 100^{\circ}$
[15593|p519] b -cosθ=cos(180°-θ)
[15594|p519] $$
- \cos 3 5 ^ {\circ} = \cos 1 4 5 ^ {\circ}
$$
[15595|p519|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 16
[15596|p519] Solve the following equations, giving all possible solutions in the range 0 to 360 degrees.
[15597|p519] a sinθ=√2
[15598|p519] .b tanθ=3
[15599|p519] c cosx=-
[15600|p519|T1] Answers

[15602|p519] Now mark  $\theta = 45$  degrees on a sketch of the graph  $y = \sin \theta$  and draw the line  $y = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$  like this:
[15604|p519] Using the symmetry of the graph, you can see that there is another solution at  $\theta = 135^{\circ}$ .
[15605|p519] Use your calculator to check that sin  $135^{\circ} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$ .
[15606|p519] Notice that  $135^{\circ} = 180^{\circ} - 45^{\circ}$ . You can use this rule, but drawing a sketch graph always makes it easier to understand why the...
[15607|p519|T1] TIP
[15608|p519] As well as  $\theta$  other variables can be used to represent the angle. In part (c) of the example,  $x$  is used. You work in exactly the same way ...
[15609|p519|T1] TIP
[15610|p519] This only needs to be a sketch and doesn't need to be accurate. It should be just enough for you to see how the symmetry can help.
[15611|p520|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 16 CONTINUED
[15612|p520] b Use your calculator to find one solution:  $\tan^{-1}(3) = 71.6^{\circ}$ . As before, mark this on a sketch of the graph  $y = \tan \theta$  and dra...
[15614|p520] You can see that the second solution is  $180^{\circ} + 71.6^{\circ} = 251.6^{\circ}$ . More solutions can be found by adding 180 degrees over and ove...
[15615|p520] c Use your calculator to find one solution:  $\cos^{-1}\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right) = 120^{\circ}$  Draw a sketch and mark the values:
[15617|p520] You can now see that the second solution will be at  $360^{\circ} - 120^{\circ} = 240^{\circ}$ .
[15618|p520|T1] TIP
[15619|p520] Note that you only need to sketch the part of the graph for 0 to  $360^{\circ}$  because you are only looking for solutions between these two values o...
[15620|p520] There are more solutions, but in the range 0 to  $360^{\circ}$  the line  $y = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$  only meets the graph  $y = \sin \theta$  twice.

[15665|p521|T1] 15.7 The sine and cosine rules
[15666|p521] The sine and cosine ratios are not only useful for right-angled triangles. To understand the following rules you must first look at the standard way o...
[15667|p521] Notice that the sides are labelled with lower case letters and the angles are labelled with upper case letters. The side that is placed opposite angle...
[15668|p521|T1] TIP
[15669|p521] Write  $\cos x = y$  and try to factorise.
[15671|p521|T1] The sine rule
[15672|p521] For the triangle shown on the right, the following are true:
[15673|p521] $$
\frac {\sin A}{a} = \frac {\sin B}{b} \text {a n d} \frac {\sin A}{a} = \frac {\sin C}{c} \text {a n d} \frac {\sin B}{b} = \frac {\sin C}{c}
$$
[15674|p521] These relationships are usually expressed in one go:
[15675|p521] $$
\frac {\sin A}{a} = \frac {\sin B}{b} = \frac {\sin C}{c}
$$
[15676|p521] This is the sine rule. This version of the rule, with the sine ratios placed on the tops of the fractions, is normally used to calculate angles.
[15677|p521] The formulae can also be turned upside down when you want to calculate lengths:
[15678|p521] $$
\frac {a}{\sin A} = \frac {b}{\sin B} = \frac {c}{\sin C}
$$
[15679|p521] You should remember that this represents three possible relationships.
[15680|p521] Notice that in each case, both the upper and lower case form of each letter is used. This means that each fraction that you use requires an angle and ...
[15681|p521|T1] TIP
[15682|p521] Remember, the sine rule is used when you are dealing with pairs of opposite sides and angles.
[15683|p521] 国
[15684|p522|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 17
[15685|p522] In  $\Delta ABC, A = 80^{\circ}, B = 30^{\circ}$  and side  $BC = 15\mathrm{cm}$
[15686|p522] Calculate the size of  $C$  and the lengths of the sides  $AB$  and  $AC$ .
[15688|p522|T1] Answer
[15689|p522] To calculate the angle  $C$ , use the fact that the sum of the three angles in a triangle is always  $180^\circ$
[15690|p522] $$
S o, C + 8 0 + 3 0 = 1 8 0 \Rightarrow C = 1 8 0 - 3 0 - 8 0 = 7 0 ^ {\circ}
$$
[15691|p522] Now think about the side AB. AB is opposite the angle C (forming an 'opposite pair') and side BC is opposite angle A, forming a second 'opposite pair'...
[15692|p522] So, write down the version of the sine rule that uses these pairs:
[15693|p522] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {a}{\sin A} = \frac {c}{\sin C} \Rightarrow \frac {B C}{\sin A} = \frac {A B}{\sin C} \\ \mathrm {S o}, \frac {1 5}{\sin 8 0...
[15694|p522] Similarly:
[15695|p522] AC forms an opposite pair with angle B, so once again use the pair BC and angle A:
[15696|p522] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {a}{\sin A} = \frac {b}{\sin B} \Rightarrow \frac {B C}{\sin A} = \frac {A C}{\sin B} \\ \mathrm {S o}, \frac {1 5}{\sin 8 0...
[15697|p522|T1] The ambiguous case of the sine rule
[15698|p522] The special properties of the sine function can lead to more than one possible answer.
[15699|p522] Worked example 18 demonstrates how this may happen.
[15700|p522|T1] TIP
[15701|p522] The word 'ambiguous' means that there is more than one way to interpret the question being asked. Here the ambiguous case arises because there are two...
[15702|p523|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18
[15703|p523] In triangle  $DEF,DF = 10cm,EF = 7cm$  and angle  $EDF = 34^{\circ}$
[15704|p523] Calculate, to the nearest degree, the possible size of:
[15705|p523] a angleDEF
[15706|p523] b angle DFE.
[15708|p523|T1] Answers
[15709|p523] a Angle DEF is opposite a side of length 10cm. This forms one pair.
[15710|p523] Angle EDF is opposite a side of length  $7\mathrm{cm}$  . This forms the second pair.
[15711|p523] You are trying to find an angle, so choose the version of the sine rule with the value of sine ratios in the numerators:
[15712|p523] $$
\frac {\sin 3 4 ^ {\circ}}{7} = \frac {\sin E}{1 0} \Rightarrow \sin E = 1 0 \times \frac {\sin 3 4 ^ {\circ}}{7}
$$
[15713|p523] So, angle  $DEF = \sin^{-1}\left(10 \times \frac{\sin 34^\circ}{7}\right) = 53.0^\circ$
[15714|p523] But there is actually a second angle DEF such that  $\sin E = 10 \times \frac{\sin 34^\circ}{7}$ .
[15715|p523] You can see this if you consider the sine graph. The values of both  $\sin x$  and  $\cos x$  repeat every  $360^{\circ}$ . This property of both func...
[15716|p523] Both of these are possible values of angle DEF because there are two ways to draw such a triangle.
[15718|p523] b Of course, the answers to part (a) must lead to two possible answers for part (b).
[15719|p523] If angle  $DEF = 127.0^{\circ}$ , then angle  $DFE = 180^{\circ} - 127^{\circ} - 34^{\circ} = 19^{\circ}$  (shown as  $E_{1}$  in the diagram).
[15720|p523] If angle  $DEF = 53.0^{\circ}$ , then angle  $DFE = 180^{\circ} - 53^{\circ} - 34^{\circ} = 93^{\circ}$  (shown as  $E_{2}$  in the diagram).
[15721|p523] (If you had been asked for the length  $DE$ , there would also have been two possible solutions.)
[15722|p523] You must always take care to check that all possible answers have been calculated. Bear this in mind as you work through the following exercise.
[15723|p524|T1] Exercise 15.11
[15724|p524] 1 Find the value of  $x$  in each of the following equations.
[15725|p524] a  $\frac{x}{\sin 50} = \frac{9}{\sin 98}$
[15726|p524] x 20 b sin25 sin100
[15727|p524] 20.6 x 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10...
[15728|p524] sinx sin63 d 11.4 16.2
[15729|p524] 2 Find the length of the side marked  $x$  in each of the following triangles.
[15736|p524] 3 Find the size of the angle marked  $\theta$  in the following triangles. Give your answers correct to 1 decimal place.
[15743|p524] 4 In triangle  $ABC, A = 72^\circ, B = 45^\circ$  and side  $AB = 20\mathrm{cm}$ . Calculate the size of  $C$  and the lengths of the sides  $AC$  and...
[15745|p524] 5 In triangle  $DEF, D = 140^{\circ}, E = 15^{\circ}$  and side  $DF = 6\mathrm{m}$  Calculate the size of  $F$  and the lengths of the sides  $DE$  a...
[15747|p525] 6 In triangle  $PQR, Q = 120^{\circ}$ , side  $PQ = 8\mathrm{cm}$  and side  $PR = 13\mathrm{cm}$ . Calculate the size of  $R$ , the size of  $P$ , an...
[15749|p525] 7 In triangle  $XYZ$ ,  $X = 40^{\circ}$ , side  $XZ = 12\mathrm{cm}$  and side  $YZ = 15\mathrm{cm}$ .
[15750|p525] a Explain why  $Y$  must be less than  $40^{\circ}$
[15751|p525] b Calculate, correct to 1 decimal place,  $Y$  and  $Z$
[15752|p525] c. Calculate the length of the side  $XY$ .
[15754|p525] 8  $ABCD$  is a parallelogram with  $AB = 32\mathrm{mm}$  and  $AD = 40\mathrm{mm}$  and angle  $BAC = 77^{\circ}$
[15756|p525] a Find the size of angle  $BCA$  (to the nearest degree).
[15757|p525] b Find the size of angle  $ABC$  (to the nearest degree).
[15758|p525] c Find the length of diagonal  $AC$  correct to 2 decimal places.
[15759|p525|T1] Cosine rule
[15760|p525] For the cosine rule, consider a triangle labelled in exactly the same way as that used for the sine rule.
[15762|p525] The cosine rule is stated as a single formula:
[15763|p525] $$
a ^ {2} = b ^ {2} + c ^ {2} - 2 b c \cos A
$$
[15764|p526] Notice that all three sides are used in the formula, and just one angle. The side whose square is the subject of the formula is opposite the angle use...
[15765|p526] $$
b ^ {2} = a ^ {2} + c ^ {2} - 2 a c \cos B \quad \text {o r} \quad c ^ {2} = a ^ {2} + b ^ {2} - 2 a b \cos C
$$
[15766|p526] Notice, also, that you can rearrange any version of the formula to make the cosine ratio the subject.
[15767|p526] This version can be used to calculate angles:
[15768|p526] $$
\begin{array}{l} a ^ {2} = b ^ {2} + c ^ {2} - 2 b c \cos A \\ \Rightarrow a ^ {2} + 2 b c \cos A = b ^ {2} + c ^ {2} \\ \Rightarrow 2 b c \cos A =...
[15769|p526|T1] TIP
[15770|p526] Remember, if you know all three sides of a triangle, you can use the cosine rule to find any angle. If you know two sides, and the unknown side is opp...
[15771|p526|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 19
[15772|p526] In triangle  $ABC, B = 50^{\circ}$ , side  $AB = 9\mathrm{cm}$  and side  $BC = 18\mathrm{cm}$ .
[15773|p526] Calculate the length of AC.
[15775|p526|T1] Answer
[15776|p526] Notice that  $AC = b$  and you know that  $B = 50^\circ$ .
[15777|p526] Use the cosine rule in the form,  $b^{2} = a^{2} + c^{2} - 2ac\cos B$ .
[15778|p526] $$
\begin{array}{l} b ^ {2} = 9 ^ {2} + 1 8 ^ {2} - (2 \times 9 \times 1 8 \times \cos 5 0 ^ {\circ}) \\ = 8 1 + 3 2 4 - (2 0 8. 2 6 3 1 \dots) \\ = 1...
[15779|p526] $$
\begin{array}{l} \therefore b = \sqrt {1 9 6 . 7 3 6 8 \dots} \\ = 1 4. 0 2 6 2 \dots \\ \end{array}
$$
[15780|p526] Length of AC = 14.0cm (to 3 s.f.)
[15782|p526|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[15783|p526] You learned how to rearrange a formula in Chapter 6.
[15784|p527|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 20
[15785|p527] In triangle DEF,  $F = 120^{\circ}$ , side  $EF = 25$  m and side  $FD = 34$  m. Calculate the length of side  $DE$ .
[15787|p527|T1] Answer
[15788|p527] $DE = f,$  so use the cosine rule in the form,  $f^2 = d^2 +e^2 -2de\cos F.$
[15789|p527] $$
\begin{array}{l} f ^ {2} = 2 5 ^ {2} + 3 4 ^ {2} - (2 \times 2 5 \times 3 4 \times \cos 1 2 0 ^ {\circ}) \\ = 6 2 5 + 1 1 5 6 - (- 8 5 0) \quad \te...
[15790|p527] $$
\begin{array}{l} \therefore f = \sqrt {2 6 3 1} \\ = 5 1. 2 9 3 2 \dots \\ \end{array}
$$
[15791|p527] Length of  $DE = 51.3\mathrm{m}$  (to 3 s.f.)
[15792|p527|T1] Combining the sine and cosine rules
[15793|p527] The following worked examples show how you can combine the sine and cosine rules to solve problems.
[15794|p527|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 21
[15795|p527] In triangle  $PQR,R = 100^{\circ}$  ,side  $PR = 8cm$  and side  $RQ = 5cm$
[15796|p527] a Calculate the length of side PQ.
[15797|p527] b Calculate, correct to the nearest degree,  $P$  and  $Q$
[15799|p527|T1] Answers
[15800|p527] a  $PQ = r$  , so use the cosine rule in the form,  $r^2 = p^2 +q^2 -2pq\cos R.$
[15801|p527] $$
\begin{array}{l} r ^ {2} = 5 ^ {2} + 8 ^ {2} - (2 \times 5 \times 8 \times \cos 1 0 0 ^ {\circ}) \\ = 2 5 + 6 4 - (- 1 3. 8 9 1 8 \dots) \quad \tex...
[15802|p527] $$
\begin{array}{l} \therefore r = \sqrt {1 0 2 . 8 9 1 8 \dots} \\ = 1 0. 1 4 3 5 \dots \\ \end{array}
$$
[15803|p527] Length of  $PQ = 10.1 \, \text{cm}$  (to 3 s.f.)
[15804|p528|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 21 CONTINUED
[15805|p528] b Now you know the value of  $r$  as well as the value of  $R$ , you can use the sine rule:
[15806|p528] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {\sin P}{P} = \frac {\sin Q}{q} = \frac {\sin R}{r} \\ \frac {\sin P}{5} = \frac {\sin Q}{8} = \frac {\sin 1 0 0 ^ {\circ}}{...
[15807|p528] Using the first and third fractions, sin  $P = \frac{5 \times \sin 100^{\circ}}{10.1435 \dots} = 0.4853 \dots$
[15808|p528] $R$  is obtuse so  $P$  is acute, and  $P = 29.0409\dots$
[15809|p528] $$
P = 2 9 ^ {\circ} (\text {t o t h e n e a r e s t d e g r e e})
$$
[15810|p528] To find  $Q$  you can use the angle sum of a triangle  $= 180^{\circ}$
[15811|p528] $$
Q = 1 8 0 ^ {\circ} - (1 0 0 ^ {\circ} + 2 9 ^ {\circ})
$$
[15812|p528] :Q=51°(to the nearest degree)
[15813|p528|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 22
[15814|p528] a Change the subject of the formula  $c^2 = a^2 +b^2 -2ab\cos C$  to cos C.
[15815|p528] b Use your answer to part (a) to find the smallest angle in the triangle which has sides of length  $7\mathrm{m},8\mathrm{m}$  and  $13\mathrm{m}$
[15816|p528|T1] Answers
[15817|p528] a  $c^2 = a^2 +b^2 -2ab\cos C$
[15818|p528] $$
2 a b \cos C = a ^ {2} + b ^ {2} - c ^ {2}
$$
[15819|p528] $$
\cos C = \frac {a ^ {2} + b ^ {2} - c ^ {2}}{2 a b}
$$
[15820|p528] b The smallest angle in a triangle is opposite the shortest side. In the given triangle, the smallest angle is opposite the  $7\mathrm{m}$  side. Let ...
[15821|p528] Then  $c = 7$  and take  $a = 8$  and  $b = 13$ .
[15822|p528] Using the result of part (a):
[15823|p528] $$
\begin{array}{l} \cos C = \frac {8 ^ {2} + 1 3 ^ {2} - 7 ^ {2}}{2 \times 8 \times 1 3} \\ = \frac {6 4 + 1 6 9 - 4 9}{2 0 8} \\ = \frac {1 8 4}{2 0...
[15824|p528] $$
\begin{array}{l} C = \cos^ {- 1} \frac {1 8 4}{2 0 8} \\ = 2 7. 7 9 5 7 \dots^ {\circ} \\ \end{array}
$$
[15825|p528] The smallest angle of the triangle  $= 27.8^{\circ}$  (to 1 d.p.)
[15826|p528|T1] TIP
[15827|p528] If you need to use a previously calculated value for a new problem, leave unrounded answers in your calculator to avoid introducing rounding errors.

[15854|p530|T1] 15.8 Area of a triangle
[15855|p530] You already know that the area of a triangle is given by the following formula:
[15856|p530] This method can be used if you know both the length of the base and perpendicular height, but if you don't have these values you need to use another m...
[15857|p530] You can calculate the area of any triangle by using trigonometry.
[15859|p531] Look at the triangle  $ABC$  shown in the diagram:
[15862|p531] The second copy of the triangle is drawn with a perpendicular height that you don't yet know, but if you draw the right-angled triangle  $BCM$  separa...
[15864|p531] Now note that  $\mathrm{opp}(C) = h$  and the hypotenuse  $= a$ .
[15865|p531] Using the sine ratio:  $\sin C = \frac{h}{a} \Rightarrow h = a \sin C$
[15866|p531] This means that you now know the perpendicular height and can use the base length  $b$  to calculate the area:
[15867|p531] $$
\begin{array}{l} \text {A r e a} = \frac {1}{2} \times \text {b a s e} \times \text {p e r p e n d i c u l a r h e i g h t} \\ = \frac {1}{2} \time...
[15868|p531] In fact you could use any side of the triangle as the base and draw the perpendicular height accordingly. This means that the area can also be calcula...
[15869|p531] $$
\text {A r e a} = \frac {1}{2} a c \sin B \text {o r} \text {A r e a} = \frac {1}{2} b c \sin A
$$
[15870|p531] In each case the sides used meet at the angle that has been included.

[15878|p532] $$
\begin{array}{l} \text {A r e a} = \frac {1}{2} a c \sin B \\ = \frac {1}{2} \times 1 7 \times 1 4 \times \sin 5 8 ^ {\circ} \\ = 1 0 0. 9 \mathrm ...
[15879|p532|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 24

[15882|p532|T1] Answer
[15883|p532] Notice that the area  $= \frac{1}{2} \times 8.4 \times 9.2 \times \sin F = 20$
[15884|p532] $$
\sin F = \frac {2 \times 2 0}{8 . 4 \times 9 . 2}
$$
[15885|p532] $$
\begin{array}{l} S _ {0} F = \sin^ {- 1} \left(\frac {2 \times 2 0}{8 . 4 \times 9 . 2}\right) \\ = 3 1. 2 ^ {\circ} (\text {t o} 1 \text {d . p .}...

[15915|p534|T1] 15.9 Trigonometry in three dimensions
[15916|p534] You can also use the trigonometry ratios to solve problems in three dimensions. With problems of this kind you must draw and label each triangle as yo...
[15917|p534] When you work with solids you may need to calculate the angle between an edge, or a diagonal, and one of the faces. This is called the angle between a...
[15918|p534] Consider a line  $PQ$ , which meets a plane  $ABCD$  at point  $P$ . Through  $P$  draw lines  $PR_1, PR_2, PR_3, \ldots$  in the plane and consider t...
[15920|p534] - If  $PQ$  is perpendicular to the plane, all these angles will be right angles.
[15921|p534] If  $PQ$  is not perpendicular to the plane, these angles will vary in size.
[15922|p534] It is the smallest of these angles which is called the angle between the line  $PQ$  and the plane  $ABCD$ .
[15923|p534] To identify this angle, do the following:
[15924|p534] From  $Q$  draw a perpendicular to the plane. Call the foot of this perpendicular  $R$ .
[15925|p534] The angle between the line  $PO$  and the plane is angle  $OPR$
[15927|p534] $PR$  is called the projection of  $PQ$  on the plane  $ABCD$ .
[15928|p534] The following worked example shows how you might work through a problem in three dimensions.
[15929|p535|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 25
[15930|p535] The diagram represents a room which has the shape of a cuboid.  $AB = 6m$ ,  $AD = 4m$  and  $AP = 2m$ . Calculate the angle between the diagonal  $BS...
[15932|p535|T1] Answer
[15933|p535] First identify the angle required.  $B$  is the point where the diagonal BS meets the plane ABCD.
[15934|p535] ${SD}$  is the perpendicular from  $S$  to the plane  ${ABCD}$  and so  ${DB}$  is the projection of  ${SB}$  onto the plane.
[15936|p535] The angle required is SBD.
[15937|p535] You know that triangle SBD has a right angle at  $D$  and that  $SD = 2m$  (equal to AP).
[15938|p535] To find angle SBD, you need to know the length of DB or the length of SB. You can find the length of BD by using Pythagoras' theorem in triangle ABD.
[15940|p535] $$
\begin{array}{l} B D ^ {2} = 6 ^ {2} + 4 ^ {2} = 3 6 + 1 6 = 5 2 \\ B D = \sqrt {5 2} \\ \end{array}
$$
[15941|p535] So, using right-angled triangle SBD:
[15942|p535] $$
\tan B = \frac {\operatorname {o p p} (B)}{\operatorname {a d j} (B)} = \frac {S D}{B D} = \frac {2}{\sqrt {5 2}}
$$
[15943|p535] Angle SBD = tan-1(2/√52) = 15.5013...
[15944|p535] The angle between diagonal BS and the floor  $ABCD = 15.5^{\circ}$  (to 1 d.p.)
[15946|p535|T1] TIP
[15947|p535] It can be helpful to use colour or shading in diagrams involving 3D situations.
[15948|p536|T1] Exercise 15.14

[15978|p537|T1] SUMMARY
[15979|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>Do you know ...?</td></tr>
[15980|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>A scale drawing is an accurate diagram to represent something that is much bigger, or much smaller.</td></tr>
[15981|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>An angle of elevation is measured upwards from the horizontal.</td></tr>
[15982|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>An angle of depression is measured downwards from the horizontal.</td></tr>
[15983|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>The ratio of any two lengths in a right-angled triangle depends on the angles in the triangle: sinA=opp(A)/hyp cosA=adj(A)/hyp tan...
[15984|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>Bearings are measured clockwise from north.</td></tr>
[15985|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>You can use these trigonometric ratios to calculate an unknown angle from two known sides.</td></tr>
[15986|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>You can use these trigonometric ratios to calculate an unknown side from a known side and a known angle.</td></tr>
[15987|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>The sine, cosine and tangent function can be extended beyond the angles in triangles.</td></tr>
[15988|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>The sine, cosine and tangent functions can be used to solve trigonometric equations.</td></tr>
[15989|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>The sine and cosine rules can be used to calculate unknown sides and angles in triangles that are not right-angled.</td></tr>
[15990|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>The sine rule is used for calculating an angle from another angle and two sides, or a side from another side and two known angles....
[15991|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>The cosine rule is used for calculating an angle from three known sides, or a side from a known angle and two known sides.</td></t...
[15992|p537] [Table Row] <tr><td>You can calculate the area of a non right-angled triangle by using the sine ratio.</td></tr>
[15993|p538|T1] SUMMARY CONTINUED
[15994|p538|T1] Are you able to ...?
[15995|p538] calculate angles of elevation
[15996|p538] calculate angles of depression
[15997|p538] use trigonometry to calculate bearings
[15998|p538] identify which sides are the opposite, adjacent and hypotenuse.
[15999|p538] calculate the sine, cosine and tangent ratio when given lengths in a right-angled triangle.
[16000|p538] use the sine, cosine and tangent ratios to find unknown angles and sides
[16001|p538] solve more complex problems by extracting right-angled triangles and combining sine, cosine and tangent ratios
[16002|p538] Use the sine and cosine rules to find unknown angles and sides in right-angled triangles.
[16003|p538] work with exact values of trigonometric ratios
[16004|p538] use the sine, cosine and tangent functions to solve trigonometric equations, finding all the solutions between 0 and  $360^{\circ}$
[16005|p538] use sine and cosine rules to find unknown angles and sides in triangles that are not right-angled
[16006|p538] use trigonometry in three dimensions
[16007|p538] find the area of a triangle that is not right-angled.

[16075|p541|T1] SELF ASSESSMENT
[16076|p541] You can get good marks in mathematics by clearly showing your working and methods even if you get the final answer incorrect.
[16077|p541] Evaluate your answers to the practice questions.
[16078|p541] Did you show your working?
[16079|p541] Is your working clearly laid out and systematic?
[16080|p541] - Does your working show that you understood the question and give evidence that you know how to answer it?
[16081|p541] - Do you think you would get part marks for any questions where you got the incorrect answer? Support your opinion.
[16082|p542|T1] >Chapter 16
[16083|p542|T1] Scatter diagrams and correlation
[16084|p542|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[16085|p542] - draw scatter diagrams for bivariate data
[16086|p542] - identify whether or not there is a positive or negative correlation between the two variables
[16087|p542] decide whether a correlation is strong or weak
[16088|p542] draw a line of best fit
[16089|p542] use a line of best fit to make predictions
[16090|p542] - decide how reliable your predictions are
[16091|p542] - recognise the common errors that are often made with scatter diagrams.

[16119|p544|T1] Drawing a scatter diagram
[16120|p544] When you plot a scatter diagram, the variable you plot on the vertical axis is called the dependent variable. If one variable clearly depends on the o...
[16121|p544|T1] DISCUSSION
[16122|p544] Think about your answers to question 2 in the Getting started activity, where you thought about pairs of variables you could plot on a scatter diagram...
[16123|p544|T1] LINK
[16124|p544] Correlations are used to investigate possible relationships between variables in many subjects where measurements are taken. For example, a biologist ...
[16125|p544] In the example of the ice cream shop, it seems sensible that the total sales will depend on the temperature, so plot the sales on the vertical axis.
[16126|p544|T1] TIP
[16127|p544] If you are told to plot A against B, then you should plot A on the vertical axis and B on the horizontal axis.
[16129|p545] Notice that there seems to be a relationship between the ice cream sales and the temperature. In fact, the sales rise as the temperature rises. This i...
[16130|p545] If the points been placed from the top left to bottom right you would conclude that the sales decrease as the temperature increases. Under these circu...
[16131|p545] The clearer the pattern is and the closer the points are to a straight line, the stronger the correlation. These graphs show different 'strengths' of ...
[16137|p545] You should always be ready to state whether a correlation is positive, negative, strong or weak.
[16138|p545] Notice on the graph of ice cream sales that one of the results seems to lie outside the general pattern. Unusually high sales were recorded on one day...
[16139|p546|T1] Drawing a line of best fit
[16140|p546] You can also show the general trend by drawing a line of best fit. In the diagram a line has been drawn so that it passes as close to as many points a...
[16142|p546] This is the line of best fit and you can use it to make predictions based on the collected data.
[16143|p546] For example, if you want to try to predict the ice cream sales on a day with a temperature of  $27^{\circ}C$ , you carry out the following steps:
[16144|p546] 1. Locate  $27^{\circ}C$  on the temperature axis.
[16145|p546] 2 Draw a clear line vertically from this point to the line of best fit.
[16146|p546] 3 Draw a horizontal line from the point on the line of best fit to the sales axis.
[16147|p546] 4 Read the sales value from the graph.
[16148|p546] The diagram now looks like this and the estimated value for the sales is approximately $575.

[16156|p547] a Draw a scatter diagram, with height on the horizontal axis and foot length on the vertical axis.
[16157|p547] b State what type of correlation the diagram shows.
[16158|p547] c Draw a line of best fit.
[16159|p547] d Estimate the foot length of a person with height 164 cm.
[16160|p547] Estimate the height of a person with foot length  $17\mathrm{cm}$
[16161|p547] f Comment on the likely accuracy of your estimates in parts (d) and (e).
[16162|p547|T1] Answers
[16164|p547|T1] TIP
[16165|p547] When commenting on correlation, always make sure that you refer back to the original context of the question.
[16166|p548|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1 CONTINUED
[16167|p548] b This is a strong positive correlation because foot length generally increases with height. We can make good predictions of foot length from someone'...
[16168|p548] c The line of best fit is drawn on the diagram. The line should extend across the entire data set and there should be approximately equal numbers of p...
[16169|p548] d The appropriate lines are drawn on the diagram. A height of  $164\mathrm{cm}$  corresponds to a foot length of approximately  $26\mathrm{cm}$ .
[16170|p548] e A foot length of  $17\mathrm{cm}$  corresponds to a height of approximately  $132\mathrm{cm}$
[16171|p548] Most points are reasonably close to the line, so the correlation is fairly strong. This means that the line of best fit will allow a good level of acc...
[16172|p548|T1] TIP
[16173|p548] If you are asked to comment on a prediction that you have made, always keep in mind the strength of the correlation as shown in the diagram. If the co...
[16174|p548|T1] Extrapolation
[16175|p548] Before you draw and interpret some scatter diagrams for yourself you should be aware that there may be problems with making predictions outside the ra...
[16176|p548] In Worked example 1, the data does not include any heights above  $183.4\mathrm{cm}$ . The trend may not continue or it may look different for greater...
[16177|p548] The process of extending the line of best fit beyond the collected data is called extrapolation.

[16226|p552|T1] SUMMARY
[16227|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>Do you know ...?</td></tr>
[16228|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>You can use a scatter diagram to investigate the strength of any relationship between two variables.</td></tr>
[16229|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>If one of the variables generally increases as the other variable increases, then you say that there is a positive correlation.</t...
[16230|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>If one of the variables generally decreases as the other variable increases, then you say that there is a negative correlation.</t...
[16231|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>The clearer the relationship, the stronger the correlation.</td></tr>
[16232|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>You can draw a line of best fit if the points seem to lie close to a straight line.</td></tr>
[16233|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>You can use the line of best fit to predict values of one variable from values of the other.</td></tr>
[16234|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>You should only make predictions using a line of best fit that has been drawn within the range of the data.</td></tr>
[16235|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>Are you able to ...?</td></tr>
[16236|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>draw a scatter diagram</td></tr>
[16237|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>describe the relationship between the variables shown</td></tr>
[16238|p552] [Table Row] <tr><td>use a scatter diagram to make predictions.</td></tr>

[16405|p561|T1] > Unit 4 Project
[16406|p561|T1] Marbles in a box
[16407|p561] Consider an imaginary three-dimensional game where two players take it in turn to place different coloured marbles into a box.
[16408|p561] The box is made from 27 transparent unit cubes arranged in a 3-by-3-by-3 array.
[16410|p561] The aim of the game is to make a winning row of three of your own marbles. Rows can be horizontal, vertical or diagonal.
[16411|p561] This diagram shows the placement of one winning row. The marbles are on three levels and the row is diagonal.
[16413|p561] How many different ways are there to make a winning row?
[16414|p561] Explain clearly how you got to your answer.
[16415|p561|T1] TIP
[16416|p561] Take note that in this diagram the edges of the cubes are not shown, just the placement of the marbles on each level.

[16462|p564|T1] 17.1 Earning money
[16463|p564] When people are employed they are paid for their work. Earnings can be worked out in different ways:
[16464|p564] - Wages - pay based on a fixed number of hours worked, usually paid weekly. Extra hours of work are called overtime and these are usually paid at a hi...
[16465|p564] Salary - pay based on a fixed yearly amount, usually paid monthly. Overtime may be paid, or workers may be given time off in exchange for extra time s...
[16466|p564] - Piece work - pay based on the number of items produced.
[16467|p564] - Commission - pay is based on a percentage of sales made; sometimes a low wage, called a retainer, is paid as well as commission.
[16468|p564|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[16469|p564] Emmanuel makes beaded necklaces. He is paid in South African rand at a rate of R24.50 per completed necklace. He is able to make 55 necklaces per week...
[16470|p564|T1] Answer
[16471|p564] Earnings  $= 55 \times 24.50$  Multiply items produced by the rate paid.
[16472|p564] $= \mathbb{R}1347.50$
[16473|p564|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[16474|p564] Sanjay works as a sales representative for a company that sells mobile phones in the United Arab Emirates. He is paid a retainer of 800 Dhs (dirhams) ...
[16475|p564] a How much would he earn in a week if he made no sales?
[16476|p564] b How much would he earn if he sold four phones at 3299 Dhs each in a week?
[16477|p564|T1] Answers
[16478|p564] a 800 Dhs
[16479|p564] If he made no sales, he would earn no commission, only his retainer.
[16480|p564] b Commission  $= 4.5\%$  of  $(3299\times 4)$
[16481|p564] Calculate  $4.5\%$  of the total sales Sanjay made.
[16482|p564] $= 0.045\times 13196$
[16483|p564] $= 593.82$  Dhs
[16484|p564] Earnings  $=$  retainer  $^+$  commission
[16485|p564] $= 800\mathrm{Dhs} + 593.82\mathrm{Dhs}$
[16486|p564] $= 1393.82\mathrm{Dhs}$
[16487|p564] Add this to the retainer of 800 Dhs.
[16488|p564|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[16489|p564] You learnt about the decimal equivalents of percentages in Chapter 5.
[16490|p565|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[16491|p565] Josh's hourly rate of pay is \(12.50. He is paid 'time-and-a-half' for work after hours and on Saturdays and 'double-time' for Sundays and Public Holi...
[16492|p565] One week he worked 5.5 hours on Saturday and 3 hours on Sunday. How much overtime pay would he earn?
[16493|p565|T1] Answer
[16494|p565] Saturday overtime = 1.5 × $12.50 × 5.5 (time-and-a-half = 1.5 × normal
= $103.13 time)
[16495|p565] Saturday overtime  $= 2 \times \$ 12.50 \times 3\) (double-time  $= 2 \times$  normal time)  
 $= \\(75$
[16496|p565] Total overtime = $103.13 + $75.00
= $178.13

[16510|p565|T1] TIP
[16511|p565] Commissions like these are on a sliding scale. So if the agent had sales of  $160000, she would be paid 2.5% of$ 150000 and 1.75% of the $10000 that i...

[16520|p566|T1] Deductions from earnings
[16521|p566] Gross income (earnings) is the total amount a person earns.
[16522|p566] Deductions, such as income tax, pension contributions, unemployment and health insurance, and union dues are often taken from the gross earnings befor...
[16523|p566] Net income  $=$  gross income - deductions

[16572|p568|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[16573|p568] Mr Smit's taxable income is \(153772.00 per annum. How much tax must he pay:
[16574|p568] a per year? b per month?
[16575|p568|T1] Answers
[16576|p568] a To work out the yearly tax, find his tax bracket on the table. His income is in row two because it is between $132001 and $210000. He has to pay $23...
[16577|p568] $$
\begin{array}{l} \$ 153772 - \$ 132000 = \$ 21772 \\ 25 \% \text{of}\\ 21772 = \\ 5443 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16578|p568] Tax payable =  $23760 +$ 5443 = $29203 per year
[16579|p568] b $29203 ÷ 12 = $2433.58 To find the monthly tax, divide the total from part (a) by 12.
[16580|p568|T1] LINK
[16581|p568] If you study business or economics you will need a good understanding of financial mathematics as well as the ability to apply formulae, draw and inte...
[16582|p568|T1] TIP
[16583|p568] In some Islamic countries, tax is not deducted from earnings. Instead people pay a portion of their earnings as a religious obligation (zakat).
[16584|p568|T1] TIP
[16585|p568] Per annum means each year or annually. It is often abbreviated to p.a.
[16586|p569|T1] Exercise 17.3

[16603|p569] a Li-Gon has a taxable income of \(40000 for this tax year. He tells his friends that he is in the \(25\%\) tax bracket.
[16604|p569] i Is this correct?
[16605|p569] ii Does it mean that he pays \(10000 in income tax? Explain why or why not.
[16606|p569] iii When Li-Gon checks his tax return, he finds that he only has to pay $6181.25 income tax. Show how this amount is calculated by the revenue service...

[16611|p569|T1] 17.2 Borrowing and investing money
[16612|p569] When you borrow money or you buy things on credit, you are normally charged interest for the use of the money. Similarly, when you save or invest mone...
[16613|p570|T1] Simple interest
[16614|p570] Simple interest is a fixed percentage of the original amount borrowed or invested. In other words, if you borrow  $100 at an interest rate of \(5\%$  ...
[16615|p570] Simple interest involves adding the interest amount to the original amount at regular intervals. The formula used to calculate simple interest is:
[16616|p570] $$
I = \frac {P R T}{1 0 0}, \text {w h e r e :}
$$
[16617|p570] $P =$  the principal, which is the original amount borrowed or saved
[16618|p570] $$
R = \text {t h e i n t e r e s t r a t e}
$$
[16619|p570] $$
T = \text {t h e t i m e (i n y e a r s)}.
$$
[16620|p570|T1] LINK
[16621|p570] In Islam, interest (riba) is forbidden so Islamic banks do not charge interest on loans or pay interest on investments. Instead, Islamic banks charge ...
[16622|p570|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[16623|p570] $500 is invested at 10% per annum simple interest. How much interest is earned in three years?
[16624|p570|T1] Answer
[16625|p570] $$
10 \% \text{of}\$ 500 = \frac {10}{100}\times 500 = \$ 50 \quad \text{The interest rate is} 10 \% \text{per annum.}
$$
[16626|p570] The interest every year is $50.
[16627|p570] So after three years, the interest is:
[16628|p570] $$
3 \times \$ 50 = \$ 150 \quad \text {M u l t i p l y b y t h e n u m b e r o f y e a r s}.
$$
[16629|p571|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[16630|p571] Sam invested $400 at 15% per annum for three years. How much money would the investment be worth at the end of the period?
[16631|p571|T1] Answer
[16632|p571] At the end of the period he would have  $P + I$  (the principal plus the interest paid).
[16633|p571] $$
\begin{array}{l} I = \frac {P R T}{1 0 0} \text {a n d} P = 4 0 0, \text {s o :} \\ P + I = 4 0 0 + \frac {(4 0 0 \times 1 5 \times 3)}{1 0 0} \\ =...
[16634|p571|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[16635|p571] How long will it take for $250 invested at the rate of 8% per annum simple interest to grow to $310?
[16636|p571|T1] Answer
[16637|p571] Amount = principal + interest
[16638|p571] Interest = amount - principal
[16639|p571] ∴Interest = $310 - $250 = $60
[16640|p571] Rate = 8% per annum =  $\frac{8}{100} \times 250 = \$ 20$
[16641|p571] So the interest per year is $20.
[16642|p571] Total interest  $(60)\div$  annual interest  $(20) = 3$
[16643|p571] So it will take three years for  $250 to grow to$ 310 at the rate of 8% per annum simple interest.
[16644|p571|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[16645|p571] Calculate the rate of simple interest if a principal of  $250 grows to$ 400 in three years.
[16646|p571|T1] Answer
[16647|p571] Interest paid = $400 - $250 = $150
[16648|p571] $$
I = \frac {P R T}{1 0 0}
$$
[16649|p571] Change the subject of the formula to  $R$  to find the rate.
[16650|p571] $$
1 0 0 I = P R T
$$
[16651|p571] $$
R = \frac {1 0 0 I}{P T} = \frac {1 0 0 \times 1 5 0}{2 5 0 \times 3} = 2 0
$$
[16652|p571] So, the interest rate = 20%
[16653|p571|T1] TIP
[16654|p571] You can manipulate the formula to find any of the values:
[16655|p571] $$
I = \frac {P R T}{1 0 0}
$$
[16656|p571] $$
P = \frac {1 0 0 J}{R T}
$$
[16657|p571] $$
R = \frac {1 0 0 I}{P T}
$$
[16658|p571] $$
T = \frac {1 0 0 I}{P R}
$$

[16686|p573] 6 Jessica spends  $\frac{1}{4}$  of her income from odd jobs on books,  $\frac{1}{3}$  on transport and  $\frac{1}{6}$  on clothing. She saves the res...

[16690|p573] How much interest will she earn?

[16693|p573] a How much did she repay in total?
[16694|p573] b How much interest did she pay in pounds?
[16695|p573] c At what rate was simple interest charged over the three years?
[16696|p573|T1] Hire purchase
[16697|p573] Many people buy items such as TVs, furniture and cars on a system of payment called hire purchase (HP).
[16698|p573] On HP you pay a part of the price as a deposit and the remainder in a certain number of weekly or monthly instalments. Interest is charged on outstand...
[16699|p573|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[16700|p573] The cash price of a car is \(20000. The hire purchase price is \)6000 deposit and instalments of \(700 per month for two years. How much more than the...
[16701|p573|T1] Answer
[16702|p573] $$
D e p o s i t = \$ 6 0 0 0
$$
[16703|p573] $$
\text {O n e i n s t a l m e n t} = \$ 700
$$
[16704|p573] 24 instalments = $700 × 24 = $16800 (once per month over two years is 24 monthly instalments)
[16705|p573] Total HP price  $=$  deposit  $^+$  24 instalments
[16706|p573] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \$ 6000 + \$ 16800 \\ = \$ 22 8 0 0 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16707|p573] The hire purchase price is $2800 more than the cash price.
[16708|p573|T1] TIP
[16709|p573] In HP agreements, the deposit is sometimes called the down-payment.
[16710|p573] When interest is calculated as a proportion of the amount owed it is called a flat rate of interest. This is the same as simple interest.
[16711|p574|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[16712|p574] A person bought a car for $30000 on hire purchase. The deposit was 20% and interest on the outstanding balance for the period of repayment is at 10% p...
[16713|p574|T1] Answer
[16714|p574] Cash price = $30000
[16715|p574] Deposit of  $20\% = \frac{20}{100} \times 30000 = \$  6000$
[16716|p574] Outstanding balance = $30000 - $6000 = $24000
[16717|p574] Interest of  $10\% = \frac{10}{100} \times 24000 = \$  2400$
[16718|p574] Amount to be paid by instalments = outstanding balance + interest
[16719|p574] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \$ 24000 + \$ 2400 \\ = \$ 26 4 0 0 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16720|p574] Each instalment = 26400/12 = $2200 (divide by total number of instalments)

[16734|p575|T1] Compound interest
[16735|p575] Simple interest is calculated on the original amount saved or borrowed. It is more common, to earn or to be charged compound interest. With a loan whe...
[16736|p575] One way of doing compound interest calculations is to view them as a series of simple interest calculations. This method is shown in Worked example 11...
[16737|p575|T1] LINK
[16738|p575] When a virus is out of control in a population of animals, it is often true that the number of cases starts to increase by a similar percentage each d...
[16739|p575|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11
[16740|p575] Priya invested $100 at a rate of 10%, compounded annually. How much is the investment worth after three years?
[16741|p575|T1] Answer
[16742|p575] Year 1
[16743|p575] $$
I = \frac {P R T}{1 0 0} = \frac {1 0 0 \times 1 0 \times 1}{1 0 0} = \$ 1 0
$$
[16744|p575] Use the formula for simple interest.
[16745|p575] $$
P + I = \$ 100 + \$ 10 = \$ 110
$$
[16746|p575] Year 2
[16747|p575] $$
I = \frac {P R T}{1 0 0} = \frac {1 1 0 \times 1 0 \times 1}{1 0 0} = \$ 1 1
$$
[16748|p575] P for year 2 is $110; T is one year as you are only finding the interest for year 2.
[16749|p575] $$
P + I = 1 1 0 + 1 1 = \$ 1 2 1. 0 0
$$
[16750|p575] Year 3
[16751|p575] $$
I = \frac {P R T}{1 0 0} = \frac {1 2 1 \times 1 0 \times 1}{1 0 0} = \$ 1 2. 1 0
$$
[16752|p575] P for year 3 is $121; T remains one year.
[16753|p575] $$
P + I = \$ 133.10
$$
[16754|p575|T1] TIP
[16755|p575] When the principal, rate and time are the same, compound interest will be higher than simple interest. The exception is when the interest is only calc...
[16756|p576] This table and graph compare the value of two $100 investments. The first is invested at 10% simple interest, the second at 10% compound interest.
[16757|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>Year (T)</td><td>Total $10% simple interest</td><td>Total $10% interest compounded annually</td></tr>
[16758|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>110</td><td>110</td></tr>
[16759|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>2</td><td>120</td><td>121</td></tr>
[16760|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>3</td><td>130</td><td>133.10</td></tr>
[16761|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>4</td><td>140</td><td>146.41</td></tr>
[16762|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>5</td><td>150</td><td>161.05</td></tr>
[16763|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>6</td><td>160</td><td>177.16</td></tr>
[16764|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>7</td><td>170</td><td>194.87</td></tr>
[16765|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>8</td><td>180</td><td>214.36</td></tr>
[16766|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>9</td><td>190</td><td>235.79</td></tr>
[16767|p576] [Table Row] <tr><td>10</td><td>200</td><td>259.37</td></tr>
[16769|p576] It is clear that choosing a compound interest rate is to the advantage of the investor. Remember, though, that the same effect is felt with borrowing ...
[16770|p577] You can also calculate compound interest using a multiplier. The calculations in the third column of the table show how this is done.
[16771|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>Year (T)</td><td>Total $10% interest compounded annually</td><td>Working using a multiplier</td></tr>
[16772|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>110</td><td>100 × 1.1 = 110</td></tr>
[16773|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>2</td><td>121</td><td>100 × 1.1 × 1.1 = 121</td></tr>
[16774|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>3</td><td>133.10</td><td>100 × 1.1 × 1.1 × 1.1 = 133.10</td></tr>
[16775|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>4</td><td>146.41</td><td>100 × (1.1)4 = 146.41</td></tr>
[16776|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>5</td><td>161.05</td><td>100 × (1.1)5 = 161.05</td></tr>
[16777|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>6</td><td>177.16</td><td>100 × (1.1)6 = 177.16</td></tr>
[16778|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>7</td><td>194.87</td><td>100 × (1.1)7 = 194.87</td></tr>
[16779|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>8</td><td>214.36</td><td>100 × (1.1)8 = 214.36</td></tr>
[16780|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>9</td><td>235.79</td><td>100 × (1.1)9 = 235.79</td></tr>
[16781|p577] [Table Row] <tr><td>10</td><td>259.37</td><td>100 × (1.1)10 = 259.37</td></tr>
[16782|p577] - Add the annual interest rate to 100 to get a percentage increase (subtract for a decrease):  $100\% + 10\% = 110\%$
[16783|p577] Express this as a decimal:  $\frac{110}{100} = 1.1$
[16784|p577] - Multiply the principal by a power of the decimal using the number of years as the power. So, for five years:  $100 \times (1.1)^{5}$
[16785|p577] You can also insert values into a formula to calculate the value  $(V)$  of an investment when it is subject to compound interest.
[16786|p577] $$
V = P \left(1 + \frac {r}{1 0 0}\right) ^ {n}, \text {w h e r e}
$$
[16787|p577] $P$  is the amount invested
[16788|p577] $r$  is the percentage rate of interest.
[16789|p577] $n$  is the number of years of compound interest.
[16790|p577|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 12
[16791|p577] $1500 is invested at 5% p.a. compound interest. What will the investment be worth after five years?
[16792|p577|T1] Answer
[16793|p577] $$
\begin{array}{l} V = P \left(1 + \frac {r}{1 0 0}\right) ^ {n} \\ = 1 5 0 0 (1 + 0. 0 5) ^ {5} \\ = \$ 1 9 1 4. 4 2 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16794|p577] Insert values in the formula and then use your calculator.
[16795|p577|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[16796|p577] You learnt about indices in Chapters 1 and 2.
[16797|p577|T1] TIP
[16798|p577] Multiply the decimal by itself the same number of times as the number of years. For three years it would be
[16799|p577] $$
\begin{array}{l} 1. 1 \times 1. 1 \times 1. 1 \text {o r} \\ (1. 1) ^ {3} \text {n o t} 1. 1 \times 3. \\ \end{array}
$$
[16800|p577|T1] TIP
[16801|p577] You are expected to know this formula.
[16802|p578|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13
[16803|p578] A sum of money is invested at a rate of  $5\%$  interest, compounded yearly.
[16804|p578] After five years it grows to $2500. What was the initial sum invested?
[16805|p578|T1] Answer
[16806|p578] $$
V = P \left(1 + \frac {r}{1 0 0}\right) ^ {n}
$$
[16807|p578] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 5 0 0 = P \left(1 + \frac {5}{1 0 0}\right) ^ {5} \\ = P \times 1. 0 5 ^ {5} \\ \end{array}
$$
[16808|p578] Substitute values for  $V, r$  and  $n$ .
[16809|p578] $$
\begin{array}{l} P = \frac {2 5 0 0}{1 . 0 5 ^ {5}} \\ = \$ 1 9 5 8. 8 2 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16810|p578] Rearrange to solve for  $P$ .

[16839|p579|T1] Exponential growth and decay
[16840|p579] When a quantity increases (grows) in a fixed proportion (normally a percentage) at regular intervals, we say that the growth is exponential. Similarly...
[16841|p579] Increasing exponential functions produce curved graphs that slope steeply up to the right. Decreasing exponential functions produce curved graphs that...
[16842|p579] Exponential growth and decay can be expressed using formulae.
[16843|p579] For growth:  $y = a(1 + r)^n$
[16844|p579] For decay:  $y = a(1 - r)^n$
[16845|p579] Where  $a$  is the original value or principal,  $r$  is the rate of change expressed as a decimal and  $n$  is the number of time periods.
[16846|p579|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[16847|p579] When financial investments increase or decrease in value at an exponential rate we talk about appreciation (growth) and depreciation. When the number ...
[16848|p579] You will deal with exponential curves in more detail in Chapter 18.
[16849|p580|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 14
[16850|p580] $100 is invested subject to compound interest at a rate of 8% per annum. Find the value of the investment correct to the nearest cent after a period o...
[16851|p580|T1] Answer
[16852|p580] Value  $= a(1 + r)^n$
[16853|p580] Use the formula for exponential growth and substitute the given values.
[16854|p580] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 1 0 0 (1 + 0. 0 8) ^ {1 5} \\ = 1 0 0 (1. 0 8) ^ {1 5} \\ = 3 1 7. 2 1 6 9 1 1 4 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16855|p580] Value of investment is $317.22 (correct to the nearest cent).
[16856|p580|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[16857|p580] The value of a new computer system depreciates by \(30\%\) per year. If it costs \\(1200 new, what will it be worth after two years?
[16858|p580|T1] Answer
[16859|p580] $$
\begin{array}{l} \text {V a l u e} = a (1 - r) ^ {n} \\ = 1 2 0 0 (1 - 0. 3) ^ {2} \\ = 1 2 0 0 (0. 7) ^ {2} \\ = 5 8 8 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16860|p580] Value after two years is $588.
[16861|p580] Use the formula for exponential decay and substitute the given values.

[16903|p582] d Given what you have found out, what advice would you give a young person about to buy their first car?
[16904|p582|T1] 17.3 Buying and selling
[16905|p582] When people trade, they buy goods, mark them up (decide on a price) and then sell them.
[16906|p582] The price the trader pays for goods is called the cost price.
[16907|p582] The price the goods are sold at is called the selling price.
[16908|p582] If the selling price is higher than the cost price, the goods are sold at a profit.
[16909|p582] If the selling price is lower than the cost price, the goods are sold at a loss.
[16910|p582] Profit = selling price - cost price
[16911|p582] Loss  $=$  cost price - selling price
[16912|p583|T1] Calculating the selling price, cost price and mark up
[16913|p583] People who sell goods have to decide how much profit they want to make. In other words, they have to decide by how much they will mark up the cost pri...
[16914|p583] Cost price + % mark up = selling price
[16915|p583] The cost price is always  $100\%$ . If you add  $10\%$  mark up, the selling price will be  $110\%$ .
[16916|p583|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18
[16917|p583] At a market, a trader makes a profit of  $1.08 on an item selling for$ 6.48.
[16918|p583] What is his percentage profit?
[16919|p583|T1] Answer
[16920|p583] Cost price = $6.48 - $1.08 = $5.40
[16921|p583] Subtract the profit from the selling price to find the cost price of the item.
[16922|p583] profit Percentage profit  $=$  cost price  $\times 100$
[16923|p583] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \frac {1 . 0 8}{5 . 4 0} \times 1 0 0 \\ = 20\% \\ \end{array}
$$
[16924|p583|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 19
[16925|p583] Find the selling price of an article bought for $400 and sold at a loss of 10%.
[16926|p583|T1] Answer
[16927|p583] Cost price = $400
[16928|p583] $$
\begin{array}{l} \text{Loss} = 10\% \text{of}\\ \\ \$ 400 \\ = \frac {1 0}{1 0 0} \times 4 0 0 \\ = \$ 40 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16929|p583] Selling price  $=$  cost price - loss
[16930|p583] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \$ 400 - \$ 40 \\ = \$ 360 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16931|p584|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 20
[16932|p584] A trader sells her product for $39. If her mark up is 30%, what is the cost price of the product?
[16933|p584|T1] Answer
[16934|p584] Cost price + mark up = selling price
[16935|p584] Selling price  $= 130\%$  of the cost price
[16936|p584] So, \( \\( {39} = {130}\%  \times \) selling price
[16937|p584] To find  $100\%$
[16938|p584] $$
\frac {3 9}{1 3 0} \times 1 0 0 = \$ 3 0
$$
[16939|p584] The cost price is $30.
[16940|p584] Divide by 130 to find  $1\%$  and then multiply by 100 to find  $100\%$  (which is the cost price).

[16952|p584] 7 Tim sells burgers for $6.50 and makes a profit of $1.43 on each one. What is his percentage profit on cost price?
[16953|p584|T1] APPLY YOUR SKILLS
[16954|p584] 8 VAT at a rate of  $17\%$  is added each time an item is sold on. The original cost of an item is  $\$ 112.00$ . The item is sold to a wholesaler, wh...

[16956|p584] b Express the tax as a percentage of the original price.
[16957|p585|T1] Discount
[16958|p585] If items are not being sold as quickly as a shop would like or if they want to clear a stock as new fashions come out, then goods may be sold at a dis...
[16959|p585] Discount can be treated in the same way as percentage change (loss) as long as you remember that the percentage change is always calculated as a perce...
[16960|p585|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 21
[16961|p585] During a sale, a shop offers a discount of  $15\%$  on a pair of jeans originally priced at $75. What is the sale price?
[16962|p585|T1] Answer
[16963|p585] Discount = 15% of $75
[16964|p585] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \frac {1 5}{1 0 0} \times 7 5 \\ = \$ 11.25 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16965|p585] Sale price = original price - discount
[16966|p585] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \$ 75 - 1 1. 2 5 \\ = \$ 63.75 \\ \end{array}
$$
[16967|p585] You can also work out the price by considering the sale price as a percentage of  $100\%$ .
[16968|p585] 100 - 15 = 85, so the sale price is 85% of $75:
[16969|p585] $$
\frac {8 5}{1 0 0} \times 7 5 = \$ 6 3. 7 5
$$

[17057|p589|T1] SELF ASSESSMENT
[17058|p589] Find any errors in your work.
[17059|p589] For each one, decide what type of error you made:
[17060|p589] - careless (writing the wrong number, not following instructions, forgetting to give reasons, not showing steps in calculation)
[17061|p589] computational (miscalculating a value using the basic operations)
[17062|p589] - precision (mistakes with signs, decimal places, forgetting brackets or order of operations, missing units, incorrect notation)
[17063|p589] - mathematical (not using properties or rules, not completing all the steps needed to solve the problem).
[17064|p589] Write down three suggestions to help yourself avoid these errors in the future.

[17114|p593|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS

[17118|p593] [Table Row] <tr><td>x</td><td>-3</td><td>-2</td><td>-1</td><td>0</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td></tr>

[17120|p593] You can use these points to plot and draw a graph just as you did with linear equations. The graph of a quadratic relationship is called a parabola

[17125|p593] If the coefficient  $x^2$  of in the equation is positive, the parabola is a 'valley' shaped curve.
[17126|p593] If the coefficient of  $x^2$  in the equation is negative, the parabola is a 'hill' shaped curve.

[17167|p596|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[17168|p596] Construct a table of values for  $y = x^2 + 2x - 1$  for values  $-4 \leq x \leq 2$ .
[17169|p596] Plot the points to draw the graph.
[17170|p596] [Table Row] <tr><td>x</td><td>-4</td><td>-3</td><td>-2</td><td>-1</td><td>0</td><td>1</td><td>2</td></tr>
[17171|p596] [Table Row] <tr><td>x²</td><td>16</td><td>9</td><td>4</td><td>1</td><td>0</td><td>1</td><td>4</td></tr>

[17175|p596] In this table, you work out each term separately.
[17176|p596] Add the terms of the equation in each column to get the totals for the last row (the y-values of each point).
[17177|p596] To draw the graph:
[17178|p596] - plot the points and join them to make a smooth curve
[17179|p596] - label the graph with its equation.
[17181|p597|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[17182|p597] Draw the graph of  $y = 6 + x - x^2$  for values of  $x$  from -3 to 4.

[17189|p597] To plot the graph of a quadratic relationship:
[17190|p597] complete a table of values (often some of the values will be given).
[17191|p597] - draw the axes with a ruler and label them
[17192|p597] - plot the  $(x, y)$  values from the table of values
[17193|p597] - join the points with a smooth curve.

[17218|p599|T1] Sketching quadratic functions
[17219|p599] You can use the characteristics of the parabola to sketch a graph without drawing up a table of values. Your sketch should show the general features o...
[17220|p599|T1] Sketching simple quadratic functions
[17221|p599] When the equation is of the form  $y = ax^2$  or  $y = ax^2 + c$ :
[17222|p599] - Check the sign of  $a$  to decide whether the graph is  $\cup$  or  $\cap$  shaped. If  $a$  is positive the graph will be  $\cup$  shaped, if  $a$ ...
[17223|p599] Find the  $y$  -intercept by making  $x = 0$  in the equation. The coordinates of the  $y$  -intercept are  $(0,c)$
[17224|p599] Calculate the  $x$  -intercepts by substituting  $y = 0$  into the equation. If the graph has no  $x$  -intercepts, you must work out the coordinates ...
[17225|p599] - Mark the values you have worked out on the axis and draw a smooth curve to complete the graph. Remember to label the graph with its equation.
[17226|p599|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[17227|p599] Sketch the graph of  $y = 2x^{2}$ .
[17229|p599] The coefficient of  $x$  is  $+2$ , so the graph is U shaped.
[17230|p599] There is no constant, c, so the y-intercept is 0 and the graph goes through the origin.
[17231|p599] When  $y = 0, x = 0$ , so there is only one solution for  $x$  and you need to find a point on the graph.
[17232|p599] Using  $x = 1$  substitute into the equation:  $y = 2(1)^2 = 2$  So (1, 2) is a point on the graph.
[17233|p599] Sketch and label the graph.
[17234|p599|T1] TIP
[17235|p599] Graphs of the form  $y = ax^2 + c$  are symmetrical about the  $y$ -axis and the turning point is on the  $y$ -axis.
[17236|p600|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[17237|p600] Sketch and label the graph of  $y = -x^2 + 4$ .
[17238|p600|T1] Answer
[17240|p600] The coefficient of  $x$  is  $-1$  so the graph is  $\cap$  shaped.
[17241|p600] The constant, c is 4, so the y-intercept is (0, 4).
[17242|p600] When  $y = 0$
[17243|p600] $$
\begin{array}{l} - x ^ {2} + 4 = 0 \\ \Rightarrow x ^ {2} - 4 = 0 \\ \Rightarrow x ^ {2} = 4 \\ \Rightarrow x = \pm \sqrt {4} \\ \end{array}
$$
[17244|p600] $$
\text {S o} x = - 2 \text {o r} 2
$$
[17245|p600] The x-intercepts are  $(-2,0)$  and  $(2,0)$
[17246|p600] Sketch and label the graph.
[17247|p600|T1] Turning points
[17248|p600] To find the coordinates of the turning point of a parabola, you need to find the axis of symmetry.
[17249|p600] When the equation is in standard form  $y = ax^2 + bx + c$ , you can find the axis of symmetry using  $x = -\frac{b}{2a}$ . This gives the  $x$ -coord...
[17250|p600] You can then find the  $y$ -coordinate of the turning point by substituting the value of  $x$  into the original equation. This  $y$ -value is the min...
[17251|p600|T1] TIP
[17252|p600] The turning point of a parabola is the minimum or maximum point of the graph. For the graph  $y = ax^2 + bx + c$ , the turning point is a maximum if  ...
[17253|p600|T1] Sketching quadratic functions of the form  $y = ax^2 + bx + c$
[17254|p600] When the equation is in the standard form  $y = ax^{2} + bx + c$ :
[17255|p600] - Identify the shape of the graph. If the  $x^2$  term is positive the graph is  $\cup$  shaped; if the  $x^2$  term is negative, the graph is  $\cap$...
[17256|p600] Find the  $y$  -intercept by making  $x = 0$  . The coordinates of the  $y$  -intercept are  $(0,c)$
[17257|p600] Calculate the  $x$  -intercepts by substituting  $y = 0$  into the equation and solving for  $x$  . If there is only one intercept then the graph just...
[17258|p600] Find the axis of symmetry and the coordinates of the turning point.
[17259|p600] - Use what you know about the shape of the graph and its symmetry to draw a smooth curve. Label the graph.
[17260|p601|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[17261|p601] Sketch the graph of  $y = x^{2} + 2x - 3$ .
[17262|p601|T1] Answer
[17263|p601] $x^{2}$  is positive, so the graph is U shaped.
[17264|p601] y-intercept  $= (0, - 3)$  Remember that there is only ever one y-intercept.
[17265|p601] To find the  $x$ -intercepts make  $y = 0$ , so
[17266|p601] $$
x ^ {2} + 2 x - 3 = 0
$$
[17267|p601] $$
(x + 3) (x - 1) = 0
$$
[17268|p601] $$
x = - 3 \text {o r} x = 1
$$
[17269|p601] So,  $(-3,0)$  and  $(1,0)$  are the  $x$ -intercepts.
[17270|p601] The axis of symmetry is  $x = -\frac{b}{2a} = -\frac{2}{2(1)} = -1$ .
[17271|p601] Substitute  $x = -1$  to find the turning point:  $(-1, -4)$ .
[17273|p601|T1] TIP
[17274|p601] The graph is symmetrical about the vertical line halfway between the  $x$ -intercepts. This gives another way to find the line of symmetry. Halfway be...
[17275|p602|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[17276|p602] Sketch the graph  $y = -2x^{2} - 4x + 6$ .
[17277|p602|T1] Answer
[17278|p602] $a = -2$  so the graph is  $\cap$  shaped.
[17279|p602] The  $y$  -intercept  $= (0,6)$
[17280|p602] Find the x-intercepts:
[17281|p602] $$
\begin{array}{l} - 2 x ^ {2} - 4 x + 6 = 0 \\ x ^ {2} + 2 x - 3 = 0 \\ (x - 1) (x + 3) = 0 \\ x = 1 \text {o r} x = - 3 \\ \end{array}
$$
[17282|p602] (1, 0) and  $(-3, 0)$  are the  $x$ -intercepts.
[17283|p602] Find the axis of symmetry using  $x = -\frac{b}{2a}$ $x = \frac{4}{2(-2)} = -1$
[17284|p602] Substitute  $x = -1$  into the equation to find the  $y$ -coordinate of the turning point.
[17285|p602] $$
y = - 2 (- 1) ^ {2} - 4 (- 1) + 6 = 8
$$
[17286|p602] The turning point is at  $(-1, 8)$  and is a maximum because a is negative.
[17287|p602] Sketch the graph and label all the important features.
[17288|p602] Divide both sides by common factor  $-2$
[17289|p602] Factorise the trinomial.
[17290|p602] Solve for  $x$ .
[17291|p602] Remember this is the  $x$  coordinate of the turning point.
[17293|p602|T1] Find the turning point by completing the square
[17294|p602] You can find the coordinates of the turning point of a parabola algebraically by completing the square. This involves changing the quadratic equation ...
[17295|p602] Consider the equation  $y = x^{2} + 4x - 5$ .
[17296|p602] You can rewrite this in completed square form as  $y = (x + 2)^2 - 9$ .
[17297|p602] Squaring any value gives an answer that is either positive or 0. So, for any value of  $x$ , the smallest possible value of  $(x + 2)^2$  is 0.
[17298|p602] This means that the minimum value of  $(x + 2)^2 - 9$  is -9 and that this occurs when  $x = -2$ .
[17299|p602] The turning point of the graph  $y = (x + 2)^2 - 9$  has the coordinates  $(-2, -9)$ .
[17300|p602|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[17301|p602] You learned how to solve quadratic equations by completing the square in Chapter 14. Revise that section now if you've forgotten how to do this.
[17302|p603|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[17303|p603] a Determine the equation of the axis of symmetry and the turning point of  $y = x^2 - 8x + 13$  by completing the square.
[17304|p603] b Sketch the graph.
[17305|p603|T1] Answers
[17306|p603] a  $y = x^{2} - 8x + 13$
[17307|p603] First complete the square.
[17308|p603] $$
y = (x - 4) ^ {2} - 1 6 + 1 3
$$
[17309|p603] Half of 8 is four, but
[17310|p603] $(x - 4)^2 = x^2 - 8x + 16$  so you have to subtract 16 to keep the equation balanced.
[17311|p603] $$
y = (x - 4) ^ {2} - 3
$$
[17312|p603] Simplify your solution.
[17313|p603] Turning point: (4, -3)
[17314|p603] Axis of symmetry:  $x = 4$
[17315|p603] b To sketch the graph, you must find the intercepts.
[17316|p603] y-intercept = (0,13)
[17317|p603] You can read this from the original equation.
[17318|p603] To find the  $x$ -intercept(s), let  $y = 0$  and solve.
[17319|p603] $$
\begin{array}{l} 0 = (x - 4) ^ {2} - 3 \\ 3 = (x - 4) ^ {2} \\ x - 4 = \pm \sqrt {3} \\ x = \pm \sqrt {3} + 4 \\ x = 5. 7 \text {o r} 2. 3 \\ \end{...
[17320|p603] Sketch the graph and label it.
[17322|p603] Remember that there is a negative and a positive root.
