[19374|p700|T1] SUMMARY
[19375|p700] Do you know ...?
[19376|p700] Histograms are specialised bar graphs used for displaying continuous and grouped data.
[19377|p700] If the class widths are unequal, the bars are not equally wide and the vertical axis shows the frequency density.
[19378|p700] frequency per class interval Frequency density  $=$  class width
[19379|p700] Cumulative frequency is a running total of the class frequencies up to each upper class boundary.
[19380|p700] When cumulative frequencies are plotted they give a cumulative frequency curve or ogive.
[19381|p700] The curve can be used to estimate the median value in the data.
[19382|p700] The data can be divided into four equal groups called quartiles. The interquartile range is the difference between the upper and lower quartiles  $(Q_...
[19383|p700] Large amounts of data can be divided into percentiles, which divide the data into 100 equal groups. If a score of 20 out of 25 is at the 82nd percenti...

[19388|p701] calculate cumulative frequencies
[19389|p701] plot and draw a cumulative frequency curve
[19390|p701] use a cumulative frequency curve to estimate the median
[19391|p701] find quartiles and calculate the interquartile range
[19392|p701] estimate and interpret percentiles.

[19726|p719|T1] KEY WORDS
[19727|p719] direct proportion inverse proportion rate ratio speed
[19728|p719] A ratio compares amounts in a particular order. The amounts are expressed in the same units and are called the terms of the ratio. A ratio is usually ...
[19729|p719] A rate compares two different quantities and the units of both are given in the rate. For example, speed is often given in kilometres per hour; this i...

[19754|p719|T1] TIP
[19755|p719] Rates are often used in daily life. When we write a rate such as kilometres per hour, we use the abbreviation km/h. The / means 'per'.
[19756|p720|T1] 21.1 Working with ratio
[19757|p720] A ratio is a numerical comparison of amounts. The order in which you write the amounts is very important. For example, if there is one teacher for eve...
[19758|p720] We normally write ratios in the form  $1:25$ , but when we work with them, it is sometimes useful to express the ratio as a fraction.
[19759|p720] Think about the teacher to student ratio 1:25. This means there is 1 teacher for every 25 students.
[19760|p720] You can write this as  $\frac{1}{25}$ . This fraction compares the number of teachers with the number of students. It means that there is  $\frac{1}{2...
[19761|p720] So, if there are 150 students you can use the fraction to work out how many teachers there are:
[19762|p720] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {1}{2 5} = \frac {?}{1 5 0} \\ \frac {1}{2 5} \text {o f} 1 5 0 = 6 \\ \end{array}
$$
[19763|p720] So, for 150 students there will be 6 teachers.
[19764|p720] 6 is equivalent to  $\frac{1}{25}$  and this matches the ratio 1:25.
[19765|p720] When you write two quantities as a ratio, you must make sure they are both in the same units. For example, the ratio of 20c to $1 is not 20:1, it is 2...
[19766|p720|T1] Writing ratios in simplest form
[19767|p720] Ratios are in their simplest form when you write them using the smallest whole numbers possible. The ratio of 20:100 above is not in its simplest form...
[19768|p720] $$
\frac {2 0}{1 0 0} = \frac {2}{1 0} = \frac {1}{5} \text {s o} 2 0: 1 0 0 = 1: 5
$$
[19769|p720] If a breakfast cereal has 200 grams of rice for every 300 grams of wheat and 500 grams of corn, the ratio of rice to wheat to corn is  $200:300:500$ ....
[19770|p720|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[19771|p720] A painter mixed eight litres of white paint with three litres of red paint to get pink paint.
[19772|p720] What is the ratio of:
[19773|p720] a red paint to white paint?
[19774|p720] b white paint to the total amount of paint in the mixture?
[19775|p720] c red paint to the total amount of paint in the mixture?
[19776|p720|T1] TIP
[19777|p720] When you say a ratio, you use the word 'to', so you say 5:2 as '5 to 2'.
[19778|p721|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1 CONTINUED
[19779|p721|T1] Answers
[19780|p721] a 3 litres to 8 litres  $= 3:8$
[19781|p721] b 8 litres white out of a total of 11 litres so 8:11 is the required ratio.
[19782|p721] c 3 litres red out of a total of 11 litres so 3:11 is the required ratio.
[19783|p721|T1] LINK
[19784|p721] Ratios are commonly used in food science to compare the ingredients in food and to give dietary guidelines. Scientists may also use a measure called t...
[19785|p721|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[19786|p721] To make concrete, you mix cement, sand and gravel in the ratio 1:2:4.
[19787|p721] a What is the ratio of cement to gravel?
[19788|p721] b What is the ratio of sand to gravel?
[19789|p721] c What is the ratio of gravel to the total amount of concrete?
[19790|p721] d What fraction of the concrete is cement?
[19791|p721|T1] Answers
[19792|p721] a Cement to gravel is 1:4
[19793|p721] b Sand to gravel is  $2:4 = 1:2$
[19794|p721] Concrete  $= 1 + 2 + 4 = 7$  parts  $\therefore$  gravel is 4 parts to 7, so 4:7 is the required ratio
[19795|p721] Concrete  $= 1 + 2 + 4 = 7$ $\therefore$  cement  $= \frac{1}{7}$

[19855|p723|T1] Equivalent ratios
[19856|p723] Equivalent ratios are basically the same as equivalent fractions. If you multiply or divide the terms of the ratio by the same number (except 0) you g...
[19857|p723|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[19858|p723] You dealt with common factors in Chapter 1 and you learnt about the reciprocals of fractions in Chapter 5.
[19859|p724|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[19860|p724] For each of the following ratios find the missing value.
[19861|p724] a  $1:4 = x:20$
[19862|p724] b  $4:9 = 24:y$
[19863|p724|T1] Answers
[19864|p724] Method 1: multiplying by a common factor.
[19865|p724] a  $1:4 = x:20$
[19866|p724] $$
2 0 + 5 = 4, \text {s o} 2 0 = 4 \times 5
$$
[19867|p724] 1:4=5:20
[19868|p724] 1 must be multiplied by 5 as well.
[19870|p724] Work out what 4 is multiplied by to get 20.
[19872|p724] $$
2 0 \div 5 = 4, \text {s o} 2 0 = 4 \times 5
$$
[19873|p724] For an equivalent ratio, you must multiply 1 by 5 as well.
[19874|p724] b  $4:9 = 24:y$
[19875|p724] $$
2 4 \div 4 = 6, \text {s o} 4 \times 6 = 2 4
$$
[19876|p724] 4:9=24:54
[19877|p724] 9 must be multiplied by 6 as well.
[19878|p724] Method 2: cross multiplying fractions.
[19879|p724] a  $\frac{1}{4} = \frac{x}{20}$
[19880|p724] Write the ratios as fractions.
[19881|p724] $$
x = 1 \times \frac {2 0}{4}
$$
[19882|p724] Solve the equation by multiplying both sides by 20.
[19883|p724] $$
x = 5
$$
[19884|p724] 4 24 b 9
[19885|p724] Write each ratio as a fraction.
[19886|p724] $$
\frac {9}{4} = \frac {y}{2 4}
$$
[19887|p724] Take the reciprocal of the fractions (turn them upside down) to get  $y$  at the top and make the equation easier to solve.
[19888|p724] $$
\frac {9 \times 2 4}{4} = y
$$
[19889|p724] Solve the equation by multiplying both sides by 24.
[19890|p724] $$
\frac {2 1 6}{4} = y
$$
[19891|p724] $$
y = 5 4
$$
[19892|p724|T1] REFLECTION
[19893|p724] Two methods are shown for finding missing values in equivalent ratios. Which method made most sense to you? Why?
[19894|p724] You learnt that if  $\frac{a}{b} = \frac{c}{d}$  then the cross-products ad and bc are equal.
[19895|p724] Do you understand why this works or do you just follow the rule?
[19896|p725|T1] Exercise 21.2
[19898|p725] 1 Find the unknown values in the following equivalent ratios. Use whichever method you find easiest.
[19899|p725] a  $2:3 = 6:x$  b  $6:5 = y:20$  c  $12:8 = 3:y$  d  $27:x = 9:2$  e  $3:8 = 66:x$  f  $1:5 = 13:y$  g  $x:25 = 7:5$  h  $40:9 = 800:$  i  $3:7 = 600:...
[19900|p725] 2 Use the equation (cross multiplying fractions) method to find the unknown values in the following equivalent ratios.
[19901|p725] a  $x:20 = 3:4$  b  $12:21 = x:14$  c  $2:5 = 8:y$  d  $3:5 = x:4$  e  $1:10 = x:6$  f  $8:13 = 2:y$  g  $4:5 = x:7$  h  $5:4 = 9:y$
[19902|p725] 3 Say whether these statements are true or false. If a statement is false, explain why it is false.
[19903|p725] a The ratio  $1:6$  is the same as the ratio  $6:1$
[19904|p725] b The ratio 1:6 is equivalent to 3:18.
[19905|p725] The ratio 20:15 can be expressed as 3:4.
[19906|p725] d If the current ratio of a mother's age to her daughter's age is  $8:1$ , and the daughter is nine, then the mother is 48 years old.
[19907|p725] e If Mr Smith's wages are  $\frac{5}{8}$  of Mr Jones' wages, then the ratio of their wages is 20:32.

[19918|p726|T1] APPLY YOUR SKILLS CONTINUED
[19919|p726] 6 An epoxy glue comes in two tubes (red and black), which have to be mixed in the ratio 1:4 (red:black).
[19920|p726] a If you measure 5 ml from the red tube, how much do you need to measure from the black tube?
[19921|p726] b How much would you need from the red tube if you used  $10\mathrm{ml}$  from the black tube?
[19922|p726] 7 A brand of pet food contains meat, cereal and fats in the ratio  $2:9:1$ . During one shift, the factory making the pet food used  $3500\mathrm{kg}$...
[19923|p726|T1] Dividing a quantity in a given ratio
[19924|p726] Ratios can be used to divide or share quantities. There are two ways of solving problems like these.
[19925|p726] Method 1: find the value of one part. This is the unitary method.
[19926|p726] 1 Add the values in the ratio to find the total number of parts involved.
[19927|p726] 2 Divide the quantity by the total number of parts to find the quantity per part (the value of one part).
[19928|p726] 3 Multiply the values in the ratio by the quantity per part to find the value of each part.
[19929|p726] Method 2: express the shares as fractions. This is the ratio method.
[19930|p726] 1 Add the values in the ratio to find the total number of parts involved.
[19931|p726] 2 Express each part of the ratio as a fraction of the total parts.
[19932|p726] 3 Multiply the quantity by the fraction to find the value of each part.
[19933|p726|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[19934|p726] Share $24 between Jess and Anne in the ratio 3:5.
[19935|p726|T1] Answer
[19936|p726] Method 1
[19937|p726] $$
3 + 5 = 8
$$
[19938|p726] There are 8 parts in the ratio.
[19939|p726] $$
2 4 + 8 = 3
$$
[19940|p726] This is the value of 1 part.
[19941|p726] $$
J e s g e t s \mathbb {9}
$$
[19942|p726] Jess gets 3 parts:  $3 \times 3 = 9$
[19943|p726] $$
\text {A n n e g e t s} \$ 15
$$
[19944|p726] Anne gets 5 parts:  $5 \times 3 = 15$
[19945|p726|T1] Method 2
[19946|p726] $$
3 + 5 = 8
$$
[19947|p726] There are 8 parts in the ratio.
[19948|p726] Jess gets  $\frac{3}{8}$  of  $24 = \frac{3}{8} \times 24 = \frac{9}{8}$
[19949|p726] Express each part as a fraction of the total parts and multiply by the quantity.
[19950|p726] Anne gets 5/8 of $24 = 5/8 × 24 = $15

[19978|p727|T1] REFLECTION
[19979|p727] Did you use the unitary method or the ratio method most in this exercise? Why?
[19980|p727] Are there problems or situations where one method is more efficient than the other? Explain your answer.
[19981|p727|T1] TIP
[19982|p727] The capital letters N:P:K on fertiliser bags are the chemical symbols for the elements. The ratio of chemicals is always given on packs of fertiliser.
[19983|p728|T1] 21.2 Ratio and scale
[19984|p728] Scale drawings (maps and plans) and models such as the one of the Louvre Museum in Abu Dhabi (shown at the start of this chapter), are the same shape ...
[19985|p728] Scale is a ratio. It can be expressed as 'length on drawing: real length'.
[19986|p728] The scale of a map, plan or model is usually given as a ratio in the form  $1:n$ . For example, the architects who designed the new Louvre building fo...
[19987|p728] A scale of  $1:33$  means that a unit of measurement on the model must be multiplied by 33 to get the length (in the same units) of the real building....
[19988|p728|T1] Expressing a ratio in the form  $1:n$
[19989|p728] All ratio scales must be expressed in the form  $1:n$  or  $n:1$
[19990|p728] To change a ratio so that one part  $= 1$  you need to divide both parts by the number that you want expressed as 1.
[19991|p728|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[19992|p728] Express  $5:1000$  in the form  $1:n$
[19993|p728] Answer
[19994|p728] $$
\begin{array}{l} 5: 1 0 0 0 = \frac {5}{5}: \frac {1 0 0 0}{5} \\ = 1: 2 0 0 \\ \end{array}
$$
[19995|p728] Divide both sides by 5, i.e. the number that you want expressed as 1.
[19996|p728|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[19997|p728] Express  $4\mathrm{mm}:50\mathrm{cm}$  as a ratio scale.
[19998|p728] Answer
[19999|p728] 4mm:50cm=4mm:500mm
[20000|p728] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 4: 5 0 0 \\ = \frac {4}{4}: \frac {5 0 0}{4} \\ - 1: 1 2 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[20001|p728] Express the amounts in the same units first.
[20002|p728] Divide by 4 to express in the form  $1:n$ .
[20003|p728|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[20004|p728] Write 22:4 in the form  $n:1$
[20005|p728] Answer
[20006|p728] $$
2 2: 4 = \frac {2 2}{4}: \frac {4}{4}
$$
[20007|p728] $$
= 5. 5: 1
$$
[20008|p728] Divide both sides by 4, i.e. the number that you want is expressed as 1.
[20009|p728] In this form you may get a decimal answer on one side.
[20011|p728|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[20012|p728] Scale drawings were discussed in more detail in Chapter 15.
[20013|p728] Some scale drawings, such as diagrams of cells in Biology, are larger than the real items they show. In an enlargement the scale is given in the form ...
[20014|p728|T1] TIP
[20015|p728] The form  $1:n$  or  $n:1$  may give a ratio with decimal values.
[20016|p729|T1] Solving scale problems
[20017|p729] There are two main types of problems involving scale:
[20018|p729] - calculating the real length of an object given its scaled length
[20019|p729] - calculating the scaled length of an object given its real length.
[20020|p729] In both cases you will be told one of the lengths and the scale, expressed as 'length on the diagram: real length'.
[20021|p729] You can write the scale as fractions and cross-multiply to find the unknown length.
[20022|p729|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[20023|p729] The scale of a map is 1:25000.
[20024|p729] a What is real distance between two points that are  $5\mathrm{cm}$  apart on the diagram?
[20025|p729] b Express the real distance in kilometres.
[20026|p729|T1] Answers
[20027|p729] a Map distance: real distance  $= 1:25000$
[20028|p729] $$
\begin{array}{l} \mathrm {S o}, 5 \mathrm {c m}: \times \mathrm {c m} = 1: 2 5 0 0 0 \\ \frac {5}{x} = \frac {1}{2 5 0 0 0} \\ 5 \times 2 5 0 0 0 =...
[20029|p729] $$
\therefore \text {R e a l} = 1 2 5 0 0 0 \mathrm {c m}
$$
[20030|p729] b  $1\mathrm{km} = 100000\mathrm{cm}$
[20031|p729] $$
\begin{array}{l} 1 2 5 0 0 0 \mathrm {c m} \div 1 0 0 0 0 0 \\ = 1. 2 5 \mathrm {k m} \\ \end{array}
$$
[20032|p729] Substitute the map distance and use  $x$  to represent the unknown real distance.
[20033|p729] Write the ratios as fractions.
[20034|p729] Cross multiply to find the real distance.
[20035|p729] The units in your answer will the same units as the map distance units.
[20036|p729] From part (a) you know the real distance is  $120000\mathrm{cm}$
[20037|p729] You know that  $1\mathrm{km} = 100000\mathrm{cm}$
[20038|p729] So convert the real distance to km.
[20039|p729|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[20040|p729] A dam wall is  $480\mathrm{m}$  long. How many centimetres long will it be on a map with a scale of 1:12000?
[20041|p729|T1] Answers
[20042|p729] Map length: real length = 1:12000
[20043|p729] Substitute the real length and use  $x$  to represent the unknown map length.
[20044|p729] So,  $x_m:480m = 1:12000$
[20045|p729] $$
\frac {x}{4 8 0} = \frac {1}{1 2 0 0 0}
$$
[20046|p729] $$
\begin{array}{l} x = \frac {4 8 0}{1 2 0 0 0} 1 \\ x = 0. 0 4 \\ \end{array}
$$
[20047|p729] ∴ map distance = 0.04 m
[20048|p729] $$
= 4 \mathrm {c m}
$$
[20049|p729] Write the ratios as fractions.
[20050|p729] Cross multiply to find the map length.
[20051|p729] $1\mathrm{m} = 100\mathrm{cm}$  so multiply by 100 to convert the answer to cm.

[20058|p730] [Table Row] <tr><td colspan="2">A biology book shows a diagram of a flea drawn to a scale of 12:1. If the flea in the diagram is 25 mm long, how long ...
[20059|p730] [Table Row] <tr><td>Answer</td><td></td></tr>
[20060|p730] [Table Row] <tr><td>Diagram length: real length = 12:1</td><td>Substitute the length on the diagram and use x to represent the real length.</td></tr>
[20061|p730] [Table Row] <tr><td>So, 25 mm: x mm = 12:1</td><td></td></tr>
[20062|p730] [Table Row] <tr><td>25/x = 12/1</td><td rowspan="2">Write the ratios as fractions and solve for x.</td></tr>
[20063|p730] [Table Row] <tr><td>25 = 12x</td></tr>
[20064|p730] [Table Row] <tr><td>25/12 = x</td><td></td></tr>
[20065|p730] [Table Row] <tr><td>2.08 = x</td><td></td></tr>
[20066|p730] [Table Row] <tr><td>.. real length = 2.08 mm (2 d.p.)</td><td>Round your answer to 2 decimal places.</td></tr>

[20129|p733|T1] 21.3 Rates
[20130|p733] A rate compares two different quantities. In a rate, the quantity of one thing is usually given in relation to one unit of the other thing. For exampl...
[20131|p733] Rates can be simplified just like ratios. When a rate is in simplest form, the first quantity is expressed per one unit of the second, so, for example...
[20132|p733|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11
[20133|p733] 492 people live in an area of  $12\mathrm{km}^2$ . Express this as a rate in its simplest terms.
[20134|p733|T1] Answer
[20135|p733] 492 people in  $12\mathrm{km}^2$
[20136|p733] 492 people per km²
[20137|p733] $= 41$  people/km²
[20138|p733] Divide by 12 to get a rate per unit.
[20139|p733] Don't forget to write the units.
[20140|p733|T1] INVESTIGATION
[20141|p733|T1] Population density
[20142|p733] Population density is a rate that specifies the numbers of people, animals or plants in a given area (normally per square kilometre).
[20143|p733] 1 Work in pairs to answer these questions about population density.
[20144|p733] a Which are the most and least densely populated areas in the world?
[20145|p733] b Suggest why some places are densely populated while others are not.
[20146|p733] c Why do social scientists usually look at population distribution as well as population density when they study different populations?
[20147|p734|T1] INVESTIGATION CONTINUED
[20148|p734] 2 In biology, scientists often state that where conditions for an organism are favourable, the population density will be high, and that where conditi...
[20149|p734] a Find an environmental example to support this hypothesis.
[20150|p734] b Do you think this hypothesis is true for human populations? Explain your answer, giving examples.
[20151|p734] 3 How is population density data useful in the following areas?
[20152|p734] a Ecology
[20153|p734] b Epidemiology
[20154|p734] c Infrastructure planning
[20155|p734|T1] Average speed
[20156|p734] You need to be able to work with speed, distance and time quantities to solve problems.
[20157|p734] Average speed is one of the most commonly used rates. We talk about average speed because usually a vehicle will change speed during a journey. The dr...
[20158|p734] You can use the distance-time-speed triangle to help you solve problems related to distance, time or speed.
[20160|p734] If you cover the letter of the quantity you need to find, then the remaining letters in the triangle give you the calculation you need to do (a multip...
[20164|p734|T1] TIP
[20165|p734] A rate like km/h may sometimes be written kph (the 'p' stands for 'per').
[20166|p735|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 12
[20167|p735] A bus travels  $210\mathrm{km}$  in three hours, what is its average speed in  $\mathrm{km / h}$ ?
[20168|p735] Answer
[20169|p735] $$
\text {S p e e d} = \frac {D}{T}
$$
[20170|p735] $$
\text {D i s t a n c e} = 2 1 0 \mathrm {k m}, \text {t i m e} = 3 \mathrm {h}
$$
[20171|p735] $$
\begin{array}{l} \therefore \text {s p e e d} = \frac {2 1 0}{3} \\ = 7 0 \mathrm {k m} / \mathrm {h} \\ \end{array}
$$
[20172|p735] Its average speed is  $70\mathrm{km / h}$
[20174|p735|T1] TIP
[20175|p735] When you see the phrases 'how fast', 'how far' or 'for how long' you know you are dealing with a speed, distance or time problem.
[20176|p735|T1] LINK
[20177|p735] Nurses and other medical support staff work with ratio and rates when they calculate medicine doses, convert between units of measurement and set the ...
[20178|p735|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13
[20179|p735] I walk at  $4.5\mathrm{km / h}$ . How far can I walk in  $2\frac{1}{2}$  hours at the same speed?
[20180|p735] Answer
[20181|p735] $$
\text {D i s t a n c e} = S \times T
$$
[20182|p735] $$
\text {S p e e d} = 4. 5 \mathrm {k m} / \mathrm {h}, \text {t i m e} = 2. 5 \mathrm {h}
$$
[20183|p735] $$
\therefore \text {d i s t a n c e} = 4. 5 \times 2. 5 = 1 1. 2 5 \mathrm {k m}
$$
[20184|p735] I can walk  $11.25\mathrm{km}$
[20186|p735|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 14
[20187|p735] How long will it take to cover  $200\mathrm{km}$  at a speed of  $80\mathrm{km / h}$ ?
[20188|p735] Answer
[20189|p735] $$
\text {T i m e} = \frac {D}{S}
$$
[20190|p735] $$
\text {D i s t a n c e} = 2 0 0 \mathrm {k m}, \text {s p e e d} = 8 0 \mathrm {k m} / \mathrm {h}
$$
[20191|p735] $$
\therefore \text {t i m e} = \frac {2 0 0}{8 0} = 2. 5
$$
[20192|p735] It would take  $2\frac{1}{2}$  hours.
[20194|p736|T1] Exercise 21.5
[20195|p736|T1] APPLY YOUR SKILLS
[20196|p736] 1 Express each of these relationships as a rate in simplest form.
[20197|p736] a 12 kg for $5
[20198|p736] b 120 litres for  $1000\mathrm{km}$

[20201|p736] e 135 students for 5 teachers
[20202|p736] f 15 hours spent per 5 holes dug
[20203|p736] 2 A quarry produces 1200 t of crushed stone per hour. How much stone could it supply in:
[20204|p736] a an eight-hour shift?
[20205|p736] b five eight-hour shifts?
[20206|p736] 3 Water leaks from a pipe at a rate of  $5\ell /\mathrm{h}$  How much water will leak from the pipe in:
[20207|p736] a a day?
[20208|p736] b a week?
[20209|p736] 4 A machine fills containers at a rate of 135 containers per minute. How long will it take to fill 1000 containers at the same rate?
[20210|p736] 5 Two friends walk at  $4.25\mathrm{km / h}$  How far will they walk in three hours?
[20211|p736] 6 How far will a train travelling at  $230\mathrm{km / h}$  travel in:
[20212|p736] a 31/2 hours?
[20213|p736] b 20 minutes?

[20229|p737|T1] 21.4 Kinematic graphs
[20230|p737] Kinematics is the study of how objects move. A kinematic graph may show how far an object moves over time or how its speed changes with time.
[20231|p737|T1] Distance-time graphs
[20232|p737] Graphs that show the connection between the distance an object has travelled and the time taken to travel that distance are called distance-time graph...
[20233|p737] On such graphs, time is normally shown along the horizontal axis and distance on the vertical axis.
[20235|p737|T1] TIP
[20236|p737] In travel graphs time is an independent variable and it is always shown on the  $x$ -axis.
[20237|p737] Look at the graph. Can you see that it shows the following journey:
[20238|p737] a cycle ride for 4 minutes from home to a bus stop 1 km away
[20239|p737] a 2 minute wait for the bus
[20240|p737] a 7 km journey on the bus that takes 10 minutes.
[20241|p737] The line of the graph remains horizontal while the person is waiting for the bus because they don't get any further from the starting point. The steep...
[20242|p737|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[20243|p737] You learned how to read and draw line graphs in Chapter 4.
[20244|p737|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[20245|p737] Ashraf's school is  $4\mathrm{km}$  from home and it takes 40 minutes to walk to school. One morning he leaves at 7 a.m. After 15 minutes, he realises...
[20247|p738|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15 CONTINUED
[20248|p738] a How far had he walked before he remembered his boots?
[20249|p738] b What happens to the graph as he returns home?
[20250|p738] c What does the horizontal line on the graph represent?
[20251|p738] d How fast did he run in m/min to get back home?
[20253|p738|T1] Answers
[20254|p738] a Ashraf walked 1.5 km before he remembered his boots.
[20255|p738] b The graph slopes downwards (back towards  $0\mathrm{km}$ ) as he goes home.
[20256|p738] c The horizontal part of the graph corresponds with the three minutes at home.
[20257|p738] d He runs  $1.5\mathrm{km}$  in 10 minutes, an average speed  $150\mathrm{m / min}$

[20281|p739|T1] Speed in distance-time graphs
[20282|p739] The steepness gradient of a graph gives an indication of speed.
[20283|p739] - A straight line on a graph indicates a constant speed. Any change in the angle of the line indicates a change of speed.
[20285|p740] The steeper the graph, the greater the speed.
[20286|p740] An upward slope and a downward slope represent movement in opposite directions.
[20287|p740] The distance-time graph shown is for a person who walks, cycles and then drives for three equal periods of time. For each period, speed is given by th...
[20288|p740] $$
\text {s p e e d} = \frac {\text {d i s t a n c e} \text {t r a v e l l e d}}{\text {t i m e} \text {t a k e n}}
$$
[20290|p740] Speed is a rate of change. A straight line from the origin shows a constant rate of change and you can use the formula  $\frac{\text{change in } y}{\t...
[20291|p740] If the gradient changes along the graph, the speed will be different for different time periods.
[20292|p740] The gradient precisely describes the steepness of a line.
[20293|p740] In the diagram, the steepness of line  $AB$  is measured by: increase in y-coordinate increase in x-coordinate
[20294|p740] This is the same as  $\frac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}}$  or gradient of a straight line graph.
[20295|p740] A positive gradient means that as  $x$  increases  $y$  also increases.
[20296|p740] On a distance-time graph, the  $y$  value indicates distance from the starting point, so a positive gradient means the object is moving away from the ...
[20297|p740] For a distance-time graph:
[20298|p740] $$
\frac {\text {c h a n g e i n y - c o o r d i n a t e (d i s t a n c e)}}{\text {c h a n g e i n x - c o o r d i n a t e (t i m e)}} = \frac {\text...
[20299|p740] Therefore, the gradient of the graph tells you the speed of the object and its direction of motion. This is known as the velocity of the object.
[20301|p741] Here is another example:
[20302|p741] The travel graph represents a car journey.
[20303|p741] The horizontal sections have zero gradient (so the car was stationary during these times).
[20304|p741] For section  $AB$ , the gradient is positive:
[20305|p741] $$
\text {G r a d i e n t} = \frac {N B}{A N} = \frac {4 0 - 0}{0 . 5} = 8 0 \mathrm {k m / h}
$$
[20306|p741] the velocity was  $80\mathrm{km / h}$  in the direction away from home.
[20307|p741] For section  $CD$ , the gradient is negative:
[20308|p741] $$
\text {G r a d i e n t} = \frac {2 0 - 4 0}{0 . 2 5} = - 8 0 \mathrm {k m / h}
$$
[20309|p741] ..the velocity was  $-80\mathrm{km / h}$
[20310|p741] For section  $EF$  the gradient is negative:
[20311|p741] $$
\text {G r a d i e n t} = \frac {0 - 2 0}{0 . 3 5} = - 5 7. 1 \mathrm {k m} / \mathrm {h}
$$
[20312|p741] the velocity was  $-57.1\mathrm{km / h}$
[20314|p741|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[20315|p741] You learned how to calculate the gradient of a straight line graph in Chapter 10. Remember the gradient of a line is:
[20316|p741] positive if the line slopes up from left to right
[20317|p741] negative if the line slopes down from left to right.
[20318|p741|T1] TIP
[20319|p741] When the velocity is positive, the direction of motion is away from home. When the velocity is negative, the direction is towards home.

[20367|p744|T1] Speed-time graphs
[20368|p744] In certain cases, the speed (or velocity) of an object may change. An increase in speed is called acceleration; a decrease in speed is called decelera...
[20369|p744] This graph shows a train journey between two stations.
[20371|p744] The train starts at zero speed.
[20372|p744] The speed increases steadily reaching  $18\mathrm{m / s}$  after 15 seconds.
[20373|p744] The train travels at a constant speed (horizontal section) of  $18\mathrm{m / s}$  for 25 seconds.
[20374|p744] The train then slows down at a steady rate till it stops.
[20375|p744] The entire journey takes 60 seconds.
[20376|p744] Look at the first part of the journey again.
[20377|p744] The speed increased by  $18\mathrm{m / s}$  in 15 seconds.
[20378|p744] $\frac{18\mathrm{m / s}}{15\mathrm{seconds}}$  is the gradient of the line representing the first part of the journey.
[20379|p744] This is a rate of  $1.2\mathrm{m / s}$  every second. This is the rate of acceleration. You write this as  $1.2\mathrm{m / s^2}$  (or  $\mathrm{m / s ...
[20380|p744] For a speed-time graph, the gradient = acceleration.
[20381|p744] A positive gradient (acceleration) is an increase in speed.
[20382|p744] A negative gradient (deceleration) is a decrease in speed.
[20383|p744|T1] Distance travelled in a speed-time graph
[20384|p744] You already know that distance = speed × time. On a speed-time graph, this is represented by the area of shapes under the sections of graph. You can u...
[20385|p744|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[20386|p744] You worked with distance, time and speed earlier in this chapter. Make sure you remember how to use and manipulate the formulae.
[20387|p744|T1] TIP
[20388|p744] You may sometimes see m/s written as m s-1 and m/s2 written as m s-2.
[20389|p745|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 16
[20390|p745] This speed-time graph represents the motion of a particle over a period of five seconds.
[20392|p745] a During which periods of time was the particle accelerating?
[20393|p745] b Calculate the particle's acceleration 3 seconds after the start.
[20394|p745] c Calculate the distance travelled by the particle in the 5 seconds.
[20395|p745|T1] Answers
[20396|p745] a The particle was accelerating in the period 0 to 0.8 seconds (section OA) and in the period 2 to 3.5 seconds (section BC).
[20397|p745] b The gradient is constant between 2 and 3.5 seconds so acceleration was also constant in that period. So, the acceleration 3 seconds after the start ...
[20398|p745] $$
\frac {2 5 - 1 5 (m / s)}{3 . 5 - 2 (s)} = \frac {1 0}{1 . 5} = 6. 7 m / s ^ {2}
$$
[20399|p745] c Distance travelled  $=$  area under graph
[20400|p745] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \text {a r e a} \vert + \text {a r e a} \vert + \text {a r e a} \vert + \text {a r e a} \vert + \text {a r e a} \vert + \text {a...
[20401|p745] The distance travelled is  $91.5\mathrm{m}$
[20402|p745|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[20403|p745] The areas under a straight line graph will always be polygons. Apply the area formulae you learnt in Chapter 7 to calculate the area of the shapes und...
[20404|p745|T1] Units are important
[20405|p745] When you calculate acceleration and distance travelled from a speed-time graph, the unit of speed on the vertical axis must involve the same unit of t...
[20406|p745] If the units of time are not the same, convert the unit on one of the axes to a compatible unit.
[20407|p746|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 17
[20408|p746] The diagram shows the distance-time graph for a short car journey. The greatest speed reached is  $60\mathrm{km / h}$  . The acceleration in the first...
[20410|p746] a Draw the speed-time graph of this journey.
[20411|p746] b Calculate the average speed, in km/h, for the journey.
[20412|p746|T1] Answers
[20413|p746] a
[20415|p746] Since the acceleration and deceleration are both constant, the speed-time graph consists of straight lines.
[20416|p746] The greatest speed is  $60\mathrm{km / h}$
[20417|p746] b Average speed = total distance / total time
[20418|p746] $$
\begin{array}{l} = \frac {2 \mathrm {k m}}{(4 \text {m i n u t e s})} \\ = \frac {2 \times 1 5}{6 0 (\text {m i n u t e s})} \\ = 3 0 k m / h \\ \e...
[20419|p746] Units of speed are more commonly m/s or km/h so the units need changing.
[20420|p746] Multiply top and bottom by 15 to get 60 minutes  $(= 1$  hour) on the bottom.
[20421|p746] Calculate to give answer in km/h.

[20446|p747|T1] 21.5 Proportion
[20447|p747] Quantities increase or decrease in proportion if multiplying (or dividing) one quantity by a value results in multiplying (or dividing) the other quan...
[20448|p747|T1] Direct proportion
[20449|p747] When two quantities are in direct proportion they increase or decrease at the same rate. In other words, the ratio of the quantities is equivalent (in...
[20450|p747|T1] LINK
[20451|p747] Home economists, chefs and food technologists use proportional reasoning to mix ingredients, convert between units or work out the cost of a dish.
[20452|p748] Here are some examples of quantities that are in direct proportion:
[20453|p748] [Table Row] <tr><td>Speed (km/h)</td><td>0</td><td>45</td><td>60</td><td>75</td><td>90</td><td>120</td></tr>
[20454|p748] [Table Row] <tr><td>Distance covered in an hour (km)</td><td>0</td><td>45</td><td>60</td><td>75</td><td>90</td><td>120</td></tr>
[20455|p748] Distance = speed × time, so the faster you drive in a set time, the further you will travel in that time.
[20456|p748] [Table Row] <tr><td>Number of items</td><td>0</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td></tr>
[20457|p748] [Table Row] <tr><td>Mass (kg)</td><td>0</td><td>2</td><td>4</td><td>6</td><td>8</td></tr>
[20458|p748] If one item has a mass of  $2\mathrm{kg}$ , then two of the same item will have a mass of  $4\mathrm{kg}$  and so on. The more you have of the same it...
[20459|p748] [Table Row] <tr><td>Number of hours worked</td><td>0</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td></tr>
[20460|p748] [Table Row] <tr><td>Amount earned ($)</td><td>0</td><td>12</td><td>24</td><td>36</td></tr>
[20461|p748] The more hours you work, the more you earn.
[20462|p748|T1] Graphs of directly proportional relationships
[20463|p748] If you draw the graph of a directly proportional relationship you will get a straight line that passes through the origin.
[20464|p748] Of course, the converse (opposite) of this is also true. When a graph is a straight line that passes through the origin, one quantity is directly prop...
[20466|p748] This graph shows the amount of Indian rupees you would get for different amounts of US dollars at an exchange rate of US$1: Rs 75. Exchange rates are ...
[20467|p748|T1] LINK
[20468|p748] When a liquid cools, the rate at which the temperature decreases is directly proportional to the difference between the temperature of the liquid and ...
[20469|p749|T1] Exercise 21.9
[20470|p749] 1 Which of these could be examples of direct proportion?
[20471|p749] a The length of the side of a square and its area.
[20472|p749] b The ages and heights of students.
[20473|p749] The amount of money collected in a sponsored walk if you are paid 5c per kilometre.

[20477|p749] g The number of chickens you could feed with  $20\mathrm{kg}$  of feed.
[20478|p749] The height of the tree and the number of years since it was planted.
[20479|p749] i The area of the sector of a circle and the angle at the centre.
[20480|p749] 2 This graph shows two variables that are directly proportional to each other.
[20482|p749] a Find the values of  $a$  and  $b$
[20483|p749] b What equation describes this relationship?
[20484|p749|T1] Calculating with direct proportion
[20485|p749] The unitary method is useful for solving a range of problems involving proportion. Using this method, you start by finding the value of one unit of th...
[20486|p749|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18
[20487|p749] Five bottles of perfume cost $200. What would 11 bottles cost?
[20488|p749|T1] Answer
[20489|p749] Unitary method
[20490|p749] 5 bottles cost $200
[20491|p749] 1 bottle costs  $200 + 5 =$ 40
[20492|p749] 11 bottles cost \(11 \times \\)40 = \\(440$
[20493|p750|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18 CONTINUED
[20494|p750] You can also solve this problem using the ratio method.
[20495|p750] $$
\frac {5}{2 0 0} = \frac {1 1}{x}
$$
[20496|p750] Write out each part as a fraction.
[20497|p750] $$
\frac {2 0 0}{5} = \frac {x}{1 1}
$$
[20498|p750] Take the reciprocal of both ratios (tum them upside down) to make it easier to solve the equation.
[20499|p750] $$
\frac {2 0 0 \times 1 1}{5} = x
$$
[20500|p750] $$
x = \$ 440
$$

[20536|p751|T1] Inverse proportion
[20537|p751] In inverse proportion, one quantity decreases in the same proportion as the other quantity increases. Think about this in terms of money. If you have ...
[20538|p751] [Table Row] <tr><td>Price $</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>4</td><td>10</td></tr>
[20539|p751] [Table Row] <tr><td>Number you can buy</td><td>20</td><td>10</td><td>5</td><td>2</td></tr>
[20540|p751] In other words, as the price increases, the number of pens you can buy decreases. Looking at the table, you can see that as price doubles, the number ...
[20541|p751] The graph of an inversely proportional relationship is half of a hyperbola  $(y = \frac{a}{x}$  where  $a$  is positive) and not a straight line.
[20542|p751|T1] TIP
[20543|p751] Feet is the plural of (one) foot.
[20544|p752] This graph shows how the volume of air in a syringe changes when the pressure on the air is increased. You can see from the graph that this is an inve...
[20546|p752|T1] LINK
[20547|p752] You may have learnt about the relationship between gas volume and increased pressure when you studied Boyle's law in science.
[20548|p752|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 19
[20549|p752] A person travelling at  $30\mathrm{km / h}$  takes 24 minutes to get home from work. How long will the journey take if they travel at  $36\mathrm{km /...
[20550|p752|T1] Answer
[20551|p752] 30km/h takes 24 minutes.
[20552|p752] This is inverse proportion; as one value decreases the other increases.
[20553|p752] So,  $1\mathrm{km / h}$  would take  $30\times 24$  minutes.
[20554|p752] To get  $1\mathrm{km / h}$  you divide the speed by 30, so multiply the time by 30.
[20555|p752] at 36km/h it will take 30x24 36
[20556|p752] To get  $36\mathrm{km / h}$  you multiply the speed by 36, so divide the time by 36.
[20557|p752] $= 20$  minutes.
[20558|p752|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 20
[20559|p752] A peson working six hours per day can complete a job in four days. How many hours per day will they need to work to complete the job in three days?
[20560|p752|T1] Answer
[20561|p752] For 4 days it takes 6 hours per day  
 $\therefore 1$  day would take  $4 \times 6$  hours = 24 hours per day  
3 days would take  $\frac{24}{3} = 8$ ...

[20575|p753] 36 people.

[20578|p753|T1] 21.6 Direct and inverse proportion in algebraic terms
[20579|p753] We can use generalised equations to represent direct and inverse relationships between two quantities,  $x$  and  $y$ , using  $k$  to represent a con...
[20580|p753|T1] Direct proportion
[20581|p753] If the values of two variables are always in the same ratio, we say that the variables are in direct proportion. If the variables are  $P$  and  $Q$ ,...
[20582|p753] $P \propto Q$  means that  $\frac{P}{Q}$  is constant. That is,  $P = kQ$ , where  $k$  is a constant.
[20583|p753] If the constant is 2, then  $P = 2Q$ . This means that whatever  $P$  is,  $Q$  will be double that.
[20584|p753] You can also write this as  $\frac{P}{Q} = 2$ .
[20585|p753|T1] Inverse proportion
[20586|p753] If the product of the value of two variables is constant, the variables are said to be inversely proportional. If the variables are  $P$  and  $Q$ , y...
[20587|p753] $PQ = k$  can also be written as  $P = \frac{k}{Q}$
[20588|p753] So  $P$  is inversely proportional to  $Q$  can be written as  $P \propto \frac{1}{Q}$ .
[20589|p753|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[20590|p753] A question might ask you to find a proportion equation and then find unknowns by solving it. Recap how to solve equations in Chapter 6.
[20591|p754|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 21
[20592|p754] $y$  is directly proportional to  $x^3$  and when  $x = 2, y = 32$ .
[20593|p754] a Write this relationship as an equation.
[20594|p754] b Find the value of  $y$  when  $x = 5$
[20595|p754|T1] Answers
[20596|p754] a  $y\propto x^3$  , which means (as an equation)  $y = kx^{3}$
[20597|p754] $$
\text {W h e n} x = 2, x ^ {3} = 2 ^ {3} = 8
$$
[20598|p754] $$
\therefore 3 2 = 8 k
$$
[20599|p754] $$
\therefore k = \frac {3 2}{8} = 4 \text {a n d} y = 4 x ^ {3}
$$
[20600|p754] b If  $x = 5$  ,then
[20601|p754] $$
y = 4 x ^ {3} = 4 \times 5 ^ {3} = 5 0 0
$$
[20602|p754|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 22
[20603|p754] If is inversely proportional to  $d^2$  and when  $d = 3$ ,  $F = 12$ .
[20604|p754] Find the value of  $F$  when  $d = 4$
[20605|p754|T1] Answer
[20606|p754] $F\propto \frac{1}{d^2}$  which means (as an equation)  $F = \frac{k}{d^2}$
[20607|p754] When  $d = 3$  and  $F = 12, 12 = \frac{k}{3^2} = \frac{k}{9}$
[20608|p754] $$
\begin{array}{l} \therefore k = 1 2 \times 9 = 1 0 8 \\ S _ {0}, F = \frac {1 0 8}{d ^ {2}} \\ \text {I f} d = 4, \text {t h e n} F = \frac {1 0 8}...
[20609|p754|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 23
[20610|p754] Some corresponding values of the variables  $p$  and  $q$  are shown in the table. Are  $p$  and  $q$  directly proportional?
[20611|p754] [Table Row] <tr><td>p</td><td>2.8</td><td>7</td><td>11.2</td><td>16.8</td></tr>
[20612|p754] [Table Row] <tr><td>q</td><td>2</td><td>5</td><td>8</td><td>12</td></tr>
[20613|p754|T1] Answer
[20614|p754] Compare each pair in turn:
[20615|p754] $$
\frac {2 . 8}{2} = 1. 4 \quad \frac {7}{5} = 1. 4 \quad \frac {1 1 . 2}{8} = 1. 4 \quad \frac {1 6 . 8}{1 2} = 1. 4
$$
[20616|p754] All the values are the same.
[20617|p754] So, the values are directly proportional,  $p = 1.4q$ .
[20618|p754|T1] TIP
[20619|p754] The relationship between quantities is usually described in words and you will need to add the  $\alpha$  symbol in your working, as in these examples...
[20620|p755|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 24
[20621|p755] [Table Row] <tr><td>x</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td></tr>
[20622|p755] [Table Row] <tr><td>y</td><td>12</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr>
[20623|p755] Copy and complete this table of values for:
[20624|p755] a yxx
[20625|p755] b  $y\propto \frac{1}{x}$
[20626|p755|T1] Answers
[20627|p755] a  $y\times x$  means  $y = kx$
[20628|p755] Write the relationship as an equation.
[20629|p755] $$
1 2 = 3 k
$$
[20630|p755] Solve the equation for  $k$ .
[20631|p755] $$
\therefore k = 4 \text {a n d} y = 4 x
$$
[20632|p755] Substitute the value of  $k$  into original equation.
[20633|p755] [Table Row] <tr><td>x^</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td></tr>
[20634|p755] [Table Row] <tr><td>y</td><td>12</td><td>16</td><td>20</td><td>24</td></tr>
[20635|p755] b  $y\propto \frac{1}{x}$  means  $xy = k$
[20636|p755] Write the relationship as an equation.
[20637|p755] $$
\therefore k = 3 \times 1 2 = 3 6 \text {a n d} y = \frac {3 6}{x}
$$
[20638|p755] Use a value of  $x$  and corresponding value of  $y$ , to solve the equation for  $k$ .
[20639|p755] [Table Row] <tr><td>x</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td></tr>
[20640|p755] [Table Row] <tr><td>y</td><td>12</td><td>9</td><td>7.2</td><td>6</td></tr>
[20641|p755|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 25
[20642|p755] The speed of water in a river is determined by a water-pressure gauge. The speed (vm/s) is directly proportional to the square root of the height (h c...
[20643|p755|T1] Answer
[20644|p755] $v \propto \sqrt{h}$  means that  $v = k\sqrt{h}$  where  $k$  is constant.
[20645|p755] When  $y = 8$ ,  $h = 36$  and so  $8 = k\sqrt{36} = 6k$
[20646|p755] It follows that  $k = \frac{4}{3}$  and the formula connecting  $v$  and  $h$  is  $v = \frac{4\sqrt{h}}{3}$ .
[20647|p755] $$
\text {W h e n} h = 1 8, v = \frac {4 \sqrt {1 8}}{3} = 5. 6 6 (\text {t o} 3 \text {s . f .})
$$

[20700|p757|T1] SUMMARY
[20701|p757|T1] Do you know ...?
[20702|p757] A ratio is a comparison of two or more quantities in a set order. Ratios can be expressed in the form  $a:b$  or  $\frac{a}{b}$ . Ratios have no units...
[20703|p757] Ratios can be simplified by multiplying or dividing both quantities by the same number. This method produces equivalent ratios.
[20704|p757] Map scales are good examples of ratios in everyday life. The scale of a map is usually given in the form  $1:n$ . This allows you to convert map dista...
[20705|p757] A rate is a comparison of two different quantities. Usually a rate gives an amount of one quantity per unit of the other. Rates must include the units...
[20706|p757] Speed is one of the most common rates of change. Speed = distance ÷ time.
[20707|p757] Kinematic graphs are used to show relationships between:
[20708|p757] distance and time (distance-time graph)
[20709|p757] speed and time (speed-time graph)
[20710|p757] and to solve problems in these areas.
[20711|p757|T1] TIP
[20712|p757] Sometimes you may see 'varies as' written instead of 'is directly proportional to'. Similarly, 'varies inversely with' means 'is inversely proportiona...
[20713|p758|T1] SUMMARY CONTINUED
[20714|p758] The gradient of a distance-time graph shows how the speed changes over time.
[20715|p758] Proportion is a constant ratio between two sets of numbers.
[20716|p758] When quantities are in direct proportion they increase or decrease at the same rate.
[20717|p758] When quantities are inversely proportional, one increases as the other decreases.
[20718|p758] Algebraic expressions can be used to represent direct and indirect (inverse) proportion and to solve problems related to these concepts. The symbol fo...
[20719|p758|T1] Are you able to ...?
[20720|p758] To simplify ratios and find the missing values in equivalent ratios,
[20721|p758] divide quantities in a given ratio
[20722|p758] convert measurements on maps, plans and other scale diagrams to real measurements and vice versa
[20723|p758] express relationships between different quantities as rates in their simplest form and solve problems relating to rates
[20724|p758] read and interpret kinematic graphs
[20725|p758] by calculating average speed
[20726|p758] by calculating acceleration and deceleration from a graph and finding the distance travelled using the area under a linear speed-time graph
[20727|p758] 1. solve problems involving direct and indirect proportion
[20728|p758] express direct and inverse proportion in algebraic terms
[20729|p758] solve direct and inverse proportion problems using algebraic methods.

[20786|p761|T1] SELF ASSESSMENT
[20787|p761] You can get good marks in mathematics by clearly showing your working and methods even if you get the final answer incorrect.
[20788|p761] Evaluate your answers to the practice questions.
[20789|p761] Did you show your working?
[20790|p761] Is your working clearly laid out and systematic?
[20791|p761] - Does your working show that you understood the question and give evidence that you know how to answer it?
[20792|p761] - Do you think you would get part marks for any questions where you got the incorrect answer? Support your opinion.
[20794|p762|T1] Chapter 22
[20795|p762|T1] More equations, formulae and functions
[20796|p762|T1] IN THIS CHAPTER YOU WILL:
[20797|p762] make your own equations and use them to solve worded problems
[20798|p762] - construct and transform more complex formulae
[20799|p762] - use function notation to describe simple functions and their inverses
[20800|p762] form composite functions.
[20801|p763] Formulae can be used to describe very simple things as well as complicated situations. They can be used to calculate the area of a shape, to decide wh...
[20802|p763] Many real-life calculations rely on formulae. For example, working out how much it will cost to tile rooms of different sizes, converting measurements...
[20803|p763] In this chapter you will work with more complicated formulae and equations. You will need to be able to rearrange formulae to solve related problems.
[20804|p763] You will also revise what you know about functions and learn how to use a more formal mathematical notation to describe functions and their inverses. ...

[20806|p763] composite function
[20807|p763] function
[20808|p763] function notation
[20809|p763|T1] GETTING STARTED
[20810|p763] 1 A driver's education manual says that you can work out a safe following distance  $(d)$  between vehicles that are travelling at  $s$  kilometres pe...
[20811|p763] a What does this mean in words?
[20812|p763] b How many vehicle lengths should a truck driver leave between the truck and the vehicle in front of it at a speed of  $90\mathrm{km}$  per hour?
[20813|p763] c At what speed is 3 vehicle lengths a safe following distance?
[20814|p763] How does an increase in speed affect the safe following distance?
[20815|p763] 2 The cost of adding a new USB port and cable to a system is $C when the length of the cable is y metres and C = 4.5 + 1.8y.
[20816|p763] a What do you think 4.5 represents in this formula?
[20817|p763] b What is the meaning of coefficient 1.8?
[20818|p763] c How long is the cable when the total cost is $26.55?

[20834|p764] b If a certain number is multiplied by 12 the result is 96.
[20835|p764] A number added to 12 gives 55.
[20836|p764] d The sum of a number and 13 is 25.
[20837|p764] e When six is subtracted from a certain number, the result is 14.
[20838|p764] If a number is subtracted from nine the result is  $-5$
[20839|p764] g The result of dividing a number by seven is 2.5.

[20843|p764] b When six is subtracted from five times a certain number, the result is 54.

[20870|p765|T1] Solving more complex problems
[20871|p765] The problems you solved in Exercise 22.1 involved simple algebraic manipulation. You need to be able to set up equations to solve any problem. To do t...
[20872|p765] To solve problems by setting up equations:
[20873|p765] - Read the problem carefully, paying attention to the words used.
[20874|p765] - Decide what you need to find and what information is already given. It might help to draw a bar model to represent the problem.
[20875|p765] - Ask yourself if there is anything to be assumed or deduced from the given information. For example, if the problem mentions equal lengths and widths...
[20876|p765] - Consider whether there is a formula or mathematical relationship that you can use to connect the information in the problem. For example, if you are...
[20878|p766|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[20879|p766] My mother was 26 years old when I was born. Now, she is three times as old as I am. What are our ages now?
[20880|p766|T1] Answer
[20881|p766] Let my age now be x.
[20882|p766] . my mother's age now is 3x.
[20883|p766] She is 3 times as old as me.
[20884|p766] The difference in ages is 26 years, so:
[20885|p766] Mother will always be 26 years older.
[20886|p766] $$
\begin{array}{l} 3 x - x = 2 6 \\ \therefore 2 x = 2 6 \\ \therefore x = 1 3 \\ \end{array}
$$
[20887|p766] My age now is 13. My mother's age now is 39.
[20888|p766|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[20889|p766] The longest sides of a parallelogram are five times longer than its shorter sides. If it has a perimeter of  $9.6\mathrm{m}$ , what are the lengths of...
[20890|p766|T1] Answer
[20891|p766] Let the shorter side be  $x$  metres.  
∴ the longer side is  $5x$ .
[20893|p766] $$
\begin{array}{l} 5 x + x + 5 x + x = 9. 6 m \\ 1 2 x = 9. 6 m \\ x = \frac {9 . 6}{1 2} = 0. 8 m \\ \end{array}
$$
[20894|p766] So, the shorter side is  $0.8\mathrm{m}$  and the longer side is  $5\times 0.8 = 4\mathrm{m}$

[20901|p766] Always say what the variables represent.

[20926|p768|T1] SELF ASSESSMENT
[20927|p768] Complete your own 3:2:1 summary to assess your understanding of writing equations and using them to solve problems.

[20930|p768] 2 questions I had were:

[20932|p768|T1] Deriving quadratic equations
[20933|p768] To solve some word problems you might need to derive and solve a quadratic equation. Before you can solve the equation you must write the word problem...
[20934|p768|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[20935|p768] The product of two consecutive integers is 42. Form and solve a quadratic equation to find both possible pairs of integers.
[20936|p768|T1] Answer
[20937|p768] Use the letter  $n$  to represent the smaller of the two numbers. Then the larger of the two numbers is  $n + 1$ .
[20938|p768] The product of the two numbers is 42, so
[20939|p768] $$
\begin{array}{l} n (n + 1) = 4 2 \\ \Rightarrow n ^ {2} + n = 4 2 \\ \Rightarrow n ^ {2} + n - 4 2 = 0 \\ \Rightarrow (n + 7) (n - 6) = 0 \\ \Right...
[20940|p768] $$
\text {I f} n = - 7, \text {t h e n} n + 1 = - 6.
$$
[20941|p768] Check: -7 and -6 are consecutive integers and  $-6 \times -7 = 42$ .
[20942|p768] $$
\text {I f} n = 6, \text {t h e n} n + 1 = 7.
$$
[20943|p768] Check: 6 and 7 are consecutive integers and  $6 \times 7 = 42$ .
[20944|p768] So the pairs of integers are 6, 7 and -7, -6.
[20945|p768|T1] TIP
[20946|p768] Refer back to
[20947|p768] Chapter 2 if you need some ideas for completing a 3:2:1 self assessment.
[20948|p768|T1] TIP
[20949|p768] You might have spotted the solution 6, 7 without using algebra, but writing a quadratic equation means you will definitely find all the solutions.
[20950|p769|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[20951|p769] The length of a rectangle is  $2\mathrm{cm}$  greater than its width. The area of the rectangle is  $15\mathrm{cm}$ . Find its perimeter.
[20952|p769|T1] Answer
[20954|p769] Always draw a diagram to show the information and to help you visualise the situation.
[20955|p769] The area is the length  $\times$  width, so
[20956|p769] $$
\begin{array}{l} x (x + 2) = 1 5 \\ \Rightarrow x ^ {2} + 2 x = 1 5 \\ \Rightarrow x ^ {2} + 2 x - 1 5 = 0 \\ \Rightarrow (x + 5) (x - 3) = 0 \\ \R...
[20957|p769] $x$  is the width of the rectangle,
[20958|p769] so it cannot be a negative number.
[20959|p769] This means  $x$  must be 3.
[20960|p769] The dimensions of the rectangle are
[20961|p769] $$
3 \mathrm {c m} \times 5 \mathrm {c m}.
$$
[20962|p769] Its perimeter  $= 3 + 5 + 3 + 5 = 16\mathrm{cm}$
[20963|p769] Use  $x$  to represent the width of the rectangle. This means that the length will be  $x + 2$
[20964|p769|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[20965|p769] A right-angled triangle has height  $h$  cm and base  $b$  cm. The hypotenuse of the triangle has length  $\sqrt{13}$  cm. If the area of the triangle...
[20966|p769|T1] Answer
[20967|p769] Use the formula for the area of a triangle:
[20968|p769] $$
\begin{array}{l} \frac {1}{2} b h = 3 \\ \Rightarrow b h = 6 \\ \Rightarrow h = \frac {6}{b} \tag {1} \\ \end{array}
$$
[20969|p769] Now use Pythagoras' theorem and the fact that the hypotenuse has length  $\sqrt{13}$  cm:
[20970|p769] $$
b ^ {2} + h ^ {2} = 1 3 \tag {2}
$$
[20971|p769] Substitute [1] into [2]:
[20972|p769] $$
\begin{array}{l} b ^ {2} + \left(\frac {6}{b}\right) ^ {2} = 1 3 \\ \Rightarrow b ^ {2} + \frac {3 6}{b ^ {2}} = 1 3 \\ \end{array}
$$
[20973|p769|T1] TIP
[20974|p769] Where possible, make one unknown the subject of the equation, so that it can be substituted into any later equation.
[20975|p770|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5 CONTINUED
[20976|p770] Solve the equation to find the values of  $b$  and substitute into (1) to find the values of  $h$ :
[20977|p770] $$
\begin{array}{l} (b ^ {2}) ^ {2} + 3 6 = 1 3 b ^ {2} \\ \Rightarrow (b ^ {2}) ^ {2} - 1 3 (b ^ {2}) + 3 6 = 0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad (b ^ {2} - 9) (b...
[20978|p770|T1] Exercise 22.3
[20979|p770] 1 A number is 3 more than another number and the product of these two numbers is 40. Find the possible pairs of numbers.
[20980|p770] 2 A ball starts to roll down a slope. If the ball is  $d$  metres from its starting point at time  $t$  seconds and  $d = t^2 + 3t$ , find the time wh...
[20981|p770] 3 The nth term of the sequence
[20982|p770] [Table Row] <tr><td>1</td><td>3</td><td>6</td><td>10</td><td>15</td><td>...</td></tr>
[20983|p770] is  $\frac{n(n + 1)}{2}$ , where  $n$  is the position of each term in the sequence.
[20984|p770] Use algebra to find the position of the number 78.
[20985|p770] 4 The sum of two integers is 11 and the product of the same two integers is 28. Use algebra to show that the two integers must be 4 and 7.

[20992|p770] a Show that  $x^{2} - x - 1 = 0$
[20993|p770] b Solve this equation, giving your answers to 2 decimal places.
[20994|p770] c Explain why one of your solutions does not work in this case.
[20995|p770] Find the perimeter of the rectangle.
[20997|p770|T1] TIP
[20998|p770] This is the sequence of triangular numbers.
[20999|p770|T1] TIP
[21000|p770] A rectangle that can be divided up in this way is known as a golden rectangle and the positive solution of the equation that you have solved is known ...
[21001|p771] 9 A ball is thrown from a building and falls  $3t + 5t^2$  metres in  $t$  seconds. After how many seconds has the ball fallen  $6\mathrm{m}$ ?

[21010|p771|T1] 22.2 Using and rearranging formulae
[21011|p771] You already know that the variable which is written alone on one side of the  $\mathbf{\Pi } = \mathbf{\Pi }$  sign (usually the left) of a formula is...
[21012|p771] In some situations it is more helpful to have a different variable as the subject, so you will need to rearrange the formula.
[21013|p771] To change the subject of a formula:
[21014|p771] expand to get rid of any brackets if necessary
[21015|p771] use inverse operations to isolate the variable required.
[21016|p772|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[21017|p772] Solve for  $h$  if  $A = 2\pi r(r + h)$
[21018|p772] Answer
[21019|p772] $$
\begin{array}{l} A = 2 \pi r (r + h) \\ A = 2 \pi r ^ {2} + 2 \pi r h \\ A - 2 \pi r ^ {2} = 2 \pi r h \\ \end{array}
$$
[21020|p772] Expand to remove the brackets.
[21021|p772] Subtract to isolate the term with  $h$  in it.
[21022|p772] $$
\frac {(A - 2 \pi r ^ {2})}{2 \pi r} = h
$$
[21023|p772] Divide to get rid of  $2\pi r$  on the right-hand side.
[21024|p772] $$
h = \frac {(A - 2 \pi r ^ {2})}{2 \pi r}
$$
[21025|p772] Express the formula in terms of  $h$ .
[21026|p772|T1] Formulae containing squares and square roots
[21027|p772] Some formulae have squared terms and square roots. You need to remember that a squared number has both a negative and a positive root when you solve t...
[21028|p772] TIP
[21029|p772] $\sqrt{x}$  means the positive square root only, so  $\sqrt{9}$  is equal to 3.
[21030|p772] However, if  $x^2 = 9$  then  $x = \pm \sqrt{9} = \pm 3$ . You must use  $\pm$  when undoing a square.
[21031|p772|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[21032|p772] Make  $x$  the subject of the formula  $ax^2 = b$ .
[21033|p772] Answer
[21034|p772] $$
a x ^ {2} = b
$$
[21035|p772] $$
x ^ {2} = \frac {b}{a}
$$
[21036|p772] Divide both side by a.
[21037|p772] $$
x = \pm \sqrt {\frac {b}{a}}
$$
[21038|p772] Take square root of both sides to get  $x$ .
[21039|p772|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[21040|p772] Given  $r = \sqrt{\frac{A}{\pi}}$  express the formula in terms of A.
[21041|p772] Answer
[21042|p772] $$
r = \sqrt {\frac {A}{\pi}}
$$
[21043|p772] $$
r ^ {2} = \frac {A}{\pi}
$$
[21044|p772] Square both sides to get rid of the square root.
[21045|p772] $$
\pi r ^ {2} = A
$$
[21046|p772] Multiply each side by  $\pi$ .
[21047|p772] $$
A = \pi r ^ {2}
$$
[21048|p772] TIP
[21049|p772] If you are told to solve for  $x$ , or find  $x$ , it means the same as 'make  $x$  the subject of the formula'.
[21050|p773|T1] LINK
[21051|p773] The time it takes a pendulum to swing back and forth (period) does not depend on the mass of the pendulum bob or on how far the pendulum swings, it de...
[21052|p773] The equation for the period  $(T)$  of a simple pendulum is  $T = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{L}{g}}$ , where  $L$  is the length of the pendulum and  $g$  is th...
[21053|p773] The frequency  $(F)$  of a pendulum is the number of times it swings all the way back and forth in one second (expressed in swings per second). Freque...
[21054|p773] You can use this equation to calculate the length of a pendulum for a given frequency. This is the principle behind the metronome that musicians use t...
[21056|p773|T1] Exercise 22.4
[21057|p773] 1 Make  $x$  the subject of each formula.
[21058|p773] a  $m = x + bp$
[21059|p773] b  $n = pr - x$
[21060|p773] c  $4x = m$
[21061|p773] d  $ax^2 -b = c$
[21062|p773] e  $d - 2b = mx + c$
[21063|p773] $\frac{x}{y} = {3b}$
[21064|p773] g m=
[21065|p773] mx P
[21066|p773] i  $m = \frac{2x}{k}$
[21067|p773] j  $p = \frac{20}{x}$
[21068|p773] 2 Solve for  $x$
[21069|p773] a  $m = 3(x + y)$
[21070|p773] b  $c = 4(t - x)$
[21071|p773] $y = 3(x - 5)$
[21072|p773] d  $r = 2r(3 - x)$
[21073|p773] e  $m = 4c(x - y)$
[21074|p773] f  $a = \pi r(2r - x)$
[21075|p773] 3 Express each formula in terms of the variable given in brackets.
[21076|p773] a  $E = mc^2$
[21077|p773] (m)
[21078|p773] b  $I = \frac{PRT}{100}$  (R)
[21079|p773] c.
[21080|p773] $k = \frac{1}{2} mv^2 (m)$
[21081|p773] d  $A = \frac{h(a + b)}{2}$  (b)
[21082|p773] e 1
[21083|p773] (h)
[21084|p773] f
[21085|p773] V=πr²h (h)
[21086|p773] 4 Make  $x$  the subject of each formula.
[21087|p773] a  $m = ax^{2}$
[21088|p773] b  $x^{2} - y = m$
[21089|p773] $m = n - x^{2}$
[21090|p773] d  $\frac{x^2}{y} = a$
[21091|p773] $a = \frac{bx^2}{c}$
[21092|p773] $a = {x}^{2} - {b}^{2}$
[21093|p773] g m=
[21094|p773] h  $\sqrt{xy} = m$
[21095|p773] i  $a = \sqrt{5x}$
[21096|p773] j  $y = \sqrt{x - z}$
[21097|p773] k  $y = \sqrt{x} -z$
[21098|p773] 1  $a = b + \frac{c}{\sqrt{x}}$
[21099|p773] m  $a - b\sqrt{x} = m$
[21100|p773] n  $\sqrt{3x - 1} = y$
[21101|p773] $a = \sqrt{y - 2x}$
[21102|p773] P  $y = \frac{a}{\sqrt{4x - b}}$
[21103|p773] 5 The formula for converting temperatures from Celsius to Fahrenheit is  $F = 32 + \frac{9C}{5}$ . Find the temperature in degrees  $C$  to the neares...
[21104|p773] a 100
[21105|p773] b 212
[21106|p773] c 32
[21107|p773|T1] TIP
[21108|p773] When you have several calculations like this it is quicker to rearrange the formula before substituting in each value.
[21109|p774] 6 You can find the area of a circle using the formula  $A = \pi r^2$ . If  $\pi = 3.14$ , find the radius  $r$ , of circular discs of metal with the f...
[21110|p774] a 14
[21111|p774] b 120
[21112|p774] c 0.5
[21113|p774|T1] Formulae where the subject appears in more than one term
[21114|p774] When the variable that is to be the subject occurs more than once, you need to collect the like terms and factorise before you can express the formula...
[21115|p774|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[21116|p774] Given that  $m = 6 - \frac{12}{P}$ , make  $p$  the subject of the formula.
[21117|p774] Answer
[21118|p774] $$
m = 6 - \frac {1 2}{p}
$$
[21119|p774] $$
m p = 6 p - 1 2
$$
[21120|p774] $$
m p - 6 p = - 1 2
$$
[21121|p774] $$
p (m - 6) = - 1 2
$$
[21122|p774] $$
p = \frac {- 1 2}{(m - 6)} \text {o r} \frac {1 2}{6 - m}
$$
[21123|p774] Multiply both sides by  $p$  to remove the fraction.
[21124|p774] Collect like terms.
[21125|p774] Factorise.

[21164|p776|T1] 22.3 Functions and function notation
[21165|p776] A function is a rule or set of instructions for changing one number (the input) into another number (the output). If  $y$  is a function of  $x$ , the...
[21166|p776|T1] Function notation
[21167|p776] Function notation is a mathematical way of writing equations (functions). Function notation is widely used in computer applications and also in techni...
[21168|p776] You already know that a function can be represented in a number of ways. For example, you can show the function  $y = 4x - 1$  using:
[21169|p776] a function machine (flow diagram): Input  $\rightarrow \boxed{\times 4}\rightarrow \boxed{-1}\rightarrow$  output
[21170|p776] a mapping diagram:
[21172|p776] a table of values:
[21173|p776] [Table Row] <tr><td>x</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td></tr>
[21174|p776] [Table Row] <tr><td>y</td><td>3</td><td>7</td><td>11</td></tr>
[21175|p776] a set of  $x$  and  $y$  -values (coordinates):  $\{(1,3),(2,7),(3,11),(4,15)\}$  In set notation this is written as  $\{(x,y):y = 4x - 1\}$
[21176|p776] a graph:
[21178|p776] When you write the equation  $y = 4x - 1$  in function notation it becomes  $f(x) = 4x - 1$ .
[21179|p777] You read  $\mathrm{f}(x)$  as 'the function of  $x$ ' or 'f of  $x$ '.
[21181|p777] If  $f(x) = 4x - 1$ , then  $f(5)$  means the value of the function when  $x = 5$ .
[21182|p777] In other words,  $f(5) = 4 \times 5 - 1 = 19$ .
[21183|p777] Similarly.  $f(-2) = 4 \times -2 - 1 = -9$ .
[21184|p777] The number  $4x - 1$  is sometimes called the image of  $x$  (under function  $f$ ).
[21185|p777] When a problem involves two or more functions, you use different letters to represent them. For example, you could have:
[21186|p777] $$
g (x) = x ^ {2} - 2 x + 3 \text {a n d} h (x) = 5 x - 3
$$
[21187|p777] You can show the steps you take to work out the value of any function  $f(x)$  using a simple flow diagram. For example, you can represent the functio...
[21188|p777] $$
x - \boxed {x 5} - \boxed {- 3} \rightarrow 5 x - 3
$$
[21189|p777] The function  $j(x) = 5(x - 3)$  can be represented as:
[21190|p777] $$
x \rightarrow \boxed {- 3} \rightarrow \boxed {\times 5} \rightarrow 5 (x - 3)
$$
[21191|p777] Note that the flow charts show the same operations but, as they are done in a different order, they produce different results.
[21192|p777|T1] INVESTIGATION
[21193|p777|T1] Shadow maths
[21194|p777] 1 What does it mean mathematically when we say 'the length of your shadow is a function of your height and the time of day'?
[21195|p777] 2 Investigate how you can use mathematical functions involving the length of a shadow and time to determine the height of tall objects such as trees o...
[21196|p777|T1] TIP
[21197|p777] In function notation you leave out the  $y$  and replace it with the notation  $f(x)$ . So, if  $f$  is a function and  $x$  is an input, then  $f(x)$...
[21199|p778|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[21200|p778] Given that  $f(x) = x^{2} - 3x$  and  $y = \ldots$  find the value of:
[21201|p778] a f(6)
[21202|p778] b f(-3)
[21203|p778] g(1)
[21204|p778] d g(6)
[21205|p778|T1] Answers
[21206|p778] a  $f(6) = 6^{2} - 3(6) = 36 - 18 = 18$
[21207|p778] b  $f(-3) = (-3)^{2} - 3(-3) = 9 + 9 = 18$
[21208|p778] c g（）=4（）-6=2-6=-4
[21209|p778] d g(6) = 4(6) - 6 = 24 - 6 = 18
[21210|p778|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11
[21211|p778] Given  $h(x) = 9 - x^2$
[21212|p778] Find:
[21213|p778] i h(0)
[21214|p778] ii h(3)
[21215|p778] iii h(9)
[21216|p778] iv h(-9)
[21217|p778|T1] Answers
[21218|p778] i  $h(0) = 9 - (0)^2 = 9 - 0 = 9$
[21219|p778] ii  $h(3) = 9 - (3)^2 = 9 - 9 = 0$
[21220|p778] iii  $h(9) = 9 - (9)^2 = 9 - 81 = -72$
[21221|p778] iv  $h(-9) = 9 - (-9)^2 = 9 - 81 = -72$
[21222|p778|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 12
[21223|p778] $$
f (x) = 3 + 2 x
$$
[21224|p778] Solve the equation  $f(x) = 6$ .
[21225|p778|T1] Answer
[21226|p778] $$
3 + 2 x = 6
$$
[21227|p778] The functions are equivalent.
[21228|p778] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 x = 6 - 3 \\ 2 x = 3 \\ x = 1. 5 \\ \end{array}
$$
[21229|p778|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13
[21230|p778] Given the functions  $f(x) = x^2$  and  $g(x) = x + 2$ ,
[21231|p778] a solve the equation  $f(x) = g(x)$
[21232|p778] b solve the equation  $4g(x) = g(x) - 3.$
[21233|p779|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13 CONTINUED
[21234|p779|T1] Answers
[21235|p779] $f(x) = g(x)$
[21236|p779] $$
f (x) = g (x)
$$
[21237|p779] $$
x ^ {2} = x + 2
$$
[21238|p779] The functions are equivalent.
[21239|p779] $$
x ^ {2} - x - 2 = 0
$$
[21240|p779] $$
(x - 2) (x + 1) = 0
$$
[21241|p779] Factorise.
[21242|p779] $$
S o, x = 2 o r x = - 1
$$
[21243|p779] b  $4g(x) = g(x) - 3$
[21244|p779] $$
3 g (x) = - 3
$$
[21245|p779] Subtract  $g(x)$  from both sides.
[21246|p779] $$
g (x) = - 1
$$
[21247|p779] Divide both sides by three.
[21248|p779] $$
x + 2 = - 1
$$
[21249|p779] Replace  $g(x)$  with  $x + 2$ .
[21250|p779] $$
x = - 3
$$
[21251|p779|T1] Domain and range
[21252|p779] A function is defined by a rule that provides the output values for corresponding input values.
[21253|p779] The domain (D) of a function is the set of input values. These are the possible values for the independent variable (the  $x$ -values).
[21254|p779] The range (R) is the set of output values from the rule. These are the  $y$ -values, which are dependent on the variable input.
[21255|p779] There may be restrictions on the domain. For example, if you are working with time or distance, the input values cannot be negative. Restrictions on t...
[21256|p779|T1] TIP
[21257|p779|T1] Remember:
[21258|p779] You cannot divide by 0.
[21259|p779] The square root of a negative number is not a real number.
[21260|p779] The square root sign  $(\sqrt{})$  refers to the positive square root only.
[21261|p779|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 14
[21262|p779] Determine the domain and range of each function.
[21263|p779] a  $y = \sqrt{2x - 1}$
[21264|p779] 3x b y=2x+1
[21265|p779|T1] Answers
[21266|p779] a  $y = \sqrt{2x - 1}$
[21267|p779] Domain:  $y$  will not be a real number if  $(2x - 1)$  is negative.
[21268|p779] $2x - 1\geq 0$  (must be positive)
[21269|p780|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 14 CONTINUED
[21270|p780] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 x \geqslant 1 \\ x \geqslant \frac {1}{2} \quad \text {S o}, x \text {v a l u e s} \text {m u s t} \text {b e g r e a t e r} \te...
[21271|p780] $$
\text {D o m a i n :} \left\{x: x \geqslant \frac {1}{2} \right\}
$$
[21272|p780] Range: The  $\sqrt{}$  sign means only positive square roots.
[21273|p780] So,  $y$  must be 0 or greater than 0.
[21274|p780] $$
\text {R a n g e :} \{y: y \geqslant 0 \}
$$
[21275|p780] $$
b y = \frac {3 x}{2 x + 1}
$$
[21276|p780] $$
\begin{array}{l} y \text {w i l l} (2 x + 1) = 0 \\ 2 x + 1 = 0 \\ 2 x = - 1 \\ x = - \frac {1}{2} \\ D o m a i n: \left\{x: x \neq - \frac {1}{2} ...
[21277|p780] To find the range we need to work out for which values of  $y, x$  will be undefined.
[21278|p780] $$
\begin{array}{l} 2 x y + y = 3 x \quad \text {R e a r r a n g e} \\ 2 x y - 3 x = - y \\ x (2 y - 3) = - y \quad \text {F a c t o r i s e} \\ \math...

[21301|p781] 3  $f(x) = x^{2} - 4$  ,find:
[21302|p781] a f(2)
[21303|p781] b f(0)

[21330|p781] 11  $f(x) = \frac{4 + x}{x} (x\neq 0)$
[21331|p781] a Calculate  $\mathrm{f}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)$  , simplifying your answer.
[21332|p781] b Solve  $f(x) = 3$ .
[21333|p781] 12  $f(x) = (2x + 1)(x + 1)$  find:
[21334|p781] a f(2)
[21335|p781] b f(-2)
[21336|p781] c f(0)
[21337|p781|T1] Composite functions
[21338|p781] A composite function is a combination of two or more functions. If you have two functions, the composite function is the result of making the output o...
[21339|p781] Input  $\rightarrow$  [function 1]  $\rightarrow$  output of function 1  $\rightarrow$  [function 2]  $\rightarrow$  output
[21340|p781] Look at these two functions:  $f(x) = 2x + 1$  and  $g(x) = x^2$ .
[21341|p781] You can apply function f followed by function g to find the composite func. For the input  $x = 4$ :
[21342|p781] $$
f (4) = 2 (4) + 1 = 8 + 1 = 9
$$
[21343|p781] $$
(9 \text {i s t h e r e s u l t o f t h e f i r s t f u n c t i o n .})
$$
[21344|p781] $$
\mathrm {g} (9) = 9 ^ {2} = 8 1
$$
[21345|p781] $$
\text {(T h e f u n c t i o n g h a s b e e n a p p l i e d t o t h e r e s u l t .)}
$$
[21346|p781] You can write what has been done as  $g[f(4)] = 81$ . However, normally the square brackets are left out and you just write  $g f(4) = 81$ .
[21347|p782] $\mathbf{gf}(x)$  is a composite function.
[21348|p782] The order of the letters in a composite function is important:
[21349|p782] $$
\operatorname {g f} (4) \neq \operatorname {f g} (4)
$$
[21350|p782] $\operatorname{fg}(x)$  means do f first then g, but  $\operatorname{fg}(x)$  means do g first then f.
[21351|p782] So, the function closest to the  $x$  is applied first.
[21352|p782] You can also find an algebraic expression for the composite function  $\operatorname{gf}(x)$ :
[21353|p782] $$
\mathrm {f} (x) = 2 x + 1
$$
[21354|p782] $(2x + 1$  is the result of the first function.)
[21355|p782] $$
\mathrm {g} (2 x + 1) = (2 x + 1) ^ {2}
$$
[21356|p782] $$
= 4 x ^ {2} + 4 x + 1
$$
[21357|p782] (The function  $\mathbf{g}$  has been applied to the result.)
[21358|p782] $$
\operatorname {S o}, \operatorname {g f} (x) = 4 x ^ {2} + 4 x + 1 \text {a n d} \operatorname {g f} (4) = 4 \times 4 ^ {2} + 4 \times 4 + 1 = 6 4 ...
[21359|p782|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[21360|p782] Given  $f(x) = 2x - 1$  and  $g(x) = x^2 + 6$ , find:
[21361|p782] a fg(x)
[21362|p782] b ff(x)
[21363|p782|T1] Answers
[21364|p782] a fg(x) = 2(x² + 6) - 1
[21365|p782] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 2 x ^ {2} + 1 2 - 1 \\ = 2 x ^ {2} + 1 1 \\ f g (x) = 2 x ^ {2} + 1 1 \\ \end{array}
$$
[21366|p782] Input  $g(x)$  into  $f(x)$
[21367|p782] b  $ff(x) = 2(2x - 1) - 1$
[21368|p782] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 4 x - 2 - 1 \\ = 4 x - 3 \\ f f (x) = 4 x - 3 \\ \end{array}
$$
[21369|p782] Input  $f(x)$  into  $f(x)$ .
[21370|p782|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 16
[21371|p782] Given the functions  $f(x) = x^2 - 2x$  and  $g(x) = 3 - x$ , find the value of:
[21372|p782] a gf(4)
[21373|p782] b fg(4)
[21374|p782] c ff(-1)
[21375|p782] d gg(100)
[21376|p782|T1] Answers
[21377|p782] a  $g f(4) = g[f(4)] = g[16 - 8] = g[8] = 3 - 8 = -5$
[21378|p782] b fg(4) = f[g(4)] = f[3 - 4] = f[-1] = (-1)² - 2(-1) = 1 + 2 = 3
[21379|p782] c  $ff(-1) = f[f(-1)] = f[1 + 2] = f[3] = 9 - 6 = 3$
[21380|p782] d  $gg(100) = g[g(100)] = g[3 - 100] = g[-97] = 3 - (-97) = 3 + 97 = 100$

[21419|p783] 8 If  $f(x) = x^4$  and  $g(x) = \sqrt{(x^2 + 36)}$ , evaluate:
[21420|p783] a  $\operatorname {fg}(x)$
[21421|p783] b  $\mathbf{gf}(x)$
[21422|p783] c ff(0)
[21423|p783] d gg(-2)
[21424|p783] 9 Given that  $f(x) = -x$ ,  $g(x) = x - 1$  and  $h(x) = \frac{1}{x + 2}$ , show why it is not possible to evaluate  $hgf(1)$ .
[21425|p783|T1] Inverse functions
[21426|p783] The inverse of any function (f) is the function that will do the opposite of f. In other words, the function that will undo the effects of f. So, if f...
[21427|p783] In effect, when  $f$  is applied to a number and the inverse of  $f$  is applied to the result, you will get back to the number you started with.
[21428|p783] In simple cases, you can find the inverse of a function by inspection. For example, the inverse of  $x \to x + 5$  must be  $x \to x - 5$  because sub...
[21429|p783] Similarly, the inverse of  $x \to 2x$  is  $x \to \frac{x}{2}$ , because to undo multiply by two you have to divide by two.
[21430|p783] The inverse of the function (f) is written as  $\mathsf{f}^{-1}$
[21431|p784] So, if  $f(x) = x + 5$ , then  $f^{-1}(x) = x - 5$ .
[21432|p784] and, if  $g(x) = 2x$ , then  $g^{-1}(x) = \frac{x}{2}$ .
[21433|p784] Some functions do not have an inverse. Think about the function  $x \to x^2$ . This is a function because for every value of  $x$ , there is only one ...
[21434|p784|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[21435|p784] You briefly worked with inverse functions in trigonometry in Chapter 15.
[21436|p784|T1] Finding the inverse of a function
[21437|p784] There are two methods of finding the inverse:
[21438|p784] Method 1: using a flow diagram.
[21439|p784] In this method you draw a flow diagram for the function and then work out the inverse by 'reversing' the flow to undo the operations in the boxes.
[21440|p784] Method 2: reversing the mapping.
[21441|p784] In this method you use the fact that if  $f$  maps  $x$  onto  $y$ , then  $f^{-1}$  maps  $y$  onto  $x$ .
[21442|p784] To find  $f^{-1}$  you have to find a value of  $x$  that corresponds to a given value of  $y$ .
[21443|p784] Worked examples 17-20 show how to find the inverse for two functions, first using method 1 and then using method 2.
[21444|p784|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 17
[21445|p784] Find the inverse of  $f(x) = 3x - 4$ .
[21446|p784|T1] Answer
[21447|p784] Using method 1, the flow diagram, you get:  $f \colon$  input  $\rightarrow \boxed{\times 3} \rightarrow \boxed{-4} \rightarrow$  output
[21448|p784] Reversing the diagram gives:  $f^{-1}$ : output  $\leftarrow \boxed{+3} \leftarrow \boxed{+4} \leftarrow \text{input}$
[21449|p784] Let  $x$  be the input to  $f^{-1}:\frac{x + 4}{3}\gets \boxed{+3}\gets \boxed{+4}\gets x$
[21450|p784] $$
S _ {0}, f ^ {- 1} (x) = \frac {x + 4}{3}
$$
[21451|p784|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18
[21452|p784] Given  $g(x) = 5 - 2x$  find  $g^{-1}(x)$
[21453|p784|T1] Answer
[21454|p784] Using method 1, the flow diagram, you get:  $g \colon \text{input} \to \boxed{\times(-2)} \to \boxed{+5} \to \text{output}$
[21455|p784] Reversing the diagram gives:  $g^{-1}$ : output  $\leftarrow \boxed{+(-2)} \leftarrow \boxed{-5} \leftarrow \text{input}$
[21456|p784] Let  $x$  be the input to  $g^{-1}:\frac{x - 5}{-2}\gets \boxed{+(-2)}\gets \boxed{-5}\gets x$
[21457|p784] $$
S _ {0}, g ^ {- 1} (x) = \frac {x - 5}{- 2} = \frac {5 - x}{2}
$$
[21458|p785|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 19
[21459|p785] Find the inverse of the function  $f(x) = 3x - 4$ .
[21460|p785|T1] Answer
[21461|p785] Using method 2, reversing the mapping.
[21462|p785] $$
y = 3 x - 4
$$
[21463|p785] Suppose the function maps  $x$  onto  $y$  (  $y$  is the subject).
[21464|p785] $$
y + 4 = 3 x
$$
[21465|p785] Make  $x$  the subject of the formula, so that  $y$  maps onto  $x$ .
[21466|p785] $$
x = \frac {y + 4}{3}
$$
[21467|p785] You know that  $f^{-1}$  maps  $y$  onto  $x$ , so  $f^{-1}(y) = \frac{y + 4}{3}$ .
[21468|p785] This is usually written in terms of  $x$  so,  $f^{-1}(x) = \frac{x + 4}{3}$
[21469|p785|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 20
[21470|p785] Given  $g(x) = 5 - 2x$ , find  $g^{-1}(x)$ .
[21471|p785|T1] Answer
[21472|p785] Let  $y = 5 - 2x$  This means g maps x onto y.
[21473|p785] $2x = 5 - y$  Make  $x$  the subject of the formula, so that  $y$  maps onto  $x$
[21474|p785] $$
x = \frac {5 - y}{2}
$$
[21475|p785] g-1 maps y onto x, so g-1(y) =  $\frac{5 - y}{2}$
[21476|p785] This is usually written in terms of  $x$  so,  $g^{-1}(x) = \frac{5 - x}{2}$

[21524|p786|T1] SUMMARY
[21525|p786|T1] Do you know ...?
[21526|p786] When you set up your own equations to represent problems you need to state what the variables stand for.
[21527|p786] You can rearrange formulae to make any of the variables the subject. This is called changing the subject of the formula. It may also be called solving...
[21528|p786] A function is a rule for changing one variable into another.
[21529|p786] Functions are written using notation of  $\mathrm{f}\left( x\right)  = x + 2$  .
[21530|p786] You can use a flow diagram to represent the steps in a function.
[21531|p786] A composite function is a function of a function. The order of a composite function is important  $\operatorname{fg}(x)$  means do g first then f.
[21532|p786] An inverse function is function that undoes the original function. It is the reverse of the function.
[21533|p786|T1] Are you able to ...?
[21534|p786] set up your own equations and use them to solve worded problems
[21535|p786|T1] change the subject of formula
[21536|p786] set up and rearrange more complicated formulae such as those that contain squares, square roots or where the subject appears in more than one term
[21537|p786] read, understand and use function notation to describe simple functions
[21538|p786] form composite functions such as  $\operatorname {gf}(x)$  and  $\operatorname {ff}(x)$
[21539|p786] find the inverse of a function using a flow diagram
[21540|p786] find the inverse of a function by reversing the mapping.
[21541|p786] #
[21542|p786] #

[21610|p789] - use the sum and difference of vectors to express them in terms of coplanar vectors
[21611|p789] use position vectors.
