[21649|p791|T1] 23.1 Simple plane transformations
[21650|p791] Transformation means change. In mathematics, a transformation is a change in the position or size of an object (or point). In this section you will de...
[21651|p791] - reflection (a flip or mirror image)
[21652|p791] rotation (a turn)
[21653|p791] translation (a slide movement)
[21654|p791] enlargement (making the object larger or smaller).
[21655|p791] REFLECTION
[21656|p791] BEELECTION
[21657|p791] B.  ${I}_{A}{I}_{L}{I}_{B}$
[21658|p791] TnRnNnS LnATnRnN
[21661|p791] A transformation produces an image of the original object in a new position or at a different size. A point,  $P$ , on the object is labelled as  $P'$...
[21662|p791] Reflections, rotations and translations change the position of an object, but they do not change its size. So, the object and its image are congruent....
[21663|p791] When you enlarge an object, you change its size. The object and its image are similar. In other words, the lengths of corresponding sides on the image...
[21664|p791|T1] Reflection
[21665|p791] A reflection is a mirror image of the shape. The line of reflection is called the mirror line. Corresponding points on the object and the image are th...
[21666|p791|T1] LINK
[21667|p791] Photographers need to think about reflections, rotations and enlargements when taking and processing photographs. The combination of symmetries in a p...
[21669|p791|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[21670|p791] You learnt about congruency and similarity in Chapter 11 and you dealt with lines of symmetry (mirror lines) in Chapter 19. You will use these concept...
[21673|p792] To fully define a reflection, you need to give the equation of the mirror line.
[21674|p792|T1] Properties of reflection
[21675|p792] A point and its image are equidistant from the mirror line  $(m)$  after reflection about the line  $m$
[21676|p792] The mirror line bisects the line joining a point and its image at right angles.
[21677|p792] A line segment and its image are equal in length.  $AB = A'B'$
[21678|p792] A line and its image are equally inclined to the mirror line. angle  $AOM =$  angle  $A^{\prime}OM$
[21679|p792] - Points on the mirror line are their own images and are invariant.
[21680|p792] Under reflection, a figure and its image are congruent.
[21687|p792|T1] TIP
[21688|p792] Note that we usually draw the mirror line as a dashed line.
[21689|p792|T1] TIP
[21690|p792] You need  $^ \text{加}$  o be able to work with reflections in horizontal and vertical lines only.
[21691|p792|T1] TIP
[21692|p792] Invariant means a point, or a line, remains unchanged in its position and size.
[21693|p793|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 1
[21694|p793] Reflect triangle ABC about the mirror line.
[21696|p793|T1] Answer
[21698|p793] In the diagram,  $A$  is 1 unit from the mirror line, so its image  $A^{\prime}$  is also 1 unit from the mirror line. Point  $B$  is 2 units from the...
[21699|p793] The reflection of a straight line is a straight line. So, to obtain the reflection of triangle ABC, join  $A^\prime$  to  $B^{\prime}$ $B^{\prime}$  t...
[21700|p793|T1] TIP
[21701|p793] When the mirror line is one of the grid lines it is simple to reflect any point. You count the squares from the point to the mirror line and the refle...
[21702|p793|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[21703|p793] A shape and its reflection are shown on the grid.
[21704|p793] a Draw the mirror line.
[21705|p793] b What is the equation of the mirror line?
[21707|p793|T1] Answers
[21709|p793] a The mirror line must be the same distance from corresponding points on A and A'.
[21710|p793] b The mirror line is parallel to the y-axis. The  $x$ -value of any point on it is 4, so the equation of the line is  $x = 4$ .
[21711|p793|T1] TIP
[21712|p793] The mirror line is the perpendicular bisector of the line joining any point and its image.
[21713|p794|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[21714|p794] Shape A is the object.
[21715|p794] Reflect shape A in the y-axis. Label the image B.
[21716|p794] b Reflect shape A and shape B in the x-axis. Label the images A' and B' respectively.

[21720|p794] a The  $y$  -axis  $(x = 0)$  is the mirror line.
[21721|p794] b The  $x$  -axis  $(y = 0)$  is the mirror line.

[21748|p795|T1] Rotation
[21749|p795] A rotation is a turn around a fixed point. Rotation occurs when an object is turned around a given point. Rotation can be clockwise or anti-clockwise....
[21750|p795] In this diagram, the object has been rotated  $90^{\circ}$  clockwise about the centre of rotation (a vertex of the object).
[21752|p796|T1] Properties of rotation
[21753|p796] A rotation through  $180^{\circ}$  is a half turn; a rotation through  $90^{\circ}$  is a quarter turn.
[21754|p796] A point and its image are equidistant from the centre of rotation.
[21755|p796] Each point of an object moves along the arc of a circle whose centre is the centre of rotation. All the circles are concentric:
[21757|p796] Only the centre of rotation is invariant.
[21758|p796] The object and the image are congruent after rotation.
[21760|p796] The perpendicular bisector of a line joining a point and its image passes through the centre of rotation.
[21762|p796] A line segment and its image are equal in length.
[21764|p796|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[21765|p796] You dealt with rotation when you studied rotational symmetry in Chapter 19.
[21767|p797] To describe a rotation you need to give:
[21768|p797] the centre of rotation
[21769|p797] the amount of turn  $(90^{\circ},180^{\circ}$  or  $270^{\circ}$
[21770|p797] the direction of the turn (clockwise or anti-clockwise).
[21771|p797] You can use thin paper or tracing paper to help you with rotations:
[21772|p797] 1 Trace the shape and label the vertices.
[21773|p797] 2 Place the tracing over the object.
[21774|p797] 3 Use the point of a pair of compasses or pen to hold the paper at the point (centre) of rotation.
[21775|p797] 4 Turn the paper through the given turn.
[21776|p797] 5 The new position of the shape is the image.
[21777|p797|T1] TIP
[21778|p797] The centre of rotation will normally be the origin (0, 0), a vertex of the shape or the midpoint of a side of the shape. The amount of turn will norma...
[21779|p797|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[21780|p797] Rotate this shape  $90^{\circ}$  clockwise about:
[21781|p797] a the origin (label the image  $A'^{'}B'^{'}C'^{'}D'^{'}$
[21782|p797] b point  $A$  (label the image  $A^{\prime \prime}B^{\prime \prime}C^{\prime \prime}D^{\prime \prime}$
[21784|p797|T1] Answers
[21786|p798|T1] Exercise 23.2
[21787|p798] 1 Copy the diagrams in parts (a) to (c).
[21788|p798] Draw the images of the given triangle under the rotations described.
[21790|p798] Centre of rotation (0, 0); angle of rotation  $90^{\circ}$  anti-clockwise.
[21792|p798] Centre of rotation (3, 1); angle of rotation  $180^{\circ}$ . (Note that (3, 1) is the midpoint of  $AB$ .)
[21794|p798] Centre of rotation  $(-1,0)$ ; angle of rotation  $180^{\circ}$ .
[21795|p798] 2 Shapes A to E and their images are shown on the grid. For each shape, fully describe each rotation.
[21797|p798] 3 Fully describe the rotation that maps triangle  $ABC$  onto triangle  $A'B'C'$  in each case.
[21801|p798|T1] TIP
[21802|p798] To fully describe a rotation, you must give the centre of rotation as well as the angle and direction of the rotation.

[21806|p799] Is it possible for Kofi to rotate all the furniture through point  $(0,0)$  by the following amounts and for the furniture still to fit into the room?
[21807|p799] a  $90^{\circ}$  clockwise
[21808|p799] b  $90^{\circ}$  anti-clockwise
[21809|p799] c  $180^{\circ}$  clockwise
[21810|p799|T1] REFLECTION
[21811|p799|T1] Identifying the reasons for mistakes
[21812|p799] Research shows that mistakes are often related to misconceptions or misunderstanding and that simply finding and correcting mistakes does not help to ...
[21813|p799] Identify any mistakes you made in this exercise.
[21814|p799] - Analyse why you made these mistakes. Decide if you were careless or whether you misunderstood any of the concepts.
[21815|p799] - Suggest one thing you will do so that you don't make similar mistakes in the future.
[21816|p799|T1] Translation
[21817|p799] A translation, or slide, is the movement of an object over a specified distance along a line. The object is not twisted or turned. The movement is ind...
[21818|p800] You can describe a translation using a column vector:  $\binom{x}{y}$ . This means a movement of  $x$  units in the  $x$ -direction (left or right) an...
[21819|p800] In this diagram, the triangle T is translated to five positions. Each translation is described below the diagram:
[21821|p800|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[21822|p800] You will deal with vectors in more detail later in this chapter.
[21823|p800] Position 1  $\left( \begin{array}{l}7\\ 0 \end{array} \right)$
[21824|p800] Position 2  $\begin{array}{r}\left( \begin{array}{l}0\\ 4 \end{array} \right) \end{array}$
[21825|p800] Position 3  $\left( \begin{array}{l} - 7\\ 0 \end{array} \right)$
[21826|p800] Position 4  $\left( \begin{array}{l}0\\ -8 \end{array} \right)$
[21827|p800] Position 5  $\binom{7}{-8}$
[21828|p800|T1] Properties of translation
[21829|p800] A translation moves every point in an object the same distance in the same direction, so you can describe the translation of the whole object by descr...
[21830|p800] To specify the translation, give both the distance and direction of the translation using a column vector  $\binom{x}{y}$ .
[21831|p800] No part of the object is invariant.
[21832|p800] The object and the image are congruent.
[21833|p800|T1] TIP
[21834|p800] Be careful when writing column vectors. There is no dividing line, so they should not look like fractions.
[21835|p800] Write  $\binom{3}{8}$  rather
[21836|p800] than  $\left(\frac{3}{8}\right)$  they mean different things.

[21855|p801] The phrase 'under the translation  $\binom{2}{-3}$
[21856|p801] means the same as after translating
[21857|p801] using the vector  $\binom{2}{-3}$
[21858|p801] 4 On squared paper, draw  $x$ - and  $y$ -axes and mark the points  $A(3,5)$ ,  $B(2,1)$  and  $C(-1,4)$ .

[21862|p802] 6 A rectangle  $MNOP$  with vertices  $M(1,6),N(6,6),O(6,3)$  and  $P(1,3)$  is transformed by the translation  $\binom{-3}{2}$  to produce rectangle ...
[21863|p802] a Represent this translation accurately on a set of axes.
[21864|p802] b Give the coordinates of the vertices of the image.
[21865|p802|T1] Enlargement
[21866|p802] When you enlarge a shape, you make it bigger (or smaller). In an enlargement the lengths of sides on the object are multiplied by a constant scale fac...
[21867|p802] $$
\text {S c a l e} = \frac {\text {i m a g e} \text {l e n g t h}}{\text {o r i g i n a l} \text {l e n g t h}}
$$
[21868|p802] If the scale factor is given, you can find the lengths of corresponding sides by multiplication.
[21869|p802] This diagram shows a square which has been enlarged by a scale factor of 1.5.
[21870|p802] This means that  $\frac{\text{side } B}{\text{side } A} = 1.5$ .
[21872|p802] When an object is enlarged from a fixed point, it has a centre of enlargement. The centre of enlargement determines the position of the image. Lines d...
[21873|p802] You can determine the scale factor by comparing any two corresponding sides, for example:
[21874|p802] $$
\frac {A ^ {\prime} B ^ {\prime}}{A B} = \frac {2}{1} = 2,
$$
[21875|p802] or by comparing the distances of two corresponding vertices from the origin, for example:
[21876|p802] $$
\frac {O C ^ {\prime}}{O C} = 2
$$
[21878|p802|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[21879|p802] 'Scale factor' was introduced in Chapter 11. It is the multiplier that tells you how much one shape is larger than another.
[21880|p802|T1] LINK
[21881|p802] When you pinch an image on a phone screen to make it bigger you are transforming the image by enlargement.
[21882|p803|T1] Properties of enlargement
[21883|p803] The centre of enlargement can be anywhere (inside the object, outside the object or on a vertex or line).
[21884|p803] - A scale factor greater than 1 enlarges the object whilst a scale factor between 0 and 1 reduces the size of the object, although this is still descr...
[21885|p803] An object and its image are similar (not congruent) with sides in the ratio  $1:k$  where  $k$  is the scale factor.
[21886|p803] - Angles of the object are invariant.
[21887|p803|T1] TIP
[21888|p803] Remember, similar shapes are the same shape but not the same size. Congruent shapes are the same size.
[21889|p803|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[21890|p803] The figure shows quadrilateral ABCD and its image  $A'B'C'D'$  under an enlargement. Find the centre of enlargement and the scale factor.
[21893|p803|T1] Answer
[21894|p803] Join the point A and its image A'.
[21895|p803] Extend  $AA^{\prime}$  in both directions. Similarly, draw and extend  $BB^{\prime}$ $CC^{\prime}$  and  $DD^{\prime}$
[21896|p803] The point of intersection of these lines is the centre of enlargement,  $O$
[21897|p803] $$
\begin{array}{l} O A = 2 5 \mathrm {m m} \\ O A ^ {\prime} = 5 0 \mathrm {m m} \\ \end{array}
$$
[21898|p803] Scale factor  $= \frac{50}{25} = 2$
[21900|p803] Measure OA and OA'.
[21901|p803] OA' is twice as long as OA.
[21902|p803|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[21903|p803] Draw the image of rectangle ABCD with  $o$  as the centre of enlargement and a scale factor of 2.
[21905|p804|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6 CONTINUED
[21906|p804|T1] Answer
[21907|p804] Join OA. Continue (produce) the line beyond A.
[21908|p804] Measure OA.
[21909|p804] Multiply the length of  $OA$  by 2.
[21910|p804] Mark the position of  $A^\prime$  on the produced line so that  $OA^{\prime} = 2OA$
[21911|p804] Repeat for the other vertices.
[21912|p804] Join  $A'B'C'D'$ .
[21914|p804|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[21915|p804] Draw  $A'B'C'D'$ , the image of ABCD under an enlargement by a scale factor of  $\frac{1}{3}$  through the origin.
[21917|p804|T1] Answer
[21918|p804] A scale factor of  $\frac{1}{3}$  means the image will be smaller than the object.
[21919|p804] Determine the coordinates of each vertex on the image. You can do this by multiplying the  $(x, y)$  coordinates of the vertices on the object by  $\f...
[21920|p804] $$
A = (1 2, 1 5), \text {s o} A ^ {\prime} = (4, 5)
$$
[21921|p804] $$
B = (9, 6), \text {s o} B ^ {\prime} = (3, 2)
$$
[21922|p804] $$
C = (1 8, 6), \text {s o} C ^ {\prime} = (6, 2)
$$
[21923|p804] $$
D = (2 1, 9), \text {s o} D ^ {\prime} = (7, 3)
$$
[21924|p804] Plot the point and draw and label the enlargement.
[21925|p804] continued...
[21926|p804|T1] TIP
[21927|p804] You can also measure the length of the line from the origin to each vertex on the object and divide those lengths by 3 to determine the position of ea...

[21966|p809|T1] 23.2 Further transformations
[21967|p809] In addition to the transformations you have already dealt with, you need to be able to reflect an object through any line, rotate an object about any ...
[21968|p809|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[21969|p809] Reflect shape A in the line  $y = x$ .
[21971|p810|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8 CONTINUED
[21972|p810|T1] Answer
[21973|p810] Draw the line  $y = x$ .
[21974|p810] Apply the rules you know for reflecting shapes to draw the image  $A'$ .
[21976|p810|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 9
[21977|p810] Sketch triangle A with vertices at  $(1,1)$ ,  $(5,1)$  and  $(5,4)$ . Rotate this shape  $180^{\circ}$  about the point  $(5,5)$ .
[21978|p810|T1] Answer
[21979|p810] Plot the points and join them to draw triangle A.
[21980|p810] Mark the centre of rotation.
[21981|p810] Draw the image and label it  $A^{\prime}$
[21983|p811|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 10
[21984|p811] Enlarge rectangle ABCD by a scale factor of -2 with the origin as a centre of enlargement.
[21985|p811|T1] Answer
[21986|p811] Multiply each set of coordinates by  $-2$
[21987|p811] A(1,4), so A'(-2, -8)
[21988|p811] B(3,4), so B'(-6, -8)
[21989|p811] C(3,1), so  $C^{\prime}(-6, - 2)$
[21990|p811] D(1,1), so D'(-2, -2)
[21991|p811] Plot the points.
[21992|p811] Make sure you label them correctly.
[21994|p811|T1] TIP
[21995|p811] Drawing in the rays from each vertex allows you to check the points on the image are in line with the corresponding ones on the object.
[21996|p811] If a point and its image are on opposite sides of the centre of enlargement, then the scale factor is negative.
[21997|p811|T1] Combining transformations
[21998|p811] You've already seen that an object can undergo a single transformation to map it to an image. An object can also undergo two transformations in succes...
[21999|p811] The following capital letters are conventionally used to represent different transformations:
[22000|p811] M Reflection (remember the M is for mirror!)
[22001|p811] R Rotation
[22002|p811] T Translation
[22003|p811] E Enlargement
[22004|p812|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 11
[22005|p812] For the shape P shown in the diagram, let T be the translation  $\binom{2}{1}$  and let M be the reflection in the y-axis.
[22007|p812] a Draw the image  $\mathsf{P}^{\prime}$  after the transformation MT(P).
[22008|p812] b Draw the image P" after the transformation TM(P).
[22009|p812] c What single transformation maps  $\mathsf{P}'$  onto  $\mathsf{P}''$ ?
[22010|p812|T1] Answer
[22011|p812] a MT(P) means do T first then do M.
[22012|p812] Use a pencil. Do the first transformation and (faintly) draw the shape. Do the second transformation, draw the image.
[22013|p812] Label it correctly.
[22015|p812] b TM(P) means do M first then do T.
[22016|p812] Use a pencil. Do the first transformation and (faintly) draw the shape. Do the second transformation, draw the image.
[22017|p812] Label it correctly.
[22019|p812] c P' can be mapped to P" by the translation  $\binom{4}{0}$ .

[22053|p817|T1] 23.3 Vectors
[22054|p817|T1] LINK
[22055|p817] The word 'vector' means carrier. In a mathematical context, it is about picking an object up and translating it. In a biological context, animals (inc...
[22056|p817] Some quantities are best described by giving both a magnitude (size) and a direction. For example, a wind speed of  $35\mathrm{km / h}$  from the sout...
[22057|p817] Other quantities such as time, temperature, speed, mass and area can be described by only giving their magnitude (they don't have a direction). These ...
[22058|p817] A vector is an ordered pair of numbers that you can use to describe a translation. The ordered pair gives both magnitude and direction.
[22059|p817|T1] Vector notation
[22060|p817] Vectors can be represented by a directed line segment as shown in the diagrams. Note that the notation is either a small letter with a wavy line benea...
[22062|p817] Vectors can also be represented by a named line such as  $AB$ . In such cases, the vector is denoted by  $\overrightarrow{AB}$ . The order of letters ...
[22063|p817|T1] Writing vectors as number pairs
[22064|p817] Vectors can also be written as a column vector using number pair notation. Look at line  $PQ$  in the diagram.
[22066|p818] This line represents the translation of  $P$  to  $Q$ . The translation is two units in the positive  $x$ -direction and four units in the positive  $...
[22067|p818] You can therefore write  $\overrightarrow{PQ} = \binom{2}{4}$ .
[22068|p818|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 12
[22069|p818] Express  $\overrightarrow{RS}$  and  $\overrightarrow{LM}$  as column vectors.
[22071|p818] Answer
[22072|p818] $$
\overrightarrow {R S} = \binom {3} {4}
$$
[22073|p818] Translation from  $R$  to  $S$  is three units right and four up.
[22074|p818] $$
\overrightarrow {L M} = \binom {3} {- 2}
$$
[22075|p818] Translation from  $L$  to  $M$  is three units right and two down.
[22076|p819|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 13
[22077|p819] Draw the column vectors  $\binom{1}{3}$  and  $\binom{-2}{-4}$ .
[22079|p819] Start at any point, for example A, and move one right and three up to B. Join the points and indicate the direction using an arrow.
[22080|p819] Start at any point, for example  $T$ , and move two left and then four down to S. Join the points and indicate the direction using an arrow.
[22081|p819|T1] Using vectors to describe a translation
[22082|p819] You have already seen that column vectors can be used to describe translations.
[22083|p819] In this diagram, triangle  $ABC$  is translated to triangle  $A'B'C'$ . All points on the object have moved two units to the right and three units up,...
[22085|p819|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 14
[22086|p819] Square R is translated to square S. Find the column vector for the translation.
[22088|p819|T1] Answer
[22089|p819] The column vector is  $\binom{2}{3}$ .
[22090|p819] Use one vertex of the object and the same vertex in its image to work out the translation.
[22091|p820|T1] Exercise 23.6
[22092|p820] 1 Write a column vector for each of the vectors shown on the diagram.
[22094|p820] 2 Represent these vectors on squared paper.
[22095|p820] a AB = (5)
[22096|p820] b CD = (2)
[22097|p820] PQ
[22098|p820] d  $\overrightarrow{RS} = \binom{0}{3}$
[22099|p820] $\overrightarrow{TU} = \binom {-2}{0}$
[22100|p820] $\overrightarrow{MN} = \binom{-2}{-4}$
[22101|p820] 9  $\overrightarrow{KL} = \binom{0}{-5}$
[22102|p820] h  $\overrightarrow{VW} = \binom{-3}{-3}$
[22103|p820] i EF=
[22104|p820] j  $\overrightarrow{JL} = \binom{-3}{-2}$
[22105|p820] k MP
[22106|p820] $\overrightarrow{QT} = \binom {-4}{2}$
[22107|p820] 3 In the diagram,  $ABCD$  is a parallelogram.
[22108|p820] a Write column vectors for the following:
[22109|p820] AB and DC
[22110|p820] BC and AD.
[22111|p820] b What can you say about the two pairs of vectors?
[22113|p820] 4 In the diagrams below, shapes A, B, C, D, E and F are mapped onto images A', B', C', D', E' and F' by translation. Find the column vector for the tr...
[22120|p821|T1] Equal vectors
[22121|p821] Equal vectors have the same size (magnitude) and direction. As vectors are usually independent of position, they can start at any point. The same vect...
[22122|p821] In the diagram,  $\overrightarrow{AB}, \overrightarrow{CD}, \overrightarrow{XY}, \overrightarrow{LM}$  and  $\overrightarrow{RS}$  are equal vectors.
[22124|p821] $$
\overrightarrow {A B} = \overrightarrow {C D} = \overrightarrow {X Y} = \overrightarrow {L M} = \overrightarrow {R S} = \binom {1} {2}
$$
[22125|p821] When equal vectors share a common point, for example when  $\overrightarrow{AB} = \overrightarrow{BC}$  you can deduce that that the points  $A, B$  a...
[22126|p822|T1] Multiplying a vector by a scalar
[22127|p822] Look at the diagram. Vector  $\overrightarrow{AC}$  is twice as long as vector  $\overrightarrow{AB}$ .
[22128|p822] You can say:
[22129|p822] $$
\overrightarrow {A C} = 2 \overrightarrow {A B} = 2 \binom {2} {1} = \binom {4} {2}.
$$
[22131|p822] Here is another example.
[22132|p822] A force, represented by vector  $\mathbf{f}$ , is needed to move a  $1\mathrm{kg}$  concrete block.
[22133|p822] If you want to move a  $2\mathrm{kg}$  concrete block, you need to apply twice the force. In other words, you would need to apply  $\mathbf{f} + \math...
[22134|p822] A force of 2f has the same direction as f, but it has twice its magnitude.
[22136|p822] Multiplying any vector  $\binom{x}{y}$  by a scalar  $k$ , gives  $k\binom{x}{y} = \binom{kx}{ky}$ .
[22137|p822] Vector a multiplied by 2 is the vector 2a. Vector 2a is twice as long as vector a, but they have the same direction. In other words, they are either p...
[22138|p822] $$
\text {I f} \mathbf {a} = \binom {3} {2} \text {t h e n} 2 \mathbf {a} = 2 \binom {3} {2} = \binom {6} {4}.
$$
[22139|p822] Vector a multiplied by -1 is the vector -a, which is opposite in direction to a, but with the same magnitude as a.
[22140|p822|T1] TIP
[22141|p822] Remember a scalar is basically just a number. It has magnitude but no direction.
[22142|p823|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 15
[22143|p823] $$
\text {I f} u = \binom {8} {- 4}, \text {f i n d} \frac {1}{4} u.
$$
[22144|p823] Answer
[22145|p823] $$
\frac {1}{4} u = \frac {1}{4} \left( \begin{array}{l} 8 \\ - 4 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{l l} \frac {1}{4} \times & 8 \\ \frac {1}...
[22146|p823|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 16
[22147|p823] $$
\text {I f} \mathbf {v} = \binom {- 3} {2}, \text {f i n d} - 5 \mathbf {v}.
$$
[22148|p823] Answer
[22149|p823] $$
- 5 v = - 5 \binom {- 3} {2} = \binom {- 5 \times - 3} {- 5 \times 2} = \binom {1 5} {- 1 0}
$$
[22150|p823|T1] TIP
[22151|p823] When  $k$  is positive, ka is in the same direction as a and k times as long.When k is negative, then ka is opposite in direction to a but still k tim...

[22169|p823|T1] TIP
[22170|p823] Given that  $\overrightarrow{AJ} = 3\overrightarrow{AD}$  and  $A$  is common to both vectors, points  $A, D$  and  $J$  are collinear.
[22171|p824] 3 If  $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ -4 \end{pmatrix}$  and  $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$  calculate:
[22172|p824] a -2a
[22173|p824] b 3b
[22174|p824] 3 2b

[22180|p824|T1] Adding vectors
[22181|p824] In the diagram, point  $A$  is translated to point  $B$  and then translated again to end up at point  $C$ . However, if you translated the point dire...
[22183|p824] You can represent each translation as a column vector:
[22184|p824] $$
\overrightarrow {A B} = \binom {3} {1}, \quad \overrightarrow {B C} = \binom {- 2} {2}, \quad \overrightarrow {A C} = \binom {1} {3}
$$
[22185|p824] You know that  $\overrightarrow{AB} + \overrightarrow{BC} = \overrightarrow{AC}$ , so:
[22186|p824] $$
\binom {3} {1} + \binom {- 2} {2} = \binom {1} {3}
$$
[22187|p824] So, to add the vectors, you add the corresponding  $x$ - and  $y$ -coordinates:
[22188|p824] $$
\binom {x _ {1}} {y _ {1}} + \binom {x _ {2}} {y _ {2}} = \binom {x _ {1} + x _ {2}} {y _ {1} + y _ {2}}
$$
[22189|p824] This is called the 'nose to tail' method or the triangle law.
[22190|p824|T1] LINK
[22191|p824] Airline pilots need to consider vectors when landing in a crosswind. The plane can be controlled to move relative to the air, but the air is often als...
[22192|p825|T1] Subtracting vectors
[22193|p825] Think again about the three vectors:
[22194|p825] $$
\overrightarrow {A B} = \binom {3} {1}, \quad \overrightarrow {B C} = \binom {- 2} {2}, \quad \overrightarrow {A C} = \binom {1} {3}
$$
[22195|p825] Subtracting a vector is the same as adding its negative, so:
[22196|p825] $$
\overrightarrow {A C} - \overrightarrow {A B} = \overrightarrow {A C} + (- \overrightarrow {A B})
$$
[22197|p825] The diagram shows the result of adding  $\overrightarrow{AC}$  and  $-\overrightarrow{AB}$  'nose to tail'. This shows that vector  $\overrightarrow{A...
[22198|p825] $$
\mathrm {S o}, \overrightarrow {A C} - \overrightarrow {A B} = \overrightarrow {B C}
$$
[22199|p825] $$
\binom {1} {3} - \binom {3} {1} = \binom {- 2} {2}
$$
[22201|p825] To subtract the vectors, you subtract the corresponding  $x$ - and  $y$ -coordinates:
[22202|p825] $$
\binom {x _ {1}} {y _ {1}} - \binom {x _ {2}} {y _ {2}} = \binom {x _ {1}} {y _ {1}} + \binom {- x _ {2}} {- y _ {2}} = \binom {x _ {1} - x _ {2}} ...
[22203|p825|T1] TIP
[22204|p825] You could also use the fact that vector  $-\overrightarrow{AB}$  is the same size as  $\overrightarrow{AB}$  but in the opposite direction, so  $-\ove...
[22205|p825] This means that  $\overrightarrow{AC} - \overrightarrow{AB} = \overrightarrow{AC} + \overrightarrow{BA}$
[22206|p825] If you rearrange the vectors, you can apply the nose to tail rule method and add them:
[22207|p825] $$
\overrightarrow {A C} - \overrightarrow {A B} = \overrightarrow {B A} + \overrightarrow {A C} = \overrightarrow {B C}
$$
[22208|p826|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 17

[22210|p826] Find in the figure directed line segments equal to the following:
[22211|p826] a AE+EC

[22216|p826] a AE+EC=AC
[22217|p826] b DB+BE=DE
[22218|p826] (If you travel from  $D$  to  $B$  and then from  $B$  to  $E$ , you have gone back on yourself and ended up at  $E$ , which is the same as travelling...
[22219|p826] $\overrightarrow{AD} + \overrightarrow{DB} + \overrightarrow{BC} = \overrightarrow{AC}$
[22220|p826] $$
(\overrightarrow {A D} + \overrightarrow {D B} = \overrightarrow {A B} \text {a n d} \overrightarrow {A B} + \overrightarrow {B C} = \overrightarro...
[22221|p826] $$
\therefore \overrightarrow {A D} + \overrightarrow {D B} + \overrightarrow {B C} = \overrightarrow {A C})
$$
[22222|p826] $\overrightarrow{CB} + \overrightarrow{BE} + \overrightarrow{EA} + \overrightarrow{AD} = \overrightarrow{CE} + \overrightarrow{EA} + \overrightarrow{A...
[22224|p826|T1] TIP
[22225|p826] Any section of a line joining two points is called a line segment.
[22226|p826|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 18
[22227|p826] If  $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$  and  $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}$  find the column vectors equal to:
[22228|p826] a a+b
[22229|p826] b a-b
[22230|p826] c 3a

[22232|p826] e 2a-3b

[22236|p826] 3a=3（3）=（3×3）=（9） 4 3x4 12
[22237|p826] d a+4b=（3）+4（2）=（3+8）=（11）
[22238|p826] 2a-3b=2（3）-3（2）-（6）-（6）=（0） 11

[22257|p827] But  $\binom{6}{2}=2\binom{3}{1}$ , so  $\overrightarrow{PQ}=2\overrightarrow{QR}$  and  $\overrightarrow{PQ}$  is parallel to  $\overrightarrow{QR}$ ...
[22258|p827] Point  $Q$  is common to  $\overrightarrow{PQ}$  and  $\overrightarrow{QR}$ , so  $P, Q$  and  $R$  are collinear.

[22294|p829|T1] SELF ASSESSMENT
[22295|p829] Develop a set of success criteria to assess your understanding of vectors.
[22296|p829] 1 Draw a table like this one:
[22297|p829] [Table Row] <tr><td>Success criteria</td><td>Evidence of success</td><td>Improvements</td></tr>
[22298|p829] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr>
[22299|p829] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr>
[22300|p829] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr>
[22301|p829] 2 Look back at the learning intentions at the start of this chapter. Use these to develop a list of criteria that you can use to decide whether you ha...
[22302|p829] I can write a column vector to describe a translation.
[22303|p829] 3 Once you have your list, check your work against the success criteria.
[22304|p829] - Place a tick (✓) in the second column if you can find evidence that you have met each one. (You are looking for how your work shows you have achieve...
[22305|p829] If you cannot find evidence, write down what you can do to improve in that particular area.
[22306|p829] 4 Make any improvements that you need to over the next few days and then reassess your work using the same criteria.
[22307|p829|T1] The magnitude of a vector
[22308|p829] The magnitude of a vector is its length. You use the notation  $|AB|$  or  $|a|$  to write the magnitude of a vector  $(AB)$ .
[22309|p829] You can use Pythagoras' theorem to calculate the magnitude of a vector.
[22310|p829] In general, if  $\overrightarrow{AB} = \binom{x}{y}$  then  $\left|\overrightarrow{AB}\right| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ .
[22311|p829|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 21
[22312|p829] Find the magnitude of the vector  $\overrightarrow{AB} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ -4 \end{pmatrix}$ .
[22313|p829] Answer
[22315|p829] Draw AB as the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle.
[22316|p829] $$
A B ^ {2} = 3 ^ {2} + 4 ^ {2}
$$
[22317|p829] (Pythagoras' theorem)
[22318|p829] $$
A B ^ {2} = 9 + 1 6
$$
[22319|p829] $$
A B ^ {2} = 2 5
$$
[22320|p829] $$
A B = 5
$$
[22321|p829] $$
\therefore | \overrightarrow {A B} | = 5 \text {u n i t s}
$$
[22322|p829|T1] TIP
[22323|p829] Remember: success criteria are sometimes called 'what I'm looking for'.
[22324|p829|T1] TIP
[22325|p829] The magnitude of a vector is sometimes called the modulus.
[22326|p830|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 22
[22327|p830] $$
\text {I f} a = \binom {- 5} {1 2} \text {f i n d} | a |.
$$
[22328|p830] Answer
[22329|p830] $$
\begin{array}{l} | a | = \sqrt {(- 5) ^ {2} + (1 2) ^ {2}} \\ = \sqrt {1 6 9} \\ = 1 3 \\ \end{array}
$$
[22330|p830|T1] Position vectors
[22331|p830] A vector that starts from the origin  $(O)$  is called a position vector.
[22332|p830] In this diagram, point  $A$  has the position vector  $\overrightarrow{OA}$  or a.
[22333|p830] If  $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$  then the coordinates of point  $A$  will be (3, 2).
[22334|p830] Because the coordinates of the point  $A$  are the same as the components of the column vector  $\binom{3}{2}$  you can use position
[22335|p830] vectors to find the magnitude of any vector.
[22337|p830|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 23
[22338|p830] The position vector of  $A$  is  $\binom{3}{2}$  and the
[22339|p830] position vector of  $B$  is  $\binom{-2}{4}$
[22340|p830] Find the vector 2AB.
[22341|p830] Answer
[22342|p830] $$
\overrightarrow {O A} = \binom {3} {2} \text {a n d} \overrightarrow {O B} = \binom {- 2} {4}
$$
[22343|p830] $$
\begin{array}{l} \overrightarrow {A B} = \overrightarrow {A O} + \overrightarrow {O B} = - \overrightarrow {O A} + \overrightarrow {O B} = \overrig...
[22344|p830] $$
\mathrm {S o}, 2 \overrightarrow {A B} = 2 \binom {- 5} {2} = \binom {- 1 0} {4}.
$$
[22345|p830] Alternative method:
[22346|p830] You could also find the column vector for  $\overrightarrow{AB}$  by counting the movements parallel to the  $x$ -axis followed by those parallel to t...
[22347|p830] Movement parallel to  $x$ -axis  $= -5$  units. Movement parallel to the  $y$ -axis  $= 2$  units.
[22348|p830] $$
\overrightarrow {A B} = \left( \begin{array}{c} - 5 \\ 2 \end{array} \right)
$$
[22350|p831|T1] TIP
[22351|p831] $\overrightarrow{AB} = \mathbf{b} - \mathbf{a}$  where a and b are the positive vectors of A and B.
[22353|p831|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 24
[22354|p831] If  $A$  is point  $(-1, -2)$  and  $B$  is  $(5, 6)$ , find  $|\overrightarrow{AB}|$ .
[22355|p831] Answer
[22356|p831] $$
\begin{array}{l} \overrightarrow {O A} = \left( \begin{array}{l} - 1 \\ - 2 \end{array} \right) \text {a n d} \overrightarrow {O B} = \left( \begin...

[22403|p833] 11 Line  $MN$  has endpoints  $M(3,2)$  and  $N(7,14)$ . What are the coordinates of point  $P$ , which divides  $MN$  in the ratio  $1:3$ ?
[22404|p833] 12 In this triangle,  $M$  is the midpoint of  $AB$  and the ratio  $ON:NA$  is  $1:2$ .
[22405|p833] Find in terms of a and b in its simplest form:
[22406|p833] AB b AM c ON
[22408|p833] 13 In this quadrilateral  $OABC$ ,  $AB$  is parallel to  $OC$  and the ratio  $OC$  to  $AB$  is  $2:3$ .  $\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}$  and  $...
[22409|p833] $N$  is the midpoint of  $OB$
[22410|p833] $M$  is a point on  $AB$  such that  $\overrightarrow{AM} = \frac{1}{3}\overrightarrow{AB}$ .
[22412|p833] a Find, in terms of a and b, in its simplest form:
[22413|p833] i
[22414|p833] AB
[22415|p833] ii
[22416|p833] AM
[22417|p833] III

[22419|p833] iv
[22420|p833] NC
[22421|p833] b Explain why the vectors  $\overrightarrow{MN}$  and  $\overrightarrow{NC}$  shows that  $M, N$  and  $C$  lie on a straight line.
[22422|p833|T1] DISCUSSION
[22423|p833|T1] Perpendicular vectors
[22424|p833] Work with a partner. You will need a ruler and squared paper.

[22427|p834|T1] SUMMARY
[22428|p834|T1] Do you know ...?
[22429|p834] A transformation involves a change in the position and/or size of a shape.
[22430|p834] A reflection is a mirror image, a rotation is a turn, a translation is a slide and an enlargement is an increase in size.
[22431|p834] To fully describe a reflection you need to give the equation of the mirror line.
[22432|p834] To fully describe a rotation you need to give the angle and centre of rotation.
[22433|p834] To describe a translation you can use a column vector  $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ .
[22434|p834] To describe an enlargement you need to give the scale factor and the centre of enlargement.
[22435|p834] A vector has both magnitude and direction. You can add and subtract vectors but you cannot multiply or divide vectors. You can multiply a vector by a ...
[22436|p834] The magnitude of a vector  $\left( \begin{array}{l}x\\ y \end{array} \right) = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$ . You write the magnitude as  $|\overline{XY}|$  or  ...
[22437|p834] A position vector is a vector that starts at the origin.
[22438|p834|T1] Are you able to ...?
[22439|p834] To reflect points and plane figures about horizontal and vertical lines,
[22440|p834] To rotate plane figures about the origin, vertices of the object and midpoints of the sides are
[22441|p834] translate shapes using a column vector
[22442|p834] to construct enlargements of simple shapes using the scale factor and centre of enlargement
[22443|p834] recognise and describe single transformations
[22444|p834] recognise and describe combined transformations
[22445|p834] add and subtract vectors and multiply vectors by a scalar
[22446|p834] calculate the magnitude of a vector
[22447|p834] use position vectors to find the magnitude of vectors.

[22541|p840] These outcomes can also be shown on a tree diagram:
[22543|p840] On a tree diagram the outcomes are written at the end of the branches.

[22564|p841|T1] 24.2 Calculating probability from tree diagrams
[22565|p841|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[22566|p841] For independent events  $P(A$  and then  $B) = P(A)\times P(B)$
[22567|p841] For mutually exclusive events  $P(A \text{ or } B) = P(A) + P(B)$ .
[22568|p841] Read through Chapter 8 again if you have forgotten this.
[22569|p841] Here is the tree diagram showing possible outcomes for throwing a dice and tossing a coin at the same time (H is used for head and T is used for tail)...
[22570|p841] This is the same diagram as the one at the start of Section 24.1, but now the probability of each outcome is written by the side of each branch.
[22572|p842|T1] LINK
[22573|p842] One particular kind of study of tiny particles is called quantum mechanics. This looks at the probability of finding particles in particular places at...
[22574|p842|T1] The probability of combined events on a tree diagram
[22575|p842] To find the probability of one particular combination of outcomes:
[22576|p842] - multiply the probabilities on consecutive branches, for example the probability of throwing a 5 and getting an H is  $\frac{1}{6} \times \frac{1}{2}...
[22577|p842] To find the probability when there is more than one favourable combination or when the events are mutually exclusive:
[22578|p842] - multiply the probabilities on consecutive branches
[22579|p842] - add the probabilities (of each favourable combination) obtained by multiplication, for example, throwing 1 or 2 and getting an H is
[22580|p842] $$
\left(\frac {1}{6} \times \frac {1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac {1}{6} \times \frac {1}{2}\right) = \frac {1}{1 2} + \frac {1}{1 2} = \frac {2}{1 2} = ...
[22581|p842] When you are interested only in specific probabilities, you can draw a tree diagram that only shows the favourable outcomes. For example, if you wante...
[22582|p842] $$
P (<   5 \text {a n d} H) = \frac {4}{6} \times \frac {1}{2} = \frac {1}{3}
$$
[22583|p842] Throw of Toss of the dice the coin
[22585|p842|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[22586|p842] You learnt in Chapter 8 that mutually exclusive events cannot both happen together.
[22587|p842|T1] TIP
[22588|p842] There are four numbers on a dice that are less than 5. As they are equally likely to occur, the probability of scoring
[22589|p842] $$
<   5 \text {i s} \frac {4}{6} = \frac {2}{3}.
$$
[22590|p842|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 2
[22591|p842] Two coins are tossed together. Draw a tree diagram to find the probability of getting:
[22592|p842] a two tails
[22593|p842] b one head and one tail.
[22594|p842|T1] Answers
[22596|p842] a  $P(TT) = P(T$  on 1st toss)  $\times P(T$  on 2nd toss)
[22597|p842] $$
= \frac {1}{2} \times \frac {1}{2} = \frac {1}{4}
$$
[22598|p842] b  $P(HT$  or  $TH) = P(HT) + P(TH)$
[22599|p842] $$
= \left(\frac {1}{2} \times \frac {1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac {1}{2} \times \frac {1}{2}\right) = \frac {1}{4} + \frac {1}{4} = \frac {1}{2}
$$
[22600|p843|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 3
[22601|p843] This tree diagram shows all possible combinations of male and female calves for a cow after three pregnancies.
[22602|p843] This assumes that each pregnancy produces one calf and that the outcomes, male or female, are equally likely. Find the probability that:
[22603|p843] a at least one calf is female
[22604|p843] b two of the calves are female
[22605|p843] c the first and last born calves are the same sex.
[22607|p843|T1] Answers
[22608|p843] a P(at least one female) = 7(1/2 × 1/2 × 1/2)
[22609|p843] $$
\begin{array}{l} = 7 \times \frac {1}{8} \\ = \frac {7}{8} \\ \end{array}
$$
[22610|p843] b P(two are female) = 3/8
[22611|p843] c  $P(\text{first and last same sex}) = \frac{4}{8} = \frac{1}{2}$
[22612|p843] All outcomes except MMM have at least one female.
[22613|p843] This makes seven outcomes. As each outcome is
[22614|p843] $\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2}$  you can simply multiply this by 7.
[22615|p843] There are three out of eight outcomes where there are two females.
[22616|p843] FFF, FMF, MFM and MMM have the first and last with the same sex. The probability for each combination is  $\frac{1}{8}$ , so you can add the favourabl...

[22674|p845|T1] 24.3 Calculating probability from Venn diagrams
[22675|p845] You used Venn diagrams to show the relationships between sets in Chapter 9. Now you are going to use Venn diagrams to solve probability problems.
[22676|p846] This Venn diagram shows the results of a survey in which people were asked whether they watch programme  $A$  or programme  $B$ . Study the diagram an...
[22678|p846] $\mathcal{E}$  means the universal set. In probability this is the sample space, or set of all possible outcomes. In this example the sample space is ...
[22679|p846] $\mathfrak{n}(A)$  means the number of elements in set  $A$
[22680|p846] $$
\mathrm {n} (A) = 4 0 + 3 0 = 7 0
$$
[22681|p846] $P(A)$  means the probability that an element is in set  $A$ . You can write this as the number of elements in set  $A$  as a fraction of the sample s...
[22682|p846] Remember to include the elements in the intersection in set  $A$ .
[22683|p846] $$
P (A) = \frac {7 0}{1 0 0} = \frac {7}{1 0} \text {o r} 0. 7 \quad .
$$
[22684|p846] $A \cap B$  is the intersection of sets  $A$  and  $B$ . It is the elements shared by  $A$  and  $B$ . You write the probability of the two events hap...
[22685|p846] $$
\mathrm {n} (A \cap B) = 3 0, \text {s o} P (A \cap B) = \frac {3 0}{1 0 0} = \frac {3}{1 0} \text {o r} 0. 3
$$
[22686|p846] $A \cup B$  is the union of sets  $A$  and  $B$ . It is the elements in both sets, with none repeated. You write the probability of either event  $A$ ...
[22687|p846] $$
\ln (A \cup B) = 4 0 + 3 0 + 2 0 = 9 0, \text {s o} P (A \cup B) = \frac {9 0}{1 0 0} = \frac {9}{1 0} \text {o r} 0. 9
$$
[22688|p846] When a question contains words like 'is not' or 'neither' it is a clue that you are looking for the complement of a set. For example, 'What is the pro...
[22689|p846|T1] TIP
[22690|p846] 1-  $P(A\cup B)$  is the same as  $P(A\cup B)'$  .The complement of  $A\cup B$
[22691|p847|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 4
[22692|p847] In a survey, 25 people were asked to say if they liked fruit and if they liked vegetables.
[22693|p847] 15 people said they liked vegetables and 18 said they liked fruit.
[22694|p847] Assuming that everyone surveyed liked fruit or vegetables or both, draw a Venn diagram and use it to work out the probability that a person chosen at ...
[22695|p847] a both fruit and vegetables
[22696|p847] b either fruit or vegetables
[22697|p847|T1] Answers
[22698|p847] Start by defining the sets and writing the information in set language. Use letters to make it quicker and easier to refer to the sets.
[22699|p847] $$
\mathcal {E} = \{\text {n u m b e r o f p e o l e s u r v e y e d} \}, n (\mathcal {E}) = 2 5
$$
[22700|p847] $$
F = \{\text {p e o p l e w h o l i k e f r u i t} \}, \text {s o} n (F) = 1 8
$$
[22701|p847] $$
V = \{\text {p e o p l e w h o l i k e v e g e t a b l e s} \}, \text {s o} n (V) = 1 5
$$
[22702|p847] $$
n (F) + n (V) = 1 8 + 1 5 = 3 3
$$
[22703|p847] But the total number of people surveyed was only 25.
[22704|p847] $33 - 25 = 8$  so 8 people must have said they liked both fruit and vegetables.
[22705|p847] $$
n (F \cap V) = 8
$$
[22706|p847] Once you've defined the sets, you can draw the diagram.
[22707|p847] You don't know the names of the people surveyed, so you have to work with the number of people in each set.
[22709|p847] a After you have drawn the diagram, calculate the probability.
[22710|p847] In words:
[22711|p847] $$
P (\text {P e r s o n l i k e s b o t h}) = \frac {\text {n u m b e r o f p e o l e w h o l i k e b o t h}}{\text {n u m b e r o f p e o l e s u r ...
[22712|p847] In set language:
[22713|p847] $$
P (F \text {a n d} V) = \frac {n (F \cap V)}{n (\ell)} = \frac {8}{2 5} = 0. 3 2
$$
[22714|p847] b  $P(F$  or  $V) = \frac{10}{25} +\frac{8}{25} +\frac{7}{25} = \frac{25}{25} = 1$
[22715|p847] This is the same as  $F \cup V$ .
[22716|p847|T1] MATHEMATICAL CONNECTIONS
[22717|p847] In Chapter 9 you saw that numbers in Venn diagrams can represent either the elements in a set or the number of elements in a set. In probability, you ...
[22718|p848|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 5
[22719|p848] In a survey, 30 people were asked whether they used the bus, metro or E-hailing providers for public transport. The survey found that 16 people use th...
[22720|p848] a Draw a Venn diagram to show the results.
[22721|p848] b How many of the people surveyed do not use any of three types of transport?
[22722|p848] c If a person was chosen at random, calculate:
[22723|p848] i P(bus and metro) ii P(bus only) iii P(not bus, metro or E-hail).
[22724|p848|T1] Answers
[22725|p848] a
[22727|p848] b This is the number of elements outside the three sets  $= 4$
[22728|p848] C P(B and M) = 4 2 15
[22729|p848] ii  $P(B\text{only}) = \frac{11}{30}$
[22730|p848] iii  $P(\text{not} B, M \text{or} E) = \frac{4}{30} = \frac{2}{15}$

[22800|p850|T1] SELF ASSESSMENT

[22807|p850|T1] TIP

[22809|p851|T1] 24.4 Conditional probability
[22810|p851] If the probability of an event depends on the outcome of a previous event then the probability is said to be conditional.
[22811|p851] For two events  $A$  and  $B$ ,  $P(B$  given that  $A$  has happened) refers to the conditional probability of  $B$  happening given that  $A$  has a...
[22812|p851] The way that you work out the conditional probability depends on whether the events are independent or not.
[22813|p851|T1] Independent events
[22814|p851] Imagine you roll two normal six-sided dice.
[22815|p851] The first dice lands on a 6. What is the probability of the second dice also landing on 6?
[22816|p851] These two events are independent. The score on the second dice is not affected by the outcome of the first.
[22817|p851] If two events  $A$  and  $B$  are independent, it is always true that
[22818|p851] $P(B$  given that  $A$  has happened)  $= P(B)$
[22819|p851] so in this case, the probability of getting a 6 with the second dice is  $\frac{1}{6}$ .
[22820|p851|T1] Dependent events
[22821|p851] If two events  $A$  and  $B$  are dependent, the first event does affect the probability of the second event.
[22822|p851] For example, suppose you have an apple, an orange and a banana and you choose two of the fruits at random. If you choose the apple first, you can only...
[22823|p851] To find the probability of  $B$  given that  $A$  has happened, use the rule:
[22824|p851] $$
P (B \text {g i v e n t h a t} A \text {h a s h a p p e n e d}) = \frac {P (A \text {a n d} B)}{P (A)}
$$
[22825|p851] When you deal with Venn diagrams, this rule can be written in set language as:
[22826|p851] $$
P (B \text {g i v e n t h a t} A \text {h a s h a p p e n e d}) = \frac {P (A \cap B)}{P (A)}
$$
[22827|p851] You can use tree diagrams and Venn diagrams to help you solve problems involving conditional probability.
[22828|p851|T1] TIP
[22829|p851] When you are using a tree diagram always check whether the probability of an event changes because of the outcome of a previous event. Questions invol...
[22830|p852|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 6
[22831|p852] A bag contains 21 balls. There are 12 blue balls and 9 green balls. Without looking, two balls are removed one after the other, without replacing them...
[22832|p852] a Draw a tree diagram to represent the situation.
[22833|p852] b Find the probability that:
[22834|p852] both balls are blue (BB)
[22835|p852] ii both balls are green (GG)
[22836|p852] one ball is green and the other is blue.
[22837|p852] c A third ball is taken at random. What is the probability that:
[22838|p852] i all three balls are blue?
[22839|p852] ii at least one of the balls is green?
[22840|p852|T1] Answers
[22841|p852] a
[22843|p852] This is an example of conditional probability. You cannot choose the same ball twice, so for the second set of branches there are only 20 balls left. ...
[22844|p852] 12 11 11 b i 21 20 35
[22845|p852] 9 8 6 ii P(GG) 21 20 35
[22846|p852] 12 9 12 18 35
[22847|p852] The blue and green can be chosen in either order.
[22848|p852] c
[22850|p852] You may find it helpful to add a third set of branches to the diagram, but, if you can see the pattern of the probabilities on the branches, you can j...
[22851|p852] $$
i P (B B B) = \frac {1 2}{2 1} \times \frac {1 1}{2 0} \times \frac {1 0}{1 9} = \frac {2 2}{1 3 3}
$$
[22852|p852] ii  $P(\text{at least one green}) = 1 - P(\text{all blue})$
[22853|p852] $$
= 1 - \frac {2 2}{1 3 3} = \frac {1 1 1}{1 3 3}
$$
[22854|p852] (Sometimes it is faster to work out the probabilities that you don't want and subtract the result from 1.)
[22855|p853|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 7
[22856|p853] In a group of 50 students, 36 students work on tablet computers, 20 work on laptops and 12 work on neither of these.
[22857|p853] A student is chosen at random. What is the probability that this student:
[22858|p853] a works on a tablet and a laptop computer?
[22859|p853] b works on at least one type of computer?
[22860|p853] c works on a tablet given that he or she works on a laptop?
[22861|p853] d does not work on a laptop, given that he or she works on a tablet?
[22862|p853|T1] Answers
[22863|p853] Start by identifying the sets and drawing a Venn diagram.
[22864|p853] $T =$  {students who work on tablets}  $n(T) = 36$
[22865|p853] $L =$  {students who work on laptops}  $n(L) = 20$
[22866|p853] $50 - 12 = 38$  so there are 38 students in  $T$  and  $L$  combined.
[22867|p853] $36 + 20 = 56$  , but there are only 38 students in  $T$  and L combined.
[22868|p853] $56 - 38 = 18$  so 18 students work on both  $(T\cap L)$
[22870|p853] a P works on both)  $= P(T\cap L) = \frac{18}{50} = \frac{9}{25}$
[22871|p853] b  $P(\text{works on at least one}) = 1 - P(\text{works on neither}) = 1 - \frac{12}{50} = \frac{38}{50} = \frac{19}{25}$
[22872|p853] c  $P(T$  given that  $L$  has happened)  $= \frac{P(L\text{and}T)}{P(L)} = \frac{n(L\cap T)}{n(L)}$
[22873|p853] $$
= \frac {1 8}{2 0} = \frac {9}{1 0}
$$
[22874|p853] d P(Not L given T has happened) = P(L' and T) = 18/36 = 1/2
[22875|p853|T1] TIP
[22876|p853] $P(T$  given that  $L$  has happened) is dependent on students already using a laptop, so the probability is calculated using the total number of stud...
[22877|p853|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8
[22878|p853] A group of Grade 10 and Grade 11 students were asked which device they used most often to access the internet. The data is given in the table.
[22879|p853] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>Phone</td><td>Tablet</td><td>PC</td></tr>
[22880|p853] [Table Row] <tr><td>Grade 10</td><td>200</td><td>330</td><td>120</td></tr>
[22881|p853] [Table Row] <tr><td>Grade 11</td><td>250</td><td>320</td><td>80</td></tr>
[22883|p854|T1] WORKED EXAMPLE 8 CONTINUED
[22884|p854] a What is the probability a randomly chosen student uses a phone to access the internet, given that the student is in Grade 11?
[22885|p854] b A student is in Grade 10. What is the probability that the student uses a PC to access the internet?
[22886|p854] c If a randomly chosen student uses a tablet to access the internet, what is the probability they are in Grade 11?
[22887|p854|T1] Answers
[22888|p854] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>Phone</td><td>Tablet</td><td>PC</td><td>Total</td></tr>
[22889|p854] [Table Row] <tr><td>Grade 10</td><td>200</td><td>330</td><td>120</td><td>650</td></tr>
[22890|p854] [Table Row] <tr><td>Grade 11</td><td>250</td><td>320</td><td>80</td><td>650</td></tr>
[22891|p854] [Table Row] <tr><td>Total</td><td>450</td><td>650</td><td>200</td><td></td></tr>
[22892|p854] Add totals to the table so that you can use them to calculate probabilities.
[22893|p854] a
[22894|p854] [Table Row] <tr><td></td><td>Phone</td><td>Tablet</td><td>PC</td><td>Total</td></tr>
[22895|p854] [Table Row] <tr><td>Grade 10</td><td>200</td><td>330</td><td>120</td><td>650</td></tr>
[22896|p854] [Table Row] <tr><td>Grade 11</td><td>250</td><td>320</td><td>80</td><td>650</td></tr>
[22897|p854] [Table Row] <tr><td>Total</td><td>450</td><td>650</td><td>200</td><td></td></tr>
[22898|p854] You know the student is in Grade 11, so you only need to look at the values for Grade 11.
[22899|p854] P(Phone user given Grade 11) =  $\frac{250}{650} = \frac{5}{13}$
[22900|p854] 250 out of the 650 students in Grade 11 use a phone to access the internet.
[22901|p854] b P(PC user given Grade 10) =  $\frac{120}{650} = \frac{12}{65}$
[22902|p854] This time you need to look at the Grade 10 values.
[22903|p854] c P(Grade 11 given they use a tablet) =  $\frac{320}{650} = \frac{32}{65}$
[22904|p854] You know the student uses a tablet so use the values in the tablet column.
[22905|p854] 650 students use a tablet and 320 are in Grade 11.
[22906|p854|T1] TIP
[22907|p854] Conditional probability involves finding something using something that you know already. So for  $P(A$  given that  $B$  has happened),  $A$  is the ...

[22975|p858|T1] SUMMARY
[22976|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>Do you know ...?</td></tr>
[22977|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>The sample space is all the possible outcomes of a statistical experiment.</td></tr>
[22978|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>When an event has two or more stages it is called a combined event.</td></tr>
[22979|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>Tree diagrams and Venn diagrams are useful for organising the outcomes of different stages in an event.
They are particularly usef...
[22980|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>The outcomes are written at the ends of branches on a tree diagram. The probability of each outcome is written
next to the branche...
[22981|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>For independent events you find the probability by multiplying the probabilities on each branch of the tree.</td></tr>
[22982|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>When events are mutually exclusive, you need to add the probabilities obtained by multiplication.</td></tr>
[22983|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>The probability that an event happens, given that another event has already happened, is called conditional
probability.</td></tr>
[22984|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>Are you able to ...?</td></tr>
[22985|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>draw a tree diagram to organise the outcomes for simple combined events</td></tr>
[22986|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>find the probability of each branch of a tree diagram</td></tr>
[22987|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>calculate the probability of events using tree diagrams</td></tr>
[22988|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>draw a Venn diagram to represent sets of information and use it to calculate probabilities</td></tr>
[22989|p858] [Table Row] <tr><td>use tree diagrams and Venn diagrams to determine conditional probability.</td></tr>

[23019|p859] 5 The universal set for a Venn diagram is the set of 26 letters of the Roman alphabet. A = {letter in the word 'Abibliophobia'}
[23020|p859] $\mathbf{B} = \{\mathrm{first~8~letters~of~the~alphabet}\}$
[23021|p859] $C = \{$  letters in the phrase 'afraid to run out of reading material'  $\}$
[23022|p859] a Draw a Venn diagram to show this information. [4]
[23023|p859] b List the following sets:
[23024|p859] i AnBnC [2]
[23025|p859] ii  $(A\cup B)\cap C^{\prime}$  [2]
[23026|p859] iA∩(BUc)
[23027|p859] In a group of 59 children, some like to watch Hoggle, Goggle or Smuggle (or some combination of these TV programmes). 4 children watch all three, 3 wa...

[23035|p860] Can you answer yes to all of these questions?
[23036|p860] If not, write down what you need to do to change your answer.
[23037|p860] Did I understand all of the questions?
[23038|p860] Did I know what to do to answer them?
[23039|p860] - Did I follow the instructions correctly?
[23040|p860] Was my work clear and organised?
[23041|p860] - Did I perform procedures accurately?
[23042|p860] Was I able to use my calculator efficiently?
[23043|p860] Could I interpret results in the context of the given problem?
[23044|p860] Were my solutions correct?
[23045|p860] If I made mistakes, could I work out what I did wrong?

[23359|p874] Cambridge IGCSE Mathematics (0580) Paper 41 Q2, June 2020
[23360|p875|T1] > Glossary
[23361|p875|T1] Key words
[23362|p875] adjacent: a 'shorter' side of a right-angled triangle that is 'next to' an angle other than the right angle.
[23363|p875] alternate angles: a pair of angles on opposite sides of the transversal between two parallel lines.
[23364|p875] alternate segment: when an angle is drawn between a tangent and a chord the alternate segment is the segment that the angle does not cross.
[23365|p875] apex: in a pyramid, the apex is the point, above the base, at which all the sloping sides meet.
[23366|p875] asymptote: a line that a graph approaches but never intersects.
[23367|p875] axis of symmetry: a line that divides a plane shape into two symmetrical halves or a 'rod' about which a solid can rotate and still look the same in d...
[23368|p875] base: when working with indices, the base is the number that is being raised to a power.
[23369|p875] bearing: an angle indicating the direction of travel between two points. The bearing begins from the 'North' direction and is measured clockwise round...
[23370|p875] bias: something that affects the chance of an event occurring in favour of a desired outcome.
[23371|p875] bivariate data: two measurements, relating to an investigation, taken at the same time.
[23372|p875] categorical data: non-numerical data.
[23373|p875] centre of rotation: the point around which a plane shape can rotate and show the same shape in different positions.
[23374|p875] class interval: the group into which numeral data has been placed.
[23375|p875] coefficient: in a term which is a mixture of numbers and letters, the coefficient is the number that is multiplying the letters.
[23376|p875] co-interior angles: a pair of angles between the parallel lines on the same side of a transversal.
[23377|p875] column vector: number pair notation used to describe a vector as the movement between two points:  $x$  units in the  $x$ -direction (left or right) a...
[23378|p875] combined events: one event followed by another event.
[23379|p875] common denominator: a common value that two or more fractions need to be converted to in order to be able to add and/or subtract fractions.
[23380|p875] complement (of a set): set of objects that are not in a set, but which are part of the larger universal set.
[23381|p875] complementary angles: two angles that add to give  $90^{\circ}$
[23382|p875] completing the square: writing a quadratic expression in the form  $a(x + b)^2 + c$ .
[23383|p875] composite function: applying a function to a value and then another function to that result.
[23384|p875] composite number: integer with more than two factors i.e. it has more factors than just 1 and itself.
[23385|p875] compound interest: interest paid on interest already earned and not just the original capital.
[23386|p875] conditional probability: the probability of an event, assuming that another has occurred.
[23387|p875] congruent: shapes that are identical in both shape and size.
[23388|p875] consecutive: following one after the other.
[23389|p875] constant term: a term in an equation or expression that has a fixed numerical value.
[23390|p875] Continuous data: data that can take any value in a range, such as height or weight.
[23391|p875] conversion: changing one quantity or unit into its equivalent in another unit.
[23392|p875] correlation: the relationship between bivariate data.
[23393|p875] corresponding angles: a pair of angles in the same position at each intersection.
[23394|p875] cosine ratio: for a given angle (other than the right-angle) in a right-angled triangle, the cosine ratio is the length of the side adjacent to the an...
[23395|p875] Cosine rule: a formula connecting the three sides of a triangle and one of the angles.
[23396|p875] cost price: the price that a trader pays for goods.
[23397|p875] cube number: a cube number is the result obtained when a number is multiplied by itself and then multiplied by itself again.
[23398|p875] cube root: the number which, when multiplied by itself, and then by itself again, gives the cube.
[23399|p875] Cumulative frequency: a 'running total' of the frequencies.
[23400|p876] cumulative frequency curve: a curve formed using the cumulative frequencies as the vertical axis value.
[23401|p876] cyclic quadrilateral: a quadrilateral whose vertices all exactly touch the circumference of a circle.
[23402|p876] denominator: the number on the bottom of a fraction.
[23403|p876] dependent variable: a variable whose value depends on the value of another variable.
[23404|p876] derivative of function: the derivative of function (or derivative) of a function is another function that gives the rate of change at any point on a g...
[23405|p876] difference between two squares: a method of factorising (putting into brackets) one squared term subtracted from another.
[23406|p876] differentiation: the process of finding a derived function, which tells you the gradient of the function at a point on the curve.
[23407|p876] direct proportion: when two quantities increase or decrease at the same rate.
[23408|p876] discount: the amount by which an original selling price is reduced.
[23409|p876] discrete data: data that can only take certain (usually integer) values.
[23410|p876] element: an item in a set, sometimes called a member of the set.
[23411|p876] empty set: a set with no elements.
[23412|p876] enlargement: a transformation of a shape that keeps the ratio of corresponding sides the same but increases or decreases the lengths of the sides.
[23413|p876] Equation of a line: a formula that shows how the  $x$ -coordinate is related to the  $y$ -coordinate, for any point on a line.
[23414|p876] equivalent fraction: the result of multiplying (or dividing) the top and bottom of a fraction by the same value.
[23415|p876] event: the outcome that is being tested for in a probability 'experiment'.
[23416|p876] Exact value: precise or accurate value, not an approximation.
[23417|p876] expand: multiply the terms inside a bracket by the term multiplying the bracket. (This includes multiplying one bracket by another.)
[23418|p876] experimental probability: the chance of an event happening, calculated by running an 'experiment' many times.
[23419|p876] exponent: another word for power or index, indicating how many times a base number is multiplied by itself.
[23420|p876] exponential: a function formed when the variable is in the index.
[23421|p876] expression: a group of terms linked by operation signs.
[23422|p876] extrapolation: a value determined by continuing a line of best fit beyond the plotted data.
[23423|p876] face: a plane shape that forms part of a solid.
[23424|p876] factor: a number that divides exactly into another number with no remainder.
[23425|p876] factorisation: to rewrite an expression using brackets.
[23426|p876] formula: a general 'rule' expressed algebraically (such as how to find the area of a shape).
[23427|p876] frequency density: the frequency of a class divided by the width of the class.
[23428|p876] function: a set of rules or instructions for changing one number (an input) into another (an output).
[23429|p876] function notation: an alternative mathematical way of writing equations.
[23430|p876] Gradient: the steepness of a line (or the steepness of a tangent drawn at a point on a curve).
[23431|p876] grouped data: the collection of individual data values into convenient groups. Used especially for continuous data.
[23432|p876] histogram: a specialised graph used to illustrate grouped continuous data.
[23433|p876] hyperbola: a graph defined by the equation  $xy = k$ , where  $k$  is a constant. (Also called reciprocal graphs.)
[23434|p876] hypotenuse: the longest side of a right angled triangle.
[23435|p876] independent events: events where the outcome is not affected/influenced by what has occurred before.
[23436|p876] index: another word for power or exponent, indicating how many times a base number is multiplied by itself.
[23437|p876] Index notation: a method of writing number using a base number and a power, for example  $2 \times 2 \times 2 = 2^{3}$ .
[23438|p876] integer: any of the negative and positive whole numbers, including zero.
[23439|p876] interest: the amount charged for borrowing, or earned for investing, money.
[23440|p876] Interest rate: the percentage charged for borrowing, or earned for investing, money. (Usually an annual rate.)
[23441|p876] interquartile range: the difference between the upper and lower quartiles.
[23442|p876] intersection: the intersection of two sets is the set of elements that are found in both sets (the overlapping or shared elements).
[23443|p876] inverse function: a function that does the opposite of the original function.
[23444|p876] inverse proportion: when one quantity decreases in the same proportion as another quantity increases.
[23445|p877] irrational number: a (decimal) number that does not terminate or recur and cannot be written as a fraction.
[23446|p877] line of best fit: a trend line drawn onto a scatter graph that passes as close to as many data points as possible.
[23447|p877] line symmetry: a line that divides a plane shape into two halves so that one half is the mirror image of the other. (See also axis of symmetry.)
[23448|p877] linear equation: a linear equation has no terms with a power in  $x$  greater than one.
[23449|p877] linear inequalities: similar to linear equations but using  $<, >, \leqslant$  or  $\geqslant$ .
[23450|p877] loss: when goods are sold for less than they were bought, the loss is the cost price less the selling price.
[23451|p877] lower bound: the exact smallest value that a number (given to a specified accuracy) could be.
[23452|p877] lower quartile: the value of data at the  $25^{\text{th}}$  percentile.
[23453|p877] lowest terms: an equivalent fraction where the numerator and denominator are the smallest allowable whole numbers. Also called simplest form.
[23454|p877] magnitude: the size (of a vector) irrespective of direction.
[23455|p877] maximum: a turning point or vertex on a graph whose y-coordinate is greater than points immediately to its left and right.
[23456|p877] mean: an average that uses all the data.
[23457|p877] median: an average, the middle value of data when it is arranged in increasing order.
[23458|p877] metric: the metric system uses measurements that are fractions or multiples of metres.
[23459|p877] midpoint: exactly halfway between the ends of a line segment.
[23460|p877] minimum: a turning point or vertex on a graph whose y-coordinate is lower than points immediately to its left and right.
[23461|p877] mixed number: a number with a whole number part and a fraction part.
[23462|p877] modal class: for grouped data, a class that has the highest frequency.
[23463|p877] mode: an average, the most frequently occurring value in a set of data.
[23464|p877] multiple: the result of multiplying a number by an integer.
[23465|p877] mutually exclusive events: events that cannot happen at the same time.
[23466|p877] negative correlation: a trend, in bivariate data, where, as one value increases, the other value decreases.
[23467|p877] net: the plane shape formed from the faces of a solid when it is 'unfolded'.
[23468|p877] numerator: the number on the top of a fraction.
[23469|p877] numerical data: data that is in the form of numbers.
[23470|p877] opposite: a 'shorter' side of a right-angled triangle that is 'opposite' an angle other than the right angle.
[23471|p877] Outcomes: the possible results of an 'experiment'.
[23472|p877] parabola: the graph of a quadratic relationship.
[23473|p877] parallel (lines): lines that are the same distance apart along their length.
[23474|p877] percentile: the value of data at a specified position (the data must be arranged in increasing order).
[23475|p877] perpendicular: at right angles to each other.
[23476|p877] perpendicular bisector: a line that cuts exactly through the middle of another line, making an angle of  $90^{\circ}$  with it.
[23477|p877] plane symmetry: a flat surface that cuts a solid into two halves so that one half is the mirror image of the other.
[23478|p877] positive correlation: a trend in bivariate data where as one value increase, so does the other.
[23479|p877] power: another word for exponent or index, indicating how many times a base number is multiplied by itself.
[23480|p877] prime factor: a prime number that divides exactly into another number with no remainder.
[23481|p877] prime number: a whole number greater than 1 which has only two factors: the number itself and 1.
[23482|p877] principal: the initial amount of money invested or borrowed.
[23483|p877] probability: a measure of how likely an event is to happen.
[23484|p877] profit: when goods are sold for more than they were bought, the profit is the selling price less the cost price.
[23485|p877] projection: the image of a line on a plane such that the angle between the angle and the image is the smallest possible.
[23486|p877] quadratic equation: an equation that contains a quadratic expression.
[23487|p877] quadratic expression: an expression where one term has a variable squared (and no variable with a higher power).
[23488|p877] Qualitative data: another name for categorical data.
[23489|p877] Quantitative data: another name for numerical data.
[23490|p877] Range: a measure of the spread of data. The difference between the highest value and the lowest value.
[23491|p877] rate: a comparison of two different quantities.
[23492|p877] Ratio: a comparison of amounts in a particular order.
[23493|p877] Rational number: a number that can be expressed as a fraction in the form  $\frac{a}{b}$  where  $a$  and  $b$  are integers and  $b \neq 0$ .
[23494|p878] rationalising the denominator: expressing the denominator of any fraction as a rational number by removing any surds.
[23495|p878] reciprocal: the fraction obtained when the values of the numerator and denominator are interchanged. (See also hyperbola.)
[23496|p878] recurring decimal: a decimal that continues to infinity repeating itself at regular intervals.
[23497|p878] reflection: a transformation that creates an image by reflecting points in a given line.
[23498|p878] region: a region in a plane that satisfies a set of linear inequalities.
[23499|p878] relative frequency: the experimental probability of an event happening.
[23500|p878] rotation: a transformation that creates an image by rotating points by a given angle about a fixed point.
[23501|p878] rotational symmetry: symmetry by turning a shape about a fixed point so that it looks the same in different positions.
[23502|p878] sample space: all the possible outcomes of an event or combination of events.
[23503|p878] sample space diagram: a list or diagram that shows all the equally likely outcomes of an 'experiment'.
[23504|p878] scalar: a quantity that has size (magnitude) but not a direction.
[23505|p878] scale: a ratio that indicates how much smaller (or larger) a drawing is from the original object.
[23506|p878] scale factor: the multiplying factor for the sides of a shape that is enlarged from an original.
[23507|p878] scatter diagram: a diagram that plots pairs of bivariate data to help determine if there is any correlation between them.
[23508|p878] selling price: the price that a trader sells goods for.
[23509|p878] sequence: a number pattern or list of numbers in a particular order.
[23510|p878] set: a list or collection of objects that share a characteristic.
[23511|p878] set builder notation: a way of describing what elements are in a set without having to list them all.
[23512|p878] similar: plane objects that have the same shape and proportion but are different in size.
[23513|p878] simple interest: interest that is calculated only on the original amount borrowed or invested.
[23514|p878] simplest form: an equivalent fraction where the numerator and denominator are the smallest allowable whole numbers. Also called lowest terms.
[23515|p878] simultaneous: at the same time (or in the same position).
[23516|p878] sine ratio: for a given angle (other than the right-angle) in a right-angled triangle, the sine ratio is the length of the side opposite to the angle ...
[23517|p878] sine rule: in any triangle, the ratio of the sine of an angle to the length of the side opposite the angle is always the same.
[23518|p878] slant height: in a cone, the slant height is the shortest distance from a point on the circumference of the base to the apex.
[23519|p878] solution: the value obtained from solving an equation.
[23520|p878] speed: a rate that compares distance travelled in a given time.
[23521|p878] square number: the product obtained when an integer is multiplied by itself.
[23522|p878] square root: a number that, when multiplied by itself, gives a square.
[23523|p878] standard form: a shorthand method of writing very large or very small numbers.
[23524|p878] stationary point: a point on a graph where it stops increasing or decreasing.
[23525|p878] stem-and-leaf diagram: a type of bar graph made by arranging numerical data in a display, the first part of the numbers forms the stem and the last pa...
[23526|p878] subject: the variable written by itself (usually to the left of the  $\equiv$  sign).
[23527|p878] subscript notation: a method of writing the  $n^{\mathrm{th}}$  term as  $u_{n}$ $(u\mathrm{sub}n)$
[23528|p878] subset: a set whose elements are all also members of another set.
[23529|p878] subtended angle: an angle formed at the meeting of two given lines.
[23530|p878] supplementary angles: two angles that add to give  $180^{\circ}$
[23531|p878] surd: the irrational root of a number, for example,  $\sqrt{2}$ .
[23532|p878] surface area: the total area of the faces of a three-dimensional solid.
[23533|p878] tangent ratio: for a given angle (other than the right-angle) in a right-angled triangle, the tangent ratio is the length of the side opposite to the ...
[23534|p878] term (in algebra): part of an expression.
[23535|p878] term (in sequences): any of the numbers in a sequence.
[23536|p878] terminating decimal: any decimal that has a fixed number of decimal places.
[23537|p878] theoretical probability: the chance of an event happening, calculated if it is known that the possible outcomes are equally likely.
[23538|p879] transformation: a change in the position of a point or line following a given rule.
[23539|p879] translation: a transformation that creates an image of a point by sliding' it along a plane.
[23540|p879] trial: an 'experiment' to determine the value of an outcome.
[23541|p879] turning point: a point on a graph where it changes direction. Usually a maximum or minimum point.
[23542|p879] two-way table: a table that summarises the data from two or more sets of data.
[23543|p879] union: the union of two sets is the set of all the elements in the combined sets.
[23544|p879] universal set: the set that contains all the elements you are dealing with.
[23545|p879] Upper bound: the largest value that a number (given to a specified accuracy) could be.
[23546|p879] upper quartile: the value of data at the  $75^{\text{th}}$  percentile.
[23547|p879] variable: a letter in a formula or equation that can have different values.
[23548|p879] vector: a quantity that has direction as well as size.
[23549|p879] Venn diagram: a pictorial method for illustrating the elements and interconnections of sets.
[23550|p879] vertically opposite: a pair of equal angles formed when two straight lines cross.
[23551|p879] vertices: the points where two or more edges of a plane shape meet.
[23552|p879] volume: the amount of space contained inside, or occupied by a solid object.
[23553|p879] Zero correlation: no apparent linear relationship between two sets of data.

[24542|p890] - 'Investigation' activities encourage you to extend your learning by investigating a real-life example, or by discussing it with your classmates.
[24543|p890] Project activities created by NRICH help you develop your problem solving and collaboration skills with real-life mathematics.
[24544|p890] - At the end of some exercises you will find opportunities to assess your own work, or that of your classmates, and consider how you can improve.
